The devil was there, who became proud, but his pride cast him into the depth of hell

Þær wæs se deofol ðe modegode, ac his modignes hine awearp into helle grunde
therefore our weakness may not ascend thither, if it be proud, when the angel might not be there when he became proud

God bebead, on þære ealdan ǽ, his folce þæt hi sceoldon him offrian ælc frumcenned hyse-cild, oþþe alysan hit ut mid fif scyllingum
God, in the old law, commanded his people, that they should offer to him every firstborn male child, or redeem it with five shillings

Eac on heora orfe, swa hwæt swa frumcenned wære, bringan þæt to Godes huse, and hit ðær Gode offrian
Of their cattle also, to bring whatever was firstborn to God's house, and there offer it to God

Gif hit þonne unclæne nyten wære, þonne sceolde se hlaford hit acwellan, oþþe syllan Gode oþer clæne nyten
But if it were an unclean beast, then should the master slay it, or give to God another clean beast

We ne þurfon þas bebodu healdan nú lichamlice, ac gástlice
We need not now hold these commands bodily, but spiritually

Þonne on urum mode bið acenned sum ðing gódes, and we þæt to weorce awendað, þonne sceole we þæt tellan to Godes gyfe, and þæt Gode betæcan
When in our mind something good is brought forth and we turn it to action, then should we account that as God's grace, and consign it to God

Ure yfelan geðohtas oððe weorc we sceolan alysan mid fif scyllingum
Our evil thoughts or actions we should redeem with five shillings

þæt is we sceolon ure yfelnysse behreowsian mid urum fif andgitum, þæt synd gesihþ, and hlyst, and swæc, and stenc, and hrepung
that is, we should repent of our wickedness with our five senses, which are, sight, and hearing, and taste, and smell, and touch

Eac swa þa unclænan nytenu getacniað ure unclænan geþohtas and weorc, ða we sceolon symle acwellan, oððe behwyrfan mid clænum
So also as the unclean beasts betoken our unclean thoughts and actions, these we should always kill or exchange for pure

þæt is þæt we sceolon ure unclænnysse and ure yfelnesse symle adwæscan, and forlætan yfel, and dón gód
that is, we should always destroy our impurity and our wickedness, and forsake evil, and do good

Seo eadige Maria ða geoffrode hire lác Gode mid þam cilde, swa hit on Godes ǽ geset wæs
The blessed Mary then offered her gift to God with the child, as it was appointed in God's law

Hit wæs swa geset on þære ealdan ǽ þurh Godes hæse, þæt ða þe mihton ðurhteon sceoldon bringan anes geares lamb mid heora cylde, Gode to lace, and ane culfran, oþþe ane turtlan
It was so appointed in the old law, by God's behest, that those who could accomplish it, should bring a yearling lamb with their child, as a gift to God, and a pigeon or a turtle-dove

Gif þonne hwylc wif to ðam unspedig wære þæt heo ðas ðing begytan ne mihte, þonne sceolde heo bringan twegen culfran-briddas, oððe twá turtlan
But if any woman were so needy that she could not get those things, then she should bring two young pigeons, or two turtle-doves

Þas læssan lác, þæt sind þa fugelas, þe wæron wannspedigra manna lác, wæron for Criste geoffrode
These smaller gifts, that is, the birds, which were the gifts of indigent persons, were offered for Christ

Se Ælmihtiga Godes Sunu wæs swiðe gemyndig ure neoda on eallum ðingum
The Almighty Son of God was very mindful of our needs in all things

na þæt an þæt he wolde mann beon for ús, ðaða he God wæs, ac eac swylce he wolde beon þearfa for us, ðaða he rice wæs: to ðy þæt he us forgeafe dæl on his rice, and mænsumunge on his godcundnysse
not only would he for us become man when he was God, but he would also be poor for us when he was rich, that he might give us part in his kingdom and community in his Godhead

Lamb getacnað unscæððinysse and þa maran godnysse
A lamb betokens innocence and the greater goodness

gif we þonne swa earme beoð þæt we ne magon þa maran godnysse Gode offrian, þonne sceole we him bringan twa turtlan, oþþe twegen culfran-briddas, þæt is twyfealdlic onbryrdnes eges and lufe
but if we are so poor that we cannot offer to God the greater goodness, then should we bring him two turtle-doves or two young pigeons

On twa wisan bið se man onbryrd: ærest he him ondræt helle wíte, and bewepð his synna, syððan he nimð eft lufe to Gode
that is, a twofold affection of awe and love

þonne onginð he to murcnienne, and ðincð him to lang hwænne he beo genumen of ðyses lifes earfoðnyssum, and gebroht to ecere reste
In two ways is a man affected: first, he dreads hell-torment, and bewails his sins

Lytel wæs an lamb, oððe twa turtlan, Gode to bringenne
Little was a lamb, or two turtle-doves to bring to God

ac hé ne sceawað na þæs mannes lac swa swiðe swa hé sceawað his heortan
but he regards not a man's gift so much as he regards his heart

Nis Gode nan neod ure æhta
God hath no need of our gifts

ealle ðing sindon his, ægðer ge heofen, ge eorðe, and sǽ, and ealle ða ðing ðe on him wuniað: ac he forgeaf eorðlice ðing mannum to brice, and bebead him þæt hí sceoldon mid þam eorðlicum ðingum hine oncnawan þe hí ær forgeaf, na for his neode, ac for mancynnes neode
all things are his, heaven, and earth, and sea, and all the things which dwell in them: but he gave to men earthly things for use, and commanded them with those earthly things to acknowledge him who first gave them, not for His need, but for need of mankind

Gif ðu oncnæwst ðinne Drihten mid ðinum æhtum, be ðinre mæðe, hit fremeð þe sylfum to ðam ecan life: gif ðu hine forgitst, hit hearmað þe sylfum and na Gode, and þu ðolast ðære ecan mede
If thou acknowledgest thy Lord with thy possessions, according to thy ability, it forwards thyself to eternal life

God gyrnð þa godnysse ðines modes, and na ðinra æhta
if thou forgettest him, it harms thyself and not God, and thou losest the everlasting meed

Gif ðu hwæt dest Gode to lofe, mid cystigum mode, þonne geswutelast ðu þa gódnysse þines modes mid þære dæde
God desires the goodness of thy mind, and not of thy possessions

gif þu ðonne nan gód dón nelt, Gode to wurðmynte, ðonne geswutelast ðu mid þære uncyste ðine yfelnysse, and seo yfelnys þe fordeð wið God
If thou doest aught for the praise of God with devout mind, then thou manifestest the goodness of thy mind by that deed

On ðære ealdan ǽ is gehwær gesett, þæt God het gelomlice þas fugelas offrian on his lace, for ðære getacnunge þe hí getacniað
In the old law it is in several places mentioned, that God frequently commanded birds to be offered to him in sacrifice, for the betokening which they betoken

Nis nu nanum men alyfed þæt he healde þa ealdan ǽ lichomlice, ac gehealde gehwa hí gastlice
Now it is not allowed to any man to hold the old law bodily, but let everyone hold it spiritually

Culfran sind swiðe unscæððige fugelas, and bilewite, and hí lufiað annysse, and fleoð him floccmælum
Pigeons are very innocent and gentle birds, and they love unity, and fly flockwise

Do eac swa se cristena man
Let the christian man also do so

beo him únsceaðþig, and bilewite, and lufige annysse, and broðorrædene betwux cristenum mannum
let him be innocent, and gentle, and love unity and fellowship among christian men

þonne geoffrað he gastlice Gode þa culfran-briddas
then offers he to God spiritually the young pigeons

Þa turtlan getacniað clænnysse: hí sind swa geworhte, gif hyra oðer oðerne forlyst, þonne ne secð seo cucu næfre hire oðerne gemacan
The turtle-doves betoken purity: they are so created, that if one of them lose the other, the living one never seeks to itself another mate

Gif ðonne se cristena man swa deð for Godes lufon, þonne geoffrað he ða turtlan on þa betstan wisan
But if the christian man does so for love of God, then offers he the turtle-doves in the best manner

Ðas twa fugel-cyn ne singað na, swa swa oðre fugelas, ac hi geomeriað, forðan þe hi getacniað haligra manna geomerunge on ðisum life, swa swa Crist cwæð to his apostolum
These two birds sing not like other birds, but they murmur

Ge beoð geunrotsode on þisum life, ac eower unrotnys bið awend to ecere blisse
for they betoken the groaning of holy men in this life, as Christ said to his apostles

Eadige beoð þa þe heora synna bewepað, forðan ðe hi beoð gefrefrode
And again he said

Se ealda man Symeon, þe we ær embe spræcon, ne gyrnde ná þæt he moste Crist gehyran sprecan, forðan ðe he hine gecneow þæt he God wæs, ðeah ðe he ða-gyt on þære menniscnysse unsprecende wære
The old man Simeon, of whom we erewhile spoke, desired not that he might hear Christ speak, for he knew him to be the Son of God, though he, in his state of humanity, was yet without speech

Sprecan he mihte, gif he wolde
He could have spoken, had he been willing

and ealswa wis he wæs ða, þaþa he wæs anre nihte, swa swa he wæs, þaþa he wæs ðrittig geara
and he was as wise when he was one day old as he was when he was thirty years

ac he wolde abídan his wæstma timan on ðære menniscnysse, swa swa hit gecyndelic is on mancynne
but he would abide the time of his growth in human nature, as is natural in mankind

Symeon cwæð þa
Simeon then said

Drihten, þu forlætst me nu on sibbe of ðysum life, forðon þe míne eagan habbað gesewen ðinne Halwendan
Lord, thou wilt let me now depart in peace from this life, for mine eyes have seen thy Healing One

Se Halwenda þe he embe spræc is ure Hælend Crist, seðe com to gehælenne ure wunda, þæt sindon ure synna
The Healing One of whom he spake is our Saviour Christ, who came to heal our wounds, that is, our sins

He cwæð þa Symeon
Simeon then said

Ðone þu gearcodest ætforan gesihðe ealles folces
Whom thou hast prepared before the sight of all people

Hine ne gesawon na ealle men lichomlice, ac he is gebodod eallum mannum, gelyfe seðe wylle
All men saw him not bodily, but he is announced to all men, let him believe who will

Se þe on hine gelyfð, he gesihð hine nu mid his geleafan, and on þan ecan life mid his eagum
He who believes in him, sees him now with his faith, and in the eternal life with his eyes

Symeon cwæð þa-gyt
Simeon yet said

He is leoht to onwrigennysse ðeoda, and wuldor þinum folce Israhel
He is a light for the enlightening of the gentiles, and a glory to thy people Israel

Ealle ðas word spræc se Symeon be ðam cilde to þam heofenlican Fæder, þe hine to mannum sende
All these words concerning the child, Simeon spake to the heavenly Father, who sent him to men

He is soð leoht þe todræfde þa þeostra ðises lifes, swa swa he sylf cwæð on his godspelle
He is the true light who scattered the darkness of this life, as he himself said in his gospel

Ic eom leoht ealles middangeardes, se ðe me fyligð, ne cymð he na on þystrum, ac he hæfð lifes leoht
I am the light of all the world

Þa Maria, þæt halige mæden, and þæs cildes fostor-fæder, Ioseph, wæron ofwundrode þæra worda þe se ealda Symeon clypode be ðam cilde
Then the holy maiden Mary, and Joseph, the child's foster-father, wondered at the words which the old Simeon uttered concerning the child

And se Symeon him ða sealde bletsunge, and witegode gyt mare be þam cilde, and cwæð
And Simeon then gave him his blessing, and prophesied yet more concerning the child, and said

Þis cild is gesett manegum mannum to hryre, and manegum to æriste and to tacne, and þam bið wiðcweden
This child is set for the fall of many men, and for the rising of many, and for a sign, and which shall be spoken against

Swa swa ða men þe on Crist gelyfað beoð gehealdene þurh his to-cyme, swa eac þa þe nellað gelyfan on Crist beoð twyfealdlice fordemde
So as those men who believe in Christ will be saved by his coming, so also those who will not believe in Christ will be doubly condemned

Anfealdlice hi sind scyldige ðurh Adames synne, and twyfealdlice hi beoð fordemde, þonne hí wiðsacað Cristes to-cymes, and nellað gelyfan on ðone soðan Hælend
Simply they are guilty through Adam's sin, and doubly they will be condemned, when they deny Christ's coming, and will not believe in the true Saviour

Ðam ungeleaffullum mannum com Crist to hryre, and þam geleaffullum to æriste
Christ came for the fall of unbelieving men, and for the rising of the faithful

and eac anum gehwilcum gelyfedum men wæs Cristes to-cyme ægðer ge hryre ge ærist
and also to every believing man was Christ's coming both a fall and a rising

Hu ðonne
But how

He com to ðy þæt he wolde ælc yfel towurpan, and ælc góod aræran
He came because he would cast down every evil, and rear up every good

Nu towyrpð he on ús leahtras, and arærð mihta
Now he casts down vices in us, and rears up virtues

He towyrpð modignysse, and arærð eadmodnysse
He casts down pride, and rears up humility

He towyrpð galnysse, and arærð clænnysse
He casts down libidinousness, and rears up chastity

And ealle unðeawas he towyrpð on his gecorenum mannum, and arærð on him ealle godnysse
And all wickedness he casts down in his chosen men, and rears up all goodness

Ne mæg þæt gód beon getymbrod buton þæt yfel beo ær toworpen
Good cannot be built up unless evil be previously cast down

To tacne com Crist, and þam is wiðcweden
Christ came for a sign, and which shall be spoken against

His acennednys is wundorlic tacn, forðan ðe he wæs of mædene acenned, swa swa nan oðer nis
His birth is a wonderful sign, because he was born of a maiden, as no other is

and þæt wiðcwædon þa ungeleaffullan men, and noldon gelyfan
and against that unbelieving men spake, and would not believe

And eac his æriste of deaðe, and his upstige to heofenum, and ealle ða wundra þe he worhte, ealle hit wæron tacna, and ðam wiðcwædon þa ungeleaffullan, and þa geleaffullan gelyfdon
And, likewise, his resurrection from death, and his ascension to heaven, and all the wonders which he wrought—all these were signs, and the unbelieving spake against them, and the faithful believed

Þa cwæð se ealda Symeon to ðære eadigan Marian
Then said the old Simeon to the blessed Mary

His swurd sceal ðurhgán ðine sawle
His sword shall pierce through thy soul

Þæt swurd getacnode Cristes ðrowunge
The sword betokened Christ's passion

Næs seo eadige Maria na ofslegen ne gemartyrod lichomlice, ac gastlice
The blessed Mary was not slain nor martyred bodily, but spiritually

Ðaða heo geseh niman hyre cild, and adrifan ísene næglas þurh þa handa and þurh ða fét, and syððan mid spere gewundigan on ða siðan, þa wæs Cristes ðrowung hire ðrowung
When she saw her child taken, and iron nails driven through his hands and through his feet, and his side afterwards wounded with a spear, then was his suffering her suffering

and heo wæs mare ðonne martyr, forðon þe mare wæs hyre modes þrowung þonne wære hire lichaman, gif heo gemartyrod wære
and she was then more than a martyr, for her mind's suffering was greater than her body's would have been, had she been martyred

Ne cwæð na se Symeon þæt Cristes swurd sceolde þurhgán Marian lichaman, ac hyre sawle
The old Simeon said not that Christ's sword should pierce through Mary's body, but her soul

Cristes swurd is her gesett, swa swa we cwædon, for his ðrowunge
Christ's sword is here set, as we said, for his passion

Þeah ðe Maria gelyfde þæt Crist arisan wolde of deaðe, þeah-hwæðere eode hyre cildes þrowung swiðe þearle into hire heortan
Though Mary believed that Christ would arise from death, her child's suffering went, nevertheless, very deeply into her heart

Þaða se Symeon hæfde gewitegod þas witegunge be Criste, þa com þær sum wuduwe, seo wæs Anna gehaten
When Simeon had prophesied this prophecy concerning Christ, then came there a widow, who was called Anna

Seo leofode mid hire were seofon gear, and syððan heo wæs wuduwe feower and hund-eahtatig geara, and þeowode Gode on fæstenum, and on gebedum, and on clænnysse
She had lived with her husband seven years

and wæs on eallum þam fyrste wunigende binnan þam Godes temple
and had afterwards been a widow eighty-four years, and served God with fastings, and prayers, and with chastity

and com ða to þam cilde, and witegode be him, and andette Gode
and was in all that time dwelling within God's temple

Behealde, ge wíf, and understandað hu be hire awriten is
Rightly was so holy a woman worthy to prophesy concerning Christ, since she had so long served God in chastity

Seofon gear heo leofode mid hire were, and siððan heo wæs wunigende on wudewan háde, oð feower and hund-eahtatig geara, swa lybbende swa se apostol tæhte
Behold, ye women, and understand how it is written concerning her

He cwæð, se apostol Paulus
Seven years she had lived with her husband, and was afterwards continuing in widowhood eighty-four years

Seo wuduwe þe lyfað on estmettum, heo ne lyfað na, ac heo is dead
so living as the apostle taught

Þeos Anna, ðe we embe sprecað, ne lufude heo na estmettas, ac lufude fæstenu
The widow who liveth in luxuries, she liveth not, but she is dead

Ne ferde heo wórigende geond land, ac wæs wunigende geþyldelice binnan Godes temple
This Anna, of whom we speak, loved not luxuries, but loved fasts

Gif wife getimige þæt heo hire wer forleose, ðonne nime heo bysne be ðisre wudewan
She loved not idle discourses, but occupied herself in prayers

Ðry hadas sindon þe cyðdon gecyðnysse be Criste
There are three states which bare witness of Christ: that is maidenhood, and widowhood, and lawful matrimony

þæt is mæigð-had, and wudewan-had, and riht sinscype
A maiden is the mother of Christ, and in maidenhood John the Baptist continued, who testified of Christ, and many others besides him

Mæden is Cristes modor, and on mægð-hade wunude Iohannes se Fulluhtere, þe embe Crist cydde, and manega oðre to-eacan him
This Anna, of whom we before spake, was a widow

Widewe wæs ðeos Anna, þe we gefyrn ær embe spræcon
Zacharias, the father of John, was a married man

Zacharias, Iohannes fæder, wæs wer
both he and his wife prophesied concerning Christ

ægðer ge he ge his wíf witegodon embe Crist
These three states are agreeable to God, if men righteously live in them

Þas ðry hadas syndon Gode gecweme, gif hi rihtlice lybbað
Maidenhood is both in men and in women

Mægð-had is ægþer ge on wæpmannum ge on wífmannum
Those have right maidenhood who from childhood continue in chastity, and despise in themselves all lust, both of body and mind, through God's succour

Þa habbað rihtne mægð-had þa þe fram cild-hade wuniað on clænnysse, and ealle galnysse on him sylfum forseoð, ægðer ge modes ge lichoman, þurh Godes fultum
Then shall they have from God a hundredfold meed in the everlasting life

Þonne habbað hi æt Gode hundfealde mede on ðam ecan life
Widows are those who, after the death of their consorts, live in chastity for love of God: they shall have a sixtyfold meed from God for their tribulation

Widewan beoð þa þe æfter heora gemacan on clænnysse wuniað for Godes lufon: hí habbað þonne syxtigfealde mede æt Gode hyra geswinces
Those who rightly hold their marriage vow, and at permitted times, and for procreation of children, have carnal intercourse, shall have a thirtyfold meed for their discretion

Þa ðe rihtlice healdað hyra ǽwe, and on alyfedum timan, for bearnes gestreone, hæmed begáð, hí habbað þrittigfealde mede for hyra gesceadwisnysse
He who will satiate his libidinousness as often as he lists, shall be compared with the beasts and not with men

Se ðe wile his galnysse gefyllan swa oft swa hine lyst, þonne bið he wiðmeten nytenum and na mannum
Concerning this the apostle Paul taught

Be þysum tæhte se apostol Paulus
Let those who have wives be as though they had none

forðan ealle hyra unlustas hi sceolon gebetan sylfwylles on þyssum life, oððe unþances æfter ðyssum life
and they shall come afterwards to the everlasting life with more difficulty

and hí cumað siððan to ðam ecan life mid maran earfoðnysse
Those men who are without a lawful consort, and run from one to other, shall have no part and no blessing with Christ, unless they desist and make atonement

Þa men þe beoð butan rihtre ǽwe, and yrnað fram anum to oðrum, nabbað hí nænne dæl ne nane bletsunge mid Criste, buton hí ðæs geswicon and hit gebeton
Let us now resume the gospel where we previously left it

Seo eadige Maria, and Ioseph, ðæs cildes fostor-fæder, gecyrdon to þære byrig Nazareth mid þam cilde
The blessed Mary, and Joseph, the child's foster-father, returned to the city of Nazareth with the child

and þæt cild weox, and wæs gestrangod, and mid wisdome afylled, and Godes gifu wæs on him wunigende
and the child grew, and was strengthened, and filled with wisdom, and God's grace was dwelling within him

He weox and wæs gestrangod on þære menniscnysse, and he ne behofode nanes wæstmes ne nanre strangunge on þære godcundnysse
He grew and was strengthened in human nature, but he required no growth and no strengthening in his divine nature

He æt, and dranc, and slep, and weox on gearum, and wæs þeah-hwæðere eal his lif butan synnum
He ate, and drank, and slept, and grew in years, and was, nevertheless, all his life without sins

He nære na man geðuht, gif he mannes life ne lyfode
He would not have seemed a man, if he had not lived the life of a man

He wæs mid wisdome afylled, forþan ðe he is himsylf wisdom, and on him wunað eal gefyllednys þære godcundnysse: lichomlice Godes gifu wunude on him
He was filled with wisdom, because he is himself wisdom, and in him dwelleth all fullness of the divine nature: God's grace dwelt bodily within him

Micel gifu wæs þæt ðære menniscnysse, þæt he wæs Godes Sunu and God sylf, swa hraðe swa he ongann man to beonne
A great grace was that of his human nature, that he was the Son of God and God himself, as soon as he began to be man

He wæs æfre God of þam Fæder acenned, and wunigende mid þam Fæder and mid þam Halgan Gaste: hí ðry án God untodæledlic
He was ever God begotten of the Father, and dwelling with the Father and with the Holy Ghost: these three one God indivisible

þry on hadum, and án God on anre godcundnysse, and on anum gecynde æfre wunigende
three in persons, and one God in one Godhead, and in one nature ever continuing

Se Sunu ana underfeng þa menniscnysse, and hæfde anginn, seðe æfre wæs
The Son only assumed human nature, and had a beginning, who was ever

He wæs cild, and weox on þære menniscnysse, and þrowode deað sylfwilles, and aras of deaðe mid þam lichaman þe he ær on þrowode, and astah to heofenum, and wunað nu æfre on godcundnysse and on menniscnysse, an Crist, ægðer ge God ge mann, undeadlic, seðe ær his ðrowunge wæs deadlic
He was a child, and grew in human nature, and voluntarily suffered death, and arose from death with the body in which he before had suffered, and ascended to heaven, and continueth now for ever in divine nature and in human nature, one Christ, both God and man, immortal, who before his passion was mortal

He þrowade, ac he ne ðrowað heonon-forð næfre eft, ac bið æfre butan ende, eallswa éce on þære menniscnysse swa he is on þære godcundnysse
He suffered, but henceforth he will never suffer again, but will ever be without end, as eternal in his human nature as he is in his divine nature

Wite gehwa eac þæt geset is on cyrclicum þeawum, þæt we sceolon on ðisum dæge beran ure leoht to cyrcan, and lætan hí ðær bletsian: and we sceolon gán siððan mid þam leohte betwux Godes husum, and singan ðone lofsang ðe þærto geset is
Be it known also to everyone that it is appointed in the ecclesiastical observances, that we on this day bear our lights to church, and let them there be blessed: and that we should go afterwards with the light among God's houses, and sing the hymn that is thereto appointed

Þeah ðe sume men singan ne cunnon, hi beron þeah-hwæðere þæt leoht on heora handum
Though some men cannot sing, they can, nevertheless, bear the light in their hands

forðy on ðissum dæge wæs þæt soðe Leoht Crist geboren to þam temple, seðe us alysde fram þystrum, and us gebrincð to þam ecan leohte, seðe leofað and rixað á butan ende
for on this day was Christ, the true Light, borne to the temple, who redeemed us from darkness and bringeth us to the Eternal Light, who liveth and ruleth ever without end

Amen
Amen

Her is geræd on þissum godspelle, þe we nu gehyrdon of ðæs diacones muðe, þæt
It is here read in this gospel, which we now have heard from the deacon's mouth, that

se Hælend gename onsundron his twelf leorning-cnihtas, and cwæð to him, Efne we sceolon faran to ðære byrig Hierusalem, and þonne beoð gefyllede ealle ða ðing þe wæron be me awritene þurh witegan
Jesus took his twelve disciples apart, and said to them, Behold, we shall go to the city of Jerusalem, and then shall be fulfilled all the things that have been written of me by the prophets

Ic sceal beon belǽwed ðeodum, and hí doð me to bysmore, and beswingað, and syððan ofsleað, and ic arise of deaðe on þam ðriddan dæge
I shall be betrayed to the Gentiles, and they shall mock and scourge me, and afterwards slay me, and I shall arise from death on the third day

Þa nyston his leorning-cnihtas nan andgit þyssera worda
But his disciples knew not the meaning of these words

Ða gelámp hit þæt hí genealæhton anre byrig þe is gehaten Hiericho, and ða sæt þær sum blind man be ðam wege
Then it came to pass that they came near to a city which is called Jericho, and there sat a certain blind man by the way

and þaþa he gehyrde þæs folces fær mid þam Hælende, ða acsode he hwa þær ferde
and when he heard the passing of the people with Jesus, he asked who was passing there

Hi cwædon him to, þæt þæt wære ðæs Hælendes fær
They said to him that Jesus was passing

Þa begann he to hrymenne, and cwæð, Hælend, Dauides Bearn, gemiltsa mín
Then he began to cry, and said, Jesus, Son of David, have pity on me

Ða men, þe beforan þam Hælende ferdon, ciddon ongean ðone blindan, þæt he suwian sceolde
The men, who were going before Jesus, chided the blind man, that he might be silent

He clypode þa miccle swiðor, Hælend, Dauides Bearn, gemiltsa mín
He cried then much louder, Jesus, Son of David, have pity on me

Þa stód se Hælend, and het lædan þone blindan to him
Jesus then stood, and bade them lead the blind man to him

Þaða he genealæhte, þa acsode se Hælend hine, Hwæt wylt ðu þæt ic þe dó
When he came near Jesus asked him, What wilt thou that I shall do unto thee

He cwæð, Drihten, þæt ic mage geseon
He said, Lord, that I may see

And se Hælend him cwæð to, Loca nu: þin geleafa hæfð ðe gehæled
And Jesus said to him, Look now: thy faith hath healed thee

And he ðærrihte geseah, and fyligde þam Hælende, and hine mærsode
And he immediately saw, and followed Jesus, and glorified him

Þa eal þæt folc, þe þæt wundor geseh, herede God mid micelre onbryrdnysse
Then all the people who saw that miracle glorified God with great fervour

Ðyses godspelles anginn hrepode ures Hælendes þrowunge, þeah-hwæðere ne ðrowade hé na on ðysne timan
The beginning of this gospel touched our Saviour's passion, though he did not suffer at this time

ac hé wolde feorran and lange ær cyðan his ðrowunge his leorning-cnihtum, þæt hí ne sceoldon beon to swiðe afyrhte þurh ða þrowunge, þonne se tima come þæt hé ðrowian wolde
but he would from afar and long before make known his passion to his disciples, that they might not be too much terrified by his passion, when the time came that he would suffer

Heora mód wearð afyrht þurh Crístes segene, ac hé hí eft gehyrte mid þam worde þe hé cwæð
Their mind was terrified by Christ's saying, but he again cheered them by the words which he spake

Ic arise of deaðe on þam ðriddan dæge
I will arise from death on the third day

Þa wolde he heora geleafan gestrangian and getrymman mid wundrum
He would then strengthen and confirm their faith with miracles

And hí ða comon to ðære stowe þær se blinda man sæt be ðam wege, and Crist hine gehælde ætforan gesihðe ealles þæs werodes, to ði þæt he wolde mid þam wundre hí to geleafan gebringan
And they came then to the place where the blind man sat by the way, and Christ healed him before the sight of all the multitude, to the end that, with that miracle, he might bring them to belief

Þeah-hwæðere þa wundra þe Crist worhte, oðer ðing hí æteowdon þurh mihte, and oðre ðing hí getacnodon þurh geryno
But the miracles which Christ wrought manifested one thing by power, and another thing they betokened by mystery

He worhte þa wundra soðlice þurh godcunde mihte, and mid þam wundrum þæs folces geleafan getrymde
He wrought those miracles indeed through divine power, and with those miracles confirmed the people's faith

ac hwæðre þær wæs oðer ðing digle on ðam wundrum, æfter gastlicum andgite
but yet there was another hidden thing in those miracles, in a spiritual sense

Þes án blinda man getacnode eall mancynn, þe wearð ablend þurh Adames gylt, and asceofen of myrhðe neoxena-wanges, and gebroht to ðissum life þe is wiðmeten cwearterne
The one blind man betokened all mankind, who were blinded through Adam's sin, and thrust from the joy of Paradise, and brought to this life, which is compared to a prison

Nu sind we ute belocene fram ðam heofenlican leohte, and we ne magon on ðissum life þæs ecan leohtes brucan
Now we are shut out from the heavenly light, and we may not, in this life, enjoy the light eternal

ne we his na mare ne cunnon buton swa micel swa we ðurh Cristes lare on bocum rædað
nor know we of it more than so much as, through Christ's teaching, we read in books

Þeos woruld, þeah ðe heo myrige hwíltidum geðuht sy, nis heo hwæðere ðe gelicere ðære ecan worulde, þe is sum cweartern leohtum dæge
This world, though it may sometimes seem gay, yet is no more like the world eternal, than is some prison to the light day

Eal mancyn wæs, swa we ær cwædon, ablend mid geleaflæste and gedwylde
All mankind, as we before said, was blinded with lack of faith and error

ac þurh Cristes to-cyme we wurdon abrodene of urum gedwyldum, and onlihte þurh geleafan
but through Christ's advent we were drawn from our errors, and enlightened by faith

Nu hæbbe we þæt leoht on urum mode, þæt is Cristes geleafa
We have now the light in our mind, that is Christ's faith

and we habbað þone hiht þæs ecan lifes myrhðe, þeah ðe we gyt lichamlice on urum cwearterne wunian
and we have a hope of the joy of everlasting life, though we yet bodily dwell in our prison

Se blinda man sæt æt þære byrig þe is geháten Hiericho
The blind man sat at the city which is called Jericho

Hiericho is gereht and geháten 'mona
Jericho is interpreted and called moon

' Se mona deð ægðer ge wycxð ge wanað: healfum monðe he bið weaxende, healfum he bið wanigende
The moon both waxes and wanes: for a half month it is waxing, for a half it is waning

Nu getacnað se mona ure deadlice lif, and ateorunge ure deadlicnysse
Now the moon betokeneth our mortal life and the decay of our mortality

On oðerne ende men beoð acennede, on oþerne ende hí forðfarað
At the one end men are born, at the other they depart

Þaða Crist com to ðære byrig Hiericho, þe ðone monan getacnað, þa underfeng se blinda man gesihðe
When Christ came to the city of Jericho, which betokeneth the moon, the blind man received sight

Þæt is, ðaða Crist com to ure deadlicnysse, and ure menniscnysse underfeng, þa wearð mancyn onliht, and gesihðe underfeng
That is, when Christ came to our mortality, and assumed our human nature, mankind was enlightened, and received sight

He sæt wið ðone weig
He sat by the way

and Crist cwæð on his godspelle
and Christ said in his gospel

Ic eom weig, and soðfæstnys, and líf
I am the way, and truth, and life

Se man þe nan ðing ne cann ðæs ecan leohtes, he is blind
The man who knows nothing of the eternal light is blind

ac gif he gelyfð on þone Hælend, þonne sitt he wið þone weig
but if he believes in Jesus, then sits he by the way

Gif he nele biddan þæs ecan leohtes, he sitt ðonne blind be ðam wege unbiddende
If he will not pray for the light eternal, then sits he blind by the way, without prayer

Se ðe rihtlice gelyfð on Críst, and geornlice bitt his sawle onlihtinge, he sitt be ðam wege biddende
He who rightly believes in Christ, and fervently prays for his soul's enlightening, he sits by the way praying

Swa hwa swa oncnæwð þa blindnysse his modes, clypige he mid inweardre heortan, swá swá se blinda cleopode
Whosoever is sensible of his mind's blindness, let him cry with inward heart, as the blind man cried

Hælend, Dauides Bearn, gemiltsa mín
Jesus, Son of David, have pity on me

Seo menigu þe eode beforan ðam Hælende ciddon ðam blindan, and heton þæt he stille wære
The multitude that went before Jesus chided the blind man, and bade him be still

Seo menigu getacnað ure unlustas and leahtras þe us hremað, and ure heortan ofsittað, þæt we ne magon us swa geornlice gebiddan, swa we behofedon
The multitude betokens our evil desires and vices, which call to us and occupy our hearts, so that we cannot pray so fervently as we ought

Hit gelimpð gelomlice, þonne se man wile yfeles geswican, and his synna gebetan, and mid eallum mode to Gode gecyrran, ðonne cumað þa ealdan leahtras þe hé ær geworhte, and hí gedrefað his mod, and willað gestillan his stemne, þæt he to Gode ne clypige
It happens frequently when a man is desirous to withdraw from evil and atone for his sins, and with his whole mind turn to God, that his old misdeeds, which he had previously committed, will then come and afflict his mind, and will still his voice, that he may not cry to God

Ac hwæt dyde se blinda, þaþa þæt folc hine wolde gestyllan
But what did the blind man, when the people would still him

He hrymde ðæs ðe swiðor, oð þæt se Hælend his stemne gehyrde, and hine gehælde
He called so much the louder, until Jesus heard his voice and healed him

Swa we sceolon eac dón, gif us deofol drecce mid menigfealdum geðohtum and costnungum: we sceolon hryman swiðor and swiðor to ðam Hælende, þæt he todræfe ða yfelan costnunga fram ure heortan, and þæt he onlihte ure mod mid his gife
So should we do also, if the devil trouble us with manifold thoughts and temptations: we should call louder and louder to Jesus, that he drive the evil temptations from our hearts, and that he enlighten our mind with his grace

Gif we ðonne þurhwuniað on urum gebedum, þonne mage we gedon mid urum hreame þæt se Hælend stent, seðe ær eode, and wile gehyran ure clypunge, and ure heortan onlihtan mid godum and mid clænum geðohtum
But if we continue praying, then may we with our cry incline Jesus to stand, who was before passing on, and to hear our cry, and enlighten our hearts with good and pure thoughts

Ne magon ða yfelan geðohtas ús derian, gif hi ús ne liciað
Evil thoughts cannot harm us, if they are not pleasing to us

ac swa ús swiðor deofol bregð mid yfelum geðohtum, swa we beteran beoð, and Gode leofran, gif we ðone deofol forseoð and ealle his costnunga, ðurh Godes fultum
but the more the devil terrifies us with evil thoughts, so much the better shall we be, and dearer to God, if we despise the devil and all his temptations through God's assistance

Hwæt is þæs Hælendes stede, oððe hwæt is his fær
What is Jesus's standing, or what is his passing

He ferde ðurh his menniscnysse, and he stod þurh þa godcundnysse
He passed through his human nature, and he stood through the divine nature

He ferde ðurh ða menniscnysse, swa þæt he wæs acenned, and ferde fram stowe to stowe, and deað þrowade, and of deaðe arás, and astah to heofenum
He passed through human nature, so that he was born, and passed from place to place, and suffered death, and from death arose, and ascended to heaven

Þis is his fær
This is his passing

He stent ðurh ða godcundnysse
He stands through his divine nature

forðon ðe hé is ðurh his mihte æghwær andweard, and ne ðearf na faran fram stowe to stowe
because he is, by his power, everywhere present, and needs not go from place to place

forðon ðe hé is on ælcere stowe þurh his godcundnysse
because he is in every place through his divine nature

Þaða he ferde, þa gehyrde he þæs blindan clypunge
When he was passing he heard the blind man's cry

and þaþa he stod, þa forgeaf he him gesihðe
and when he stood he gave him sight

forðan þurh ða menniscnysse he besargað ures modes blindnysse, and ðurh ða godcundnysse he forgifð us leoht, and ure blindnysse onliht
because through his human nature he bewails the blindness of our minds, and through his divine nature he gives us light, and enlightens our blindness

He cwæð to ðam blindan men
He said to the blind man

Hwæt wilt ðu þæt ic ðe do
What wilt thou that I do to thee

Wenst ðu þæt hé nyste hwæt se blinda wolde, seðe hine gehælan mihte
Thinkest thou that he knew not what the blind man desired, he who could heal him

Ac he wolde þæt se blinda bæde
But he would that the blind man should pray

forðon þe hé tiht ælcne swiðe gemaglice to gebedum: ac hwæðere he cwyð on oðre stowe
for he exhorts everyone very urgently to prayers: for though he says, in another place

Eower heofenlica Fæder wat hwæs ge behofiað, ærðan ðe ge hine æniges ðinges biddan
Your heavenly Father knoweth what ye require, before ye pray to him for anything

þeah-hwæðere wile se goda God þæt we hine georne biddon
yet the good God desires that we should fervently pray to him

forðan þurh ða gebedu bið ure heorte onbryrd and gewend to Gode
because by prayers is our heart stimulated and turned to God

Ða cwæð se blinda
Then said the blind man

La leof, do þæt ic mæge geseon
Sir, do that I may see

Ne bæd se blinda naðor ne goldes, ne seolfres, ne nane woruldlice ðing, ac bæd his gesihðe
The blind man prayed neither for gold, nor silver, nor any worldly things, but prayed for his sight

For nahte he tealde ænig ðing to biddenne buton gesihðe
For naught he accounted it to pray for anything but sight

forðan ðeah se blinda sum ðing hæbbe, he ne mæg butan leohte geseon þæt he hæfð
because, though the blind may have something, he cannot without light see that which he has

Uton forði geefenlæcan þisum men, þe wæs gehæled fram Criste, ægðer ge on lichaman ge on sawle: ne bidde we na lease welan, ne gewitenlice wurðmyntas
Let us then imitate this man who was healed by Christ, both in body and in soul: let us pray, not for deceitful riches, nor transitory honours

ac uton biddan leoht æt urum Drihtne: na þæt leoht ðe bið geendod, þe bið mid þære nihte todræfed, þæt ðe is gemæne ús and nytenum
but let us pray to our Lord for light: not for that light which will be ended, which will be driven away by the night, that which is common to us and to the brutes

ac uton biddan þæs leohtes þe we magon mid englum anum geseon, þæt ðe næfre ne bið geendod
but let us pray for that light which we can see with angels only, which shall never be ended

To ðam leohte soðlice ure geleafa us sceal gebringan, swa swa Crist cwæð to ðam blindan menn
To that light verily our faith shall bring us, as Christ said to the blind man

Lóca nu, þin geleafa ðe gehælde
Look now: thy faith hath healed thee

Nu smeað sum ungeleafful man, Hu mæg ic gewilnian ðæs gastlican leohtes, þæt þæt ic geseon ne mæg
Now some unbelieving man will ask, How may I desire the spiritual light which I cannot see

Nu cweðe ic to ðam menn, þæt ða ðing þe hé understynt and undergytan mæg, ne undergyt he ná ða ðing þurh his lichaman, ac þurh his sawle
Now to that man I say, that the things which he understands and may comprehend, he understands those things not through his body, but through his soul

þeah-hwæðere ne gesihð nan man his sawle on ðisum life
yet no man sees his soul in this life

Heo is ungesewenlic, ac ðeah-hwæðere heo wissað þone gesewenlican lichaman
It is invisible, but, nevertheless, it guides the visible body

Se lichama, ðe is gesewenlic, hæfð lif of ðære sawle, þe is ungesewenlic
The body, which is visible, has life from the soul, which is invisible

Gewíte þæt ungesewenlice ut, þonne fylð adune þæt gesewenlice
If that which is invisible depart, then will the visible fall down

forðan þe hit ne stod na ær ðurh hit sylf
because it before stood not of itself

Þæs lichoman lif is seo sawul, and þære sawle lif is God
The life of the body is the soul, and the life of the soul is God

Gewite seo sawul ut, ne mæg se muð clypian, þeah ðe hé gynige
If the soul depart, the mouth cannot cry, though it gape

ne eage geseon, þeah ðe hit open sy
nor the eye see, though it be open

ne nán limn ne deð nan ðing, gif se lichama bið sawulleas
nor will any limb do anything, if the body be soulless

Swa eac seo sawul, gif God hí forlæt for synnum, ne deð heo nan ðing to góde
So also the soul, if God, for its sins, forsake it, it will do nothing good

Ne mæg nan man nan ðing to góde gedon, butan Godes fultume
No man may do anything good without God's support

Ne bið seo synfulle sawul na mid ealle to nahte awend, ðeah ðe heo gode adeadod sy
The sinful soul will not be wholly turned to naught, though it be rendered dead to good

ac heo bið dead ælcere duguðe and gesælðe, and bið gehealden to ðam ecan deaðe, þær þær heo æfre bið on pinungum wunigende, and þeah-hwæðere næfre ne ateorað
but it will be dead to every excellence and happiness, and will be preserved to eternal death, where it will be ever continuing in torments, and yet will never perish

Hu mæg þe nú twynian þæs ecan leohtes, ðeah hit ungesewenlic sy, þonne þu hæfst líf of ungesewenlicre sawle, and þe ne twynað nan ðing þæt þu sawle hæbbe, ðeah ðu hí geseon ne mage
How canst thou now doubt of the eternal light, though it be invisible, when thou hast life from an invisible soul, and thou doubtest not that thou hast a soul, though thou canst not see it

Se blinda, ðaða hé geseon mihte, þa fyligde hé ðam Hælende
The blind man, when he could see, followed Jesus

Se man gesihð and fylið Gode, seðe cann understandan God, and gód weorc wyrcð
That man sees and follows God, who can understand God, and does good works

Se man gesihð and nele Gode fylian, seðe understent God, and nele gód wyrcan
That man sees and will not follow God, who understands God, and will not do good works

Ac uton understandan God and gód weorc wyrcean: uton behealdan hwíder Crist gange, and him fylian
But let us understand God, and do good works: let us behold whither Christ goes, and follow him

þæt is þæt we sceolon smeagan hwæt hé tæce, and hwæt him licige, and þæt mid weorcum gefyllan, swa swa hé sylf cwæð
that is, that we should meditate on what he teaches, and what is pleasing to him, and that with works fulfil, as he himself said

Se ðe me þenige, fylige hé me
He who will serve me, let him follow me

þæt is, geefenlæce hé me, and onscunige ælc yfel, and lufige ælc gód, swa swa ic do
that is, let him imitate me, and shun every evil, and love every good, as I do

Ne teah Crist him na to on ðisum life land ne welan, swa swa he be him sylfum cwæð
Christ gained for himself in this life neither land nor riches, as he of himself said

Deor habbað hola, and fugelas habbað nest, hwær hí restað, and ic næbbe hwider ic ahylde min heafod
The beasts have holes, and the birds have nests, where they rest, and I have not where I may lay down my head

Swa micel he hæfde swa he rohte, and leofode be oðra manna æhtum, se ðe ealle ðing áh
He had as much as he recked of, and lived on the possessions of other men, he who owned all things

We rædað on Cristes bec þæt þæt folc rædde be him, þæt hí woldon hine gelæccan, and ahebban to cyninge, þæt he wære heora heafod for worulde, swa swa he wæs godcundlice
We read in the book of Christ that the people resolved concerning him, that they would seize him, and set him up for king, that he might be their temporal head, as he was divinely

Þaþa Crist ongeat ðæs folces willan, ða fleah hé anstandende to anre dúne, and his geferan gewendon to sǽ, and se Hælend wæs up on lande
When Christ perceived the people's will he fled alone to a mountain, and his companions went to the sea, and Jesus was up on land

Ða on niht eode se Hælend up on ðam wætere mid drium fotum, oðþæt he com to his leorning-cnihtum, ðær ðær hí wæron on rewute
Then by night Jesus went on the water with dry feet, until he came to his disciples, where they were in a ship

He forfleah þone woruldlican wurðmynt, þaþa he wæs to cyninge gecoren
He fled from worldly honour, when he was chosen king

ac he ne forfleah na þæt edwit and ðone hosp, þaþa ða Iudeiscan hine woldon on rode ahón
but he fled not from reproach and scorn, when the Jews would hang him on a cross

He nolde his heafod befon mid gyldenum cynehelme, ac mid þyrnenum, swa swa hit gedon wæs on his þrowunge
He would not encircle his head with a golden crown, but with one of thorns, as it was done at his passion

He nolde on ðissum life rixian hwilwendlice, seðe ecelice rixað on heofonum
He would not reign for a while in this life, who rules eternally in heaven

Nis ðeos woruld na ure eðel, ac is ure wræcsið
This world is not our country, but is our place of exile

forði ne sceole we na besettan urne hiht on þissum swicelum life, ac sceolon efstan mid godum geearnungum to urum eðele, þær we to gesceapene wæron, þæt is to heofenan rice
therefore should we not set our hope in this deceitful life, but should hasten with good deserts to our country, for which we were created, that is, to the kingdom of heaven

Soðlice hit is awriten
Verily it is written

Swa hwa swa wile beon freond þisre worulde, se bið geteald Godes feond
Whosoever will be a friend of this world, he shall be accounted a foe of God

Crist cwæð on sumere stowe, þæt
Christ said in some place, that

Se weig is swiðe nearu and sticol, seðe læt to heofonan rice
The way is very narrow and steep which leads to the kingdom of heaven

and se is swiðe rúm and smeðe, seðe læt to helle-wite
and it is very wide and smooth which leads to hell-torment

Se weig, seðe læt to heofenan rice, is forði nearu and sticol, forði þæt we sceolon mid earfoðnysse geearnian urne eðel
The way which leads to the kingdom of heaven is narrow and steep, in order that we should with difficulty gain our country

Gif we hine habban willað, we sceolon lufian mildheortnysse, and clænnysse, and soðfæstnysse, and rihtwisnysse, and eadmodnysse, and habban soðe lufe to Gode and to mannum, and dón ælmessan be ure mæðe, and habban gemet on urum bigleofan, and gehwilce oðere halige ðing began
If we desire to obtain it, we should love mercy, and chastity, and truth, and righteousness, and humility, and have true love to God and to men, and give alms according to our means, and be moderate in our food, and observe all other holy things

Þas ðing we ne magon dón butan earfoðnyssum
These things we cannot do without difficulties

ac gif we hí doð, þonne mage we mid þam geswincum, ðurh Godes fultum, astigan ðone sticolan weg þe us gelæt to ðam ecan life
but if we do them, then may we with those labours, through God's support, ascend the steep way which leads us to eternal life

Se weg seðe læt to forwyrde is forði brad and smeðe, forði þe únlustas gebringað þone man to forwyrde
The way which leads to perdition is broad and smooth, because wicked lusts bring a man to perdition

Him bið swiðe softe, and nan geswinc þæt he fylle his galnysse, and druncennysse, and gytsunge begange and modignysse, and ða unstrangan berype, and dón swa hwæt swa hine lyst: ac ðas unðeawas and oðre swilce gelædað hine butan geswince to ecum tintregum, buton he ær his ende yfeles geswice and gód wyrce
It is very soft to him and no labour to satiate his libidinousness and drunkenness, and practise covetousness and pride, and rob the weak, and do whatsoever he lists: but those evil practices and others such lead him without labour to eternal torments, unless before his end he desist from evil and do good

Dysig bið se wegferenda man seðe nimð þone smeðan weg þe hine mislæt, and forlæt ðone sticolan þe hine gebrincð to ðære byrig
Foolish is the wayfaring man who takes the smooth way that misleads him, and forsakes the steep which brings him to the city

Swa eac we beoð soðlice ungerade, gif we lufiað þa sceortan softnysse and ða hwilwendlican lustas to ðan swiðe, þæt hi us gebringan to ðam ecan pinungum
So also shall we be truly inconsiderate, if we love brief voluptuousness and transitory pleasures so greatly that they bring us to eternal torments

Ac uton niman þone earfoðran weg, þæt we her sume hwile swincon, to ðy þæt we ecelice beon butan geswince
But let us take the more difficult way, that we may here for some time labour, in order to be eternally without labour

Eaðe mihte Crist, gif he wolde, on þisum life wunian butan earfoðnyssum, and faran to his ecan rice butan ðrowunge, and butan deaðe
Easily might Christ, had he been willing, have continued in this life without hardships, and gone to his everlasting kingdom without suffering, and without death

ac he nolde
but he would not

Be ðam cwæð Petrus se apostol
Concerning which Peter the apostle said

Crist ðrowode for us, and sealde us bysne, þæt we sceolon fyligan his fotswaðum
Christ suffered for us, and gave us an example, that we should follow his footsteps

þæt is, þæt we sceolon sum ðing þrowian for Cristes lufon, and for urum synnum
that is, that we should suffer something for love of Christ, and for our sins

Wel ðrowað se man, and Gode gecwemlice, seðe winð ongean leahtras, and godnysse gefremað, swa swa he fyrmest mæg
Well suffers the man, and acceptably to God, who strives against wickedness, and promotes goodness, as he best may

Se ðe nan ðing nele on ðissum life ðrowian, he sceal ðrowian unþances wyrsan ðrowunga on þam toweardan life
He who will suffer nothing in this life, shall suffer against his will in the life to come

Nu genealæcð clæne tid and halig, on þære we sceolon ure gimeleaste gebetan: cume forði gehwa cristenra manna to his scrifte, and his diglan gyltas geandette, and be his láreowes tæcunge gebete
Now is a pure and holy time drawing nigh, in which we should atone for our remissness: let, therefore, every christian man come to his confessor, and confess his secret sins, and amend by the teaching of his instructor

and tihte ælc oðerne to góde mid godre gebysnunge, þæt eal folc cweðe be ús, swa swa be ðam blindan gecweden wæs, ðaða his eagan wæron onlihte
and let everyone stimulate another to good by good example, that all people may say of us, as was said of the blind man when his eyes were enlightened

þæt is, Eall folc þe þæt wundor geseah, herede God, seðe leofað and rixað á butan ende
that is, All people who saw that miracle praised God, who liveth and reigneth ever without end

Amen
Amen

Ic wolde eow trahtnian þis godspel, ðe mann nu beforan eow rædde, ac ic ondræde þæt ge ne magon ða micelan deopnysse þæs godspelles swa understandan swa hit gedafenlic sy
I would expound to you this gospel which has just now been read before you, but I fear that ye cannot understand the great depth of this gospel as it is fitting

Nu bidde ic eow þæt ge beon geðyldige on eowerum geðance, oðþæt we ðone traht mid Godes fylste oferrædan magon
Now I pray you to be patient in your thoughts till, with God's assistance, we can read over the text

Se Hælend wæs gelæd fram þam Halgan Gaste to anum westene, to ðy þæt he wære gecostnod fram deofle: and he ða fæste feowertig daga and feowertig nihta, swa þæt he ne onbyrigde ætes ne wætes on eallum þam fyrste: ac siððan him hingrode
Jesus was led by the Holy Ghost to a waste, in order that he might be tempted by the devil: and he there fasted forty days and forty nights, so that he tasted neither food nor drink in all that time: but he then hungered

Þa genealæhte se costnere, and him to cwæð, Gif ðu sy Godes Sunu, cweð to ðisum stanum þæt hi beon awende to hlafum
Then the tempter approached, and said to him, If thou art the Son of God, say to these stones that they be turned to loaves

Ða andwearde se Hælend, and cwæð, Hit is awriten, ne leofað se mann na be hlafe anum, ac lyfað be eallum ðam wordum þe gað of Godes muðe
Then Jesus answered, and said, It is written, Man liveth not by bread alone, but liveth by all the words that go from the mouth of God

Þa genam se deofol hine, and gesette hine uppan ðam scylfe þæs heagan temples, and cwæð, Gif ðu Godes Sunu sy, feall nu adún: hit is awriten, þæt englum is beboden be ðe, þæt hi ðe on hira handum ahebbon, þæt þu furðon ne ðurfe ðinne fot æt stane ætspurnan
Then the devil took him, and set him upon the summit of the lofty temple, and said, If thou art the Son of God, fall now down: it is written, that angels are commanded concerning thee, that they shall lift thee in their hands, that thou may not dash thy foot on a stone

Þa cwæð se Hælend eft him to, Hit is awriten, Ne fanda þines Drihtnes
Then said Jesus again to him, It is written, Tempt not thy Lord

Þa genam se deofol hine eft, and gesette hine uppan anre swiðe heahre dune, and æteowde him ealles middangeardes welan, and his wuldor, and cwæð him to, Ealle ðas ðing ic forgife ðe, gif ðu wilt feallan to minum fotum and gebiddan þe to me
Then the devil took him again, and set him upon a very high mountain, and showed him all the wealth and glory of the world, and said to him, All these things will I give thee, if thou wilt fall at my feet, and adore me

Ða cwæð se Hælend him to, Ga ðu underbæcc, sceocca
Then said Jesus to him, Go thou behind, Satan

Hit is awriten, Gehwá sceal hine gebiddan to his Drihtne anum, and him anum ðeowian
It is written, Everyone shall adore his Lord alone, and him alone serve

Þa forlet se deofol hine, and him comon englas to, and him ðenodon
Then the devil left him, and angels came to him, and ministered unto him

Se Halga Gast lædde þone Hælend to þam westene, to ðy þæt he wære þær gecostnod
The Holy Ghost led Jesus to the waste, that he might there be tempted

Nu wundrað gehwá hú se deofol dorste genealæcan to ðam Hælende, þæt he hine costnode: ac hé ne dorste Cristes fándian, gif him alyfed nære
Now everyone will wonder how the devil durst approach Jesus to tempt him: but he durst not tempt Jesus, if it had not been allowed him

Se Hælend com to mancynne forði þæt he wolde ealle ure costnunga oferswiðan mid his costnungum, and oferswiðan urne ðone ecan deað mid his hwilwendlicum deaðe
Jesus came to mankind because he would overcome all our temptations by his temptations, and overcome our eternal death with his temporary death

Nu wæs he swa eadmod þæt he geðafode ðam deofle þæt he his fandode, and he geðafode lyðrum mannum þæt hi hine ofslogon
Now he was so humble that he permitted the devil to tempt him, and he permitted wicked men to slay him

Deofol is ealra unrihtwisra manna heafod, and þa yfelan men sind his lima: nu geðafode God þæt þæt heafod hine costnode, and þæt ða limu hine ahengon
The devil is the head of all unrighteous men, and evil men are his limbs: now God permitted the head to tempt him, and the limbs to crucify him

Þam deofle wæs micel twynung, Hwæt Crist wære
To the devil it was a great doubt, What Christ were

His líf næs na gelógod swa swa oðra manna líf
His life was not ordered like the lives of other men

Crist ne æt mid gyfernysse, ne he ne dránc mid oferflowendnysse, ne his eagan ne ferdon worigende geond mislice lustas
Christ ate not with avidity, nor did he drink with excess, nor did his eyes pass wandering amid various pleasures

Þa smeade se deofol hwæt he wære
Then the devil meditated what he were

hwæðer he wære Godes Sunu, seðe manncynne behaten wæs
whether he were the Son of God, who had been promised to mankind

Cwæð þa on his geðance, þæt he fandian wolde hwæt he wære
He said then in his thoughts, that he would prove what he were

Ða fæste Crist feowertig daga and feowertig nihta on án, ða on eallum þam fyrste ne cwæð se deofol to him þæt he etan sceolde, forðan þe hé geseh þæt him nan ðing ne hingrode
When Christ was fasting forty days and forty nights together, in all that time the devil did not say to him that he should eat, because he saw that he hungered not

Eft, ðaða Crist hingrode æfter swa langum fyrste, ða wende se deofol soðlice þæt he God nære, and cwæð to him
Afterwards, when Christ hungered after so long a time, then verily the devil weened that he was not God, and said to him

Hwi hingrað þe
Why hungerest thou

Gif ðu Godes Sunu sy, wend þas stanas to hlafum, and et
If thou art the Son of God, turn these stones to loaves, and eat

Eaðe mihte God, seðe awende wæter to wine, and seðe ealle gesceafta of nahte geworhte, eaðelice he mihte awendan ða stanas to hlafum: ac he nolde nan ðing don be ðæs deofles tæcunge
Easily might God, who turned water to wine, and he who wrought all creatures from nothing, easily might he have turned the stones to loaves: but he would do nothing by the devil's direction

ac cwæð him to andsware
but said to him in answer

Ne lifað na se man be hlafe anum, ac lifað be ðam wordum ðe gað of Godes muðe
Man liveth not by bread alone, but liveth by the words which go from the mouth of God

Swa swa þæs mannes lichama leofað be hlafe, swa sceal his sawul lybban be Godes wordum, þæt is, be Godes lare, þe he þurh wise menn on bocum gesette
As man's body lives by bread, so shall his soul live by the words of God, that is, by God's doctrine, which, through wise men, he has set in books

Gif se lichama næfð mete, oþþe ne mæg mete ðicgean, þonne forweornað he, and adeadað: swa eac seo sawul, gif heo næfð þa halgan lare, heo bið þonne weornigende and mægenleas
If the body has not food, or cannot eat food, then it decays and dies: so likewise the soul, if it has not the holy doctrine, it will be perishable and powerless

Þurh ða halgan lare heo bið strang and onbryrd to Godes willan
By the holy doctrine it will be strong, and stimulated to God's will

Þa wæs se deofol æne oferswiðed fram Criste
Then was the devil once overcome by Christ

And he ða hine genam, and bær upp on þæt templ, and hine sette æt ðam scylfe, and cwæð to him, Gif ðu Godes Sunu sy, sceot adún
And he then took him and bare him up on the temple, and set him on the summit, and said to him, If thou art the Son of God, dart down

forðan þe englum is beboden be ðe, þæt hí ðe on handum ahebban, þæt þu ne ðurfe ðinne fót æt stane ætspurnan
for it is commanded to angels concerning thee, that they shall raise thee on their hands, that thou may not dash thy foot against a stone

Her begánn se deofol to reccanne halige gewritu, and he leah mid þære race
Here the devil began to expound the holy scriptures, and he lied in his exposition

forðan ðe hé is leas, and nan soðfæstnys nis on him
because he is false, and there is no truth in him

ac he is fæder ælcere leasunge
but he is the father of all leasing

Næs þæt na awriten be Criste þæt hé ða sæde, ac wæs awriten be halgum mannum: hí behofiað engla fultumes on þissum life, þæt se deofol hí costnian ne mote swa swiðe swa he wolde
It was not written of Christ what he there said, but was written of holy men: they require the support of angels in this life, that the devil may not tempt them so much as he would

Swa hold is God mancynne, þæt he hæfð geset his englas us to hyrdum, þæt hí ne sceolon na geðafian þam reðum deoflum þæt hí ús fordon magon
So benevolent is God to mankind, that he has set his angels over us as guardians, that they may not allow the fierce devils to fordo us

Hi moton ure afandian, ac hí ne moton us nydan to nanum yfle, buton we hit sylfe agenes willan dón, þurh þa yfelan tihtinge ðæs deofles
They may tempt us, but they cannot compel us to any evil, unless we ourselves do it of our own will, through the evil instigation of the devil

We ne beoð na fulfremede buton we beon afandode: þurh ða fandunge we sceolon geðeon, gif we æfre wiðsacað deofle, and eallum his larum
We shall not be perfect unless we be tempted: through temptation we shall thrive, if we ever resist the devil and all his precepts

and gif we genealæcað urum Drihtne mid geleafan, and lufe, and godum weorcum
and if we draw nigh to our Lord with faith, and love, and good works

gif we hwær aslidon, arisan eft þærrihte, and betan georne þæt ðær tobrocen bið
if we anywhere slide down, arise forthwith, and earnestly mend what shall there be broken

Crist cwæð þa to ðam deofle
Christ said to the devil

Ne sceal man fandigan his Drihtnes
No one shall tempt his Lord

Þæt wære swiðe gilplic dǽd gif Crist scute ða adún, þeah ðe he eaðe mihte butan awyrdnysse his lima nyðer asceotan, seðe gebigde þone heagan heofenlican bigels
It would have been a very proud deed if Christ had cast himself down, though he easily might, without injury of his limbs, have cast himself down, who bowed the high arch of heaven

ac he nolde nan ðing dón mid gylpe
but he would do nothing in pride, because pride is a deadly sin

forðon þe se gylp is an heafod-leahter
so he would not cast himself down, because he would shun pride

þa nolde he adún asceotan, forðon ðe he onscunode þone gylp
but said

ac cwæð
No one shall tempt his Lord

Se man fándiað his Drihtnes, seðe, mid dyslicum truwan and mid gylpe, sum wundorlic ðing on Godes naman dón wile, oððe seðe sumes wundres dyslice and butan neode, æt Gode abiddan wile
Then was the devil, by Christ's patience, overcome a second time

Þa genam he hine eft, and abær hine úpp on ane dune, and ætywde him ealles middangeardes welan and his wuldor, and cwæð to him, Ealle ðas ðing ic forgife ðe, gif ðu wilt afeallan to minum fotum, and þe to me gebiddan
Then he took him again, and bare him up on a mountain, and showed him all the riches of the world and its glory, and said to him, All these things will I give thee, if thou wilt fall at my feet, and adore me

Dyrstelice spræc se deofol her, swa swa he ær spræc, þaþa he on heofenum wæs, þaþa he wolde dælan heofonan rice wið his Scyppend, and beon Gode gelíc
Presumptuously spake the devil here, as he before spake, when he was in heaven, when he would share the heavenly kingdom with his Creator, and be equal to God

ac his dyrstignys hine awearp ða into helle
but his presumption then cast him down into hell

and eac nu his dyrstignys hine geniðerode, þaða he, ðurh Cristes þrowunge, forlet mancynn of his anwealde
and now also his presumption humbled him, when he, through Christ's passion, let mankind out of his power

He cwæð
He said

Þas ðing ic forgife ðe
These things will I give thee

Him ðuhte þæt he ahte ealne middangeard
It seemed to him that he possessed all the world

forðon ðe him ne wiðstod nan man ærðam þe Crist com þe hine gewylde
because no man withstood him before Christ came who subdued him

Hit is awriten on halgum bocum
It is written in holy books

Eorðe and eall hire gefyllednys, and eal ymbhwyrft and þa ðe on ðam wuniað, ealle hit syndon Godes æhta
Earth and all its fullness, and all the globe and those who dwell on it, all are God's possessions

and na deofles
and not the devil's

Þeah-hwæðere Crist cwæð on his godspelle be ðam deofle, þæt he wære middangeardes ealdor, and he sceolde beon út-adræfed
Nevertheless, Christ said in his gospel concerning the devil, that he was the prince of the world, and he should be driven out

He is ðæra manna ealdor, þe lufiað þisne middangeard, and ealne heora hiht on þissum lífe besettað, and heora Scyppend forseoð
He is the prince of those men who love this world, and set all their hope in this life, and despise their Creator

Ealle gesceafta, sunne, and mona, and ealle tunglan, land, and sǽ, and nytenu, ealle hí ðeowiað hyra Scyppende
All creatures, sun, and moon, and all stars, land, and sea, and cattle, all serve their Creator

forðon þe hí farað æfter Godes dihte
because they perform their course after God's direction

Se lyðra man ána, þonne he forsihð Godes beboda, and fullgǽð deofles willan, oððe þurh gytsunge, oþþe ðurh leasunge, oððe ðurh graman, oððe ðurh oðre leahtras, þonne bið he deofles ðeowa, þonne he deofle gecwemð, and þone forsihð ðe hine geworhte
Wicked man alone, when he despises the commandments of God, and fulfils the devil's will, either through covetousness, or through leasing, or through anger, or through other sins, then is he the devil's thrall, then is he acceptable to the devil, and despises him who created him

Crist cwæð ða to ðam deofle, Ga ðu underbæcc, sceocca
Christ then said to the devil, Go thou behind, Satan

Hit is awriten, Man sceal hine gebiddan to his Drihtne, and him anum ðeowian
It is written, Man shall adore his Lord, and serve him alone
