He cwæð to ðam deofle
He said to the devil

Ga ðu underbæc
Go thou behind

Deofles nama is gereht, 'Nyðer-hreosende
The name of devil is interpreted, Falling down

' Nyðer he ahreas, and underbæc he eode fram frimðe his anginnes, þaða he wæs ascyred fram ðære heofonlican blisse
He fell down, and he went behind from the beginning of his enterprize, when he was cut off from heavenly bliss

on hinder he eode eft þurh Cristes to-cyme
he went behind again through Christ's advent

on hinder he sceal gán on domes dæge, þonne he bið belocen on helle-wite on écum fyre, he and ealle his geferan
he shall go behind on doomsday, when he shall be shut up in hell in eternal fire, he and all his associates

and hí næfre siððan út-brecan ne magon
and they never afterwards may burst out

Hit is awriten on ðære ealdan ǽ, þæt nan man ne sceal hine gebiddan to nanum deofelgylde, ne to nanum ðinge, buton to Gode anum
It is written in the old law that no man shall worship any idol, nor anything, save God alone

forðon ðe nán gesceaft nys wyrðe þæs wurðmyntes, buton se ana seðe Scyppend is ealra ðinga: to him anum we sceolon ús gebiddan
because no creature is worthy of that honour, save him alone who is the Creator of all things: him only should we worship

he ana is soð Hlaford and soð God
he alone is true Lord and true God

We biddað þingunga æt halgum mannum, þæt hi sceolon ús ðingian to heora Drihtne and to urum Drihtne
We pray for their intercessions to holy men, that they may mediate for us with their Lord and our Lord

ne gebidde we ná, ðeah-hwæðere, us to him, swa swa we to Gode doð, ne hi þæt geðafian nellað
still we do not worship them as we do God, nor would they permit it

swa swa se engel cwæð to Iohanne þam apostole, ðaða he wolde feallan to his fotum: he cwæð
as the angel said to John the apostle, when he would fall at his feet: he said

Ne do þu hit na, þæt þu to me abuge
Do thou it not, that thou bowest to me

Ic eom Godes þeowa, swa swa ðu and þine gebroðra: gebide ðe to Gode anum
I am God's servant, as thou and thy brethren: worship God alone

Þa forlét se deofol Crist, and him comon englas to, and him ðenodon
Then the devil left Christ, and angels came to him, and ministered to him

He wæs gecostnod swa swa mann, and æfter ðære costnunge him comon halige englas to, and him ðenodon, swa swa heora Scyppende
He was tempted as a man, and after the temptation holy angels came to him, and ministered to him as to their Creator

Buton se deofol gesawe þæt Crist man wære, ne gecostnode he hine
Unless the devil had seen that Christ was a man, he would not have tempted him

and buton he soð God wære, noldon ða englas him ðenian
and unless he had been true God, the angels would not have ministered to him

Mycel wæs ures Hælendes eaðmodnys and his geþyld on ðisre dæde
Great was our Saviour's meekness and his patience in this deed

He mihte mid anum worde besencan ðone deofol on þære deopan nywelnysse
He might with one word have sunk the devil into the deep abyss

ac hé ne æteowde his mihte, ac mid halgum gewritum he andwyrde ðam deofle, and sealde us bysne mid his geðylde, þæt swa oft swa we fram ðwyrum mannum ænig ðing þrowiað, þæt we sceolon wendan ure mod to Godes lare swiðor þonne to ænigre wrace
but he manifested not his might, but answered the devil with the holy scriptures, and gave us an example by his patience, that, as often as we suffer anything from perverse men, we should turn our mind to God's precepts rather than to any vengeance

On ðreo wisan bið deofles costnung: þæt is on tihtinge, on lustfullunge, on geðafunge
In three ways is temptation of the devil: that is in instigation, in pleasure, in consent

Deofol tiht ús to yfele, ac we sceolon hit onscunian, and ne geniman nane lustfullunge to ðære tihtinge: gif þonne ure mod nimð gelustfullunge, þonne sceole we huru wiðstandan, þæt ðær ne beo nán geðafung to ðam yfelan weorce
The devil instigates us to evil, but we should shun it, and take no pleasure in the instigation: but if our mind takes pleasure, then should we at least withstand, so that there be no consent to evil work

Seo yfele tihting is of deofle
Instigation to evil is of the devil

ðonne bið oft þæs mannes mód gebiged to ðære lustfullunge, hwilon eac aslít to ðære geðafunge
but a man's mind is often bent to pleasure, sometimes also it lapses into consent

forðon þe we sind of synfullum flæsce acennede
seeing that we are born of sinful flesh

Næs na se Hælend on ða wisan gecostnod
Not in this wise was Jesus tempted

forðon ðe he wæs of mædene acenned buton synne, and næs nan ðing ðwyrlices on him
because he was born of a virgin without sin, and that there was nothing perverse in him

He mihte beon gecostnod þurh tihtinge, ac nan lustfullung ne hrepede his mód
He might have been tempted by instigation, but no pleasure touched his mind

Þær næs eac nan geðafung, forðon ðe ðær næs nan lustfullung
There was also no consent, because there was no pleasure

ac wæs ðæs deofles costnung forðy eall wiðutan, and nan ðing wiðinnan
therefore was the devil's temptation all without, and nothing within

Ungewiss com se deofol to Criste, and ungewiss he eode aweig
Uncertain came the devil to Christ, and uncertain he went away

forðan þe se Hælend ne geswutulode na him his mihte, ac oferdráf hine geðyldelice mid halgum gewritum
seeing that Jesus manifested not his power to him, but overcame him patiently by the holy scriptures

Se ealda deofol gecostnode urne fæder Adám on ðreo wisan: þæt is mid gyfernysse, and mid idelum wuldre, and mid gitsunge
The old devil tempted our father Adam in three ways: that is with greediness, with vain-glory, and with covetousness

and þa wearð he oferswiðed, forðon þe he geðafode ðam deofle on eallum þam ðrim costnungum
and then he was overcome, because he consented to the devil in all those three temptations

Þurh gyfernysse he wæs oferswiðed, þaþa he ðurh deofles lare æt ðone forbodenan æppel
Through greediness he was overcome, when, by the devil's instruction, he ate the forbidden apple

Þurh idel wuldor he wæs oferswiðed, ðaða he gelyfde ðæs deofles wordum, ðaða he cwæð
Through vain-glory he was overcome, when he believed the devil's words, when he said

Swa mære ge beoð swa swa englas, gif ge of þam treowe etað
Ye shall be as great as angels, if ye eat of that tree

And hí ða gelyfdon his leasunge, and woldon mid idelum gylpe beon beteran þonne hí gesceapene wæron: ða wurdon hí wyrsan
And they then believed his leasing, and would in their vain-glory be better than they had been created: then became they worse

Mid gytsunge he wæs oferswiðed, þaþa se deofol cwæð to him
With covetousness he was overcome, when the devil said to him

And ge habbað gescead ægðer ge gódes ge ýfeles
And ye shall have the power to distinguish good from evil

Nis na gytsung on feo anum, ac is eac on gewilnunge micelre geðincðe
Covetousness is not alone in money, but is also in the desire of great dignity

Mid þam ylcum ðrim ðingum þe se deofol ðone frumsceapenan mann oferswiðde, mid þam ylcan Crist oferswiðde hine, and astrehte
With the same three things with which the devil overcame the first-created man, Christ overcame and prostrated him

Þurh gyfernysse fandode se deofol Cristes, ðaða he cwæð
Through greediness the devil tempted Christ, when he said

Cweð to ðysum stanum þæt hí beon to hlafum awende, and et
Say to these stones that they be turned to loaves, and eat

Þurh idel wuldor he fandode his, þaþa he hine tihte þæt hé sceolde sceotan nyðer of ðæs temples scylfe
Through vain-glory he tempted him, when he would instigate him to dart down from the temple's summit

Þurh gitsunge he fandode his, ðaða he mid leasunge him behet ealles middangeardes welan, gif he wolde feallan to his fotum
Through covetousness he tempted him, when, with leasing, he promised him the wealth of all the world, if he would fall at his feet

Ac se deofol wæs þa oferswiðed ðurh Crist on þam ylcum gemetum þe he ær Adam oferswiðde
But the devil was overcome by Christ by the same means with which he had of yore overcome Adam

þæt he gewite fram urum heortum mid þam innfære gehæft, mid þam þe he inn-afaren wæs and us gehæfte
so that he departed from our hearts made captive by the entrance at which he had entered and made us captives

We gehyrdon on ðisum godspelle þæt ure Drihten fæste feowertig daga and feowertig nihta on án
We have heard in this gospel that our Lord fasted forty days and forty nights together

Ðaða he swa lange fæste, þa geswutelode he þa micelan mihte his godcundnysse, þurh ða he mihte on eallum ðisum andweardum life butan eorðlicum mettum lybban, gif he wolde
When he had fasted so long he manifested the great power of his godhead, by which he might, in all this present life, without earthly food, have lived, if he had been willing

Eft, ðaða him hingrode, þa geswutelode he þæt hé wæs soð man, and forði metes behofode
Afterwards, when he was hungry, he manifested that he was a true man, and therefore required food

Moyses se heretoga fæste eac feowertig daga and feowertig nihta, to ði þæt he moste underfon Godes ǽ
Moses the leader fasted also forty days and forty nights, that he might receive God's law

ac he ne fæste na þurh his agene mihte, ac þurh Godes
but he fasted not through his own power, but through God's

Eac se witega Elias fæste ealswa lange eac þurh Godes mihte, and siððan wæs genumen butan deaðe of ðisum life
The prophet Elijah also fasted as long through God's power, and was afterwards, without death, taken from this life

Nu is ðis fæsten eallum cristenum mannum geset to healdenne on ælces geares ymbryne
Now this fast is appointed to be held by all Christian men in the course of every year

ac we moton ælce dæg ures metes brucan mid forhæfednysse, ðæra metta þe alyfede sind
but we must also on each day eat our food with abstemiousness, of those meats which are permitted

Hwí is ðis fæsten þus geteald þurh feowertig daga
Why is this fast computed for forty days

On eallum geare sind getealde ðreo hund daga and fif and sixtig daga
In every year there are reckoned three hundred and sixty-five days

þonne, gif we teoðiað þas gearlican dagas, þonne beoð þær six and ðritig teoðing-dagas
now, if we tithe these yearly days, then will there be six and thirty tithing-days, and from this day to the holy Easter-day are two and forty days: take then the six Sundays from that number, then there will be six and thirty days of the year's tithing-days reckoned for our abstinence

Swa swa Godes ǽ ús bebyt þæt we sceolon ealle þa ðing þe us gesceotað of úres geares teolunge Gode þa teoðunge syllan, swa we sceolon eac on ðisum teoðing-dagum urne lichaman mid forhæfednysse Gode to lofe teoðian
As God's law enjoins us that we should of all the things which accrue to us from our yearly tillage give the tithe to God, so should we likewise on these tithing-days tithe our body with abstinence to the praise of God

We sceolon ús gearcian on eallum ðingum swa swa Godes þenas, æfter þæs apostoles tæcunge, on micclum geðylde, and on halgum wæccum, on fæstenum, and on clænnysse modes and lichaman
We should prepare ourselves in all things as God's servants, according to the apostle's teaching, with great patience, and with holy vigils, with fasts, and with chastity of mind and body

forði læsse pleoh bið þam cristenum men þæt he flæsces bruce, þonne he on ðissere halgan tide wífes bruce
for it is less perilous for a Christian man to eat flesh, than at this holy tide to have intercourse with woman

Lætað aweg ealle saca, and ælc geflitt, and gehealdað þas tid mid sibbe and mid soðre lufe
Set aside all quarrels and every dispute, and hold this tide with peace and with true love

forðon ne bið nan fæsten Gode andfenge butan sibbe
for no fast will be acceptable to God without peace

And doð swa swa God tæhte, tobrec ðinne hlaf, and syle ðone oþerne dæl hungrium men, and læd into þinum huse wǽdlan, and ða earman ælfremedan men, and gefrefra hí mid þinum godum
And do as God taught, break thy loaf, and give the second portion to an hungry man, and lead into thy house the poor, and miserable strangers, and comfort them with thy possessions

Þonne ðu nacodne geseo, scryd hine, and ne forseoh ðin agen flæsc
When thou seest one naked, clothe him, and despise not thy own flesh

Se mann þe fæst buton ælmyssan, hé deð swilce hé sparige his mete, and eft ett þæt hé ǽr mid forhæfednysse foreode
The man who fasts without alms does as though he spares his food, and afterwards eats that which he had previously forgone in his abstinence

ac þæt fæsten tælð God
but God contemns such fasting

Ac gif ðu fæstan wille Gode to gecwemednysse, þonne gehelp ðu earmra manna mid þam dæle ðe ðu þe sylfum oftihst, and eac mid maran, gif ðe to onhagige
But if thou wilt fast to God's contentment, then help poor men with the portion which thou withdrawest from thyself, and also with more, if it be thy pleasure

Forbúgað idele spellunge, and dyslice blissa, and bewepað eowre synna
Avoid idle discourse and foolish pleasures, and bewail your sins

forðon ðe Crist cwæð
for Christ said

Wá eow þe nu hlihgað, ge sceolon heofian and wepan
Woe to you who now laugh, ye shall mourn and weep

Eft he cwæð
Again he said

Eadige beoð ða ðe nu wepað, forðon ðe hi sceolon beon gefrefrode
Blessed are they who now weep, for they shall be comforted

We lybbað mislice on twelf monðum: nu sceole we ure gymeleaste on þysne timan geinnian, and lybban Gode, we ðe oðrum timan us sylfum leofodon
We live diversely for twelve months: now we shall at this time repair our heedlessness, and live to God, we who at other times have lived for ourselves

And swa hwæt swa we doð to gode, uton dón þæt butan gylpe and idelre herunge
And whatsoever good we do, let us do it without pride and vain praise

Se mann þe for gylpe hwæt to góde deð, him sylfum to herunge, næfð he ðæs nane mede æt Gode, ac hæfð his wite
The man who does any good for pride, to his own praise, will have no reward with God, but will have his punishment

Ac uton dón swa swa God tæhte, þæt ure godan weorc beon on ða wisan mannum cuðe, þæt hí magon geseon ure gódnysse, and þæt hí wuldrian and herigan urne Heofenlican Fæder, God Ælmihtigne, seðe forgilt mid hundfealdum swa hwæt swa we doð earmum mannum for his lufon, seðe leofað and rixað á butan ende on ecnysse
But let us do as God hath taught, that our good works may be so known to men that they may see our goodness, and glorify and praise our Heavenly Father, God Almighty, who requites an hundredfold whatsoever we do to poor men for love of him who liveth and reigneth ever without end to eternity

Amen
Amen

Se Hælend ferde ofer ða Galileiscan sǽ, þe is gehaten Tyberiadis, and him filigde micel menigu, forðon þe hi beheoldon ða tacna þe hé worhte ofer ða untruman men
Jesus went over the sea of Galilee, which is called of Tiberias, and a great multitude followed him, because they had seen the miracles which he had wrought on the diseased men

Þa astah se Hælend up on ane dune, and þær sǽt mid his leorning-cnihtum, and wæs ða swiðe gehende seo halige Eastertid
Then Jesus went up into a mountain, and there sat with his disciples, and the holy Easter-tide was then very nigh

Þa beseah se Hælend up, and geseah þæt ðær wæs mycel mennisc toweard, and cwæð to anum his leorning-cnihta, se wæs geháten Philippus, Mid hwam mage we bicgan hláf ðisum folce
Jesus then looked up, and saw that there was a great multitude coming, and said to one of his disciples, who was called Philip, With what can we buy bread for this people

Þis he cwæð to fándunge þæs leorning-cnihtes: he sylf wiste hwæt he dón wolde
This he said to prove the disciple: himself knew what he would do

Ða andwyrde Philippus, Þeah her wæron gebohte twa hund peningwurð hlafes, ne mihte furðon hyra ælc anne bitan of ðam gelæccan
Then Philip answered, Though two hundred pennyworth of bread were bought, yet could not every one of them get a morsel

Þa cwæð an his leorning-cnihta, se hátte Andreas, Petres broðor, Her byrð án cnapa fif berene hlafas, and twegen fixas, ac to hwán mæg þæt to swa micclum werode
Then said one of his disciples, who was called Andrew, Peter's brother, Here beareth a lad five barley loaves, and two fishes, but what is that for so great a multitude

Þa cwæð se Hælend, Doð þæt þæt folc sitte
Then said Jesus, Make the people sit

And þær wæs micel gǽrs on ðære stowe myrige on to sittenne
And there was much grass on the place pleasant to sit on: and they then all sat, about five thousand men

And hí ða ealle sæton, swa swa mihte beon fíf ðusend wera
Then Jesus took the five loaves, and blessed, and brake, and divided them among those sitting: in like manner also he divided the fishes

Ða genam se Hælend þa fíf hláfas, and bletsode, and tobræc, and todælde betwux ðam sittendum: swa gelíce eac þa fixas todælde
and they all had enough

and hí ealle genoh hæfdon
When they all were full, Jesus said to his disciples, Gather the remainder, and let it not be lost

Þaða hí ealle fulle wæron, ða cwæð se Hælend to his leorning-cnihtum, Gaderiað þa lafe, and hí ne losion
And they gathered the fragments, and filled twelve baskets with the remainder

And hi ða gegaderodon ða bricas, and gefyldon twelf wilian mid ðære lafe
The people, who saw this miracle, said that Christ was the true prophet who was to come to this world

Seo sǽ, þe se Hælend oferferde, getacnað þas andweardan woruld, to ðære com Crist and oferferde
The sea which Jesus passed over betokeneth this present world, which Christ came to and passed over

þæt is, he com to ðisre worulde on menniscnysse, and ðis lif oferferde
that is he came to this world in human nature, and passed over this life

he com to deaðe, and of deaðe aras
he came to death, and from death arose

and astah up on ane dune, and þær sæt mid his leorning-cnihtum, forðon ðe he astah up to heofenum, and þær sitt nuða mid his halgum
and went up on a mountain, and there sat with his disciples, for he ascended to heaven, and there sits now with his saints

Rihtlice is seo sǽ wiðmeten þisre worulde, forðon ðe heo is hwíltidum smylte and myrige ón to rowenne, hwilon eac swiðe hreoh and egeful on to beonne
Rightly is the sea compared to this world, for it is sometimes serene and pleasant to navigate on, sometimes also very rough and terrible to be on

Swa is þeos woruld
So is this world

hwíltidum heo is gesundful and myrige on to wunigenne, hwilon heo is eac swiðe styrnlic, and mid mislicum þingum gemenged, swa þæt heo for oft bið swiðe unwynsum on to eardigenne
sometimes it is desirable and pleasant to dwell in, sometimes also it is very rugged, and mingled with divers things, so that it is too often very unpleasant to inhabit

Hwilon we beoð hale, hwilon untrume
Sometimes we are hale, sometimes sick

nu bliðe, and eft on micelre unblisse
now joyful, and again in great affliction

forðy is þis líf, swa swa we ær cwædon, þære sǽ wiðmeten
therefore is this life, as we before said, compared to the sea

Þa se Hælend gesæt up on ðære dune, ða ahóf hé up his eagan, and geséh þæt ðær wæs micel mennisc toweard
When Jesus was sitting on the mountain, he lifted up his eyes, and saw that there was a great multitude coming

Ealle þa ðe him to cumað, þæt is ða ðe bugað to rihtum geleafan, þa gesihð se Hælend, and þam hé gemiltsað, and hyra mod onliht mid his gife, þæt hí magon him to cuman butan gedwylde, and ðam hé forgifð ðone gastlican fodan, þæt hí ne ateorian be wege
All those who come to him, that is those who incline to the right faith, Jesus sees, and on them he has pity, and enlightens their understanding with his grace, that they may come to him without error, and to these he gives ghostly food, that they may not faint by the way

Þaða he axode Philippum, hwanon hí mihton hláf ðam folce gebicgan, ða geswutelode hé Philippes nytennysse
When he asked Philip, whence they could buy bread for the people, he showed Philip's ignorance

Wel wiste Crist hwæt hé dón wolde, and he wiste þæt Philippus þæt nyste
Well Christ knew what he would do, and he knew that Philip knew not

Ða cwæð Andreas, þæt an cnapa þær bære fif berene hlafas and twegen fixas
Then said Andrew, that a lad there bare five barley loaves and two fishes

Þa cwæð se Hælend
Then said Jesus

Doð þæt þæt folc sitte
Make the people sit

and swa forðon swa we eow ær rehton
and so on, as we have before repeated it to you

Se Hælend geseh þæt hungrige folc, and hé hí mildheortlice fedde, ægðer ge þurh his gódnysse ge þurh his mihte
Jesus saw the hungry people, and he compassionately fed them, both by his goodness and by his might

Hwæt mihte seo gódnys ana, buton ðær wære miht mid þære gódnysse
What could his goodness alone have done, unless there had been might with that goodness

His discipuli woldon eac þæt folc fedan, ac hí næfdon mid hwam
His disciples would also have fed the people, but they had not wherewithal

Se Hælend hæfde þone gódan willan to ðam fostre, and þa mihte to ðære fremminge
Jesus had the good will to nourish them, and the power to execute it

Fela wundra worhte God, and dæghwamlice wyrcð
God hath wrought many miracles and daily works

ac ða wundra sind swiðe awácode on manna gesihðe, forðon ðe hí sind swiðe gewunelice
but those miracles are much weakened in the sight of men, because they are very usual

Mare wundor is þæt God Ælmihtig ælce dæg fét ealne middangeard, and gewissað þa gódan, þonne þæt wundor wære, þæt he þa gefylde fif ðusend manna mid fif hlafum: ac ðæs wundredon men, na forði þæt hit mare wundor wære, ac forði þæt hit wæs ungewunelic
A greater miracle it is that God Almighty every day feeds all the world, and directs the good, than that miracle was, that he filled five thousand men with five loaves: but men wondered at this, not because it was a greater miracle, but because it was unusual

Hwa sylð nu wæstm urum æcerum, and gemenigfylt þæt gerip of feawum cornum, buton se ðe ða gemænigfylde ða fif hlafas
Who now gives fruit to our fields, and multiplies the harvest from a few grains of corn, but he who multiplied the five loaves

Seo miht wæs ða on Cristes handum, and þa fif hlafas wæron swylce hit sæd wære, na on eorðan besawen, ac gemenigfyld fram ðam ðe eorðan geworhte
The might was there in Christ's hands, and the five loaves were, as it were, seed, not sown in the earth, but multiplied by him who created the earth

Þis wundor is swiðe micel, and deop on getacnungum
This miracle is very great, and deep in its significations

Oft gehwa gesihð fægre stafas awritene, þonne herað he ðone writere and þa stafas, and nat hwæt hi mænað
Often some one sees fair characters written, then praises he the writer and the characters, but knows not what they mean

Se ðe cann ðæra stafa gescead, he herað heora fægernysse, and ræd þa stafas, and understent hwæt hí gemænað
He who understands the art of writing praises their fairness, and reads the characters, and comprehends their meaning

On oðre wisan we sceawiað metinge, and on oðre wisan stafas
In one way we look at a picture, and in another at characters

Ne gæð na mare to metinge buton þæt þu hit geseo and herige: nis na genóh þæt þu stafas sceawige, buton ðu hí eac ræde, and þæt andgit understande
Nothing more is necessary for a picture than that you see and praise it: but it is not enough to look at characters without, at the same time, reading them, and understanding their signification

Swa is eac on ðam wundre þe God worhte mid þam fif hlafum: ne bið na genóh þæt we þæs tacnes wundrian, oþþe þurh þæt God herian, buton we eac þæt gastlice andgit understandon
So also it is with regard to the miracle which God wrought with the five loaves: it is not enough that we wonder at the miracle, or praise God on account of it, without also understanding its spiritual sense

Þa fif hlafas ðe se cnapa bær getacniað þa fif béc ðe Moyses se heretoga sette on ðære ealdan ǽ
The five loaves which the lad bare, betoken the five books which the leader Moses appointed in the old law

Se cnapa ðe hi bær, and heora ne onbyrigde, wæs þæt Iudeisce folc, ðe ða fif béc ræddon, and ne cuðe þæron nan gastlic andgit, ærðan ðe Crist com, and þa béc geopenode, and hyra gastlice andgit onwreah his leorning-cnihtum, and hi siððan eallum cristenum folce
The lad who bare them, and tasted not of them, was the Jewish people, who read the five books, and knew therein no spiritual signification, before Christ came, and opened the books, and disclosed their spiritual sense to his disciples, and they afterwards to all christian people

We ne magon nu ealle þa fif béc areccan, ac we secgað eow þæt God sylf hi dihte, and Moyses hí awrát, to steore and to lare ðam ealdan folce Israhel, and eac ús on gastlicum andgite
We cannot now enumerate to you all the five books, but we will tell you that God himself dictated them, and that Moses wrote them, for the guidance and instruction of the ancient people of Israel, and of us also in a spiritual sense

Þa béc wæron awritene be Criste, ac þæt gastlice andgit wæs þam folce digle, oð þæt Crist sylf com to mannum, and geopenede þæra boca digelnysse, æfter gastlicum andgite
These books were written concerning Christ, but the spiritual sense was hidden from the people, until Christ came himself to men, and opened the secrets of the books, according to the spiritual sense

Alii euangelistæ}} ferunt, quia panes et pisces Dominus discipulis distribuisset, discipuli autem ministrauerunt turbis
He brake the five loaves and gave to his disciples, and bade them bear them to the people

He tobrǽc ða fif hlafas and sealde his leorning-cnihtum, and het beran ðam folce
for he taught them the heavenly lore: and they went throughout all the world, and preached, as Christ himself had taught

forðon þe hé tæhte him ða gastlican láre: and hí ferdon geond ealne middangeard, and bodedon, swa swa him Crist sylf tæhte
When he had broken the loaves then were they multiplied, and grew in his hands

Mid þam ðe hé tobræc ða hlafas, þa wæron hí gemenigfylde, and weoxon him on handum
for the five books were spiritually devised, and wise doctors expounded them, and founded on those books many other books

forðon ðe ða fíf béc wurdon gastlice asmeade, and wise lareowas hí trahtnodon, and setton of ðam bocum manega oðre béc
and we with the doctrine of those books are daily spiritually fed

Þa hláfas wæron berene
The loaves were of barley

Bere is swiðe earfoðe to gearcigenne, and þeah-hwæðere fet ðone mann, þonne hé gearo bið
Barley is very difficult to prepare, and, nevertheless, feeds a man when it is prepared

Swa wæs seo ealde ǽ swiðe earfoðe and digle to understandenne
So was the old law very difficult and obscure to understand

ac ðeah-hwæðere, þonne we cumað to ðam smedman, þæt is to ðære getacnunge, þonne gereordað heo ure mod, and gestrángað mid þære diglan lare
but, nevertheless, when we come to the flour, that is to the signification, then it feeds and strengthens our mind with the hidden lore

Fif hlafas ðær wæron, and fif ðusend manna þær wæron gereordode
There were five loaves, and there were five thousand men fed

forðan ðe þæt Iudeisce folc wæs underðeodd Godes ǽ, ðe stód on fif bocum awriten
because the Jewish people was subject to God's law, which stood written in five books

Þaða Crist axode Philippum, and he his afandode, swa swa we ær ræddon, þa getacnode he mid þære acsunge þæs folces nytennysse, þe wæs under ðære ǽ, and ne cuðe þæt gastlice andgit, ðe on ðære ǽ bediglod wæs
When Christ asked Philip, and proved him, as we before read, by that asking he betokened the people's ignorance, who were under that law, and knew not the spiritual sense which was concealed in that law

Ða twegen fixas getácnodon sealm-sang and ðæra witegena cwydas
The two fishes betokened the Psalms and the sayings of the prophets

An ðæra gecydde and bodode Cristes to-cyme mid sealm-sange, and oðer mid witegunge
The one of these announced and proclaimed Christ's advent with psalm-singing, and the other with prophecy, as if they were meat to the five barley loaves, that is, to the five legal books

Nu sind þa twa gesetnyssa, þæt is sealm-sang and witegung, swylce hí syflinge wæron to ðam fíf berenum hlafum, þæt is, to ðam fíf ǽlicum bocum
The people, who were there fed, sat on the grass

Þæt folc, þe ðær gereordode, sǽt úp on ðam gærse
The grass betokened fleshly desire, as the prophet said

Þæt gærs getacnode flæsclice gewilnunge, swa swa se witega cwæð
Every flesh is grass, and the glory of the flesh is as the blossom of plants

Þær wæron getealde æt ðam gereorde fif ðusend wera
There were counted at that refection five thousand males

forðon þe ða menn, þe to ðam gastlican gereorde belimpað, sceolon beon werlice geworhte, swa swa se apostol cwæð
because those men who belong to the spiritual refection should be manfully made, as the apostle said

he cwæð
he said

Beoð wacole, and standað on geleafan, and onginnað werlice, and beoð gehyrte
Be watchful, and stand on faith, and undertake manfully, and be bold

Ðeah gif wifmann bið werlice geworht, and strang to Godes willan, heo bið þonne geteald to ðam werum þe æt Godes mysan sittað
Though if a woman be manly by nature, and strong to God's will, she will be counted among the men who sit at the table of God

Þusend getel bið fulfremed, and ne astihð nán getel ofer þæt
Thousand is a perfect number, and no number extends beyond it

Mid þam getele bið getácnod seo fulfremednys ðæra manna ðe gereordiað heora sawla mid Godes láre
With that number is betokened the perfection of those men who nourish their souls with God's precepts

Se Hælend het þa gegadrian þa láfe, þæt hí losian ne sceoldon
Jesus then bade the remainder to be gathered, that it might not be lost

and hí ða gefyldon twelf wilion mid þam bricum
and they filled twelve baskets with the fragments

Ða láfe ðæs gereordes, þæt sind ða deopnyssa ðære láre þe worold-men understandan ne magon, þa sceolon ða lareowas gegaderian, þæt hí ne losian, and healdan on heora fætelsum, þæt is, on heora heortan, and habban æfre gearo, to teonne forð þone wisdom and ða lare ægðer ge ðære ealdan ǽ ge ðære niwan
The remainder of the refection, that is the depth of the doctrine, which secular men may not understand, that should our teachers gather, that it may not be lost, and preserve in their scrips, that is, in their hearts, and have ever ready to draw forth the wisdom and doctrine both of the old law and of the new

Hí ða gegaderodon twelf wilian fulle mid þam bricum
They gathered then twelve baskets full of the fragments

Þæt twelffealde getel getacnode þa twelf apostolas
The twelvefold number betokened the twelve apostles

forðan þe hí underfengon þa digelnyssa þære láre, ðe þæt læwede folc undergitan ne mihte
because they received the mysteries of the doctrine, which the lay folk could not understand

Þæt folc, ða þe þæt wundor geseah, cwædon be Criste, þæt he wære soð wítega, ðe toweard wæs
The people, who saw that miracle, said of Christ, that he was the true prophet who was to come

Soð hí sædon, sumera ðinga: wítega hé wæs, forðan ðe hé wiste ealle towearde þing, and eac fela ðing wítegode, ðe beoð gefyllede butan twyn
In one sense they said the truth: he was a prophet, for he knew all future things, and also prophesied many things which will, without doubt, be fulfilled

He is witega, and he is ealra witegena witegung, forðan ðe ealle wítegan be him witegodon, and Crist gefylde heora ealra witegunga
He is a prophet, and he is the prophecy of all prophets, for all the prophets have prophesied of him, and Christ has fulfilled the prophecies of them all

Þæt folc geseah ða þæt wundor, and hí ðæs swiðe wundredon
The people saw the miracle, and they greatly wondered at it

Þæt wundor is awriten, and we hit gehyrdon
That miracle is recorded, and we have heard it

Þæt ðe on him heora eagan gedydon, þæt deð ure geleafa on ús
What their eyes did in them, that does our faith in us

Hí hit gesawon, and we his gelyfað þe hit ne gesawon
They saw it, and we believe it, who saw it not

and we sind forði beteran getealde, swa swa se Hælend be ús on oðre stowe cwæð
and we are therefore accounted the better, as Jesus, in another place, said of us

Eadige beoð þa þe me ne geseoð, and hi hwæðere gelyfað on me, and mine wundra mærsiað
Blessed are they who see me not, and, nevertheless, believe in me, and celebrate my miracles

Þæt folc cwæð ða be Criste, þæt he wære soð witega
The people said of Christ, that he was a true prophet

Nu cweðe we be Criste, þæt he is ðæs Lifigendan Godes Sunu, seðe wæs toweard to alysenne ealne middangeard fram deofles anwealde, and fram helle-wíte
Now we say of Christ, that he is Son of the Living God, who was to come to redeem the whole world from the power of the devil, and from hell-torment

Þæt folc ne cuðe ðæra goda, þæt hí cwædon, þæt he God wære, ac sædon, þæt he witega wære
The people knew not of those benefits, that they might have said that he was God, but they said that he was a prophet

We cweðað nu, mid fullum geleafan, þæt Crist is soð witega, and ealra witegena Witega, and þæt he is soðlice ðæs Ælmihtigan Godes Sunu, ealswa mihtig swa his Fæder, mid ðam hé leofað and rixað on annysse ðæs Halgan Gastes, á butan ende on ecnysse
We say now, with full belief, that Christ is a true prophet, and Prophet of all prophets, and that he is truly Son of the Almighty God, as mighty as his Father, with whom he liveth and reigneth in unity of the Holy Ghost, ever without end to eternity

Amen
Amen

Ure se Ælmihtiga Scyppend, seðe ealle gesceafta, buton ælcon antimbre, þurh his wisdom gesceop, and þurh his willan gelíffæste, hé gesceop mancynn to ði þæt hí sceoldon mid gehyrsumnysse and eadmodnysse ða heofenlican geðincðe geearnigan, þe se deofol mid ofermettum forwyrhte
Our Almighty Creator, who created all creatures, without any matter through his wisdom, and through his will animated them, he created mankind that they might with obedience and humility merit those heavenly honours which the devil through pride had forfeited

Þa wearð eac se mann mid deofles lotwrencum bepæht, swa þæt he tobræc his Scyppendes bebod, and wearð deofle betæht, and eal his ofspring into helle-wite
Then was man deceived by the devil's wiles, so that he brake the command of his Creator, and was, with all his offspring, delivered to the devil into hell-torment

Ða ðeah-hwæðere ofðuhte ðam Ælmihtigum Gode ealles mancynnes yrmða, and smeade hu he mihte his hand-geweorc of deofles anwealde alysan
Then, nevertheless, the Almighty God was grieved for the miseries of all mankind, and he meditated how he might redeem his handiwork from the power of the devil

forði him ofhreow þæs mannes, forðon ðe hé wæs bepæht mid þæs deofles searo-cræftum
for he took pity on man, because he had been deceived by the wiles of the devil

Ac him ne ofhreow na ðæs deofles hryre
But he had no pity for the devil's fall, because he had not been misled by any instigation, but had himself devised the presumption through which he fell

forðan ðe hé næs þurh nane tihtinge forlæred, ac hé sylf asmeade ða up-ahefednysse þe he ðurh ahreas
and he therefore, to all eternity, dwelleth in perdition, a bloodthirsty devil

Þa fram frymðe mancynnes cydde se Ælmihtiga God, hwilon ðurh getacnunga, hwilon ðurh witegunga, þæt he wolde mancynn ahreddan þurh ðone þe he ealle gesceafta mid geworhte, ðurh his agen Bearn
Then from the beginning of mankind the Almighty God made known, sometimes by signs, sometimes by prophecies, that he would redeem mankind through him with whom he had made all creatures, through his own Son

Nu wæron ða witegunga swiðe menigfealdlice gesette on halgum gewritum, ærðam ðe se Godes Sunu menniscnysse underfenge
Now there were very many prophecies recorded in the holy writings, before the Son of God assumed human nature

Sume wæron eac be ðære eadigan Marian gewitegode
Some were prophesied of the blessed Mary

An ðæra witegunga is Isaiae, se awrát betwux his witegungum, þus cweðende
One of these prophecies is of Isaiah, who wrote, among his prophecies, thus saying

Efne sceal mæden geeacnian on hire innoðe, and acennan Sunu, and his nama bið gecíged Emmanuhel
Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bring forth a son, and his name shall be called Emanuel

þæt is gereht on urum geðeode, 'God is mid us
that is interpreted in our tongue, God is with us

' Eft Ezechihel se witega geseah on his witegunge án belocen geat on Godes huse, and him cwæð to sum engel
Also Ezechiel the prophet saw in his prophecy a closed gate in the house of God, and an angel said to him

Þis geat ne bið nanum menn geopenod, ac se Hlaford ana færð inn þurh þæt geat, and eft út færð, and hit bið belocen on ecnysse
This gate shall be opened to no man, for the Lord only will go in by that gate, and again go out, and it shall be shut for ever

Þæt beclysede geat on Godes huse getacnode þone halgan mæigðhad þære eadigan Marian
That closed gate in the house of God betokened the holy maidenhood of the blessed Mary

Se Hlaford, ealra hlaforda Hlaford, þæt is Crist, becom on hire innoð, and ðurh hí on menniscnysse wearð acenned, and þæt geat bið belocen on ecnysse
The Lord, of all lords Lord, that is Christ, entered her womb, and through her was brought forth in human nature, and that gate is shut for ever

þæt is, þæt Maria wæs mæden ær ðære cenninge, and mæden on ðære cenninge, and mæden æfter ðære cenninge
that is, Mary was a virgin before the birth, and a virgin at the birth, and a virgin after the birth

Þa witegunga be Cristes acennednysse and be ðære eadigan Marian mægðhade sindon swiðe menigfealdlice on ðære ealdan ǽ gesette, and se ðe hí asmeagan wile, þær he hí afint mid micelre genihtsumnysse
The prophecies of the birth of Christ and the virginity of the blessed Mary are recorded very frequently in the old law, and he who searches will there find them in great abundance

Eac se apostol Paulus cwæð
Also the apostle Paul said

Þaþa ðæra tída gefyllednys com, ða sende God Fæder his Sunu to mancynnes alysednysse
When the fullness of times came, then God sent his Son for the redemption of mankind

Seo wurðfulle sánd wearð on ðisum dæge gefylled, swa swa Cristes boc us gewissað, þus cweðende
The glorious mission was on this day fulfilled, as the book of Christ shows us, thus saying

Godes heah-engel, Gabrihel, wæs asend fram Gode to ðære Galileiscan byrig Nazareth, to ðam mædene þe wæs Maria gehaten, and heo asprang of Dauides cynne, þæs maran cyninges, and heo wæs beweddod þam rihtwisan Iosepe
The archangel of God, Gabriel, was sent from God to the Galilean city Nazareth, to the maiden who was called Mary, and she sprang from the race of David, the great king, and she was wedded to the righteous Joseph

et reliqua
etc

Ure alysednysse anginn we gehyrdon on ðisre dægþerlican rædinge, þurh ða we awurpon þa derigendlican ealdnysse, and we sind getealde betwux Godes bearnum, þurh Cristes flæsclicnysse
The beginning of our redemption we heard in this daily lecture, through which we have cast off pernicious age, and are accounted among the children of God, through Christ's incarnation

Swiðe þæslic anginn menniscre alysednysse wæs þæt þa se engel wearð asend fram Gode to ðam mædene, to cyðenne Godes acennednysse þurh hí
A very fitting beginning of human redemption was that when the angel was sent from God to the virgin, to announce the birth of God through her

forðan ðe se forma intinga mennisces forwyrdes wæs, þaþa se deofol asende oðerne deofol, on næddran anlicnysse, to ðam frumsceapenan wífe Euan, hí to beswicenne
because the first cause of man's perdition was when the devil sent another devil, in likeness of a serpent, to the first-created woman Eve, for the purpose of deceiving her

Us becom ða deað and forwyrd þurh wíf, and us becom eft lif and hredding þurh wimman
Death and perdition befell us through a woman, and afterwards life and salvation came to us through a woman

Se heah-engel, þe cydde þæs Hælendes acennednysse, wæs gehaten Gabrihel, þæt is gereht, 'Godes strengð,' þone he bodode toweardne, þe se sealm-sceop mid þisum wordum herede
The archangel, who announced the birth of Christ, was called Gabriel, which is interpreted, God's strength, which he announced was to come, and which the psalmist praised in these words

Drihten is strang and mihtig on gefeohte
The Lord is strong and mighty in battle

On ðam gefeohte, butan tweon, þe se Hælend deofol oferwann, and middangeard him ætbræd
In the battle, without doubt, in which Jesus overcame the devil, and took from him the world

Maria wæs beweddod Iosepe ðam rihtwisan
Mary was wedded to the righteous Joseph

Hwí wolde God beon acenned of beweddodan mædene
Why would God be born of a wedded virgin

For micclum gesceade, and eac for neode
For a great reason, and also of necessity

Þæt Iudeisce folc heold Godes ǽ on þam timan: seo ǽ tæhte, þæt man sceolde ælcne wimman þe cild hæfde butan rihtre æwe stænan
The Jewish people, at that time, held God's law: the old law directed, that every woman who had a child out of lawful wedlock should be stoned

Nu ðonne, gif Maria unbeweddod wære, and cild hæfde, þonne wolde þæt Iudeisce folc, æfter Godes ǽ, mid stanum hí oftorfian
Now, therefore, if Mary had been unmarried, and had a child, the Jewish people, according to God's law, would have stoned her with stones

Ða wæs heo, ðurh Godes foresceawunge, þam rihtwisan were beweddod, and gehwá wende þæt he ðæs cildes fæder wære, ac he næs
Therefore was she, by the providence of God, married to that righteous man, and everyone imagined that he was the child's father, but he was not

Ac ðaða Ioseph undergeat þæt Maria mid cilde wæs, þa wearð he dreorig, and nolde hire genealæcan, ac ðohte þæt he wolde hí diglice forlætan
But when Joseph understood that Mary was with child, he was sad, and would not approach her, but thought that he would privily dismiss her

Þaða Ioseph þis smeade, þa com him to Godes engel, and bebead him, þæt sceolde habban gymene ægðer ge ðære meder ge þæs cildes, and cwæð, þæt þæt cild nære of nanum men gestryned, ac wære of þam Halgan Gaste
While Joseph was meditating this God's angel came to him, and commanded him, that he should have care both of the mother and of the child, and said, that the child was of no man begotten, but was of the Holy Ghost

Nis na hwæðere se Halga Gast Cristes Fæder, ac hé is genemned to ðære fremminge Cristes menniscnysse
Yet is the Holy Ghost not the father of Christ, but he is named to the accomplishment of Christ's humanity

forðan ðe he is Willa and Lufu þæs Fæder and þæs Suna
for he is the Will and Love of the Father and of the Son

Nu wearð seo menniscnys þurh þone micclan Willan gefremmed, and is ðeah-hwæðere heora Ðreora weorc untodæledlic
Now the humanity was effected through the Great Will, and is, nevertheless, the indivisible work of the Three

Hi sind þry on hádum, Fæder, and Sunu, and Halig Gast, and an God untodæledlic on anre godcundnysse
They are three in persons, Father, and Son, and Holy Ghost, and one God indivisible, in one Godhead

Ioseph ða, swa swa him se engel bebead, hæfde gymene ægðer ge Marian ge ðæs cildes, and wæs hyre gewita þæt heo mæden wæs, and wæs Cristes fostor-fæder, and mid his fultume and frofre on gehwilcum ðingum him ðenode on ðære menniscnysse
Joseph then, as the angel had commanded him, had care both of Mary and of the child, and was her witness that she was a virgin

Se engel grette Marian, and cwæð, þæt heo wære mid Godes gife afylled, and þæt hyre wæs God mid, and heo wæs gebletsod betwux wifum
The angel greeted Mary, and said, that she was filled with God's grace, and that God was with her, and she was blessed among women

Soðlice heo wæs mid Godes gife afylled, forðon ðe hire wæs getiðod þæt heo ðone abǽr þe astealde ealle gifa and ealle soðfæstnyssa
Verily she was filled with God's grace, for it was permitted her to bear him who instituted all grace and all truth

God wæs mid hire, forðan ðe he wæs on hire innoðe belocen, seðe belicð ealne middangeard on his anre handa
God was with her, for he was shut in her womb who compasses the whole earth with one hand

And heo wæs gebletsod betwux wifum, forðan ðe heo, butan wiflicre bysnunge, mid wlite hyre mægðhádes, wæs modor þæs Ælmihtigan Godes
And she was blessed among women, for she, without female example, with the beauty of maidenhood, was mother of the Almighty God

Se engel gehyrte hí mid his wordum, and cwæð hire to
The angel encouraged her with his words, and said to her

Efne ðu scealt geeacnian on ðinum innoðe, and þu acenst sunu
Behold thou shalt conceive, and thou shalt bear a Son

Oncnawað nu, þurh þas word, soðne mannan acennedne of mædenlicum lichaman
Acknowledge now, through these words, a true man, born of a maiden body

His nama wæs Hiesus, þæt is Hælend, forðan ðe hé gehælð ealle ða þe on hine rihtlice gelyfað
His name was Jesus, that is Saviour, for he shall save all those who rightly believe in him

Þes bið mǽre, and he bið gecíged Sunu þæs Hexstan
He shall be great, and he shall be called the Son of the Highest

Gelyfað nu, þurh ðas wórd, þæt he is soð God of soðum Gode, and efen-ece his Fæder, of ðam he wæs æfre acenned butan anginne
Believe now, through these words, that he is true God of true God, and co-eternal with his Father, of whom he was ever begotten without beginning

Crist heold Dauides cynesetl, na lichamlice ac gastlice
Christ held David's throne, not bodily but spiritually, for he is king of all kings, and ruleth over his chosen people, both over the people of Israel and over all other nations which abide in the right faith

forðan ðe he is ealra cyninga Cyning, and rixað ofer his gecorenan menn, ægðer ge ofer Israhela folc ge ofer ealle oðre leodscipas, ða ðe on rihtum geleafan wuniað
and Christ will bring them all to his eternal kingdom

and Crist hí ealle gebrincð to his ecan rice
Israel is interpreted, Seeing God, and Jacob is interpreted, Withering

Israhel is gecweden, 'God geseonde,' and Iacob is gecweden, 'Forscrencend
Now those men who see God in their mind, through faith, and those who wither up sins, they belong to God's kingdom, which shall never fail

Þa cwæð Maria to ðam engle
Then said Mary to the angel

Hú mæg þæt beon þæt ic cild hæbbe, forðan ðe ic nanes weres ne bruce
How may that be that I have a child, for I have known no man

Ic geteohode min lif on mægðhade to geendigenne: hu mæg hit ðonne gewurðan þæt ic, butan weres gemanan, cennan scyle
I had resolved to end my life in maidenhood: how can it then be that I, without connexion with man, shall bring forth

Þa andwyrde se engel ðam mædene
Then answered the angel to the virgin

Se Halga Gast cymð ufen on ðe, and miht ðæs Hyhstan ofersceadewað ðe
The Holy Ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee

Þurh ðæs Halgan Gastes fremminge, swa swa we ær cwædon, wearð Crist acenned on ðære menniscnysse
Through the efficacy of the Holy Ghost, as we before said, Christ was born in human nature

and Maria his modor wæs ofersceadewed ðurh mihte þæs Halgan Gastes
and Mary his mother was overshadowed by the power of the Holy Ghost

Hu wæs heo ofersceadewod
How was she overshadowed

Heo wæs swa ofersceadewod þæt heo wæs geclænsod and gescyld wið ealle leahtras, þurh mihte ðæs Halgan Gastes, and mid heofenlicum gifum gefylled and gehalgod
She was so overshadowed that she was purified from, and shielded against all sins, by the power of the Holy Ghost, and with heavenly grace filled and hallowed

Se engel cwæð
The angel said

Þæt Halige, þe of ðe bið acenned, bið geciged Godes Sunu
The holy thing that shall be born of thee shall be called the Son of God

Witodlice ealle menn beoð, swa swa se witega cwæð, mid unrihtwisnysse geeacnode, and mid synnum acennede, ac ure Hælend ana wæs geeacnod butan unrihtwisnysse, and butan synnum acenned
Verily all men are, as the prophet said, conceived in iniquity and born in sins, but our Saviour alone was conceived without iniquity, and born without sins

and he wæs halig þærrihte swa hraðe swa hé mann wæs, and fulfremed God, þæs Ælmihtigan Godes Sunu, on anum hade mann and God
and he was holy as soon as he became man, and perfect God, the Son of the Almighty God, in one person man and God

Ða cwæð Maria to ðam engle
Then said Mary to the angel

Ic eom Godes ðinen
I am God's handmaid

getimige me æfter ðinum worde
let it betide me according to thy word

Micel eadmodnys wunode on hyre mode, þaþa heo ðus cleopode
Great humility dwelt in her mind, when she thus cried

Ne cwæð heo na, Ic eom Godes modor, oððe, Ic eom cwen ealles middangeardes, ac cwæð
She said not, I am the mother of God, or, I am queen of the whole world, but said

Ic eom Godes þinen
I am God's handmaid

swa swa us mynegað þæt halige gewrit, þus cweðende
as the holy writ admonishes us, thus saying

Þonne ðu mære sy, geeadmed þe sylfne on eallum ðingum, and ðu gemetst gife and lean mid Gode
When thou art great, humble thyself in all things, and thou shalt find grace and reward with God

Heo cwæð to ðam engle
She said to the angel

Getimige me æfter ðinum worde
Let it betide me according to thy word

þæt is, Gewurðe hit swa ðu segst, þæt ðæs Ælmihtigan Godes Sunu becume on minne innoð, and mennisce edwiste of me genime, and to alysednysse middangeardes forðstæppe of mé, swa swa brydguma of his brydbedde
that is, Be it as thou sayst, that the Son of the Almighty God enter my womb, and receive human substance from me, and proceed from me, for the redemption of the world, as a bridegroom from his bride-bed

Þus becom ure Hælend on Marian innoð on þissum dæge, ðe is gehaten Annuntiatio Sanctae Mariae, þæt is, Marian bodung-dæg gecweden
Thus did our Saviour enter the womb of Mary on this day, which is called Annunciatio Sanctæ Mariæ, which is interpreted, The Annunciation-day of Mary

on þam dæge bodode se heah-engel Gabrihel ðam clænum mædene Godes to-cyme to mannum ðurh hí, and heo gelyfde þæs engles bodunge, and swa mid geleafan onfeng God on hyre innoð, and hine bær oð middewintres mæsse-dæg, and hine ða acende mid soðre menniscnysse, seðe æfre wæs wunigende on godcundnysse mid his Fæder, and mid þam Halgan Gaste, hi ðry an God untodæledlic
on which day the archangel Gabriel announced to the pure virgin the advent of God to men through her, and she believed the angel's announcement, and so with faith received God into her womb, and bare him until midwinter's mass-day, and then brought him forth in true human nature, who was ever dwelling in divine nature with his Father and the Holy Ghost, those three one God indivisible

Nu seigð se godspellere, þæt Maria ferde, æfter þæs engles bodunge, to hire magan Elisabeth, seo wæs Zacharian wif
Now saith the evangelist, that Mary, after the annunciation of the angel, went to her cousin Elizabeth, who was the wife of Zacharias

Hí butu wæron rihtwise, and heoldon Godes beboda untællice
They were both righteous, and held God's commandments blamelessly

Ða wæron hí butan cilde, oðþæt hí wæron forwerede menn
They were both childless, till they were worn-out persons

Ða com se ylca engel Gabrihel to Zacharian syx monðum ærðan ðe hé come to Marian, and cydde þæt he sceolde be his ealdan wife sunu habban, Iohannem ðone Fulluhtere
But the same angel Gabriel came to Zacharias six months before he came to Mary, and announced that he should have a son by his aged wife, John the Baptist

Þa wearð he ungeleafful þæs engles bodungum
But he believed not the annunciation of the angel

Se engel ða him cwæð to
The angel then said to him

Nu ðu nylt gelyfan minum wordum, beo ðu dumb oðþæt þæt cild beo acenned
Since thou wilt not believe my words, be thou dumb till the child shall be born

And he ða adumbode on eallum ðam fyrste, for his ungeleaffulnysse
And he was dumb during all that time for his disbelief

Nu com ða seo eadige Maria to his huse, and grette his wíf, hyre magan, Elisabeth
Now came the blessed Mary to his house, and greeted his wife Elizabeth, her cousin

Ða mid þam þe þæt wíf gehyrde þæs mædenes gretinge, ða blissode þæt cild Iohannes on his modor innoðe, and seo moder wearð afylled mid þam Halgan Gaste, and heo clypode to Marian mid micelre stemne, and cwæð, Þu eart gebletsod betwux wifum, and gebletsod is se wæstm þines innoðes
When the woman heard the virgin's greeting, the child John rejoiced in his mother's womb, and the mother was filled with the Holy Ghost, and she cried to Mary with a loud voice, and said, Thou art blessed among women, and blessed is the fruit of thy womb

Hu getimode me þæt mines Drihtnes moder wolde cuman to me
How hath it befallen me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me

Efne mid þam þe seo stefn ðinre gretinge swegde on mínum earum, ða blissode min cild on minum innoðe, and hoppode ongean his Drihten, þe þu berst on ðinum innoðe
Lo, when the voice of thy greeting sounded in mine ears, my child rejoiced in my womb, and leaped towards his Lord, whom thou bearest in thy womb

Þæt cild ne mihte na ða-gyt mid wordum his Hælend gegretan, ac he gegrette hine mid blissigendum mode
The child could not yet with words greet his Lord, but he greeted him with a rejoicing mind

Blessed art thou, Mary, for thou hast believed the words that were announced to thee from God, and it shall be accomplished so as it hath been declared to thee

Then forthwith Mary sang the hymn which we sing in God's church at every evensong

Magnificat anima mea Dominum
Magnificat anima mea Dominum

That is

It will be tedious for us to expound all this hymn, but we will shortly run over its most obscure words

God awearp ða rican of setle
these are the proud, who lift themselves above their degree

swa swa Crist sylf cwæð on his godspelle
Everyone who exalteth himself shall be humbled

Ælc ðæra þe hine onhefð, he sceal beon geeadmet

Blessed are they who are hungry and desirous of righteousness, for they shall be filled with righteousness

He hath sent the rich empty away

Those are the rich, who with pride love earthly riches more than heavenly

Many rich men thrive to God, those who do as it is written

The rich man's wealth is his soul's redemption

His wealth is his soul's redemption, if he with those transitory treasures buy for himself eternal life, and heavenly wealth with God

If he neglect this, and place his hope in earthly wealth, then will God send him away void and empty, from everlasting good

By that name are betokened all those who obey God with true humility, whom he receives into his company

Swa swa hé spræc to urum fæderum, Abrahame and his ofspringe on worulda
As he spake to our fathers, Abraham and his offspring for ever

God promised the patriarch Abraham, that in his race all mankind should be blessed

From the race of Abraham sprang the blessed Mary, and from Mary came Christ, according to his human nature, and through Christ shall all the faithful be blessed

Ne synd we na Abrahames cynnes flæsclice, ac gastlice, swa swa se apostol Paulus cwæð
We are not of Abraham's race after the flesh, but spiritually, as the apostle Paul said

Verily if ye are christians, then are ye of Abraham's offspring, and heirs according to the promise

Þæt æftemyste word is ðises lofsanges
The last words of this hymn are

On worulda
For ever

forðan ðe ure behát, þe us God behet, ðurhwunað á on worulda woruld butan ende
because our promise, which God hath promised to us, continueth for ever and ever without end

Uton biddan nu þæt eadige and þæt gesælige mæden Marían, þæt heo us geðingige to hyre agenum Suna and to hire Scyppende, Hælende Criste, seðe gewylt ealra ðinga mid Fæder and mid þam Halgum Gaste, á on ecnysse
Let us now pray the blessed and happy Virgin Mary, that she intercede for us to her own Son and Creator, Jesus Christ, who governs all things with the Father and the Holy Ghost, ever to eternity

Christ's passion has just been read before us, but we will first say to you how he came to the city of Jerusalem, and approached his own death, and would not by flight avoid his passion

Jesus went to the city of Jerusalem, and when he approached the mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples, thus saying, Go to the town which is before you, and ye shall straightways find an ass tied and its foal also: untie them, and lead them to me
