etc

Þam folce wearð cuð þæt se Hælend arærde lytle ær Lazarum of deaðe, seðe læg stincende feower niht on byrgene: þa comon þa togeanes Criste þe geleaffulle wæron, mid þam wurðmynte, swa we ær cwædon
It was known to the people that Christ a little before had raised Lazarus from death, who had lain stinking four nights in the grave: then those, who were believing, came to meet Christ with the honours which we have already mentioned

Comon eac sume ða ungeleaffullan, mid nanum wurðmynte, ac mid micclum graman, swa swa Iohannes se Godspellere cwæð, Þæt
Some also who believed not came, with no honours, but with great wrath, as John the Evangelist said, That

ða heafod-menn þæs folces smeadon betwux him þæt hi woldon ofslean þone Lazarum, þe Crist of deaðe awrehte
the chief priests of the people consulted among themselves how they should slay Lazarus, whom Christ had raised from the dead

forðan ðe manega ðæs folces menn gelyfdon on þone Hælend, þurh ðæs deadan mannes ærist
because many men of the people believed in Jesus, by reason of the dead man's rising

We wyllað nu fon on þone traht þissere rædinge
We will now proceed to the exposition of this text

Þa twegen leorning-cnihtas þe Crist sende æfter þam assan, hí getacnodon þa láreowas þe God sende mancynne to lærenne
The two disciples whom Christ sent after the ass betokened the teachers whom God sends to instruct mankind

Twegen hí wæron, for ðære getacnunge þe láreow habban sceal
They were two, because of the character which a teacher should have

He sceal habban lare, þæt he mage Godes folc mid wisdome læran to rihtum geleafan, and he sceal mid godum weorcum ðam folce wel bysnian, and swa mid þam twam ðingum, þæt is mid lare and godre bysnunge þæt læwede folc gebige symle to Godes willan
He should have learning, that he may with wisdom instruct God's people in true belief, and he should, by good works, give good example to the people, and so, with those two things, that is, with learning and good example, ever incline the lay folk to God's will

Se getígeda assa and his fola getacniað twa folc, þæt is Iudeisc and hæðen: Ic cweðe, hæðen, forði þe eal mennisc wæs ða-gyt wunigende on hæðenscipe, buton þam anum Iudeiscan folce, þe heold þa ealdan ǽ on ðam timan
The tied ass and its foal betoken two people, that is, the Jewish and the heathen: I say, heathen, because all mankind was yet continuing in heathenism, save only the Jews, who observed the old law at that time

Hí wæron getígede, forðan ðe eal mancyn wæs mid synnum bebunden, swa swa se witega cwæð
They were tied

Anra gehwilc manna is gewriðen mid rapum his synna
for all mankind was bound with sins, as the prophet said

Hú untigdon hi ðone assan and þone folan
Then God sent his apostles and their successors to bound mankind, and bade untie, and lead them to him

Hí bodedon ðam folce rihtne geleafan and Godes beboda, and eac mid micclum wundrum heora bodunge getrymdon
How untied they the ass and the foal

Þa abeah þæt folc fram deofles þeowdome to Cristes biggencum, and wæron alysede fram eallum synnum þurh þæt halige fulluht, and to Criste gelædde
They preached to the people right belief and God's commandments, and also by many miracles confirmed their preaching

Assa is stunt nyten, and unclæne, and toforan oðrum nytenum ungesceadwis, and byrðen-strang
An ass is a foolish beast, and unclean, and stupid, compared with other beasts, and strong for burthens

Swa wæron men, ær Cristes to-cyme, stunte and unclæne, ðaða hí ðeowedon deofolgyldum and mislicum leahtrum, and bugon to þam anlicnyssum þe hi sylfe worhton, and him cwædon to
So were men, before Christ's advent, foolish and unclean, while they ministered to idols, and divers sins, and bowed to the images, which they themselves had wrought, and said to them

Þu eart min God
Thou art my God

And swa hwilce byrðene swa him deofol on-besette, þa hí bæron
And whatsoever burthen the devil set on them they bare

Ac ðaða Crist com to mancynne, þa awende he ure stuntnysse to geráde, and ure unclænnysse to clænum ðeawum
But when Christ came to mankind, then turned he our foolishness to reason, and our uncleanness to pure morals

Se getemeda assa hæfde getacnunge þæs Iudeiscan folces, þe wæs getemed under þære ealdan ǽ
The tamed ass betokened the Jewish people, who were tamed under the old law

Se wilda fola hæfde getacnunge ealles oðres folces, þe wæs þa-gyt hæðen and ungetemed
The wild foal betokened all other people, who were heathen and untamed

ac hí wurdon getemede and geleaffulle þaþa Crist sende his leorning-cnihtas geond ealne middangeard, þus cweðende
but they became tamed and believing when Christ sent his disciples over the whole earth, thus saying

Farað geond ealne middangeard, and lærað ealle ðeoda, and fulliað hí on naman þæs Fæder, and þæs Suna, and þæs Halgan Gastes
Go over all the earth, and teach all nations, and baptize them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost

and beodað þæt hi healdon ealle ða beboda þe ic eow tæhte
and command that they hold all the precepts which I have taught you

Þæra assena hlaford axode, hwí hí untigdon his assan
The master of the asses asked, why they untied his asses

Swa eac ða heafod-men gehwilces leodscipes woldon þwyrlice wiðcweðan Godes bodunge
In like manner the chief men of every people would perversely oppose the preaching of God

Ac ðaða hí gesawon þæt þa bydelas gehældon, þurh Godes mihte, healte and blinde, and dumbum spræce forgeafon, and eac ða deadan to life arærdon, þa ne mihton hí wiðstandan þam wundrum, ac bugon ealle endemes to Gode
But when they saw that the preachers, through God's might, healed the halt and the blind, and gave speech to the dumb, and also raised the dead to life, then could they not withstand those miracles, but all at last inclined to God

Cristes leorning-cnihtas cwædon
Christ's disciples said

Se Hlaford behófað þæra assena, and sent hi eft ongean
The Lord hath need of the asses, and sends for them

Ne cwædon hí na Ure Hlaford, ne Ðin Hlaford, ac forðrihte, Hlaford
They did not say Our Lord, nor Thy Lord, but simply, The Lord

forðon ðe Crist is ealra hlaforda Hlaford, ægðer ge manna ge ealra gesceafta
for Christ is Lord of all lords, both of men and of all creatures

Hi cwædon
They said

He sent hí eft ongean
He sends for them

We sind gemanode and gelaðode to Godes rice, ac we ne sind na genedde
We are exhorted and invited to God's kingdom, but we are not forced

Þonne we sind gelaðode, þonne sind we untigede
When we are invited, then are we untied

and ðonne we beoð forlætene to urum agenum cyre, þonne bið hit swilce we beon ongean asende
and when we are left to our own election, then is it as though we are sent for

Godes myldheortnys is þæt we untigede syndon
It is God's mercy that we are untied

ac gif we rihtlice lybbað, þæt bið ægðer ge Godes gifu ge eac ure agen geornfulnyss
but if we live rightly, that will be both God's grace and our own zeal

We sceolon symle biddan Drihtnes fultum, forðan ðe ure agen cyre næfð nænne forðgang, buton he beo gefyrðrod þurh þone Ælmihtigan
We should constantly pray for the Lord's support

Ne het Crist him to lædan modigne stedan mid gyldenum gerædum gefreatewodne, ac þone wacan assan he geceas him to byrðre
Christ did not command them to lead to him a proud steed adorned with golden trappings, but the mean ass he chose to bear him

forðon þe he tæhte symle eadmodnysse, and ðurh hine sylfne þa bysne sealde, and ðus cwæð
for he ever taught humility, and in himself gave the example, and thus said

Leorniað æt me, þæt ic eom liðe and swiðe eadmod, and ge gemetað reste eowrum sawlum
Learn of me, who am meek and very humble, and ye shall find rest for your souls

Þis wæs gewitegod be Criste, and ealle ða ðing þe he dyde, ærðan þe he to men geboren wære
This was prophesied of Christ, and all the things which he did before he was born as man

Sión is an dún, and heo is gecweden, 'Sceawung-stow
Sion is a hill, and it is interpreted, A place of contemplation

' and Hierusalem, 'Sibbe gesihð
and Jerusalem, Sight of peace

' Siónes dohtor is seo gelaðung geleaffulra manna, þe belimpð to ðære heofenlican Hierusalem, on þære is symle sibbe gesihð, butan ælcere sace, to ðære us gebrincð se Hælend, gif we him gelæstað
The daughter of Sion is the congregation of believing men, who belong to the heavenly Jerusalem, in which is ever a sight of peace, without any strife, to which Jesus will bring us, if we follow him

Cristes leorning-cnihtas ledon hyra reaf uppan þan assan, forðan þe hé nolde on nacedum assan ridan
Christ's disciples laid their garments upon the ass, because he would not ride on a naked ass

Reaf getacniað rihtwisnysse weorc, swa swa se wítega cwæð
Garments betoken works of righteousness, as the prophet said

Drihten, þine sacerdas sind ymbscrydde mid rihtwisnysse
Lord, thy priests are clothed with righteousness

Se nacoda assa bið mid reafum gesadelod, ðonne se idela man bið mid wisra láreowa mynegungum and gebisnungum to Godes handa gefrætwod
The naked ass is saddled with garments, when the simple man is equipped to the hand of God with the exhortations and examples of wise instructors

and he ðonne byrð Crist, swa swa se apostol cwæð
and he then bears Christ, as the apostle said

Ge sind gebohte mid micclum wurðe
Ye are bought with great price

wuldriað forði, and berað God on eowrum lichaman
glorify therefore, and bear God on your bodies

God we berað on urum lichaman, forðan ðe we beoð tempel and fætels þæs Halgan Gastes, gif we us wið fule leahtras gescyldað: be ðam cwæð se ylca apostol swiðe egeslice
We bear God on our bodies, because we are a temple and shrine of the Holy Ghost, if we guard ourselves against foul sins: of which the same apostle said very awfully

Se ðe gewemð Godes tempel, God hine fordeð
He who defiles the temple of God, God will fordo him

Se ðe ne bið Godes tempel, he bið deofles tempel, and byrð swiðe swære byrðene on his bæce
He who is not a temple of God is a temple of the devil, and bears a very heavy burthen on his back

We wyllað secgan eow sum bigspell
We will say to you a parable

Ne mæg nan man hine sylfne to cynge gedon, ac þæt folc hæfð cyre to ceosenne þone to cyninge þe him sylfum licað: ac siððan he to cyninge gehalgod bið, þonne hæfð hé anweald ofer þæt folc, and hí ne magon his geoc of heora swuran asceacan
No man may make himself a king, for the people have the option to choose him for king who is agreeable to them: but after that he has been hallowed as king, he has power over the people, and they may not shake his yoke from their necks

Swa eac gehwilc man hæfð agenne cyre, ærðam þe hé syngige, hweðer hé wille filian deofles willan, oððe wiðsacan
In like manner every man has his own choice, before he sins, whether he will follow the devil's will, or withstand it

Þonne gif hé mid deofles weorcum hine sylfne bebint, ðonne ne mæg he mid his agenre mihte hine unbindan, buton se Ælmihtiga God mid strangre handa his mildheortnysse hine unbinde
Then if he bind himself with the works of the devil, he cannot by his own power unbind himself, unless the Almighty God unbind him with the strong hand of his mercy

Agenes willan and agenre gymeleaste he bið gebunden, ac þurh Godes mildheortnysse he bið unbunden, gif he ða alysednysse eft æt Gode geearnað
Of his own will and his own heedlessness he is bound, but through God's mercy he will be unbound, if he afterwards merit his liberation of God

Þæt folc ðe heora reaf wurpon under þæs assan fét, þæt sind þa martyras, þe for Cristes geleafan sealdon heora agenne lichaman to tintregum
The people who cast their garments under the feet of the ass, are the martyrs, who for Christ's faith gave their own bodies to torments

Sume hi wæron on fyre forbærnde, sume on sǽ adrencte, and mid mislicum pinungum acwealde
Some were burnt in fire, some drowned in the sea, and slain with divers tortures

and sealdon us bysne þæt we ne sceolon, for nanum ehtnyssum oððe earfoðnyssum, urne geleafan forlætan, and fram Criste bugan, ðe má ðe hí dydon
and gave us an example, that we should not, for any persecutions or hardships, forsake our faith, and incline from Christ, any more than they did

Menig man is cristen geteald on sibbe, þe wolde swiðe hraðe wiðsacan Criste, gif him man bude þæt man bead þam martyrum: ac his cristendom nis na herigendlic
Many a man is accounted a christian in peace, who would very quickly deny Christ, if he were sentenced to that to which the martyrs were sentenced: but his christianity is not praiseworthy

Ac ðæs mannes cristendom is herigendlic, seðe nele, for nanre ehtnysse, bugan fram Criste, ne for swurde, ne for fyre, ne for wætere, ne for hungre, ne for bendum
But that man's christianity is praiseworthy, who will not, for any persecution, incline from Christ, neither for sword, nor for fire, nor for water, nor for hunger, nor for bonds

ac æfre hylt his geleafan mid Godes hérungum, oð his lifes ende
but ever holds his faith with the praises of God to his life's end

Þa ðe ðæra treowa bogas heowon, and mid þam Cristes weig gedæfton, þæt sind þa lareowas on Godes cyrcan, þe plucciað þa cwydas ðæra apostola and heora æftergengena, and mid þam Godes folce gewisiað to Cristes geleafan, þæt hí beon gearwe to his færelde
Those who hewed branches of trees, and with them prepared Christ's way, are the teachers in God's church, who cull the sayings of the apostles and their successors, and with them direct God's people to the faith of Christ, that they may be prepared for his way

Þæt folc ðe Criste beforan stóp, and þæt ðe him fyligde, ealle hí sungon
The people who walked before Christ, and those who followed him, all sung

Osanna Filio Dauid
Osanna Filio David

þæt is on urum geðeode
that is, in our tongue

Sy hǽlo Dauides Bearne
Hail, Son of David

Þa ðe Criste beforan stopon, þa sind ða heahfæderas and þa wítegan, ðe wæron ǽr Cristes flæsclicnysse
Those who walked before Christ, are the patriarchs and prophets, who were before Christ's incarnation

and ða ðe him bæftan eodon, þæt sind ða ðe æfter Cristes acennednysse to him gebugon, and dæghwamlice bugað: and ealle hí singað ænne lofsang
and those who went after him, are those who inclined to Christ after his birth, and daily incline to him: and all these sing one hymn

forðan ðe wé and hí ealle healdað ænne geleafan, swa swa Petrus se apostol cwæð, ðaða he spræc be ðam heahfæderum
because we and they all hold one faith, as Peter the apostle said, when he spake of the patriarchs

We gelyfað þæt we beon gehealdene þurh Cristes gife, swa swa hí
We believe that we shall be saved by Christ's grace, as well as they

Hí cwædon
They said

Dauides Bearn
Son of David

forðan þe Crist is þæs mæran cyne-cynnes Dauides, æfter þære menniscnysse
because Christ is, according to his human nature, of the great race of David

Of ðam cynne wæs seo eadige Maria his modor
Of that race was the blessed Mary his mother

Hi sungon
They sung

Gebletsod is se ðe com on Godes naman
Blessed is he who is come in the name of God

Se Hælend com on Godes naman, forðan þe se Heofenlica Fæder hine asende ús to alysednysse
Jesus came in the name of God, for the Heavenly Father sent him for our redemption

and ealle ða wundra þe hé worhte, on eallum he herede and wuldrode his Fæder naman
and in all the miracles which he wrought, he praised and glorified his Father's name

Sy hælo Dauides Bearne on heahnyssum
Hail, Son of David, in the highest

Þæs Hælendes to-cyme and his ðrowung wæs halwendlic ægðer ge mannum ge englum
The Saviour's advent and his passion were salutary both to men and angels

forðan ðe wé geeacniað heora werod, þe se feallenda deofol gewanode
because we increase their host which the fallen devil had diminished

be ðam cwæð se apostol Paulus
concerning which the apostle Paul said

Þæt sceoldon ealle heofenlice ðing and eorðlice beon ge-edstaðelode on Criste
That all heavenly and earthly things should be re-established in Christ

Se Hælend wæs wunigende binnan ðam temple of ðisum dæge oð nu on ðunres-dæg, and ægðer ge mid láre ge mid wundrum þæt folc tihte to soðfæstnysse and to rihtum geleafan
Jesus was staying in the temple from this day till now on Thursday, and both with doctrine and with miracles stimulated the people to truth and to right faith

Þa namon ða heafod-men ándan ongean his láre, and syrwedon mid micelre smeaunge, hu hi mihton hine to deaðe gebringan
Then the chief men became envious of his doctrine, and machinated with great deliberation how they might bring him to death

Ne mihte se deað him genealæcan, gif he sylf nolde, ac he com to mannum to ði þæt he wolde beon gehyrsum his Fæder oð deað, and mancynn alysan fram ðam ecan deaðe mid his hwilwendlicum deaðe
Death could not have approached him, if he himself had not willed it, but he came to men because he would be obedient to his Father till death, and redeem mankind from eternal death by his temporary death

Þeah-hwæðere ne nydde he na þæt Iudeisce folc to his cwale, ac deofol hí tihte to ðam weorce, and God þæt geðafode, to alysednysse ealles geleaffulles mancynnes
Yet did he not compel the Jewish people to slay him, but the devil instigated them to the work, and God consented to it, for the redemption of all believing mankind

We habbað oft gesæd, and gít secgað, þæt Cristes rihtwisnys is swa micel, þæt he nolde niman mancyn neadunga of ðam deofle, buton he hit forwyrhte
We have often said, and yet say, that the justice of Christ is so great, that he would not forcibly have taken mankind from the devil, unless he had forfeited them

He hit forwyrhte ðaða he tihte þæt folc to Cristes cwale, þæs Ælmihtigan Godes
He forfeited them when he instigated the people to the slaying of Christ, the Almighty God

and ða þurh his unscæððigan deað wurdon we alysede fram ðam ecan deaðe, gif we us sylfe ne forpærað
and then through his innocent death we were redeemed from eternal death, if we do not destroy ourselves

Þa getimode ðam reðan deofle swa swa deð þam grædigan fisce, þe gesihð þæt ǽs, and ne gesihð ðone angel ðe on ðam æse sticað
Then it befell the cruel devil as it does the greedy fish, which sees the bait, and sees not the hook which sticks in the bait

bið þonne grædig þæs æses, and forswylcð þone angel forð mid þam æse
then is greedy after the bait and swallows up the hook with the bait

Swa wæs þam deofle: he geseh ða menniscnysse on Criste, and na ða godcundnysse: ða sprytte he þæt Iudeisce folc to his slege, and gefredde ða þone angel Cristes godcundnysse, þurh ða hé wæs to deaðe aceocod, and benǽmed ealles mancynnes þara ðe on God belyfað
So it was with the devil: he saw the humanity in Christ, and not the divinity: he then instigated the Jewish people to slay him, and then felt the hook of Christ's divinity, by which he was choked to death, and deprived of all mankind who believe in God

Næs na Cristes ðrowung gefremmed on þisum dæge, ac ða feower godspelleras awriton his ðrowunga on feower gesetnyssum
Christ's passion did not take place on this day, but the four evangelists recorded his sufferings in four narratives: one we read now to-day, and the others in this week

þa ane we rædað nu to-dæg, and ða oðre on ðisre wucan
The Jews took him on Friday evening, and held him that night, and on the morrow fixed him on a cross with four nails, and with a spear wounded him

Þa Iudei genámon hine on frige-æfen, and heoldon hine ða niht, and ðæs on merigen hí hine gefæstnodon on rode mid feower nægelum, and mid spere gewundedon
And then about the ninth hour, when he departed, there came two believing men, Joseph and Nicodemus, and buried his corpse before evening in a new tomb, enwrapt in precious garments

And ða embe nón-tid, þaþa hé forðferde, þa comon twegen gelyfede men, Ioseph and Nichodemus, and bebyrigdon his líc ær æfene, on niwere ðryh, mid deorwyrðum reafum bewunden
And his corpse lay in the sepulchre the Saturday night and Sunday night

And his líc læg on byrgene þa sæter-niht and sunnan-niht
and the Divinity was during that while in hell, and bound the old devil, and took from him Adam, the first-created man, and his wife Eve, and all those of their race who had before given pleasure to God

and seo godcundnys wæs on ðære hwile on helle, and gewrað þone ealdan deofol, and him of-anam Adám, þone frumsceapenan man, and his wíf Euan, and ealle ða ðe of heora cynne Gode ǽr gecwemdon
Then was the devil sensible of the hook which he had before greedily swallowed

Þa gefredde se deofol þone angel þe he ǽr grædelice forswealh
And Christ arose from death on the Easter-Sunday, which will now be in seven days, of which it is more fitting then to speak more fully than it is now: but let us now speak of the dignity of this day

Se gewuna stent on Godes cyrcan, þurh lareowas geset, þæt gehwær on Godes gelaðunge se sacerd bletsian sceole palm-twigu on ðisum dæge, and hí swa gebletsode ðam folce dælan
The custom exists in God's church, by its doctors established, that everywhere in God's congregation the priest should bless palm-twigs on this day, and distribute them so blessed to the people

and sceolon ða Godes þeowas singan ðone lofsang, þe þæt Iudeisce folc sang togeanes Criste, þaþa he genealæhte his ðrowunge
and God's servants should then sing the hymn which the Jewish people sang before Christ, when he was approaching to his passion

We geeuenlæcað þam geleaffullum of ðam folce mid þisre dæde, forðan ðe hi bæron palm-twigu mid lofsange togeanes þam Hælende
We imitate the faithful of that people with this deed, for they bare palm-twigs with hymn before Jesus

Nu sceole we healdan urne palm, oðþæt se sangere onginne ðone offring-sáng, and geoffrian þonne Gode ðone palm, for ðære getacnunge
Now we should hold our palm until the singer begins the offering-song, and then offer to God the palm for its betokening

Palm getacnað syge
Palm betokens victory

Sygefæst wæs Crist þaþa he ðone micclan deofol oferwann, and us generede: and we sceolon beon eac sygefæste þurh Godes mihte, swa þæt we ure unðeawas, and ealle leahtras, and ðone deofol oferwinnan, and ús mid godum weorcum geglencgan, and on ende ures lifes betæcan Gode ðone palm, þæt is, ure sige, and ðancian him georne, þæt we, ðurh his fultum, deoful oferwunnon, þæt he us beswican ne mihte
Victorious was Christ when he overcame the great devil and rescued us: and we should also be victorious through God's might, so that we overcome our evil practices, and all sins, and the devil, and adorn ourselves with good works, and at the end of our life deliver the palm to God, that is, our victory, and thank him fervently, that we, through his succour, have overcome the devil, so that he could not deceive us

Synfulra manna deað is yfel and earmlic, forðan ðe hí farað of ðisum scortan life to ecum pinungum: and rihtwisra manna deað is deorwyrðe, forði ðonne hí geendiað ðis geswincfulle líf, þonne beoð hí gebrohte to ðam ecan life, and bið þonne swylce heora ende beo anginn
The death of sinful men is evil and miserable, because they pass from this short life to everlasting torments: and the death of righteous men is precious, for when they end this life of tribulation they will be brought to the life eternal, and then will their end be as a beginning

forðan ðe hí ne beoð na deade, ac beoð awende of deaðe to life
for they will not be dead, but will be turned from death to life

Se lichama, ðe is þære sawle reaf, anbidað þæs micclan domes
The body, which is the garment of the soul, will await the great doom, and though it be rotted to dust, God will raise it, and will bring together soul and body to eternal life

and ðeah he beo to duste formolsnod, God hine arærð, and gebrincð togædere sawle and lichaman to ðam ecan life
and then will Christ's promise be fulfilled, who thus said

and bið þonne gefylled Cristes behát, ðe ðus cwæð
Then shall the righteous shine as the sun in their Father's kingdom

Þonne scínað ða rihtwisan swa swa sunne on heora Fæder ríce
who liveth and ruleth ever without end to eternity

seðe leofað and rixað á butan ende on ecnysse
Amen

Circlice ðeawas forbeodað to secgenne ænig spel on þam þrym swig-dagum
Church customs forbid any sermon to be said on the three still days

Oft ge gehyrdon embe ðæs Hælendes ærist, hú hé on ðisum dæge of deaðe arás
Ye have often heard concerning the Saviour's resurrection, how he on this day arose from death

ac we willað eow myngian, þæt hit ne gange eow of gemynde
but we will remind you, that it may not pass from your memory

Þaða Crist bebyrged wæs, þa cwædon þa Iudeiscan to heora ealdormenn Pilate, La leof, se swica ðe her ofslegen is, cwæð gelomlice, þaþa hé on lífe wæs, þæt hé wolde arisan of deaðe on þam ðriddan dæge
When Christ was buried, the Jews said to their governor Pilate, O Sir, the deceiver, who hath here been slain, said oftentimes, while he was living, that he would arise from death on the third day

et reliqua
etc

We cweðað nu, gif hwá his lic forstæle, nolde he hine unscrydan, forðan ðe stalu ne lufað nane yldinge
We say now, if any one had stolen his corpse, he would not have stript him, for theft loves no delay

Crist wearð æteowed on ðam ylcan dæge Petre, and oðrum twam his leorning-cnihtum, and hí gefrefrode
Christ appeared on the same day to Peter and to two others his disciples, and comforted them

Þa æt nextan com se Hælend to his leorning-cnihtum, þær hí gegaderode wæron, and cwæð him to, Sy sibb betwux eow
Then at last Jesus came to his disciples, where they were assembled, and said to them, Peace be unto you

ic hit eom, ne beo ge na afyrhte
it is I, be ye not afraid

Þa wurdon hí afærede, and wendon þæt hit sum gast wære
Then they were afraid, and weened it were a ghost

Ða cwæð he him to, Hwí sind ge afærede, and mislice ðencað be me
Then said he to them, Why are ye afraid, and think divers things of me

Sceawiað mine handa and mine fét, þe wæron mid næglum þurhdrifene
Behold my hands and my feet, that were pierced with nails

Grapiað and sceawiað: gif ic gast wære, ðonne næfde ic flæsc and ban
Grasp and behold: if I were a ghost, I should not have flesh and bones

et reliqua
etc

Se Hælend wearð þa gelomlice ætíwed his leorning-cnihtum, and hí gewissode to ðære lare and to ðam geleafan, hú hí eallum mancynne tæcan sceoldon
Jesus then frequently appeared to his disciples, and directed them to doctrine and to faith, how they should teach all mankind

and on ðam feowertigoðan dæge his æristes hé astáh lichamlice to heofonum to his Fæder
and on the fortieth day of his resurrection he ascended bodily to heaven to his Father

Ac we habbað nú micele maran endebyrdnysse þære Cristes bec gesǽd þonne ðis dægðerlice godspel behæfð, for trymminge eowres geleafan
But we have now said much more of the tenour of the book of Christ than this present day's gospel requires for the confirmation of your faith

Nu wylle we eow gereccan þæs dægþerlican godspelles traht, æfter ðæs halgan papan Gregories trahtnunge
We will now give you the explanation of this day's gospel, according to the exposition of the holy pope Gregory

Mine gebroðra þa leofostan, ge gehyrdon þæt þa halgan wíf, þe Drihtne on life filigdon, comon to his byrgene mid þære deorwyrðan sealfe, and þone ðe hí lufedon on lífe þam hí woldon deadum mid menniscre gecneordnysse ðenian
My dearest brothers, ye have heard that the holy women, who followed the Lord in life, came with precious ointment to his sepulchre, and him whom they had loved in life they would when dead serve with human devotion

Ac ðeos dǽd getacnað sum ðing to dónne on Godes gelaðunge
But this deed betokens something to be done in God's church

We ðe gelyfað Cristes æristes, we cumað gewislice to his byrgene mid deorwyrðre sealfe, gif we beoð gefyllede mid bræðe haligra mihta, and gif we mid hlysan godra weorca urne Drihten secað
We who believe in the resurrection of Christ come assuredly to his sepulchre with precious ointment, if we are filled with the breath of holy virtues, and if we with the fame of good works seek our Lord

Þa wíf ðe ða sealfe brohton, hi gesawon englas
The women who brought the ointment saw angels

forðan ðe ða geseoð þa heofonlican englas, þa þe mid bræðum godra weorca gewilniað þæs upplican færeldes
for they see the heavenly angels, who with the breath of good works yearn after the upward journey

Se engel awylte þæt hlíd of ðære ðryh
The angel rolled the lid from the tomb

na þæt hé Criste útganges rymde, ac he geswutelode mannum þæt hé arisen wæs
not that he would make way for Christ's departure, but he would manifest to men that he was risen

Se ðe com deaðlic to ðisum middangearde, acenned þurh beclysedne innoð þæs mædenes, se ylca, butan twéon, ðaða hé arás undeaðlic, mihte belocenre ðríh faran of middangearde
He who came mortal to this world, born of the closed womb of the virgin, he, without doubt, might, when he arose immortal, though in a closed tomb, depart from the world

Se engel sæt on ða swiðran healfe ðære byrgene
The angel sat on the right side of the sepulchre

Seo swiðre hand getacnað þæt ece líf, and seo wynstre ðis andwearde líf
The right hand betokens the eternal life, and the left this present life

Rihtlice sæt se engel on ða swiðran hand, forðon þe he cydde þæt se Hælend hæfde ða oferfaren ða brosnunga ðises andweardan lifes, and wæs ða wunigende on ecum ðingum undeaðlic
Rightly sat the angel on the right hand, for he manifested that Jesus had surmounted the corruptions of this present life, and was then dwelling immortal in eternity

Se bydel wæs ymbscryd mid scinendum reafe, forðan ðe he bodade þa blisse þisre freols-tíde, and ure mærða
The messenger was clad in a shining garment, because he announced the happiness of this festival-tide, and our glories

Hwæðer cweðe we, ðe ure ðe ðæra engla
But we ask, ours or the angels

We cweðað soðlice, ægðer ge ure ge heora
We say verily, both ours and theirs

Þæs Hælendes ærist is ure freols-tíd and bliss, forðan ðe he gelædde us mid his æriste to ðære undeadlicnysse þe we to gesceapene wæron
The resurrection of Jesus is our festival-tide, for by his resurrection he led us to the immortality for which we were created

His ærist wæs þæra engla bliss, forðon ðe God gefylð heora getel, þonne he ús to heofonum gebrincð
His resurrection was bliss to the angels, because God fills up their number when he brings us to heaven

Se engel gehyrte ða wíf, þus cweðende
The angel cheered the women, thus saying

Ne beo ge afyrhte
Be ye not afraid

swilce he swa cwæde, Forhtian ða ðe ne lufiað engla to-cyme
as if he had said thus, Let those fear who love not the advent of angels

beon ða ofdrædde þa þe sint ofsette mid flæsclicum lustum, and nabbað nænne hiht to engla werode
let those be terrified who are beset with fleshly lusts, and have no joy in the host of angels

Hwi forhtige ge, ge ðe geseoð eowre geferan
Why fear ye, ye who see your companions

His wlite wæs swilce líget, and his reaf swa hwít swa snáw
His countenance was like lightning, and his raiment as white as snow

Soðlice on lígette is óga, and on snáwe liðnys þære beorhtnysse
Verily in lightning is terror, and in snow the mildness of brightness

Rihtlice wæs se bydel Cristes æristes swa gehíwod
Rightly was the messenger of Christ's resurrection so figured

forðan þonne he sylf cymð to ðam micclan dome, þonne bið he swiðe egeful ðam synfullum, and swiðe liðe þam rihtwisum
for when he himself shall come to the great doom, he will be very awful to the sinful, and very mild to the righteous

He cwæð
He said

Ge secað þone Hælend: hé arás: nis hé her
Ye seek Jesus: he is risen: he is not here

He næs ða lichamlice on ðære byrgene, seðe æghwær bið þurh his godcundan mihte
He was not then bodily in the sepulchre, who is everywhere through his divine power

Þær lǽig þæt reaf bæftan þe he mid bewunden wæs, forðon ðe hé ne rohte þæs eorðlican reafes, syððan he of deaðe arás
There lay the garment behind in which he had been wrapt, for he recked not of an earthly garment, after he had arisen from death

Þeah man deadne mannan mid reafe bewinde, ne arist þæt reaf na ðe hraðor eft mid þam men, ac he bið mid þam heofenlicum reafe gescryd æfter his æriste
Though a dead man be wrapt in a garment, that garment does not the sooner rise again with the man, but he will be clad with the heavenly garment after his resurrection

Wel is gecweden be ðam Hælende, þæt he wolde cuman togeanes his geferon on Galilea
It is well said of Jesus, that he would meet his companions in Galilee

Galilea is gecweden 'Oferfæreld
Galilee is interpreted, Passing over

' Se Hælend wæs ða afaren fram ðrowunge to ǽriste, fram deaðe to life, fram wite to wuldre
Jesus passed over from passion to resurrection, from death to life, from torment to glory

And gif we farað fram leahtrum to halgum mægnum, þonne mote we geseon ðone Hælend æfter urum færelde of ðisum life
And if we pass from sins to holy virtues, then may we see Jesus after our passage from this life

Twa líf sind soðlice: þæt án we cunnon, þæt oðer us wæs uncuð ær Cristes to-cyme
For there are two lives: the one we know, the other was unknown to us before Christ's advent

Þæt án líf is deadlic, þæt oðer undeadlic
The one life is mortal, the other immortal

Ac se Hælend com and underfeng þæt án líf, and geswutelode þæt oðer
But Jesus came and assumed the one life, and made manifest the other

Þæt án líf he æteowde mid his deaðe, and þæt oðer mid his æriste
The one life he manifested by his death, and the other by his resurrection

Gif he us deadlicum mannum ærist and þæt ece líf behete, and þeah-hwæðere nolde hit þurh hine sylfne geswutelian, hwa wolde þonne his behatum gelyfan
If he to us mortal men had promised resurrection and life eternal, and yet had not been willing to manifest them in himself, who would have believed in his promises

Ac ðaða he man beon wolde, ða gemedemode hé hine sylfne eac to deaðe agenes willan, and he arás of deaðe þurh his godcundan mihte, and geswutelode þurh hine sylfne þæt þæt he us behét
But when he would become man, then he also voluntarily humbled himself to death, and he arose from death through his divine power, and manifested in himself that which he had promised to us

Nu cwyð sum man on his geðance, 'Eaðe mihte he arisan of deaðe, forðan ðe he is God: ne mihte se deað hine gehæftan
Now will some man say in his thoughts, 'Easily might he arise from death, because he is God: death could not hold him captive

' Gehyre se mann þe þis smeað andsware his smeagunge
' Let the man who imagines this hear an answer to his imagination

Crist forðferde ana on ðam timan, ac he ne arás na ana of deaðe, ac arás mid micclum werede
Christ departed at that time alone, but he arose not from death alone, but arose with a great host

Se godspellere Matheus awrát on Cristes béc, þæt manega halige menn, ðe wæron on ðære ealdan ǽ forðfarene, þæt hí arison mid Criste
The evangelist Matthew wrote in the book of Christ, that many holy men, who had died in the old law, arose with Christ

and þæt sædon gehwilce wíse láreowas, þæt hi habbað gefremod heora ærist to ðam ecan lífe, swa swa we ealle dón sceolon on ende þisre worulde
and all wise doctors have said that they have effected their resurrection to eternal life, as we all shall do at the end of this world

Þa láreowas cwædon, þæt ða aræredan menn næron soðlice gewitan Cristes æristes, gif hí næron ecelice arærde
Those doctors said, that the raised men would not truly have been witnesses of Christ's resurrection, if they had not been raised for ever

Nu sind adwæscede ealle geleaflystu, þæt nan man ne sceal ortruwian be his agenum æriste, þonne se godspellere awrát þæt fela arison mid Criste, ðe wæron anfealde men, ðeah ðe Crist God sy
Now are extinguished all infidelities, so that no man may despair of his own resurrection, when the evangelist wrote that many arose with Christ, who were simple men, although Christ be God

Nu cwæð Gregorius se trahtnere, þæt him come to gemynde, hu ða Iudeiscan clypodon be Criste, þaða he wæs on ðære rode gefæstnod
Now said the expounder Gregory, that it came to his mind, how the Jews cried out concerning Christ, when he was fastened on the cross

Hí cwædon
They said

Gif he sy Israhela cyning, þonne astige he nu of ðære rode, and we gelyfað on hine
If he be the king of Israel, then let him now descend from the cross, and we will believe in him

Gif he ða of ðære rode astige, and nolde heora hosp forberan, þonne, butan tweon, ne sealde he us nane bysne his geðyldes: ac he abád hwon, and forbær heora hosp, and hæfde geðyld
If he had then descended from the cross, and would not have borne their mockery, he had certainly not given us any example of his patience: but he remained a while, and bare their mockery, and had patience

Ac se ðe nolde of ðære rode abrecan, se arás of ðære byrgene
But he who would not break from the cross, arose from the sepulchre

Mare wundor wæs, þæt hé of deaðe arás, þonne he cucu of ðære rode abræce
A greater miracle it was, that he arose from death, than that he living should have broken from the cross

Mare miht wæs, þæt he ðone deað mid his æriste tobræc, þonne he his líf geheolde, of ðære rode astigende
A greater miracle it was, that he brake death in pieces, through his resurrection, than that he should have preserved his life by descending from the cross

Ac ðaða hí gesawon þæt he ne astah of ðære rode for heora hospum, ac ðæron deaðes gebád, þa gelyfdon hí þæt he oferswiðed wære, and his nama adwæsced: ac hit gelamp swa, þæt of ðam deaðe asprang his nama geond ealne middangeard
But when they saw that he descended not from the cross, for their mockery, but thereon awaited death, they believed that he was vanquished and his name extinguished: but it so fell out, that from death his name sprang forth over the whole earth

Þa wearð hyra bliss awend to ðam mæstan sare
Then was their joy turned to the greatest pain

forðan ðe heora sorh bið endeleas
for their sorrow shall be endless

Þas ðing getacnode se stranga Samson, se hæfde fæhðe to ðam folce ðe is gehaten Philistei
The strong Samson betokened these things, who had enmity to the people called Philistines

Ða getimode hit þæt he becom to heora byrig þe wæs Gaza gehaten: þa wæron ða Philistei swiðe bliðe, and ymbsæton ða burh
Then it befell that he came to their city which was called Gaza: whereupon the Philistines were very joyful, and surrounded the city

Ac se stranga Samson arás on midre nihte, and gelæhte ða burh-geatu, and abær hi uppon ane dune, to bismere his gefaan
But the strong Samson arose at midnight, and took the city gates, and bare them up on a hill, in derision of his foes

Se stranga Samson getacnode Crist, seo burh Gaza getacnode helle, and ða Philistei hæfdon Iudeisces folces getacnunge, þe besæton Cristes byrgene
The strong Samson betokened Christ, the city of Gaza betokened hell, and the Philistines were a token of the Jewish people, who beset the sepulchre of Christ

Ac se Samson nolde gan ydel of ðære byrig, ac he abær ða gatu up to ðære dune
But Samson would not go empty-handed from the city, but he bare the gates up to the hill

forðon þe ure Hælend Crist tobræc helle-gatu, and generode Adam, and Euan, and his gecorenan of heora cynne, and freolice of deaðe arás, and hí samod, and astah to heofonum
for our Saviour Christ brake the gates of hell, and delivered Adam, and Eve, and his chosen of their kin, and joyfully from death arose, and they with him, and ascended to heaven

Þa mánfullan he lét bæftan to ðam ecum witum
The wicked he left behind to eternal torments

And is nu helle-geat belocen rihtwisum mannum, and æfre open unrihtwisum
And now is the gate of hell shut to righteous men, and ever open to the unrighteous

Ungesælig wæs þæt Iudeisce folc, þæt hí swa ungeleaffulle wæron
Unhappy was the Jewish people, that they were so unbelieving

Ealle gesceafta oncneowon heora Scyppend, buton ðam Iudeiscum anum
All creatures acknowledged their Creator, save only the Jews

Heofonas oncneowon Cristes acennednysse
Heaven acknowledged the birth of Christ

forðan ðaða hé acenned wæs, þa wearð gesewen níwe steorra
for when he was born a new star was seen

Sǽ oncneow Crist, ðaða hé eode mid drium fotum uppon hire yðum
The sea acknowledged Christ, when he went with dry feet on its waves

Eorðe oncneow, þaþa heo eal bifode on Cristes æriste
Earth acknowledged him, when it all trembled at Christ's resurrection

Seo sunne oncneow, þaþa heo wearð aðystrod on Cristes ðrowunge fram mid-dæge oð nón
The sun acknowledged him, when it was darkened at Christ's passion from mid-day to the ninth hour

Stanas oncneowon, þaþa hí toburston on heora Scyppendes forðsiðe
The stones acknowledged him, when they burst asunder at their Creator's departure

Hell oncneow Crist, ðaða heo forlét hyre hæftlingas út, þurh ðæs Hælendes hergunge
Hell acknowledged Christ, when it let forth its captives, through the harrowing of Jesus

And ða heardheortan Iudei ðeah þurh ealle ða tacna noldon gebugan mid geleafan to ðam mildheortan Hælende, seðe wile eallum mannum gehelpan on hine gelyfendum
And yet the hardhearted Jews, through all these signs, would not incline with faith to the merciful Jesus, who will help all men who believe in him

Ac uton we gelyfan þæt God Fæder wæs æfre butan anginne, and æfre wæs se Sunu of ðam Fæder acenned
But let us believe that God the Father was ever without beginning, and that the Son was ever begotten of the Father

forðan ðe he is se Wisdom and Miht ðe se Fæder ealle gesceafta þurh gesceop
for he is the Wisdom and Power through which the Father hath created all creatures

and hí ealle wurdon gelíffæste þurh ðone Halgan Gast, seðe is Willa and Lufu þæs Fæder and þæs Suna
and they were all quickened by the Holy Ghost who is the Will and Love of the Father and of the Son

hí ðry án God untodæledlic, on ánre godcundnysse wunigende, hí ealle gelíce mihtige
these three one God indivisible, existing in one Godhead, all equally powerful

forðan swa hwæt swa læsse bið and unmihtigre, þæt ne bið na God
for whatsoever is less and less powerful, that is not God

Ac se Fæder sende ðone Sunu to ure alysednysse, and he ána underfeng ða menniscnysse, and þrowode deað be his agenum willan, and arás of deaðe on ðisum dæge, and astah to heofonum on ðam feowertigeðan dæge his æristes, ætforan manegra manna gesihðe, and rixað mid þam Ælmihtigan Fæder and ðam Halgum Gaste, nú and á on ecnysse
But the Father sent the Son for our redemption, and he alone assumed human nature, and suffered death of his own will, and arose from death on this day, and ascended to heaven on the fortieth day after his resurrection, before the sight of many men, and ruleth with the Almighty Father and the Holy Ghost, now and ever to eternity

Amen

Æfter ðæs Hælendes ǽriste wæron his discipuli belocene on anum huse for ðæs Iudeiscan folces ógan
After the resurrection of Jesus his disciples were shut in a house for dread of the Jews

et reliqua
etc

Nu cwyð se godspellere Iohannes, þæt se Hælend worhte fela oðre tacna on gesihðe his leorning-cnihta, þe næron gesette on Cristes béc
Now says the evangelist John, that Jesus wrought many other miracles in the sight of his disciples, which have not been recorded in the book of Christ

Þas wundra sind awritene to ði þæt ge sceolon gelyfan þæt se Hælend is Godes Sunu, and ge sceolon habban þæt ece líf þurh ðone geleafan
These miracles are written to the end that ye may believe that Jesus is the Son of God, and that ye may have eternal life through that belief

Nu trahtnað se papa Gregorius ðis godspel, and cwyð, þæt gehwá wundrað hu se Hælend become in to his apostolum, and wæron ðeah-hwæðere ða dura belocene
Now the pope Gregory, expounding this gospel, says, that everyone wonders how Jesus came in to his apostles, and yet the doors were shut

Nu cwyð eft se halga Gregorius, þæt Cristes lichama com inn, beclysedum durum, seðe wearð acenned of ðam mædene Marian beclysedum innoðe
But again St

Hwilc wundor is þæt se Hælend mid ecum lichaman come inn, belocenum durum, seðe mid deadlicum lichaman wearð acenned of beclysedum innoðe þæs mædenes
Gregory says, that Christ's body came in, the doors being closed, which was born of the Virgin Mary, of a closed womb

We rædað on ðære bec ðe is geháten Actus Apostolorum, þæt þa heafod-men Iudeisces folces gebrohton Cristes apostolas on cwearterne: þa on niht com him to Godes engel, and lædde hí út of ðam cwearterne, and stód on merigen þæt cweartern fæste belocen
We read in the book which is called The Acts of the Apostles, that the chief men of the Jewish people brought Christ's apostles into prison: then by night God's angel came to them, and led them out of the prison, and on the morrow the prison stood fast shut up

God mæig dón ealle ðing: nu sceole we wundrian his mihte, and eac gelyfan
God can do all things: therefore we should wonder at his might, and also believe

Þone lichaman he æteowde to grapigenne, þone ðe he inn-brohte beclysedum durum
He showed the body to be touched which he had brought in, the doors being closed

His lichama wæs grapigendlic, and ðeah-hwæðere unbrosnigendlic
His body was tangible, and, nevertheless, incorruptible

he æteowde hine grapigendlicne and unbrosnigendlicne, forðan ðe his lichama wæs þæs ylcan gecyndes ðe he ǽr wæs, ac wæs hwæðere þeah oðres wuldres
he showed himself tangible and incorruptible, for his body was of the same nature that it before was, but was yet of another glory

Se Hælend cwæð to him
Jesus said to them

Beo sibb betwux eow
Peace be among you

For sibbe com Crist to mannum, and sibbe he bead and tæhte, and nis nan ðing him gecweme þe bið butan sibbe gedón
For peace Christ came to men, and peace he enjoined and taught, and nothing is to him acceptable which is done without peace

Swa swa min Fæder sende me swa sende ic eow
As my Father sent me so I send you

Se Fæder lufað þone Sunu, ac ðeah-hwæðere he sende hine to ðrowunge for manna alysednysse
The Father loveth the Son, but yet he sendeth him to suffering for the redemption of men

Crist lufode eac his apostolas, and ðeah-hwæðere ne sette he hí to cynegum, ne to ealdormannum, ne to woruldlicere blisse
Christ also loved his apostles, and yet he established them not as kings, nor as governors, nor in worldly bliss

ac tosende hí geond ealne middangeard, to bodigenne fulluht and ðone geleafan ðe he sylf tæhte
but he sent them over all the earth, to preach baptism and the faith which he himself had taught

Þa bododon hí swa lange oð þæt þa ðweoran hí ofslogon, and hí ferdon sigefæste to heora Drihtne
They preached until the wicked slew them, and they went triumphant to their Lord

Crist bleow on ða apostolas, and cwæð
Christ blew on the apostles, and said

Onfoð Haligne Gast
Receive the Holy Ghost

Tuwa com se Halga Gast ofer ða apostolas
Twice came the Holy Ghost over the apostles

nu ǽne, and eft oðre siðe æfter Cristes upstige
once now, and again another time at Christ's ascension

Crist ableow þone Halgan Gast ofer ða apostolas, ða-gyt wunigende on eorðan, for ðære getacnunge, þæt ælc cristen mann sceal lufian his nextan swa swa hine sylfne
Christ blew the Holy Ghost over the apostles, while yet continuing on earth, for a token that every christian man should love his neighbour as himself

Eft siððan he to heofenum astáh, he sende þone ylcan Gast on fyres híwe ofer ða apostolas, to ði þæt we sceolon lufian God ofer ealle oðre ðing
Again, after he had ascended to heaven, he sent the Holy Ghost in semblance of fire over the apostles, to the end that we should love God above all other things

An is se Halga Gast, þeah ðe he tuwa become ofer ða apostolas
The Holy Ghost is one, though he came twice over the apostles

Swa is eac án lufu, and twá bebodu, þæt we sceolon lufian God and men
So there is also one love, and two commandments, that we should love God and men

Ac we sceolon geleornian on mannum hu we magon becuman to Godes lufe, swa swa Iohannes se apostol cwæð
But we should learn in men how we may come to the love of God, as John the apostle said

Se ðe ne lufað his broðor, þone ðe hé gesihð, hu mæg he lufian God, þone ðe he ne gesihð lichamlice
He who loveth not his brother, whom he seeth, how can he love God, whom he seeth not bodily

Ær ðam fyrste wæs se Halga Gast wunigende on ðam apostolum, ac hí næron to ðan swiðe onbryrde, þæt hí mihton swa bealdlice Godes geleafan bodian, swa swa hí siððan mihton, þurh gife ðæs Halgan Gastes
Before that time the Holy Ghost was dwelling in the apostles, but they were not stimulated to that degree, that they could boldly preach God's faith, as they could afterwards, through the grace of the Holy Ghost

Hí sæton beclysede, for ógan Iudeisces folces, on anum huse
They sat, for fear of the Jewish people, shut in a house

ac syððan hí wæron gefyllede mid þam Halgum Gaste, hí wurdon swa gehyrte, and swa cene, þæt hí bodedon freolice Godes naman reðum cynegum and wælreowum
but after they were filled with the Holy Ghost, they were so encouraged, and so bold, that they freely proclaimed the name of God to fierce and bloodthirsty kings

Crist cwæð to ðam apostolum
Christ said to the apostles

Þæra manna synna þe ge forgyfað, þæra beoð forgifene
Those men's sins which ye forgive, they shall be forgiven

and ðam ðe ge ofteoð þa forgifenysse, ðam bið oftogen
and those from whom ye withdraw forgiveness, from them it shall be withdrawn

Þisne anweald forgeaf Crist þam apostolum and eallum bisceopum, gif hí hit on riht healdað
This power Christ gave to the apostles and to all bishops, if they righteously hold it

Ac gif se bisceop deð be his agenum willan, and wile bíndan þone únscyldigan, and þone scyldigan alysan, þonne forlyst hé ða mihte ðe him God forgeaf
But if the bishop act by his own will, and will bind the innocent, and loose the guilty, then loses he the power which God gave him

Þam mannum he sceal dón synna forgifenysse, þe hé gesihð þæt beoð onbryrde ðurh Godes gife, and þam he sceal aheardian þe náne behreowsunge nabbað heora misdæda
To those men he shall grant forgiveness of sins, whom he sees that they are stimulated by God's grace, and to those he shall be obdurate who have no repentance of their misdeeds

Crist arærde of deaðe þone stincendan Lazarum, and þaþa hé cucu wæs, þa cwæð hé to his leorning-cnihtum
Christ raised from death the stinking Lazarus, and when he was quickened, he said to his disciples

Tolysað his bendas, þæt hé gán mæge
Loose his bands, that he may go

Þa alysdon hí þæs ge-edcucedan mannes bendas, þe Crist arærde to life
They loosed the bands of the requickened man, whom Christ had raised to life

Forði sceolon ða láreowas ða unbindan fram heora synnum þa ðe Crist gelíffæst þurh onbryrdnysse
Therefore should our teachers unbind from their sins those whom Christ quickens by stimulation

Ælc synful man þe his synna bediglað, he lið dead on byrgene
Every sinful man who conceals his sins, lies dead in the sepulchre

ac gif he his synna geandett þurh onbryrdnysse, þonne gæð he of þære byrgene, swa swa Lazarus dyde, þaða Crist hine arisan het: þonne sceal se lareow hine unbindan fram ðam ecum wíte, swa swa ða apostoli lichamlice Lazarum alysdon
but if he confess his sins through stimulation, then he goes from the sepulchre, as Lazarus did, when Christ bade him arise: then shall the teacher unbind him from the eternal punishment, as the apostles bodily unbound Lazarus

Ac se læweda mann sceal him ondrædan þæs bisceopes cwyde, þeah hé unscyldig sy
But the layman shall stand in awe of the bishop's word, though he be guiltless

þylæs ðe he ðurh modignysse scyldig weorðe
lest he become guilty through pride

Ne getimode þam apostole Thome unforsceawodlice, þæt he ungeleafful wæs Cristes æristes, ac hit getimode þurh Godes forsceawunge
It happened to the apostle Thomas not unprovidentially, that he was unbelieving of Christ's resurrection, but it happened by the providence of God

forðan ðurh his grapunge we sind geleaffulle
for through his touching we are believing

Mare ús fremode his tweonung þonne ðæra oðra apostola geleaffulnys
Of greater benefit to us was his doubt than the faith of the other apostles

forðan ðaða hé wæs gebroht to geleafan mid ðære grapunge, þa wearð seo twynung þurh þæt ús ætbroden
for when he was brought to belief by that touching, doubt was thereby taken from us

Eaðe mihte Crist arisan of deaðe butan dolhswaðum, ac to ði he heold þa dolhswaðu, þæt he wolde mid þam þa twynigendan getrymman
Easily might Christ have arisen from death without scars, but he held the scars, because he would thereby confirm the doubtful

He cwæð to Thoman
He said to Thomas

Þu gelyfst, forðan ðe ðu me gesawe
Thou believest, because thou hast seen me

He geseah ðone lichaman and þa dolhswaðu, and he gelyfde þæt he wæs God, seðe arærde þone lichaman of deaðe
He saw the body and the scars, and he believed that he was God, who had raised the body from death

Swiðe blissiað þas wórd ús þe her æfterfiliað
Greatly gladden us the words which here follow

Gesælige beoð þa þe me ne gesawon, and þeah on me gelyfað
Blessed are they who have not seen me, and yet believe in me

Mid ðam cwyde sind þa ealle getacnode þe Crist on lichaman ne gesawon, and ðeah-hwæðere hine healdað on heora mode þurh geleafan
By that saying are betokened all those who have not seen Christ in the body, and, nevertheless, hold him in their mind through faith

Se gelyfð soðlice on God, seðe mid weorcum begæð þæt þæt hé gelyfð
For he believes in God, who by works practises that which he believes

Se ðe andet þæt hé God cunne, and yfele weorc begæð, þonne wiðsæcð he God mid þam weorcum
He who acknowledges that he knows God, and performs evil works, denies God by those works

Se geleafa þe bið butan godum weorcum, se is dead
Faith without good works is dead

Þis sind ðæra apostola word, undernimað hí mid carfullum mode
These are the words of the apostles, receive them with careful mind

We sprecað embe ærist
We will speak concerning the resurrection

Nu sind sume men þe habbað twynunge be æriste, and ðonne hi geseoð deadra manna bán, þonne cweðað hí, Hu magon ðas bán beon ge-edcucode
Now there are some men who have doubt of the resurrection, and when they see the bones of dead men, they say, How can these bones be again quickened

Swilce hí wíslice sprecon
as if they speak wisely

Ac we cweðað þær-togeanes, þæt God is Ælmihtig, and mæg eal þæt he wile
But we say against them, that God is Almighty, and can do all that he will

He geworhte heofonas and eorðan and ealle gesceafta butan antimbre
He wrought heaven and earth and all creatures without matter

Nu is geðuht þæt him sy sumera ðinga eaðelicor to arærenne ðone deadan of ðam duste, þonne him wære to wyrcenne ealle gesceafta of nahte: ac soðlice him sind ealle ðing gelice eaðe, and nán ðing earfoðe
Now it seems that it is somewhat easier to him to raise the dead from the dust, than it was to him to make all creatures from naught: but truly to him are all things alike easy, and nothing difficult

He worhte Adam of láme
He wrought Adam of loam

Nu ne mage we asmeagan hú hé of ðam láme flæsc worhte, and blod bán and fell, fex and næglas
Now we cannot investigate how of that loam he made flesh and blood, bones and skin, hair and nails

Men geseoð oft þæt of anum lytlum cyrnele cymð micel treow, ac we ne magon geseon on þam cyrnele naðor ne wyrtruman, ne rinde, ne bógas, ne leaf: ac se God þe forðtihð of ðam cyrnele treow, and wæstmas, and leaf, se ylca mæg of duste arǽran flæsc and bán, sina and fex, swa swa he cwæð on his godspelle
Men often see that of one little kernel comes a great tree, but in the kernel we can see neither root, nor rind, nor boughs, nor leaves: but the same God who draws forth from the kernel tree, and fruits, and leaves, may from dust raise flesh and bones, sinews and hair, as he said in his gospel

Ne sceal eow beon forloren an hǽr of eowrum heafde
There shall not be lost to you one hair of your head

Se apostol Paulus cwæð, þæt we sceolon arisan of deaðe on ðære ylde þe Crist wæs þaða he ðrowade, þæt is embe þreo and ðritig geara
The apostle Paul said, that we should arise from death at the age that Christ was when he suffered, that is about three and thirty years

Þeah cild forðfare, oððe forwerod man, þeah-hwæðere hí cumað to þære ylde ðe we ær cwædon
Though a child depart, or a worn-out man, they will, nevertheless, come to the age we before said

hæfð þeah gehwá his agenne wæstm, þe he on þissum life hæfde, oððe habban sceolde, gif he his gebide
yet will everyone have his own growth, which he had in this life, or should have had, if he had awaited it

Gif hwá alefed wære, oððe limleas on þissum life, he bið þonne swa hit awriten is, þæt
If any one be maimed, or limbless in this life, he will be as it is written, that

Ealle ða þe to Godes rice gebyrigað, nabbað naðor ne womm ne awyrdnysse on heora lichaman
All those who belong to God's kingdom, shall have neither blemish nor hurt on their bodies

Hwæt sceole we smeagan embe ða oðre þe gewítað to ðam ecum forwyrde, hwæðer hí alefede beon oððe limlease, þonne hí beoð on ecere susle wunigende
What shall we suppose concerning those others who depart to everlasting perdition, whether they are maimed or limbless, when they are dwelling in eternal torment

Hit bið þonne swa swa Crist cwæð, þæt
It will then be as Christ said, that

Nan wer ne wifað, ne wif ne ceorlað, ne team ne bið getymed, ne hí deaðes ne abyrigað siððan, ac beoð englum gelice, þonne hí mid englum wuniað
No man taketh to wife, nor woman to husband, nor family is begotten, nor taste they of death, but will be like unto the angels, when they dwell with angels

Ne him ne lyst nanre galnysse, ne hí næfre siððan synna ne gewyrceað
No libidinousness will give them pleasure, nor will they ever perpetrate sins

Ne bið þær sorh, ne sár, ne nan gedreccednys, ac bið fulfremed sib and singal bliss, and beoð cuðe ge ða þe ær cuðe wæron ge ða þe uncuðe wæron, wunigende on broðorlicre lufe mid Gode á on ecnysse
No sorrow nor pain will be there, nor no affliction, but there will be perfect peace and continual bliss, and there will be known both those who were known before and those who were unknown, dwelling in brotherly love with God ever to eternity

Amen
Amen

Þis godspel, þe nú geræd wæs, cwyð, þæt se Hælend cwæde be him sylfum
This gospel, which has now been read, says, that Jesus said of himself

Ic eom gód hyrde: se góda hyrde sylð his agen líf for his sceapum
I am the good shepherd: the good shepherd giveth his own life for his sheep

Se hyra, seðe nis riht hyrde, he gesihð þone wulf cuman, and he forlæt ða scép and flyhð
The hireling, who is not the right shepherd, seeth the wolf coming, and he forsaketh the sheep and fleeth

and se wulf sum gelæcð and ða oðre tostencð
and the wolf teareth one, and scattereth the others

et reliqua
etc

Crist is goód gecyndelice, and soðlice nis nan ðing gód butan Gode anum
Christ is good by nature, and in sooth there is nothing good, save God only

Gif ænig gesceaft is gód, þonne is seo gódnys of ðam Scyppende, seðe is healice gód
If any creature is good, then is its goodness of the Creator, who is supremely good

He cwæð
He said

Se góda hyrde sylð his agen líf for his sceapum
The good shepherd giveth his own life for his sheep

Ure Alysend is se góda hyrde, and we cristene men sind his scép, and he sealde his agen líf for ure alysednysse
Our Redeemer is the good shepherd, and we christian men are his sheep, and he gave his own life for our redemption

He dyde swa swa he manede, and mid þam he geswutelode hwæt he bebead
He did as he exhorted, and he thereby manifested what he enjoined

Gód hyrde wæs Petrus, and gód wæs Paulus, and góde wæron ða apostoli, ðe hyra líf sealdon for Godes folce and for rihtum geleafan
A good shepherd was Peter, and good was Paul, and good were the apostles, who gave their lives for God's people and for the right faith

ac heora gódnys wæs of ðam heafde, þæt is Crist, ðe is heora heafod, and hí sind his lima
but their goodness was of the head, which is Christ, who is their head, and they are his limbs

Ælc bisceop and ælc láreow is to hyrde gesett Godes folce, þæt hí sceolon þæt folc wið ðone wulf gescyldan
Every bishop and every teacher is placed as a shepherd over God's people, that they may shield the people against the wolf

Se wulf is deofol, þe syrwð ymbe Godes gelaðunge, and cepð hu he mage cristenra manna sawla mid leahtrum fordón
The wolf is the devil, who lies in ambush about God's church, and watches how he may fordo the souls of christian men with sins

Þonne sceal se hyrde, þæt is se bisceop oððe oðer láreow, wiðstandan þam reðan wulfe mid láre and mid gebedum
Then shall the shepherd, that is, the bishop or other teacher, withstand the fierce wolf with doctrine and with prayers

Mid lare he sceal him tæcan, þæt hi cunnon hwæt deofol tæchð mannum to forwyrde, and hwæt God bebýt to gehealdenne, for begeate þæs ecan lifes
With doctrine he shall teach them, that they may know what the devil teaches for men's perdition, and what God commands to be observed for the attainment of everlasting life

He sceal him fore-gebiddan, þæt God gehealde þa strángan, and gehæle ða untruman
He shall pray for them, that God may preserve the strong and heal the weak

Se bið to strángum geteald, seþe wiðstent deofles lare
He is to be accounted strong who withstands the precepts of the devil

se bið untrum, seðe on leahtrum fylð
he is weak who falls into sins

Ac se láreow bið unscyldig, gif he þæt folc mid lare gewissað, and him wið God geðingað
But the teacher will be guiltless, if he direct the people with doctrine, and mediate for them with God

Þa twa ðing he sceal ðam folce dón, and eac mid his agenum oðrum gehelpan
These two things he shall do for the people, and also help others with his own

and gif hit swa getímað, his agen líf syllan for ðæs folces hreddinge
and if it so happen, give his own life for the saving of the people

Se hyra flihð þonne he ðone wulf gesihð
The hireling fleeth when he seeth the wolf

Se is hyra and na hyrde, seðe bið begripen on woruld-ðingum, and lufað þone wurðmynt and ða ateorigendlican edlean, and næfð inweardlice lufe to Godes sceapum
He is a hireling and not a shepherd, who is engaged in worldly things, and loves dignity and perishable rewards, and has no inward love for God's sheep

He cepð þæra sceatta, and blissað on ðam wurðmynte, and hæfð his mede for ðisum life, and bið bescyred þære ecan mede
He takes heed of treasures, and rejoices in dignity, and has his reward in this life, and will be cut off from the everlasting reward

Nast ðu hwá bið hyra, hwá hyrde, ærðam ðe se wulf cume
Thou knowest not who is a hireling, who a shepherd, before the wolf comes

ac se wulf geswutelað mid hwilcum mode he gymde þæra sceapa
but the wolf makes manifest in what manner he watches the sheep

Se wulf cymð to ðam sceapum, and sume hé abitt, sume hé tostencð, þonne se reða deofol tihð þa cristenan men, sume to forlígre, sume hé ontent to gytsunge, sume hé arærð to modignysse, sume hé þurh graman totwæmð, and mid mislicum costnungum gastlice ofslihð
The wolf comes to the sheep, and some he devours, some he scatters, when the fierce devil instigates christian men, some to adultery, some he inflames to covetousness, some he lifts up to pride, some through anger he divides, and with divers temptations spiritually slays: for the hireling is excited neither by care nor love, but flees, because he considers worldly advantages, and leaves unheeded the loss of the sheep

Ac se hyra ne bið naðor ne mid ware ne mid lufe astyred, ac flyhð, forðan þe hé smeað embe ða woruldlican hyðða, and lǽt to gymeleaste þære sceapa lyre
He flees not with body, but with mind

Ne flyhð he na mid lichaman, ac mid mode
He flees because he saw iniquity and held silence

He flyhð, forðan þe hé geseh unrihtwisnysse and suwade
He flees because he is a hireling and not a shepherd, as though it were so said, He cannot stand against the perils of the sheep, who guardeth not the sheep with love, but provideth for himself

Hé flyhð forðan ðe he is hyra, and ná hyrde, swilce hit swa gecweden sy, Ne mæg se standan ongean fræcednyssa þæra sceapa, seðe ne gymð þæra sceapa mid lufe, ac tylað his sylfes
that is, he loves worldly gain, and not God's folk

Wulf bið eac se unrihtwisa rica, ðe bereafað þa cristenan, and ða eadmodan mid his riccetere ofsitt: ac se hyra, oððe se médgylda ne gedyrstlæcð þæt he his unrihtwisnysse wiðstande, þæt he ne forleose his wurðmynt, and ða woruldlican gestreon ðe he lufað swiðor ðonne þa cristenan menn
The unrighteous powerful man also is a wolf, who robs christians, and oppresses the humble with his power: for the hireling, or the mercenary, dares not withstand his unrighteousness lest he lose his dignity, and the worldly gain which he loves more than christian men

Be ðisum awrát se wítega Ezechiel, þus cweðende
Concerning this the prophet Ezechiel wrote, thus saying

Ge hyrdas, gehyrað Godes word: Mine scép sint tostencte ðurh eowre gymeleaste, and sind abítene
Ye shepherds, hear the word of God: My sheep are scattered through your heedlessness, and are devoured

Ge cariað embe eowerne bigleofan, and ná embe þæra sceapa
Ye care for your own sustenance, and not for that of the sheep

forði ic wille ofgán ða scép æt eowrum handum
therefore I will require the sheep at your hands, and I will cause you to depart from the fold, and I will deliver my flock from you

and ic do þæt ge geswícað þære wícan, and ic wylle ahreddan mine eowde wið eow
I myself will gather my sheep that were scattered, and I will feed them in an abundant pasture: that which was lost I will seek and bring again

Ic sylf wylle gadrian mine scép þe wæron tostencte, and ic wylle hi healdan on genihtsumere læse: þæt þæt losode þæt ic wylle sécan and ongean lædan
that which was maimed I will heal

þæt þæt alefed wæs, þæt ic gehæle
the sick I will strengthen, and feed the strong, and I will pasture them in judgement and in righteousness

Þas word spræc God þurh ðone wítegan Ezechiel, be láreowum and be his folce
These words spake God through the prophet Ezechiel, concerning teachers and concerning his people

Ge sceolon beon geornfulle to eower agenre ðearfe, þeah hit swa getimige þæt se láreow gimeleas beo, and doð swa swa Crist tæhte
Ye should be zealous for your own need (though it so happen that the teacher be heedless), and do as Christ taught

Gif se láreow wel tǽce and yfele bysnige, doð swa swa he tæcð, and na be ðam þe hé bysnað
If the teacher teach well, and give evil example, do as he teacheth, and not according to his example

Se Hælend cwæð be him
Jesus says of himself

Ic eom gód hyrde, and ic oncnawe mine scép, and hí oncnawað me
I am a good shepherd, and I know my sheep, and they know me

Þæt is, ic lufige hí, and hí lufiað me
That is, I love them, and they love me

Se ðe ne lufað soðfæstnysse, ne oncneow he na gyt God
He who loves not truth, he yet knows not God

Ac behealde ge hwæðer ge sind Godes scép, hwæðer ge hine gyt oncneowon, hwæðer ge mid soðfæstnysse hine lufiað
But consider whether ye are God's sheep, whether ye yet know him, whether ye with truth love him

Hé cwæð
He said

Swa swa min Fæder oncnǽwð me, and ic oncnáwe hine, and ic sylle min agen lif for minum sceapum
As my Father knoweth me, I also know him, and I give my own life for my sheep

He oncnǽwð his Fæder ðurh hine sylfne, and we oncnawað þurh hine
He knows his Father through himself, and we know him through him

Mid þære lufe þe hé wolde for mancynne sweltan, mid þære hé cyðde hú micclan hé lufað his Fæder
With that love with which he would die for mankind, he manifested how greatly he loves his Father

He cwæð
He said

Ic hæbbe oðre scép þe ne sind na of ðisre eowde, and ða ic sceal lædan, and hi gehyrað mine stemne, and sceal beon án eowd, and án hyrde
I have other sheep which are not of this fold, and those I shall bring, and they will hear my voice, and there shall be one fold and one shepherd

Þis hé spræc on Iudea-lande: ðær wæs án eowd of ðam mannum þe on God belyfdon on ðam leodscipe
This he spake in the land of Juda: there was a fold of men who believed in God in that nation

Þa oðre scép syndon þa þe of eallum oðrum eardum to Gode búgað
The other sheep are those of all other countries who incline to God

and Crist hí gebrincð ealle on ánre eowde on ðam ecan life
and Christ will bring them all to one fold in eternal life

Manega sind hyrdas under Criste, and ðeah-hwæðere he is ána heora ealra Hyrde, seðe leofað and rixað mid Fæder and mid Halgum Gaste, á on ecnysse
Many are the shepherds under Christ, and yet he alone is Shepherd of them all, who liveth and ruleth with the Father and with the Holy Ghost ever to eternity

Amen
Amen

Ðas dagas synd gehatene Letaniae, þæt sint, Gebed-dagas
These days are called Litaniæ, that is, Prayer-days

On ðisum dagum we sceolon gebiddan ure eorðlicra wæstma genihtsumnysse, and us sylfum gesundfulnysse and sibbe, and, þæt gýt mare is, ure synna forgyfenysse
On these days we should pray for abundance of our earthly fruits, and health for ourselves, and peace, and, what is yet more, forgiveness of our sins

We rædað on bócum, þæt ðeos gehealdsumnys wurde arǽred on ðone timan ðe gelámp on anre byrig, ðe Uigenna is gecweden, micel eorð-styrung, and feollon cyrcan and hús, and comon wilde beran and wulfas, and abíton ðæs folces micelne dǽl, and þæs cynges botl wearð mid heofonlicum fyre forbærned
We read in books, that this observance was established at the time when there happened in a city, which is called Vienna, a great earthquake, and churches and houses fell, and there came wild bears and wolves, and devoured a large portion of the people, and the king's palace was burnt with heavenly fire

Þa bead se biscop Mamertus ðreora daga fæsten, and seo gedreccednys ða geswac
Then the bishop Mamertus commanded a fast of three days, and the affliction ceased

and se gewuna ðæs fæstenes ðurhwunað gehwær on geleaffulre gelaðunge
and the custom of the fast continues everywhere in the faithful church

Hí namon þa bysne ðæs fæstenys æt ðam Niniueiscan folce
They took the example of the fast from the people of Nineveh

Þæt folc wæs swiðe fyrenful: þa wolde God hí fordón, ac hí gegladodon hine mid heora behreowsunge
That people was very sinful: then would God destroy them, but they appeased him with their penitence

God spræc to anum wítegan, se wæs Ionas geháten
God spake to a prophet who was called Jonah

Far to ðære byrig Niniuen, and boda ðær ða word þe ic þe secge
Go to the city of Nineveh, and announce there the words which I say to thee

Þa wearð se wítega afyrht, and wolde forfleon Godes gesihðe, ac hé ne mihte
Then was the prophet afraid, and would flee from God's presence, but he could not

Ferde ða to sǽ, and stah on scip
He went to the sea, and entered a ship

Ðaða þa scypmen comon ut on sǽ, þa sende him God to micelne wind and hreohnysse, swa þæt hí wæron órwene heora lífes
When the shipmen came out to sea, God sent to them a great wind and tempest, so that they were hopeless of their lives

Hi ða wurpon heora waru oforbord, and se wítega læg and slép
They therefore cast their wares overboard, and the prophet lay and slept

Hi wurpon ða tán betweox him, and bædon þæt God sceolde geswutulian hwanon him þæt ungelimp become
They then cast lots among them, and prayed that God would manifest to them whence that affliction came upon them

Þa com ðæs wítegan tá upp
Then the prophet's lot came up

Hi axodon hine, Hwæt hé wære, oððe hú hé faran wolde
They asked him who he was, or how he would go

He cwæð, þæt hé wære Godes ðeow, seðe gesceop sǽ and lánd, and þæt hé fleon wolde of Godes gesihðe
He said that he was a servant of God, who created sea and land, and that he would flee from God's presence

Hí cwædon, Hú do we ymbe ðe
They said, How shall we do regarding thee

Hé andwyrde, Weorpað me oforbord, þonne geswicð þeos gedreccednys
He answered, Cast me overboard, then will this affliction cease

Hí ða swa dydon, and seo hreohnys wearð gestilled, and hí offrodon Gode heora lác, and tugon forð
They then did so, and the tempest was stilled, and they offered their gifts to God, and went on their course

God ða gegearcode ænne hwǽl, and hé forswealh þone wítegan, and abǽr hine to ðam lande þe he tó sceolde, and hine ðær út-aspáw
God then prepared a whale, and it swallowed up the prophet, and bare him to the land to which he should go, and there vomited him out

Þa com eft Godes wórd to ðam wítegan, and cwæð
Then again came the word of God to the prophet, and said

Arís nu, and ga to ðære mycelan byrig Niniuén, and boda swa swa ic ðe ær sæde
Arise now, and go to the great city Nineveh, and preach as I before said to thee

He ferde, and bodode, þæt him wæs Godes grama ónsigende, gif hí to Gode bugan noldon
He went and preached, that God's anger was about to descend on them, if they would not incline to God

Ða arás se cyning of his cynesetle, and awearp his deorwyrðe reaf, and dyde hæran to his lice, and axan uppan his heafod, and bead þæt ælc man swa dón sceolde
Then, the king arose from his throne, and cast off his precious robes, and put sackcloth on his body, and ashes upon his head, and commanded that every man should so do

and ægðer ge men ge ða sucendan cild and eac ða nytenu ne onbyrigdon nanes ðinges binnan ðrim dagum
and that both men and sucking children and also the cattle should not taste of anything within three days

Þa, ðurh þa gecyrrednysse, þæt hí yfeles geswicon, and ðurh þæt strange fæsten, him gemildsode God, and nolde hi fordón, swa swa he ǽr þa twa burhwara Sodomam and Gomorram, for heora leahtrum, mid heofonlicum fyre forbærnde
Then through that conversion, that they desisted from evil, and through that strict fast, God had mercy on them, and would not destroy them, as he had before, for their crimes, burnt the inhabitants of the two cities, Sodom and Gomorrah, with heavenly fire

We sceolon eac on ðissum dagum begán ure gebedu, and fyligan urum haligdome ut and inn, and ðone Ælmihtigan God mid geornfulnysse herian
We also on these days should offer up our prayers, and follow our relics out and in, and with fervour praise Almighty God

We wyllað nu þis godspel eow gereccan, þe her nu geræd wæs
We will now expound to you this gospel which has just been read

Quis uestrum habebit amicum
Quis vestrum habebit amicum

et reliqua
 et reliqua

Se Hælend cwæð to his leorning-cnihtum, Hwilc eower is þe hæfð sumne freond, and gæð him to on middere nihte, and cwyð
Jesus said to his disciples, Which of you who hath a friend, and goeth to him at midnight, and saith

 et reliqua
etc

Se halga Augustinus trahtnode þis godspel, and cwæð, þæt seo niht getacnode þa nytennysse þisre worulde
Saint Augustine expounded this gospel, and said, that the night betokened the ignorance of this world

Þeos woruld is afylled mid nytennysse
This world is filled with ignorance

Nu sceal forði gehwá arisan of ðære nytennysse, and gan to his frynd, þæt is, þæt he sceal gebugan to Criste mid ealre geornfulnysse, and biddan þæra ðreora hlafa, þæt is, geleafan þære Halgan Ðrynnysse
Now therefore should everyone arise from that ignorance, and go to his friend, that is, he should incline to Christ with all fervour, and pray for the three loaves, that is, belief in the Holy Trinity

Se Ælmihtiga Fæder is God, and his Sunu is Ælmihtig God, and se Halga Gast is Ælmihtig God
The Almighty Father is God, and his Son is Almighty God, and the Holy Ghost is Almighty God

na ðry Godas, ac hí ealle án Ælmihtig God untodæledlic
not three Gods, but they all one Almighty God indivisible

Þonne ðu becymst to ðisum ðrym hlafum, þæt is, to andgite ðære Halgan Ðrynnysse, þonne hæfst ðu on ðam geleafan líf and fódan ðinre sawle, and miht oðerne cuman eac mid ðam fedan, þæt is, ðu miht tæcan ðone geleafan oðrum frynd þe þe ðæs bitt
When thou comest to those three loaves, that is, to an understanding of the Holy Trinity, then hast thou, in that belief, life and food for thy soul, and mayest therewith feed another stranger also, that is, thou mayest teach the faith to another friend who shall ask it of thee

He cwæð, 'cuma,' forðan ðe we ealle sind cuman on ðisum life, and ure eard nis na her
He said a 'stranger,' because we are all strangers in this life, and our country is not here

ac we sind her swilce wegferende menn
but we are here as wayfaring men

án cymð, oðer færð
one comes, another goes

se bið acenned, se oðer forðfærð and rymð him setl
this is born, the other departs and yields up his seat to him

Nu sceal gehwá forði gewilnian þæs geleafan þære Halgan Ðrynnysse, forðan ðe se geleafa hine gebrincð to ðam ecan life
Now therefore should everyone desire faith in the Holy Trinity, for that faith will bring him to everlasting life

We wyllað eft embe ðone geleafan swiðor sprecan, forðan ðe ðises godspelles traht hæfð gódne tige
We will again speak more concerning faith, because the exposition of this gospel has a good deduction

Se hiredes ealdor, þe wæs on his reste gebroht mid his cildum, is Crist, þe sitt on heofonum mid his apostolum, and mid martyrum, and mid eallum þam halgum, þe he on ðisum life gefette
The master of the family, who was gone to rest with his children, is Christ, who sits in heaven with his apostles, and with martyrs, and with all the saints whom he fetched in this life

We sceolon clypigan to Criste, and biddan ðæra ðreora hlafa
We should call to Christ, and pray for the three loaves

Þeah hé ús þærrihte ne getiðige, ne sceole we forði þære bene geswican
Though he do not forthwith grant them to us, we should not on that account desist from prayer

He elcað, and wyle hwæðere forgyfan
He delays, and yet will give

Þi hé elcað, þæt we sceolon beon oflyste, and deorwyrðlice healdan Godes gife
He delays, that we may be desirous, and dearly hold the grace of God

Swa hwæt swa man eaðelice begyt, þæt ne bið na swa deorwyrðe swa þæt þæt earfoðlice bið begyten
Whatsoever a man gets easily is not so precious as that which is gotten with difficulty

Se Hælend cwæð
Jesus said

Gif he ðurhwunað cnucigende, þonne arist se hiredes ealdor, for ðæs oðres onhrope, and him getiðað þæs ðe he bitt, na for freondrædene, ac for his unstilnysse
If he continue knocking, the master of the family will arise, because of the other's importunity, and grant him what he asks, not for friendship, but for his clamour

Þi he cwæð
He said

Na for freondrædene
Not for friendship

forðan ðe nán man nære wyrðe ne þæs geleafan ne ðæs ecan lifes, gif Godes mildheortnys nære ðe mare ofer manncynne
because no man were worthy either of that faith, or of eternal life, if God's mercy were not the greater towards mankind

Nu sceole we cnucian, and hryman to Criste, forðan ðe hé wile us tiðian, swa swa he sylf cwæð
We should knock, and call to Christ, because he will give to us, as he himself said

Biddað, and eow bið forgifen
Ask, and it shall be given to you

secað, and ge gemetað
seek, and ye shall find

cnuciað, and eow bið geopenod
knock, and it shall be opened to you

Ælc ðæra ðe geornlice bitt, and þære bene ne geswicð, þam getiðað God þæs ecan lifes
To everyone who fervently asks, and ceases not from prayer, God will grant everlasting life

He cwæð þa oðer bigspel
He then said another parable

Hwilc fæder wile syllan his cilde stán, gif hit hine hlafes bitt
What father will give his child a stone, if he ask for bread

oþþe næddran, gif hit fisces bitt
or a serpent, if he ask for a fish

oððe þone wyrm ðrowend, gif hit æges bitt
or a scorpion, if he ask for an egg

God is ure Fæder þurh his mildheortnysse, and se fisc getacnað geleafan, and þæt æig ðone halgan hiht, se hláf ða soðan lufe
God is our Father through his mercy, and the fish betokens faith, and the egg holy hope, the bread true love

Þas ðreo ðing forgifð God his gecorenum
These three things God gives to his chosen

forðan ðe nan man ne mæg habban Godes rice, butan he hæbbe ðas ðreo ðing
