for no man can have God's kingdom, unless he have these three things

He sceal rihtlice gelyfan, and habban hiht to Gode, and soðe lufe to Gode and to mannum, gif he wile to Godes rice becuman
He must rightly believe, and have hope in God, and true love to God and to men, if he will come to God's kingdom

Se fisc getacnað geleafan, forðan ðe his gecynd is, swa hine swiðor ða yða wealcað, swa he strengra bið, and swiðor batað
The fish betokens faith, because its nature is, that the more it is tossed by the waves, the stronger it is, and the more vigorously it strikes

Swa eac se geleaffulla man, swa he swiðor bið geswenct for his geleafan, swa se geleafa strengra bið, þær ðær hé æltæwe bið
In like manner the believing man, the more he is afflicted for his faith, the stronger will be his faith, wherever it is sound

Gif hé abryð on ðære ehtnysse, he ne bið þonne geleafa, ac bið híwung
If it sink under persecution, it is then not faith, but is hypocrisy

Þæt æig getacnað hiht, forði ðe fugelas ne tymað swa swa oðre nytenu, ac ærest hit bið æig, and seo modor siððan mid hihte bret þæt æig to bridde
The egg betokens hope, seeing that birds teem not like other animals, but first it is an egg, and the mother then with hope cherishes the egg to a young bird

Swa eac ure hiht ne becom na gyt to ðam ðe he hopað, ac is swilce hé sy æig
In like manner our hope comes not yet to that which it hopes, but is, as it were, an egg

Þonne he hæfð þæt him behaten is, he bið fugel
When it has that which is promised it, it is a bird

Hláf getacnað þa soðan lufe, seo is ealra mægna mæst, swa swa se hláf bið ealra metta fyrmest
Bread betokens true love, which of all virtues is greatest, as bread is of all food the principal

Micel mægen is geleafa, and micel is se soða hiht
Faith is a great virtue, and a great virtue is true hope

þeah-hwæðere seo lufu hi oferswið, forðan ðe heo bið á on ecnysse, and ða oðre twa geendiað
yet love excels them, forasmuch as it is ever to eternity, and the other two will end

We gelyfað nu on God, and we hopiað to him: eft þonne we becumað to his ríce, swa swa he us behet, þonne bið se geleafa geendod, forðan ðe we geseoð þonne þæt we nu gelyfað
We now believe in God, and we hope in him: but after we come to his kingdom, as he has promised us, then will faith be ended, for we shall then see what we now believe

Ure hiht bið eac geendod, forðan ðe we beoð hæbbende ðæs ðe we ær hopedon
Our hope will also be ended, because we shall be in possession of what we had previously hoped for

ac seo lufu ne ateorað næfre: nu is heo forði heora selest
but love will never decay: therefore is it the most excellent of them

Seo næddre is geset on ðam godspelle ongean ðone fisc
The serpent is placed in the gospel in opposition to the fish

On næddran híwe beswác se deofol Adam
In a serpent's form the devil deceived Adam

and æfre hé winð nu ongean urne geleafan: ac seo gescyldnys is æt urum Fæder gelang
and he is now ever striving against our faith: but our protection is in the hand of our Father

Se wyrm ðrowend, þe is geset ongean þæt æig, is ættren, and slihð mid þam tægle to deaðe
The scorpion, which is set in opposition to the egg, is venomous, and stings with its tail to death

Þa ðing ðe we geseoð on ðisum lífe, ða sind ateorigendlice
Those things which we see in this life are perishable

þa ðe we ne geseoð, and us sind behátene, hi sind éce: strece ðærto þinne hiht, and anbida oðþæt ðu hi hæbbe
those which we see not, and which are promised to us are eternal: stretch thereto thy hope, and wait until thou have them

Ne loca ðu underbæc
Look not behind

ondræd þe ðone ðrowend þe geǽttrað mid þam tægle
dread the scorpion which envenoms with its tail

Se man locað underbæc, þe geortruwað Godes mildheortnysse
The man looks behind, who despairs of God's mercy

þonne bið his hiht geættrod mid þæs ðrowendes tægle
then is his hope envenomed by the scorpion's tail

Ac we sceolon æigðer ge on earfoðnyssum, ge on gelimpe and on ungelimpe, cweðan, swa swa se witega cwæð
But we should both in difficulties, and in chances and in mischances, say as the prophet said

Ic herige minne Drihten on ælcne tíman
I will praise the Lord at every time

Getimige ús tela on lichaman, getimige ús untela, symle we sceolon þæs Gode ðancian, and his naman bletsian
Betide us good in body, betide us evil, we ought ever to thank God, and bless his name

þonne bið ure hiht gehealden wið þæs wyrmes slege
then will our hope be preserved from the scorpion's sting

Stán is gesett ongean ðone hláf, forðan ðe heardmodnys is wiðerræde soðre lufe
A stone is set in opposition to bread, because hardness of mind is contrary to true love

Heardheort bið se mann, ðe nele þurh lufe oðrum fremigan, þær ðær hé mæg
Hardhearted is the man who will not through love promote the welfare of others where he can

Þæt godspel cwæð
The gospel says

Gif ge cunnon, þa ðe yfele sind, syllan ða gódnysse eowrum bearnum, hu micele swiðor wile eower Heofonlica Fæder forgyfan gódne gast him biddendum
If ye can, who are evil, give to your children what is good, how much more will your Heavenly Father give a good spirit to those asking him

Hwæt sind ða gód þe men syllað heora cildum
What are the good things that men give to their children

Hwilwendlice gódnyssa, swylce swa þæt godspel hrepode, hláf, and fisc, and æig
Transitory goods, such as the gospel touched on, bread, and fish, and an egg

Góde sind þas ðing be heora mæðe, forðan ðe se eorðlica lichama behofað þæs fodan
These things are good in their degree, because the earthly body requires food

Nu ge, gleawe men, nellað syllan eowrum cildum næddran for fisce, nele eac ure Heofonlica Fæder us syllan þæs deofles geleaflæste, gif we hine biddað þæt he ús sylle soðne geleafan
Now ye, prudent men, will not give your children a serpent for a fish, nor also will your Heavenly Father give us the devil's unbelief, if we pray to him to give us true faith

And ðu nelt syllan ðinum bearne þrowend for ǽge, nele eac God us syllan orwenysse for hihte
And thou wilt not give thy child a scorpion for an egg, nor also will God give us despair for hope

And ðu nelt ðinum bearne syllan stán for hláfe, nele eac God us syllan heardheortnysse for soðre lufe
And thou wilt not give thy child a stone for bread, nor also will God give us hardheartedness for true love

Ac se goda Heofonlica Fæder forgifð us geleafan, and hiht, and ða soðan lufe, and deð þæt we habbað gódne gast, þæt is, gódne willan
But the good Heavenly Father will give us faith, and hope, and true love, and will cause us to have a good spirit, that is, good will

Us is to smeagenne þæt word þe he cwæð
We have to consider the words which he said

Ge ðe sind yfele
Ye who are evil

Yfele we sind, ac we habbað gódne Fæder
We are evil, but we have a good Father

We habbað gehyred urne naman
We have heard our name

Ge ðe synt yfele
Ye who are evil

Ac hwá is ure Fæder
But who is our Father

Se Ælmihtiga God
The Almighty God

And hwilcera manna Fæder is he
And of what men is he the Father

Swutelice hit is gesǽd, yfelra manna
It is manifestly said, of evil men

And hwilc is se Fæder
And of what kind is the Father

Be ðam þe is gecweden
Of whom it is said

Nis nan man gód butan Gode anum
No one is good save God only

Se ðe æfre is gód, he brincð us yfele to gódum mannum, gif we bugað fram yfele, and doð gód
He who ever is good will bring us who are evil to be good men, if we will eschew evil and do good

Gód wæs se man gesceapen Adam, ac ðurh his agenne cyre, and deofles tihtinge, he wearð yfel, and eal his ofspring
The man Adam was created good, but by his own election and the instigation of the devil, he and all his offspring became evil

Se ðe synful bið, he bið yfel, and nán man nis on lífe butan sumere synne
He who is sinful is evil, and there is no man in life without some sin

Ac ure góda Fæder us geclænsað and gehælð, swa swa se witega cwæð
But our good Father will cleanse and heal us, as the prophet said

Drihten, gehæl me, and ic beo gehæled
Lord, heal me, and I shall be healed

geheald þu me, and ic beo gehealden
preserve thou me, and I shall be preserved

Se ðe gód beon wile, clypige to ðam þe æfre is gód, þæt he hine gódne gewyrce
Let him who desires to be good call to him who ever is good, that he make him good

Se man hæfð gold, þæt is gód be his mæðe: he hæfð land and welan, þa sint góde
A man has gold, that is good in its kind: he has land and riches, they are good

Ac ne bið se man gód þurh ðas ðing, butan he mid þam gód wyrce, swa swa se witega cwæð
But the man is not good through these things, unless he do good with them, as the prophet said

He aspende his ðing, and todælde ðearfum, and his rihtwisnys wunað á on worulde
He distributed his wealth, and divided it among the poor, and his righteousness continueth for ever

He gewanode his feoh and geihte his rihtwisnysse
He diminished his money, and increased his righteousness

He gewanode þæt he forlætan sceal, and þæt bið geiht þæt þæt he habban sceal on ecnysse
He diminished that which he must leave, and that will be increased which he shall have to eternity

Þu herast ðone mancgere ðe begytt gold mid leade, and nelt herigan ðone ðe begytt rihtwisnysse and heofonan rice mid brosnigendlicum feo
Thou praisest the merchant who gets gold for lead, and wilt not praise him who gets righteousness and the kingdom of heaven for perishable money

Se ríca and se ðearfa sind wegferende on ðisre worulde
The rich and the poor are wayfarers in this world

Nu berð se ríca swære byrðene his gestreona, and se ðearfa gæð æmtig
The rich now bears the heavy burthen of his treasures, and the poor goes empty

Se ríca berð mare þonne he behófige to his formettum, se oðer berð æmtigne pusan
The rich bears more provisions for his journey than he requires, the other bears an empty scrip

Forði sceal se ríca dælan his byrðene wið þone ðearfan, þonne wanað he ða byrðene his synna, and ðam þearfan gehelpð
Therefore should the rich share his burthen with the poor

Ealle we sind Godes þearfan
then will he lessen the burthen of his sins, and help the poor

uton forði oncnawan þa ðearfan þe us biddað, þæt God oncnawe us, þonne we hine biddað ure neoda
We are all God's poor

Hwæt sind þa ðe us biddað
let us therefore acknowledge the poor who ask of us, that God may acknowledge us, when we ask our needs of him

Earme men, and tiddre, and deadlice
Who are those that ask of us

Æt hwam biddað hí
Men poor, and feeble, and mortal

Æt earmum mannum, and tiddrum, and deadlicum
Of whom ask they

Butan þam æhtum, gelice sind þa þe ðær biddað, and ðaðe hí ætbiddað
Of men poor, and feeble, and mortal

Hú mihtu for sceame æniges ðinges æt Gode biddan, gif ðu forwyrnst ðinum gelícan þæs ðe ðu foreaðelice him getiðian miht
Except the possessions, alike are those who ask and those of whom they ask

Ac se ríca besihð on his pællenum gyrlum, and cwyð, 'Nis se loddere mid his tættecon mín gelíca
How canst thou for shame ask anything of God, if thou refuse to thy fellow that which thou canst most easily grant him

' Ac se apostol Paulus hine nebbað mid þisum wordum
But the rich looks on his purple garments, and says, 'The wretch with his rags is not my fellow

Ne brohte we nán ðing to ðisum middangearde, ne we nán ðing heonon mid ús lædan ne magon
' But the apostle Paul beards him with these words

Gif ríce wíf, and earm acennað togædere, gangon hí aweig
If a rich woman, and a poor one bring forth together, let them go away

nast ðu hwæðer bið þæs rícan wífan cild, hwæðer þæs earman
thou knowest not which is the rich woman's child, which the poor one's

Eft, gif man openað deaddra manna byrgynu, nast ðu hwæðer beoð þæs rícan mannes bán, hwæðer þæs ðearfan
Again, if we open the graves of dead men, thou knowest not which are the rich man's bones, which the poor one's

Ac seo gytsung is ealra yfelra ðinga wyrtruma
But covetousness is of all evil things the root, and those who follow covetousness swerve from God's faith, and fall into divers temptations, and pernicious lusts, which sink them into perdition

and þa ðe fyligað þære gytsunge, hí dweliað fram Godes geleafan, and hi befeallað on mislice costnunga and derigendlice lustas, ðe hi besencað on forwyrd
It is one thing, that a man be rich, if his parents have bequeathed him possessions

Oðer is þæt hwá ríce beo, gif his yldran him æhta becwædon
another thing, if any one become rich through covetousness

oðer is, gif hwá þurh gytsunge ríce gewurðe
The covetousness of the latter is accused before God, not the other's wealth, if his heart be not inflamed with covetousness

Þises mannes gytsung is gewreht wið God, na ðæs oðres æht, gif his heorte ne bið ontend mid þære gytsunge
For such men the apostle Paul enjoined

Swilcum mannum bebead se apostol Paulus
Enjoin the rich that they be not proud, and that they hope not in their uncertain wealth

Bebeodað þam ricum þæt hí ne modigan, ne hí ne hópian on heora ungewissum welan
but let them be rich in good works, and give to God's poor with bountiful spirit, and God will requite them an hundredfold for whatsoever they do for the poor for love of him

Se ríca and se þearfa sind him betwynan nyd-behefe
The rich and the poor are needful to each other

Se welega is geworht for ðan ðearfan, and se ðearfa for þan welegan
The wealthy is made for the poor, and the poor for the wealthy

Þam spedigum gedafenað þæt he spende and dæle
It is incumbent on the affluent, that he scatter and distribute

ðam wædlan gedafenað þæt he gebidde for ðane dælere
on the indigent it is incumbent, that he pray for the distributor

Se earma is se weg þe læt us to Godes rice
The poor is the way that leads us to the kingdom of God

Mare sylð se ðearfa þam rícan þonne he æt him nime
The poor gives to the rich more than he receives from him

Se ríca him sylð þone hláf ðe bið to meoxe awend, and se ðearfa sylð þam rícan þæt éce líf: na hé swa-ðeah, ac Crist, seðe þus cwæð
The rich gives him bread that will be turned to ordure, and the poor gives to the rich everlasting life: yet not he, but Christ, who thus said

Þæt þæt ge doð anum ðearfan on mínum naman, þæt ge doð me sylfum
That which ye do for the poor in my name, that ye do for myself

seðe leofað and rixað mid Fæder and mid Halgum Gaste á butan ende
who liveth and reigneth with the Father and the Holy Ghost ever without end

Amen
Amen

Se Hælend Crist, syððan he to ðisum life cóm, and man wearð geweaxen, þaða hé wæs ðritig wintra eald on þære menniscnysse, þa begánn he wundra to wyrcenne, and geceas ða twelf leorning-cnihtas, þa ðe we apostolas hatað
Jesus Christ, after he came to this life, and was grown to manhood, when he was thirty years old in his human nature, began to work miracles, and chose the twelve disciples whom we call apostles

Þa wæron mid him æfre syððan, and he him tæhte ealne þone wisdom ðe on halgum bocum stent, and þurh hí ealne cristendom astealde
These were afterwards always with him, and he taught them all the wisdom which stands in holy books, and through them established all christianity

Þa cwædon hi to ðam Hælende
Then said they to Jesus

Léóf, tæce ús hu we magon us gebiddan
Sir, teach us how we may pray

Ða andwyrde se Hælend, and þus cwæð
Jesus answered, and thus said

Gebiddað eow mid þisum wordum to minum Fæder and to eowrum Fæder, Gode Ælmihtigum: Pater noster, þæt is on Englisc, Þu, ure Fæder, þe eart on heofonum, Sy þín nama gehalgod
Pray in these words to my Father and your Father, God Almighty: Pater noster, that is in English, Thou, our Father, which art in heaven, hallowed be thy name

Cume ðín ríce
Thy kingdom come

Sy ðín wylla on eorðan swa swa on heofonum
Be thy will on earth as in heaven

Syle ús to-dæg urne dæghwamlican hláf
Give us to-day our daily bread

And forgyf us ure gyltas, swa swa we forgyfað ðam þe wið us agyltað
And forgive us our trespasses as we forgive them who trespass against us

And ne lǽd ðu na us on costnunge
And lead thou us not into temptation

Ac alys us fram yfele
But deliver us from evil

Sy hit swa
So be it

God Fæder Ælmihtig hæfð ænne Sunu gecyndelice and menige gewiscendlice
God, the Father Almighty, has one Son naturally, and many adoptively

Crist is Godes Sunu, swa þæt se Fæder hine gestrynde of him sylfum, butan ælcere meder
Christ is the Son of God, seeing that the Father begot him of himself without any mother

Næfð se Fæder nænne lichaman, ne he on ða wisan his Bearn ne gestrynde þe menn doð: ac his Wisdom, þe hé mid ealle gesceafta geworhte, se is his Sunu, se is æfre of ðam Fæder, and mid þam Fæder, God of Gode, ealswa mihtig swa se Fæder
The Father has no body, nor begot he his Son in that wise which men do: but his Wisdom, with which he wrought all creatures, is his Son, who is ever of the Father and with the Father, God of God, as mighty as the Father

We men sind Godes bearn, forðon þe hé us geworhte
We men are children of God, because he made us

and eft, ðaða we forwyrhte wæron, he sende his agen Bearn us to alysednysse
and afterwards, when we were undone, he sent his own Son for our redemption

Nu sind we Godes bearn, and Crist is ure broðer, gif we ðam Fæder onriht gehyrsumiað, and mid eallum mode hine weorðiað
Now are we children of God, and Christ is our brother, if we will duly obey the Father, and with all our mind worship him

Crist is ure heafod, and we sind his lima: he is mid ure menniscnysse befangen, and he hæfð urne lichaman, þone ðe hé of ðam halgan mædene Marían genam
Christ is our head, and we are his limbs: he is invested with our humanity, and he has our body, which he received of the holy maiden Mary

forði we magon cuðlice to him clypian, swa swa to urum breðer, gif we ða broðerrædene swa healdað swa swa he us tæhte
therefore may we manifestly cry to him, as to our brother, if we so observe our brotherhood as he has taught us

þæt is, þæt we ne sceolon na geðafian þæt deofol mid ænigum unðeawum us gewéme fram Cristes broðorrædene
that is, that we should not allow the devil with any evil practices to seduce us from the brotherhood of Christ

Witodlice se man þe deofle geefenlæcð, se bið deofles bearn, na þurh gecynd oððe þurh gesceapenysse, ac ðurh þa geefenlæcunge and yfele geearnunga
Verily the man who imitates the devil is a child of the devil, not by nature nor by creation, but by that imitation and evil deserts

And se man ðe Gode gecwemð, he bið Godes bearn, na gecyndelice, ac þurh gesceapenysse and ðurh gode geearnunga, swa swa Crist cwæð on his godspelle
And the man who makes himself acceptable to God is a child of God, not naturally, but by creation and by good deserts, as Christ said in his gospel

Se ðe wyrcð mines Fæder willan seðe is on heofonum, he bið min broðer, and min moder, and min sweoster
He who doeth the will of my Father who is in heaven, he is my brother, and my mother, and my sister

Forði nu ealle cristene men, ægðer ge ríce ge heane, ge æðelborene ge unæðelborene, and se hlaford, and se ðeowa, ealle hí sind gebroðra, and ealle hí habbað ænne Fæder on heofonum
Now therefore all christian men, whether high or low, noble or ignoble, and the lord, and the slave, are all brothers, and have all one Father in heaven

Nis se welega na betera on ðisum naman þonne se ðearfa
The wealthy is not better on that account than the needy

Eallswa bealdlice mót se ðeowa clypigan God him to Fæder ealswa se cyning
As boldly may the slave call God his Father as the king

Ealle we sind gelice ætforan Gode, buton hwá oðerne mid godum weorcum forðeo
We all are alike before God, unless any one excel another in good works

Ne sceal se ríca for his welan þone earman forseón
The rich for his wealth is not to despise the poor

forðan oft bið se earma betera ætforan Gode þonne se ríca
for the poor is before God often better than the rich

God is ure Fæder, þi we sceolon ealle beon gebroðru on Gode, and healdan þone broðerlican bend unforedne
God is our Father, therefore should we all be brothers in God, and hold the brotherly bond unbroken

þæt is, ða soðan sibbe, swa þæt ure ælc oðerne lufige swa swa hine sylfne, and nanum ne gebeode þæt þæt he nelle þæt man him gebeode
that is, true peace, so that each of us love other as himself, and command to no one that which he would not another should command to him

Se ðe ðis hylt, he bið Godes bearn, and Crist, and ealle halige men ðe Gode geðeoð, beoð his gebroðru and his gesweostru
He who observes this is a child of God, and Christ, and all holy persons who thrive to God, are his brothers and his sisters

We cweðað
We say

Pater noster qui es in celis
Pater noster qui es in cœlis

þæt is
that is

Ure Fæder ðe eart on heofonum
Our Father which art in heaven

forðan þe God Fæder is on heofonum, and he is æghwar, swa swa he sylf cwæð
for God the Father is in heaven, and he is everywhere, as he himself said

Ic gefylle mid me sylfum heofonas and eorðan
I fill with myself heaven and earth

And eft þæt halige godspel be him þus cwyð
And again, the holy gospel says thus concerning him

Heofon is his þrymsetl, and eorðe is his fot-sceamul
Heaven is his throne, and earth is his footstool

We wendað ús eastweard þonne we us gebiddað, forðan ðe ðanon arist seo heofen: na swilce on east-dæle synderlice sy his wunung, and forlæte west-dæl, oððe oðre dælas, se þe æghwar is andweard, na ðurh rymyt þære stowe, ac þurh his mægenðrymmes andweardnysse
We turn eastward when we pray, because from thence the heaven rises

Þonne we wendað ure neb to east-dæle, þær seo heofen arist, seoðe is ealra lichomlicra ðinga oferstigende, þonne sceal ure mód beon mid þam gemyngod, þæt hit beo gewend to ðam hehstan and þam fyrmestan gecynde, þæt is, God
not as though his dwelling be particularly in the east part, and that he forsakes the west or other parts, who is everywhere present, not through the space of the place, but by the presence of his majesty

We sceolon eac witan, þæt se synfulla is eorðe geháten, and se rihtwisa is heofen geháten
When we turn our face to the east part, where the heaven rises, which rises over all bodily things, then should our mind be thereby admonished that it turn to the highest and first nature, that is, God

forðan þe on rihtwisum mannum is Godes wunung, and se goda man bið þæs Halgan Gastes templ
We should also know that the sinful is called earth, and the righteous is called heaven

Swa eac ðær-togeanes se fordóna man bið deofles templ, and deofles wunung: forði þonne swa micel is betwux gódum mannum and yfelum, swa micel swa bið betwux heofenan and eorðan
for in righteous men is a dwelling-place of God, and the good man is a temple of the Holy Ghost

Seofon gebédu sint on þam Pater noster
In the Pater noster are seven prayers

On þam twam formum wordum ne synd nane gebedu, ac sind herunga: þæt is
In the first two words are no prayers, but praises: that is

Ure Fæder þe eart on heofonum
Our Father which art in heaven

Þæt forme gebéd is
The first prayer is

Sanctificetur nomen tuum
Sanctificetur nomen tuum

þæt is
that is

Sy ðin nama gehalgod
Hallowed be thy name

Nis þæt na swá to understandenne, swylce Godes nama ne sy genoh halig, seðe æfre wæs halig, and æfre bið, and hé us ealle gebletsað and gehalgað: ac þis word is swá to understandenne, þæt his nama sy on us gehalgod, and he us þæs getiðige, þæt we moton his naman mid urum muðe gebletsian, and he us sylle þæt geðánc, þæt we magon understandan þæt nan ðing nis swa halig swa his nama
This is not to be so understood as if the name of God were not sufficiently holy, who ever was holy, and ever will be, and who blesses and hallows us all: but these words are thus to be understood, that his name be hallowed in us, and that he grant us that we may bless his name with our mouth, and give us the thought that we may understand that nothing is so holy as his name

Þæt oðer gebéd is
The second prayer is

Adueniat regnum tuum
Adveniat regnum tuum

þæt is, on urum gereorde
that is, in our tongue

Cume ðin ríce
Thy kingdom come

Æfre wæs Godes ríce, and æfre bið: ac hit is swá to understandenne, þæt his ríce beo ofer ús, and he on us rixige, and we him mid ealre gehyrsumnysse underþeodde syn, and þæt ure ríce beo us gelǽst and gefylled, swa swa Crist us behét, þæt he wolde ús éce ríce forgyfan, þus cweðende
Ever was God's kingdom, and ever will be: but it is so to be understood, that his kingdom be over us, and he reign in us, and that we with all obedience be subject to him, and that our kingdom be realized and fulfilled to us, as Christ has promised to us, that he would give us an eternal kingdom, thus saying

Cumað, ge gebletsode mines Fæder, and gehabbað þæt ríce þæt eow gegearcod wæs fram anginne middangeardes
Come, ye blessed of my Father, and possess the kingdom that was prepared for you from the beginning of the world

Þis bið ure ríce, gif we hit nu geearniað
This will be our kingdom, if we now will merit it

and we beoð Godes ríce, þonne Crist ús betæcð his Fæder on domes dæge, swa swa þæt hálige gewrit cwyð
and we shall be God's kingdom, when Christ delivers us to his Father on doomsday, as the holy writ says

Cum tradiderit regnum Patri suo
Cum tradiderit regnum Patri suo

þæt is
that is

Þonne hé betæcð ríce his Fæder
When he shall deliver the kingdom to his Father

Hwæt is þæt ríce þæt hé betæcð his Fæder, buton ða halgan menn, ægðer ge weras ge wíf, þa þe hé alysde fram helle-wíte mid his agenum deaðe
What is the kingdom that he shall deliver to his Father, but those holy persons, both men and women, which he redeemed from hell-torment by his own death

Þa he betæcð his agenum Fæder on ende þisre worulde, and hí beoð þonne Godes ríce, and mid Gode on ecnysse rixiað, ægðer ge mid sawle ge mid lichaman, and beoð þonne gelice englum
These he will deliver to his own Father at the end of this world, and they will then be God's kingdom, and will reign with God for ever, both with soul and with body, and will then be like unto angels

Þæt ðridde gebéd is
The third prayer is

Fiat uoluntas tua sicut in celo et in terra
Fiat voluntas tua sicut in cœlo et in terra

þæt is
that is

Geweorðe þín willa on eorðan swa swa on heofonum
Thy will be done on earth as in heaven

Þæt is, Swa swa englas on heofonum þe gehyrsumiað, and mid eallum gemete to ðe geðeodað, swa eac menn þe on eorðan sind, and of eorðan geworhte, beon hí ðinum willan gehyrsume, and to ðe mid ealre geornfulnysse geðeodan
That is, As the angels in heaven obey thee, and in every way attach themselves to thee, so also may men, who are on earth and formed of earth, be obedient to thy will, and with all fervour attach themselves to thee

On þam mannum soðlice gewyrð Godes willa, þe to Godes willan gewyrceað
In those men verily God's will is done, who work according to God's will

Ure sawul is heofonlic, and ure lichama is eorðlic
Our soul is heavenly, and our body is earthly

Nu bidde we eac mid þisum wordum, þæt Godes willa geweorðe, ægðer ge on ure sawle ge on urum lichaman, þæt ægðer him gehyrsumige, and he ægðer gehealde and gescylde, ge ure sawle ge urne lichaman, fram deofles costnungum
Now, with these words, we also pray that God's will be done both in our soul and in our body, that both may obey him, and that he may preserve and shield both our soul and our body from the temptations of the devil

Þæt feorðe gebéd is
The fourth prayer is

Panem nostrum cotidianum da nobis hodie
Panem nostrum quotidianum da nobis hodie

þæt is, on urum gereorde
that is, in our tongue

Syle us nu to-dæg urne dæghwamlican hláf
Give us to-day our daily bread

Þæt is on ðrim andgitum to understandenne: þæt hé us sylle fodan urum lichaman, and sylle eac ure sawle þone gastlican hláf
This is to be understood in three senses: that he give us food for our body, and give ghostly bread to our soul

Se gastlica hláf is Godes bebod, þæt we sceolon smeagan dæghwamlice, and mid weorce gefyllan
The ghostly bread is the commandment of God, on which we should daily meditate, and with works fulfil

forðan swa swa se lichama leofað be lichamlicum mettum, swa sceal seo sawul lybban be Godes láre, and be gastlicum smeagungum
for as the body lives by bodily meats, so shall the soul live by the precepts of God, and by ghostly meditations

Hraðe se lichama aswint and forweornað, gif him bið oftogen his bigleofa: swa eac seo sawul forwyrð, gif heo næfð þone gastlican bigleofan, þæt sind Godes beboda, on þam heo sceal geðeon and beon gegódad
The body quickly wastes away and decays, if its sustenance is withdrawn from it

Eac se gastlica hláf is þæt halige husel, mid þam we getrymmað urne geleafan
in like manner the soul perishes, if it has not ghostly sustenance, that is, God's commandments, on which it shall thrive and be cherished

and ðurh ðæs halgan husles þýgene ús beoð ure synna forgyfene, and we beoð gestrangode ongean deofles costnunge
The ghostly bread is also the holy housel, with which we confirm our belief

Þi we sceolon gelomlice mid þam gastlican gereorde ure sawle geclænsian and getrymman
and through partaking of the holy housel our sins will be forgiven us, and we shall be strengthened against the temptations of the devil

Ne sceal þeah se ðe bið mid healicum synnum fordón, gedyrstlæcan þæt he Godes husel þicge, buton he his synna ær gebete: gif he elles deð, hit bið him sylfum to bealowe geðyged
Therefore should we frequently cleanse and confirm our soul with ghostly refection

Se hláf getacnað ðreo ðing, swa swa we cwædon
Yet may not he who is polluted with deadly sins dare to partake of God's housel, unless he first atone for his sins: if he do otherwise, he will partake of it to his own injury

An is þæs lichaman bígleofa
The bread, as we said, betokens three things

oðer is ðære sawle
One is sustenance of the body

ðridde is þæs halgan husles ðygen
the second, of the soul

Þyssera ðreora ðinga we sceolon dæghwamlice æt urum Drihtne biddan
the third is the partaking of the holy housel

Þæt fifte gebéd is
The fifth prayer is

Et dimitte nobis debita nostra, sicut et nos dimittimus debitoribus nostris
Et dimitte nobis debita nostra, sicut et nos dimittimus debitoribus nostris

þæt is
that is

Forgif us ure gyltas, swa swa we forgifað þam mannum þe wið us agyltað
Forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive those men who trespass against us

We sceolon dón swa swa we on ðisum wordum behatað
We should do as we promise in these words, that is, we should be merciful to each other, and, for the great love of God, forgive those men who trespass against us, that God Almighty may forgive us our sins

þæt is, þæt we beon mildheorte us betwynan, and, for ðære micclan lufe Godes, forgyfan ðam mannum þe wið us agyltað, þæt God Ælmihtig forgyfe us ure synna
But if we will not forgive the little trespasses of those men who have angered us, then will not God forgive us our great and many sins: as Christ himself said

Gif we ðonne nellað forgyfan þa lytlan gyltas ðæra manna þe us gegremedon, þone nele eac God us forgyfan ure synna mycele and manega: swa swa Crist sylf cwæð
When ye stand at your prayers, forgive whatever ye have in your mind against any man, and your Father, which is in heaven, will forgive you your sins

Þonne ge standað on eowrum gebédum, forgyfað swa hwæt swa ge habbað on eowrum mode to ænigum men, and eower Fæder, þe on heofonum is, forgyfð eow eowre synna
But if ye will not, with inward heart, forgive those who anger you, then your Father, which is in heaven, will not forgive you your sins

Gif ge þonne nellað forgyfan mid inweardre heortan þam ðe eow gremiað, þonne eac eower Fæder, ðe on heofonum is, nele eow forgyfan eowre synna
but he will command you to be bound and set in prison, that is, in hell-torment

ac he hæt eow gebindan, and on cwearterne settan, þæt is on helle-wíte
and there the devil will torture you, until ye shall have suffered for all your trespasses, until ye come to one farthing

Þæt sixte gebéd is
The sixth prayer is

Et ne nos inducas in temptationem
Et ne nos inducas in tentationem

þæt is
that is

Ne geðafa, ðu God, þæt we beon gelædde on costnunge
Permit not, thou, O God, that we be led into temptation

Oðer is costnung, oðer is fandung
One thing is temptation, another thing is trial

God ne costnað nænne mannan
God tempts no man, but, nevertheless, no man comes to the kingdom of God, unless he has been tried: therefore we should not pray that God try us not, but we should pray to God to shield us, so that we sink not under trial

ac hwæðere nán man ne cymð to Godes ríce, buton he sy afandod: forði ne sceole we na biddan þæt God ure ne afandige, ac we sceolon biddan þæt God us gescylde, þæt we ne abreoðon on ðære fandunge
The devil may try every man, whether he be aught or naught

Deofol mót ælces mannes afandigan, hwæðer he aht sy, oððe naht
whether he love God with inward heart, or act with hypocrisy

hwæðer he God mid inweardlicre heortan lufige, oððe he mid híwunge fáre
As a man tries gold in the fire, so God tries the mind of man in divers trials, whether he be steadfast

Swa swa man afandað gold on fyre, swa afandað God þæs mannes mod on mislicum fandungum, hwæðer hé ánræde sy
God knows full well, how it befalls in trial

Genoh wel wát God hu hit getimað on þære fandunge
but yet a man will have no great honour, unless he have been tried

ac hwæðere se man næfð na mycele geðincðe, buton he afandod sy
By trial he shall flourish, if he withstand temptations

Þurh ða fandunge he sceal geðeon, gif he þam costnungum wiðstent
If he fall, let him rise again: that is, if he sin, let him earnestly atone for it, and cease therefrom afterwards

Gif he fealle, he eft astande: þæt is, gif he agylte, he hit georne gebete, and syððan geswíce
for no atonement will avail, if there be not cessation

forði ne bið nán bót naht, buton þær beo geswicenes
The man who frequently sins and frequently atones, angers God

Se man þe gelomlice wile syngian, and gelomlice betan, he gremað God
and the more he sins the more he will be subject to the devil, and God will then forsake him, and he will go as the devil shall direct him, as a shattered ship at sea, which goes as the wind drives it

and swa he swiðor syngað swa he deofle gewyldra bið, and hine þonne God forlæt, and he færð swa him deofol wissað, swa swa tobrocen scíp on sǽ, þe swa færð swa hit se wind drifð
The good man the more he is tried the more cheerful he will be, and the nearer to God, until with full honour he shall go from this life to the life eternal

Se goda man swa he swiðor afandod bið swa he rotra bið, and near Gode, oðþæt hé mid fulre geðincðe færð of ðisum life to ðam ecan life
And the evil man, the oftener he sinks under trial, the more wicked he will be, and the nearer to the devil, until he goes from this life to eternal torment, if he would not cease previously, when he could and might

And se yfela swa he oftor on ðære fandunge abryð, swa he forcuðra bið, and deofle near, oðþæt he færð of ðisum life to ðam ecan wite, gif he ær geswican nolde, þaþa he mihte and moste
God therefore often awaits the evil man, and leaves him time, that he may cease from his wicked deeds, and before his end turn his mind to God, if he will

Forði anbidað God oft þæs yfelan mannes, and læt him fyrst, þæt he his mándæda geswice, and his mód to Gode gecyrre ær his ende, gif he wile
But if he will not, that he be, without any exculpation, very justly be thrust into the hand of the devil

Gif he þonne nele, þæt he beo butan ælcere ladunge swiðe rihtlice to deofles handa asceofen
Therefore is it now better for christian men, that with hardships and toil they earn the everlasting kingdom and eternal bliss with God and with all his saints, than that they by softness and evil lusts earn eternal tortures with all the devils in hell-torment

Þæt seofoðe gebéd is
The seventh prayer is

Set libera nos a malo
Sed libera nos a malo

þæt is
that is

Ac alys us fram yfele
But deliver us from evil

alys us fram deofle and fram eallum his syrwungum
deliver us from the devil and from all his wiles

God lufað us, and deofol us hatað
God loves us, and the devil hates us

God us fett and gefrefrað, and deofol us wile ofslean, gif he mót
God feeds and comforts us, and the devil will slay us if he may

ac him bið forwyrned þurh Godes gescyldnysse, gif we us sylfe nellað fordón mid unðeawum
but he will be prevented through the protection of God, if we will not fordo ourselves with evil practices

Forði we sceolon forbugan and forseon þone lyðran deoful mid eallum his lotwrencum, forðan ðe him ne gebyrað naht to ús, and we sceolon lufian and filigan urum Drihtne, seðe us lǽt to ðam ecan life
Therefore should we eschew and despise the vicious devil with all his devices, for there behoves him nothing for us, and we should love and follow our Lord, who will lead us to everlasting life

Seofon gebédu, swa swa we ær sædon, beoð on ðam Pater noster
In the Pater noster there are, as we before said, seven prayers

Þa ðreo forman gebédu beoð us ongunnene on ðysre worulde, ac hí beoð á ungeendode on þære toweardan worulde
The first three prayers are begun by us in this world, but they will ever be unended in the world to come

Seo halgung þæs mæran naman Godes ongann ús mannum þaþa Crist wearð geflæschamod mid ure menniscnysse
The hallowing of the great name of God began with us men when Christ became incarnate with our humanity

ac seo ylce halgung wunað on ecnysse, forðan ðe we on ðam ecan life bletsiað and herigað æfre Godes naman
but the same hallowing will continue to eternity, because in the life eternal we shall ever bless and praise the name of God

And God rixað nu, and his ríce stent æfre butan ende, and Godes willa bið gefremod on ðisum life ðurh góde menn: se ylca willa wunað á on ecnysse
And God reigns now, and his kingdom stands for ever, without end, and the will of God will be fulfilled in this life by good men: the same will will continue to all eternity

Þa oðre feower gebédu belimpað to ðisum life, and mid þisum life geendiað
The other four prayers belong to this life, and with this life end

On ðisum lífe we behófiað hláfes, and láre, and husel-ganges
In the life to come we require no earthly food, for we shall then be nourished with heavenly meats

On þam toweardan lífe we ne behófiað nanes eorðlices bigleofan, forðan ðe we þonne mid þam heofonlicum mettum beoð gereordode
Here we require instruction and wisdom

Her we behófiað láre and wisdomes
In the heavenly life all will be full wise, and in ghostly lore full skilled, those who now, through the precepts of wise men, are obedient to the commandments of God

On ðam heofonlican life beoð ealle ful wíse, and on gastlicre lare full geráde, þa ðe nu, þurh wísra manna láre, beoð Godes bebodum underþeodde
And here we require to partake of the holy housel for our amendment, for in the heavenly dwelling we shall have the body of Christ with us, with which he reigns to eternity

On þyssere worulde we biddað ure synna forgyfenysse, and na on þære toweardan
In this world we pray for forgiveness of our sins, and not in that to come

Se man ðe nele his synna behreowsian on his life, ne begyt he nane forgyfenysse on ðam toweardan
The man who will not repent of his sins in this life, will obtain no forgiveness in that to come

And on ðisum life we biddað þæt God us gescylde wið deofles costnunga, and us alyse fram yfele
And in this life we pray God to shield us against the temptations of the devil, and to deliver us from evil

On ðam ecan life ne bið nán costnung ne nán yfel
In the life eternal there will be no temptation and no evil

forði ðær ne cymð nán deofol ne nán yfel mann, ðe us mæge dreccan oððe derian
for there will come no devil nor evil man who may trouble or hurt us

Þær beoð geþwære sawul and lichama, þe nu on ðisum life him betweonan winnað
There will be in concord soul and body, which now in this life strive with each other

Ðær ne bið nán untrumnys, ne geswinc, ne wana nanre gódnysse, ac Crist bið mid ús eallum, and ús ealle ðing deð, butan edwite, mid ealre blisse
There will be no sickness, no toil, no lack of any goodness, but Christ will be with us all, and will do all things for us, without reproach, with all alacrity

Crist gesette þis gebéd, and swa beleac mid feawum wordum, þæt ealle ure neoda, ægðer ge gastlice ge lichamlice, ðæron sind belocene
Christ instituted this prayer, and so confined it within a few words, that all our needs, both ghostly and bodily, are therein included

and þis gebéd he gesette eallum cristenum mannum gemænelice
and this prayer he instituted for all christian men in common

Ne cwyð na on ðam gebéde, 'Min Fæder, þu ðe eart on heofonum,' ac cwyð
He says not in that prayer, 'My Father, which art in heaven,' but says

Ure Fæder
Our Father

and swa forð ealle ða word ðe þær-æfter fyligað sprecað gemænelice be eallum cristenum mannum
and so forth all the words which follow speak universally of all christian men

On ðam is geswutelod hu swiðe God lufað ánnysse and geþwærnysse on his folce
Herein is manifested how much God loves unity and concord among his people

Æfter Godes gesetnysse ealle cristene men sceoldon beon swa geðwære swilce hit án man wære: forði wa ðam men þe ða annysse tobrycð
According to the book of God all christian men should be so united as though they were one man: wo therefore to the man who breaks that unity asunder

Swa swa we habbað on anum lichaman manega lima, and hi ealle ánum heafde gehyrsumiað, swa eac we sceolon manega cristene men Criste on ánnysse gehyrsumian
So as we have in one body many limbs, and they all obey one head, so also we many christian men should obey Christ in unity

forðon þe he is ure heafod, and we synd his lima
for he is our head, and we are his limbs

We magon geseon on urum agenum lichaman hú ælc lim oðrum þenað
We may see in our own bodies how each limb serves another

Þa fét berað ealne ðone lichaman, and ða eagan lædað ða fét, and þa handa gearciað ðone bigleofan
The feet bear the whole body, and the eyes lead the feet, and the hands prepare the sustenance

Hraðe lið þæt heafod adúne, gif þa fét hit ne feriað
Soon will the head lie down, if the feet bear it not

and hraðe ealle ða lima togædere forweorðað, gif þa handa ne doð þone bigleofan þam muðe
and soon will all the limbs perish together, if the hands put not the sustenance to the mouth

Swa eac se ríca man, þe sitt on his heahsetle, hraðe geswicð he his gebeorscipes, gif ða ðeowan geswicað ðæra teolunga
In like manner the rich man, who sits on his high seat, will soon discontinue his feasting, if the servants discontinue their toils

Beo se ríca gemyndig þæt he sceal ealra ðæra góda þe him God alænde agyldan gescead hu he}} ða atuge
Let the rich be mindful that of all the good things which God has lent him, he shall render an account how he employed them

Se bið ðin hand oððe ðin fót, seðe þe ðine neoda deð
He is thy hand or thy foot, who supplieth thy wants

Se bið þin eage, seðe þe wisdom tæcð, and on rihtne weg þe gebrincð
He is thine eye who teacheth thee wisdom, and bringeth thee into the right way

Se ðe þe múndað swa swa fæder, he bið swylce hé ðin heafod sy
He who protecteth thee as a father is, as it were, thy head

Ealswa wel behófað þæt heafod þæra oðera lima, swa swa ða lima behófiað þæs heafdes
As the head requireth the other members, so these members require the head

Gif án lim bið untrum, ealle ða oðre þrowiað mid þam anum
If one limb be diseased, all the others suffer with that one

Swa we sceolon eac, gif bið an ure geferena on sumre earfoðnysse, ealle we sceolon his yfel besárgian, and hógian embe ða bote, gif we hit gebetan magon
So also should we, if one of our fellows be in any distress, all lament his evil, and meditate concerning its reparation, if we can repair it

And on eallum ðingum we sceolon healdan sibbe and annysse, gif we willað habban þa micclan geðincðe þæt we beon Godes bearn, seðe on heofonum is, on ðære he rixað mid eallum his halgum on ealra worulda woruld on ecnysse
And in all things we should hold peace and unity, if we will have the great distinction of being children of God, who is in heaven, in which he ruleth with all his saints, through all ages, to eternity

Amen
Amen

Ælc cristen man sceal æfter rihte cunnan ægðer ge his Pater noster ge his Credan
Every christian man should by right know both his Pater noster and his Creed

Mid þam Pater nostre he sceal hine gebiddan, mid ðam Credan he sceal his geleafan getrymman
With the Pater noster he should pray, with the Creed he should confirm his faith

We habbað gesæd embe þæt Pater noster, nu we wyllað secgan eow þone geleafan þe on ðam Credan stent, swa swa se wísa Augustinus be ðære Halgan Þrynnysse trahtnode
We have spoken concerning the Pater noster, we will now declare to you the faith which stands in the Creed, according to the wise Augustine's exposition of the Holy Trinity

An Scyppend is ealra ðinga, gesewenlicra and ungesewenlicra
There is one Creator of all things, visible and invisible

and we sceolon on hine gelyfan, forðon ðe hé is soð God and ána Ælmihtig, seðe næfre ne ongann ne anginn næfde
and we should all believe in him, for he is true and God alone Almighty, who never either began or had beginning

ac he sylf is anginn, and he eallum gesceaftum anginn and ordfruman forgeaf, þæt hí beon mihton, and þæt hí hæfdon agen gecynd, swa swa hit þære godcundlican fadunge gelicode
but he is himself beginning, and he to all creatures gave beginning and origin, that they might be, and that they might have their own nature, so as it seemed good to the divine dispensation

Englas he worhte, þa sind gastas, and nabbað nænne lichaman
Angels he created, which are spirits, and have no body

Menn he gesceop mid gaste and mid lichaman
Men he created with spirit and with body

Nytenu and deor, fixas and fugelas he gesceop on flæsce butan sáwle
Cattle and other beasts, fishes and birds he created in flesh without soul

Mannum he gesealde uprihtne gang
To men he gave an upright gait

ða nytenu he lét gán alotene
the cattle he let go bending downwards

Mannum he forgeaf hláf to bigleofan, and þam nytenum gærs
To men he gave bread for sustenance, and to the cattle grass

Nu mage ge, gebroðru, understandan, gif ge wyllað, þæt twa ðing syndon: án is Scyppend, oðer is gesceaft
Now, brethren, ye may understand, if ye will, that there are two things: one is the Creator, the other is the creature

He is Scyppend seðe gesceop and geworhte ealle ðing of nahte
He is the Creator who created and made all things of naught

Þæt is gesceaft þæt se soða Scyppend gesceop
That is a creature which the true Creator created

Þæt sind ærest heofonas, and englas þe on heofonum wuniað, and syððan þeos eorðe mid eallum ðam ðe hire on eardiað, and sǽ mid eallum ðam þe hyre on swymmað
These are, first, heaven, and the angels which dwell in heaven

Nu ealle ðas ðing synd mid anum naman genemnode, gesceaft
and then this earth with all those which inhabit it, and sea with all those that swim in it

Hi næron æfre wunigende, ac God hi gesceop
Now all these things are named by one name, creature

Þa gesceafta sind fela
They were not always existing, but God created them

An is se Scyppend þe hi ealle gesceop, se ana is Ælmihtig God
The creatures are many

He wæs æfre, and æfre he bið þurhwunigende on him sylfum and ðurh hine sylfne
The Creator, who created them all, is one, who alone is Almighty God

Gif he ongunne and anginn hæfde, butan tweon ne mihte he beon Ælmihtig God
He was ever, and ever he will continue in himself and through himself

soðlice þæt gesceaft ðe ongann and gesceapen is, næfð nane godcundnysse
If he had begun and had origin, without doubt he could not be Almighty God

forði ælc edwist þætte God nys, þæt is gesceaft
for the creature that began and is created, has no divinity

and þæt þe gesceaft nis, þæt is God
therefore every substance that is not God is a creature

Se God wunað on Ðrynnysse úntodæledlic, and on ánnysse ánre Godcundnysse, soðlice oðer is se Fæder, oðer is se Sunu, oðer is se Halga Gast
God exists in Trinity indivisible, and in unity of one Godhead, for the Father is one, the Son is one, the Holy Ghost is one

ac þeah-hwæðere ðæra ðreora is án Godcundnys, and gelíc wuldor, and efen-ece mægenðrymnys
and yet of these three there is one Godhead, and like glory, and coeternal majesty

Ælmihtig God is se Fæder, Ælmihtig God is se Sunu, Ælmihtig God is se Halga Gast
The Father is Almighty God, the Son is Almighty God, the Holy Ghost is Almighty God

ac þeah-hwæðere ne sind ðry Ælmihtige Godas, ac án Ælmihtig God
but yet there are not three Almighty Gods, but one Almighty God

Ðry hí sind on hadum and on naman, and án on Godcundnysse
They are three in persons and in name, and one in Godhead

Þry, forði þe se Fæder bið æfre Fæder, and se Sunu bið æfre Sunu, and se Halga Gast bið æfre Halig Gast
Three, because the Father will be ever Father, and the Son will be ever Son, and the Holy Ghost will be ever Holy Ghost

and hyra nán ne awent næfre of ðam ðe he is
and neither of them will ever change from what he is

Nu habbað ge gehyred þa Halgan Þrynnysse
Ye have now heard concerning the Holy Trinity

ge sceolon eac gehyran ða soðan Annysse
ye shall also hear concerning the true Unity

Soðlice se Fæder, and se Sunu, and se Halga Gast, habbað áne Godcundnysse, and án gecynd, and án weorc
Verily the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Ghost, have one Godhead, and one nature, and one work

Ne worhte se Fæder nán ðing ne ne wyrcð, butan ðam Suna, oððe butan þam Halgan Gaste
The Father created nothing nor creates, without the Son, or without the Holy Ghost

Ne heora nán ne wyrcð nán ðing butan oðrum
Nor does one of them anything without the others

ac him eallum is án weorc, and án rǽd, and án willa
but they have all one work, and one counsel, and one will

Æfre wæs se Fæder, and æfre wæs se Sunu, and æfre wæs se Halga Gast án Ælmihtig God
The Father was ever, and the Son was ever, and the Holy Ghost was ever One Almighty God

Se is Fæder, seðe nis naðer ne geboren ne gesceapen fram nanum oðrum
He is the Father, who was neither born of nor created by any other

Se is Fæder geháten, forðan ðe he hæfð Sunu, ðone ðe he of him sylfum gestrynde, butan ælcre meder
He is called Father, because he has a Son, whom he begot of himself, without any mother

Se Fæder is God of nanum Gode
The Father is God of no God

Se Sunu is God of ðam Fæder Gode
The Son is God of God the Father

Se Halga Gast is God forðstæppende of ðam Fæder and of ðam Suna
The Holy Ghost is God proceeding from the Father and from the Son

Þas word sind sceortlice gesæde, and eow is neod þæt we hi swutelicor eow onwreon
These words are shortly said, and it is needful for you that we more plainly expound them

Hwæt is se Fæder
What is the Father

Ælmihtig Scyppend, na geworht ne acenned, ac hé sylf gestrynde Bearn him sylfum efen-ece
The Almighty Creator, not created nor born, but he himself begot a Child coeternal with himself

Hwæt is se Sunu
What is the Son

He is ðæs Fæder Wisdom, and his Word, and his Miht, þurh ðone se Fæder gesceop ealle ðing and gefadode
He is the Wisdom of the Father, and his Word, and his Might, through whom the Father created and disposed all things

Nis se Sunu na geworht ne gesceapen, ac he is acenned
The Son is neither made nor created, but he is begotten

Acenned he is, and þeah-hwæþere he is efen-eald and efen-ece his Fæder
He is begotten, and yet he is coeval and coeternal with his Father

Nis na swa on his acennednysse swa swa bið on ure acennednysse
It is not with his birth as it is with our birth

Þonne se mann sunu gestrynð, and his cild acenned bið, þonne bið se fæder mara, and se sunu læssa
When a man begets a son, and his child is born, the father is greater and the son less

Hwí swa
Why so

Forði þonne se sunu wyxð, þonne ealdað se fæder
Because when the son waxes the father grows old

Ne fintst þu na gelice on mannum fæder and sunu
Thou findest not among men father and son alike

Ac ic ðe sylle bysne, hu ðu Godes acennednysse þy bet understandan miht
But I will give thee an example, whereby thou mayest the better understand the birth of God

Fyr acenð of him beorhtnysse, and seo beorhtnys is efen-eald þam fyre
Fire begets brightness of itself, and the brightness is coeval with the fire

Nis na þæt fyr of ðære beorhtnysse, ac seo beorhtnys is of ðam fyre
The fire is not of the brightness, but the brightness is of the fire

Þæt fyr acenð þa beorhtnysse, ac hit ne bið næfre butan ðære beorhtnysse
The fire begets the brightness, and it is never without the brightness

Nu ðu gehyrst þæt seo beorhtnys is ealswa eald swa þæt fyr þe heo of cymð
Now thou hearest that the brightness is as old as the fire of which it comes

geðafa nu forði þæt God mihte gestrynan ealswa eald Bearn, and ealswa ece swa he sylf is
allow therefore that God might beget a Child as old and as eternal as he himself is

Se ðe mæg understandan þæt ure Hælend Crist is on ðære Godcundnysse ealswa eald swa his Fæder, hé ðancige þæs Gode, and blissige
Let him who can understand that our Saviour Christ is in the Godhead as old as his Father, thank God therefore and rejoice

Seðe understandan ne mæg, he hit sceal gelyfan, þæt he hit understandan mæge
He who cannot understand it shall believe it, that he may understand it

forðan þæs witegan word ne mæg beon aídlod, ðe þus cwæð
for the word of the prophet may not be rendered void, who thus spake

Buton ge hit gelyfan, ne mage ge hit understandan
Unless ye believe it ye cannot understand it

Nu habbað ge gehyred þæt se Sunu is of ðam Fæder butan ælcum anginne
Ye have now heard that the Son is of the Father without any beginning

forðan ðe he is þæs Fæder Wisdom, and he wæs æfre mid þam Fæder, and æfre bið
for he is the Wisdom of the Father, and he was ever with the Father, and ever will be

Uton nu gehyran be ðan Halgan Gaste, hwæt he sý
Let us now hear concerning the Holy Ghost, what he is

He is se Willa and seo soðe Lufu þæs Fæder and þæs Suna, ðurh ðone sind ealle ðing gelíffæste and gehealdene, be ðam is þus gecweden
He is the Will and the true Love of the Father and of the Son, through whom all things are quickened and preserved, concerning whom it is thus said

Godes Gast gefylð ealne ymbhwyrft middangeardes, and he hylt ealle ðing, and he hæfð ingehýd ælces gereordes
The Spirit of God filleth all the circumference of earth, and he holdeth all things, and he hath knowledge of every speech

Nis hé geworht, ne gesceapen, ne acenned, ac hé is forðstæppende, þæt is ofgangende, of ðam Fæder and of ðam Suna, þam hé is gelic and efen-ece
He is not made, nor created, nor begotten, but he is proceeding, that is going from, the Father and from the Son, with whom he is equal and coeternal

Nis se Halga Gast na Sunu, forðan ðe hé nis na acenned, ac hé gæð of ðam Fæder and of ðam Suna gelice
The Holy Ghost is not a son, for he is not begotten, but he proceeds from the Father and from the Son

forðan ðe hé is heora beigra Willa and Lufu
for he is the Will and Love of them both

Crist cwæð þus be him on his godspelle
Christ spake of him thus in his gospel

Se Frofor-gást, þe ic eow asendan wille, Gast ðære soðfæstnysse, ðe of minum Fæder gæð, he cyð gecyðnysse be me
The Spirit of comfort whom I will send unto you, the Spirit of truth, which proceedeth from my Father, will bear testimony concerning me

Þæt is, He is min gewita þæt ic eom Godes Sunu
That is, He is my witness that I am the Son of God

And eac se rihta geleafa us tæcð, þæt we sceolon gelyfan on ðone Halgan Gast: he is se liffæstenda God, se gæð of ðam Fæder and of ðam Suna
And the right faith also teaches us, that we should believe in the Holy Ghost: he is the quickening God, who proceeds from the Father and from the Son

Hu gæð hé of him
How proceeds he from him

Se Sunu is þæs Fæder Wisdom, æfre of ðam Fæder
The Son is the Wisdom of the Father, ever of the Father

and se Halga Gast is heora beigra Willa, æfre of him bám
and the Holy Ghost is the Will of them both, ever of them both

Is forði þonne án Fæder, seðe æfre is Fæder, and án Sunu, seðe æfre bið Sunu, and án Halig Gast, seðe æfre is Halig Gast
There is therefore one Father, who is ever Father

Æfre wæs se Fæder, butan anginne
Ever was the Father, without beginning

and æfre wæs se Sunu mid þam Fæder, forðan ðe he is þæs Fæder Wisdom
and ever was the Son with the Father, for he is the Wisdom of the Father

æfre wæs se Halga Gast, seðe is heora beigra Willa and Lufu
ever was the Holy Ghost, who is the Will and Love of them both

Nis se Fæder of nanum oðrum, ac he wæs æfre
The Father is of no other, for he was ever

Se Sunu is acenned of ðam Fæder, ac he wæs æfre on ðæs Fæder bosme, forðan ðe he is his Wisdom, and he is of ðam Fæder eal þæt he is
The Son is begotten of the Father, for he was ever in the bosom of the Father, for he is his Wisdom, and he is of the Father all that he is

Æfre wæs se Halga Gast, forðan ðe he is, swa we ǽr cwædon, Willa and soð Lufu þæs Fæder and ðæs Suna
Ever was the Holy Ghost, for he is, as we before said, the Will and true Love of the Father and of the Son

soðlice willa and lufu getacniað an ðing: þæt þæt þu wylt, þæt ðu lufast
for will and love betoken one thing: that which thou wilt thou lovest

and þæt þæt ðu nelt, þæt ðu ne lufast
and that which thou wilt not, thou lovest not

Seo sunne ðe ofer us scinð is lichamlic gesceaft, and hæfð swa-ðeah ðreo agennyssa on hire: an is seo lichamlice edwist, þæt is ðære sunnan trendel
The sun which shines over us is a bodily creature, and has, nevertheless, three properties in itself: one is the bodily substance, that is the sun's orb

oðer is se leoma oððe beorhtnys æfre of ðære sunnan, seoðe onliht ealne middangeard
the second is the beam or brightness ever of the sun, which illumines all the earth

þridde is seo hætu, þe mid þam leoman cymð to ús
the third is the heat, which with the beam comes to us

Se leoma is æfre of ðære sunnan, and æfre mid hire
The beam is ever of the sun, and ever with it

and ðæs Ælmihtigan Godes Sunu is æfre of ðam Fæder acenned, and æfre mid him wunigende
and the Son of Almighty God is ever of the Father begotten, and ever with him existing, of whom the apostle said, that he was the brightness of his Father's glory

be ðam cwæð se apostol, þæt he wære his Fæder wuldres beorhtnys
The heat of the sun proceeds from it and from its beam

Ðære sunnan hætu gæð of hire and of hire leoman
and the Holy Ghost proceeds ever from the Father and from the Son equally

and se Halga Gast gæð æfre of ðam Fæder and of þam Suna gelice
of whom it is thus written

be ðam is þus awriten
There is no one who may hide himself from his heat

Fæder, and Sunu, and Halig Gast ne magon beon togædere genamode, ac hí ne beoð swa-þeah nahwár totwæmede
Father, and Son, and Holy Ghost, may not be named together, but yet they are nowhere separated

Nis se Ælmihtiga God na ðryfeald, ac is Ðrynnys
The Almighty God is not threefold, but is Trinity

God is se Fæder, and se Sunu is God, and se Halga Gast is God: na ðry Godas, ac hí ealle ðry án Ælmihtig God
The Father is God, and the Son is God, and the Holy Ghost is God: not three Gods, but they all three one Almighty God

Se Fæder is eac wisdom of nanum oðrum wisdome
The Father is also Wisdom of no other wisdom

Se Sunu is wisdom of ðam wisan Fæder
The Son is Wisdom of the wise Father

Se Halga Gast is wisdom
The Holy Ghost is Wisdom

Ac ðeah-hwæðere hí sind ealle ætgædere án wisdom
But yet they are all together one Wisdom

Eft se Fæder is soð lufu, and se Sunu is soð lufu, and se Halga Gast is soð lufu
Again, the Father is true Love, and the Son is true Love, and the Holy Ghost is true Love

and hí ealle ætgædere án God and án soð lufu
and they all together one God and one true Love

Eac swilce is se Fæder gast and halig, and se Sunu is gast and halig untwylice
In like manner the Father is ghost and holy, and the Son is ghost and holy undoubtedly

þeah-hwæðere se Halga Gast is synderlice geháten Halig Gast, þæt þæt hí ealle ðry sind gemænelice
nevertheless the Holy Ghost is specially called Holy Ghost, that which they all three are in common

Swa micel gelicnys is on ðyssere Halgan Ðrynnysse, þæt se Fæder nis na mare þonne se Sunu on ðære Godcundnysse
There is so great likeness in this Holy Trinity, that the Father is no greater than the Son in the Godhead

ne se Sunu nis na mare þonne se Halgan Gast
nor is the Son greater than the Holy Ghost

ne nan heora án nis na læsse þonne eall seo Ðrynnys
nor is one of them less than the whole Trinity

Swa hwær swa heora án bið, þær hí beoð ealle ðry, æfre án God untodæledlic
Wheresoever one of them is, there they are all three, ever one God indivisible

Nis heora nán máre þonne oðer, ne nán læssa ðonne oðer
No one of them is greater than other, nor one less than other, nor one before other, nor one after other

ne nán beforan oðrum, ne nán bæftan oðrum
for whatsoever is less than God, that is not God

forðan swa hwæt swa læsse bið þonne God, þæt ne bið na God
that which is later has beginning, but God has no beginning

þæt þæt lator bið, þæt hæfð anginn, ac God næfð nán anginn
The Father alone is not Trinity, nor is the Son Trinity, nor the Holy Ghost Trinity, but these three persons are one God in one Godhead

Nis na se Fæder ana Ðrynnys, oððe se Sunu Ðrynnys, oððe se Halga Gast Ðrynnys, ac þas ðry hadas sindon án God on anre Godcundnysse
When thou hearest the Father named, then thou wilt understand that he has a Son

Þonne ðu gehyrst nemnan þone Fæder, þonne understenst ðu þæt he hæfð Sunu
Again, when thou sayest, Son, thou knowest, without doubt, that he has a Father

Eft, þonne þu cwyst Sunu, þu wast, butan tweon, þæt he hæfð Fæder
Again, we believe that the Holy Ghost is the Spirit both of the Father and of the Son

Ne bepæce nán man hine sylfne, swa þæt he secge oððe gelyfe þæt ðry Godas syndon
Let no man deceive himself so as to say or to believe that there are three Gods, or that any person in the Holy Trinity is less mighty than other

oððe ænig hád on þære Halgan Þrynnysse sy unmihtigra þonne oðer
Each of the three is God, yet they are all one God

Ælc ðæra þreora is God, þeah-hwæðere hí ealle án God
for they all have one nature, and one Godhead, and one substance, and one counsel, and one work, and one majesty, and like glory, and coeternal rule

forðan ðe hí ealle habbað án gecynd, and áne godcundnysse, and áne edwiste, and án geðeaht, and án weorc, and áne mægenðrymnysse, and gelíc wuldor, and efen-ece ríce
But the Son alone was incarnate and born to man of the holy maiden Mary

Is hwæðere se Sunu ana geflæschamod and geboren to men, of ðam halgan mædene Marian
The Father was not invested with human nature, but yet he sent his Son for our redemption, and was ever with him, both in life and in passion, and at his resurrection, and at his ascension

Ne wearð se Fæder mid menniscnysse befangen, ac hwæðere hé asende his Sunu to ure alysednysse, and him æfre mid wæs, ægðer ge on life ge on ðrowunge, and on his æriste, and on his upstige
Also all the church of God confesses, according to true faith, that Christ was born of the pure maiden Mary, and of the Holy Ghost

Eac eal Godes gelaðung andet, on ðam rihtum geleafan, þæt Crist is acenned of ðam clænan mædene Marian, and of ðam Halgan Gaste
Yet is not the Holy Ghost the Father of Christ

Nis se Halga Gast þeah-hwæðere Cristes Fæder
never shall any christian man believe that: but the Holy Ghost is the Will of the Father and of the Son

ne nán cristen man þæt næfre ne sceal gelyfan: ac se Halga Gast is Willa þæs Fæder and ðæs Suna
therefore is it very rightly written in our belief, that Christ's humanity was accomplished by the Holy Ghost

Beheald þas sunnan mid gleawnysse, on ðære is, swa we ær cwædon, hætu and beorhtnys
Behold the sun with attention, in which there is, as we before said, heat and brightness

ac seo hætu drygð, and seo beorhtnys onlyht
but the heat dries, and the brightness gives light

Oðer ðing deð seo hætu, and oðer seo beorhtnys
The heat does one thing, and the brightness another

and ðeah ðe hí ne magon beon totwæmde: belimpð, hwæðere ðeah, seo hæðung to ðære hætan, and seo onlihting belimpð to ðære beorhtnysse
and though they cannot be separated, the heating, nevertheless, belongs to the heat, and the giving light to the brightness

Swa eac Crist ana underfeng ða menniscnysse, and na se Fæder, ne se Halga Gast: þeah-hwæðere hí wæron æfre mid him on eallum his weorcum and on ealre his fare
In like manner Christ alone assumed human nature, and not the Father, nor the Holy Ghost: they were, nevertheless, ever with him in all his works and in all his course

We sprecað ymbe God, deaðlice be Undeaðlicum, tyddre be Ælmihtigum, earmingas be Mildheortum
We speak of God, mortals of the Immortal, feeble of the Almighty, miserable beings of the Merciful

ac hwá mæg weorðfullice sprecan be ðam ðe is únasecgendlic
but who may worthily speak of that which is unspeakable

He is butan gemete, forðy ðe he is æghwær
He is without measure, because he is everywhere

He is butan getele, forðon ðe he is æfre
He is without number, for he is ever

He is butan héfe, forðon þe he hylt ealle gesceafta butan geswince
He is without weight, for he holds all creatures without toil

and he hí ealle gelogode on þam ðrim ðingum, þæt is on gemete, and on getele, and on héfe
and he disposed them all in three things, that is in measure, and in number, and in weight

Ac wite ge þæt nán man ne mæg fullice embe God sprecan, þonne we furðon þa gesceafta þe he gesceop ne magon asmeagan, ne areccan
But know ye that no man can speak fully concerning God, when we cannot even investigate or reckon the creatures which he has created

Hwá mæg mid wordum ðære heofenan freatewunge asecgan
Who by words can tell the ornaments of heaven

Oððe hwá ðære eorðan wæstmbærnysse
Or who the fruitfulness of earth

Oððe hwá herað genihtsumlice ealra tida ymbhwyrft
Or who shall adequately praise the circuit of all the seasons

Oððe hwá ealle oðre ðing, þonne we furðon þa lichomlican ðing, þe we onlociað, ne magon fullice befón mid ure gesihðe
Or who all other things, when we cannot even fully comprehend with our sight the bodily things on which we look

Efne ðu gesihst ðone mannan beforan ðe, ac on ðære tide þe ðu his neb gesihst, þu ne gesihst na his hricg
Behold thou seest the man before thee, but at the time thou seest his face, thou seest not his back

Ealswa, gif ðu sumne clað sceawast, ne miht ðu hine ealne togædere geseon, ac wenst abutan, þæt ðu ealne hine geseo
So also if thou lookest at a cloth, thou canst not see it all together, but turnest it about, that thou mayest see it all

Hwylc wundor is, gif se Ælmihtiga God is unasecgendlic and unbefangenlic, seðe æghwær is eall, and nahwar todæled
What wonder is it, if the Almighty God is unspeakable and incomprehensible, who is everywhere all, and nowhere divided

Nu smeað sum undeopðancol man, hu God mæge beón æghwær ætgædere, and nahwar todæled
Now some shallow-thinking man will inquire, how God can be everywhere at once, and nowhere divided

Beheald þas sunnan, hu heage heo astihð, and hu heo asent hyre leoman geond ealne middangeard, and hu heo onliht ealle ðas eorðan þe mancynn on-eardað
Behold this sun, how high he ascends, and how he sends his beams over all the world, and how he enlightens all this earth which mankind inhabit

Swa hraðe swa heo up-asprincð on ærne merigen, heo scinð on Hierusalem, and on Romebyrig, and on ðisum earde, and on eallum eardum ætgædere
As soon as he rises up at early morn, he shines on Jerusalem, and on Rome, and on this country, and on all countries at once

and hwæðere heo is gesceaft, and gæð be Godes dihte
and yet he is a creature, and goes by God's direction

Hwæt wenst ðu hu miccle swiðor is Godes andweardnys, and his miht, and his neosung æghwær
How much ampler then is God's presence, and his might, and his visitation everywhere

Him ne wiðstent nan ðing, naðer ne stænen weall ne bryden wáh, swa swa hi wiðstandað þære sunnan
Him nothing withstands, neither stone wall nor broad barrier, as they withstand the sun

Him is nan ðing digle ne uncuð
To him nothing is hidden or unknown

Þu gesceawast ðæs mannes neb, and God sceawað his heortan
Thou seest a man's face, but God seeth his heart

Godes gast afandað ealra manna heortan
The spirit of God tries the hearts of all men

and ða ðe on hine gelyfað and hine lufiað, þa he clænsað and gegladað mid his neosunge, and ðæra ungeleaffulra manna heortan he forbyhð and onscunað
and those who believe in him and love him he purifies and gladdens with his visitation, and the hearts of unbelieving men he passes by and shuns

Wite eac gehwá, þæt ælc man hæfð þreo ðing on him sylfum untodæledlice and togædere wyrcende, swa swa God cwæð, þaþa hé ærest mann gesceop
Let everyone also know that every man has three things in himself indivisible and working together, as God said when he first created man

He cwæð
He said

Uton gewyrcean mannan to ure gelicnysse
Let us make man in our own likeness

And hé worhte ða Adám to his anlicnysse
And he then made Adam in his own likeness

On hwilcum dæle hæfð se man Godes anlicnysse on him
In which part has man the likeness of God in him

On þære sawle, na on ðam lichaman
In the soul, not in the body

Þæs mannes sawl hæfð on hire gecynde þære Halgan Þrynnysse anlicnysse
The soul of man has in its nature a likeness to the Holy Trinity

forðan þe heo hæfð on hire ðreo ðing, þæt is gemynd, and andgit, and willa
for it has in it three things, these are memory, and understanding, and will

Þurh þæt gemynd se man geðencð þa ðing ðe he gehyrde, oþþe geseah, oþþe geleornode
By the memory a man thinks on the things which he has heard, or seen, or learned

Þurh þæt andgit he understént ealle ða ðing ðe he gehyrð oððe gesihð
By the understanding he comprehends all the things which he hears or sees

Of ðam willan cumað geðohtas, and word, and weorc, ægðer ge yfele ge gode
Of the will come thoughts, and words, and works, both evil and good

An sawul is, and an líf, and an edwist, seoðe hæfð þas ðreo ðing on hire togædere wyrcende untodæledlice
There is one soul, and one life, and one substance, which has these three things in it working together inseparably

forði þær þæt gemynd bið þær bið þæt andgit and se willa, and æfre hí beoð togædere
for where memory is there is understanding and will, and they are ever together

Þeah-hwæðere nis nan ðæra ðreora seo sawul, ac seo sawul þurh þæt gemynd gemanð, þurh þæt andgit heo understent, þurh ðone willan heo wile swa hwæt swa hire licað
Yet is none of these three the soul, but the soul through the memory reminds, through the understanding comprehends, through the will it wills whatsoever it likes

and heo is hwæðere án sawl and án líf
and it is, nevertheless, one soul and one life

Nu hæfð heo forði Godes anlicnysse on hire, forðan ðe heo hæfð þreo ðing on hire untodæledlice wyrcende
It has therefore God's likeness in itself, because it has three things in it inseparably working

Is hwæðere se man án man, and na ðrynnys: God soðlice, Fæder and Sunu and Hálig Gast, þurhwunað on ðrynnysse hada, and on annysse anre godcundnysse
Yet is the man one man, and not a trinity: but God, Father and Son and Holy Ghost, exists in a trinity of persons and in the unity of one Godhead

Nis na se man on ðrynnysse wunigende, swa swa God, ac he hæfð hwæðere Godes anlicnysse on his sawle þurh ða ðreo ðing þe we ær cwædon
Man exists not in trinity as God, but he has, nevertheless, the likeness of God in his soul, by reason of the three things of which we have before spoken

Arrius hatte an gedwolman, se flát wið ænne bisceop þe wæs genemned Alexander, wís and riht-gelyfed
There was a heretic called Arius, who disputed with a bishop who was named Alexander, a wise and orthodox man

Þa cwæð se gedwolman þæt Crist, Godes Sunu, ne mihte na beon his Fæder gelic, ne swa mihtig swa he
The heretic said, that Christ the Son of God could not be equal to his Father, nor so mighty as he

and cwæð, þæt se Fæder wære ær se Sunu, and nam bysne be mannum, hu ælc sunu bið gingra þonne se fæder on ðisum life
and said, that the Father was before the Son, and took example from men, how every son is younger than his father in this life

Þa cwæð se halga bisceop Alexander him togeanes
Then said the holy bishop Alexander in opposition to him

God wæs æfre, and æfre wæs his Wisdom of him acenned, and se Wisdom is his Sunu, ealswa mihtig swa se Fæder
God was ever, and ever was his Wisdom of him begotten, and the Wisdom is his Son, as mighty as his Father

Þa begeat se gedwola þæs caseres fultum to his gedwylde, and cwæð gemót ongean ðone bisceop, and wolde gebigan eal þæt folc to his gedwyldum
Then the heretic got the emperor's support to his heresy, and proclaimed a synod against the bishop, and would bend all the people to his heresies

Þa wacode se bisceop ane niht on Godes cyrcan, and clypode to his Drihtne, and ðus cwæð
Then the bishop watched one night in God's church, and cried to his Lord, and thus said

Ðu Ælmihtiga God, dém rihtne dóm betwux me and Arrium
Thou Almighty God, judge right judgement between me and Arius

Hi comon ða þæs on mergen to ðam gemote
On the morrow they came to the synod

Þa cwæð se gedwola to his geferum, þæt he wolde gán embe his neode forð
The heretic then said to his companions, that he would go forth for his need

Þaða he to gange cóm and he gesǽt, þa gewand him út eall his innewearde æt his setle, and he sæt þær dead
When he came to the place and sat, all his entrails came out, while he was sitting, and he sat there dead

Þa geswutulode God þæt he wæs swa geæmtogod on his innoðe swa swa he wæs ǽr on his geleafan
Thus God manifested that he was as void in his inside as he had before been in his belief

He wolde dón Crist læssan þonne he is, and his godcundnysse wurðmynt wanian
He would make Christ less than he is, and diminish the dignity of his Godhead

þa wearð him swa bysmorlic deað geseald swa swa he wel wyrðe wæs
when a death was given him as ignominious as he was well worthy of

Oðer gedwolman wæs se hatte Sabellius
There was another heretic who was called Sabellius

He cwæð, þæt se Fæder wære, þaþa he wolde, Fæder
He said, that the Father was, whenever he would, Father

and eft, ðaða he wolde, he wære Sunu
and again, when he would, he was Son

and eft, ðaða he wolde, wære Hálig Gast
and again, when he would, was Holy Ghost

and wære forði án God
and was therefore one God

Þa forwearð eac þes gedwola mid his gedwylde
Then this heretic also perished with his heresy

Nu eft þæt Iudeisce folc ðe Crist ofslogon, swa swa hé sylf wolde and geðafode, secgað þæt hí willað gelyfan on þone Fæder, and na on ðone Sunu ðe hyra magas ofslogon
Now again, the Jewish people who slew Christ, as he himself would and permitted, say that they will believe in the Father, and not in the Son whom their forefathers slew

Heora geleafa is naht, and hi forði losiað
Their belief is naught, and they will therefore perish

For ure alysednysse Crist geðafode þæt hí hine ofslogon
For our redemption Christ permitted them to slay him

Hit ne mihte eal mancynn gedón, gif he sylf nolde
All mankind could not have done it, if he himself had not willed it

ac se Halga Fæder gesceop and geworhte mancyn þurh his Sunu, and he wolde eft þurh ðone ylcan us alysan fram helle-wíte, ðaða we forwyrhte wæron
but the Holy Father created and made mankind through his Son, and he would afterwards through the same redeem us from hell-torment, when we were undone

Buton ælcere ðrowunge he mihte us habban, ac him ðuhte þæt unrihtlic
Without any passion he might have had us, but that seemed to him unjust

Ac se deofol forwyrhte hine sylfne, ðaða hé tihte þæt Iudeisce folc to ðæs Hælendes slege, and we wurdon alysede, þurh his unscyldigan deað, fram ðam ecan deaðe
But the devil undid himself, when he instigated the Jewish people to the slaying of Jesus, and we were redeemed by his innocent death from the eternal death

We habbað þone geleafan ðe Crist sylf tæhte his apostolum, and hi eallum mancynne
We have the belief that Christ himself taught to his apostles, and they to all mankind

and ðone geleafan God hæfð mid manegum wundrum getrymmed and gefæstnod
and that belief God has confirmed and established by many miracles

Ærest Crist ðurh hine sylfne dumbe and deafe, healte and blinde, wode and hreoflige gehælde, and ða deadan to lífe arærde: syððan, þurh his apostolas and oðre halige men, þas ylcan wundra geworhte
First Christ by himself healed dumb and deaf, halt and blind, mad and leprous, and raised the dead to life: after, by his apostles and other holy men, he wrought the same miracles

Nu eac on urum timan, gehwær þær halige men hí restað, æt heora deadum banum God wyrcð fela wundra, to ði þæt he wile folces geleafan mid þam wundrum getrymman
Now also in our time, everywhere where holy men rest, at their dead bones God works many miracles, because he will with those miracles confirm people's faith

Ne wyrcð God na þas wundra æt nanes Iudeisces mannes byrgene, ne æt nanes oðres gedwolan, ac æt riht-gelyfedra manna byrgenum, ða ðe gelyfdon on ða Halgan Ðrynnysse, and on soð Annysse anre Godcundnysse
God works not these miracles at any Jewish man's sepulchre, nor at any other heretic's, but at the sepulchres of orthodox men, who believed in the Holy Trinity, and in the true Unity of one Godhead

Wite gehwá eac, þæt nan man ne mot beon tuwa gefullod
Let everyone know also, that no man may be twice baptized

ac gif se man æfter his fulluhte aslide, we gelyfað þæt he mæge beon gehealden, gif he his synna mid wope behreowsiað, and be lareowa tæcunge hí gebet
but if a man err after his baptism, we believe that he may be saved, if with weeping he repent of his sins, and, according to the teaching of his instructors, atone for them

We sceolon gelyfan þæt ælces mannes sawul bið þurh God gesceapen, ac hwæðere heo ne bið na of Godes agenum gecynde
We are to believe that the soul of every man is created by God, but yet it is not of God's own nature

Þæs mannes lichaman antimber bið of ðam fæder and of ðære meder, ac God gescypð þone lichaman of ðam antimbre, and asent on þone lichaman sawle
The matter of a man's body is from the father and from the mother, but God creates the body from the matter, and sends a soul into the body

Ne bið seo sawl nahwar wunigende ǽror, ac God hí gescypð þærrihte, and beset on ðone lichaman, and læt hí habban agenne cyre, swa heo syngige swa heo synna forbuge
The soul is nowhere existing previously, but God creates it forthwith, and sets it in the body, and lets it have its own election, whether it shall sin, whether it shall eschew sins

Þeah-hwæðere heo behófað æfre Godes fultumes, þæt heo mæge synna forbugan, and eft to hyre Scyppende gecuman þurh gode geearnunga
Nevertheless it ever needs God's support, that it may eschew sins, and again come to its Creator through good deserts

forðon ðe nan man ne deð butan Gode nan ðing to góde
for no man doeth anything good without God

Eac we sceolon gelyfan þæt ælc lichama ðe sawle underfeng sceal arisan on domes dæge mid þam ylcum lichaman þe he nu hæfð, and sceal onfón edlean ealra his dæda: þonne habbað ða gódan ece líf mid Gode, and he sylð þa méde ælcum be his geearnungum
We are also to believe that every body which has received a soul shall arise at doomsday with the same body that he now has, and shall receive the reward of all his deeds: then will the good have eternal life with God, and he will give a meed to everyone according to his deserts

Þa synfullan beoð on helle-wite á ðrowigende, and heora wite bið eac gemetegod ælcum be his ge-earnungum
The sinful will be ever suffering in hell-torment, and their torment will also be measured to everyone according to his deserts

Uton forði geearnian þæt ece líf mid Gode þurh ðisne geleafan, and ðurh gode geearnunga, seðe þurhwunað on Ðrynnysse án Ælmihtig God áá on ecnysse
