Let us therefore merit eternal life with God through this faith, and through good deserts, who existeth in Trinity One Almighty God ever to eternity

Amen
Amen

Lucas se Godspellere ús manode on ðisre pistol-rædinge, þus cweðende
Luke the Evangelist has informed us in this epistolary reading, thus saying

Se Hælend, middangeardes Alysend, æteowde hine sylfne cucenne his gingrum, æfter his þrowunge and his æriste, on manegum ðrafungum, geond feowertig daga, and him to spræc ymbe Godes rice, samod mid him reordigende: and bebead him þæt hi of ðære byrig Hierusalem ne gewiton, ac þæt hi ðær anbidedon his Fæder behátes, he cwæð, þe ge of minum muðe gehyrdon
Jesus, the Redeemer of the world, showed himself living to his disciples, after his passion and his resurrection, by many reproofs, for forty days, and spake to them concerning the kingdom of God, eating and drinking together with them: and commanded them that they should not depart from the city of Jerusalem, but that they should await there the promise of his Father which (he said) ye have heard from my mouth

Forðan ðe Iohannes se Fulluhtere gefullode on wætere, and ge beoð gefullode on ðam Halgan Gaste nu æfter feawum dagum
For John the Baptist baptized with water, and ye shall be baptized with the Holy Ghost now after a few days

Eornostlice seo gegaderung his leorning-cnihta cwæð ða ánmodlice, Drihten leof, wilt ðu nu gesettan ende þysre worulde
The assembly of his disciples therefore said unanimously, Beloved Lord, wilt thou now put an end to this world

He him andwyrde, Nis na eow to gewitenne ða tíd oððe ða hand-hwile þe min Fæder gesette þurh his mihte: ac ge underfoð þæs Halgan Gastes mihte, and ge beoð mine gewitan on Iudea lande, and on eallum middangearde, oð þæt endenexte land
He answered them, It is not for you to know the time or the moment which my Father hath appointed through his might: but ye shall receive the might of the Holy Ghost, and ye shall be my witnesses in Judea, and in all the world, unto the uttermost land

And hé lædde hí ða út of ðære byrig up to anre dune ðe is gecweden mons Oliueti, and hi gebletsode up-ahafenum handum
And he led them then out of the city up to a hill which is called the mount of Olives, and blessed them with uplifted hands

Þa mid þære bletsunge ferde hé to heofonum, him on locigendum
Then after that blessing he went to heaven, they looking on

and þæt heofonlice wolcn leat wið his, and hine genam fram heora gesihðum
and a heavenly cloud descended towards him, and took him from their sight

Ðaða hi up to heofonum starigende stodon, ða gesawon hi ðær twegen englas on hwitum gerelan, þus cweðende, Ge Galileisce weras, hwi stande ge ðus starigende wið heofenas weard
While they stood gazing up to heaven, they saw there two angels in white garments, thus saying, Ye Galilean men, why stand ye thus gazing towards heaven

Se Hælend, þe is nu genumen of eowrum gesihðum to heofonum, swa he cymð eft swa swa ge gesawon þæt he to heofonum astáh
Jesus, who is now taken from your sight to heaven, shall so come again as ye have seen that he ascended to heaven

Hi ða gecyrdon to ðære byrig Hierusalem mid micelre blisse, and astigon upp on ane upfleringe, and þær wunedon oð Pentecosten on gebedum and on Godes herungum, oðþæt se Halga Gast him to com, swa swa se æðela Cyning him ær behét
They then returned to the city of Jerusalem with great joy, and went up on an upper flooring, and there stayed till Pentecost in prayers and in praises of God, until the Holy Ghost came to them, as the noble King had before promised them

On ðyssere geferrædene wæron Petrus and Iohannes, Iacob and Andreas, Philippus and Thomas, Bartholomeus and Matheus, se oðer Iacob and Simon, se oðer Iudas and Maria þæs Hælendes modor, and gehwilce oðre, ægðer ge weras ge wíf
In this fellowship were Peter and John, James and Andrew, Philip and Thomas, Bartholomew and Matthew, the other James and Simon, the other Judas and Mary the mother of Jesus, and several others, both men and women

Eal seo menigu wæs an hund manna and twentig, anmodlice on gebedum wunigende
The whole multitude was an hundred and twenty persons, unanimously continuing in prayers

Se Hælend tæhte ða halgan lare his leorning-cnihtum ær his ðrowunge, and æfter his æriste he wæs wunigende betwux him þas feowertig daga, fram ðære halgan Easter-tide oð þisne dægðerlican dæg, and on manegum wisum ðrafode and afandode his gingran, and ge-edlæhte þæt þæt he ær tæhte, to fulre lare and rihtum geleafan
Jesus taught the holy lore to his disciples before his passion, and after his resurrection he was continuing among them these forty days, from the holy Easter-tide until this present day, and in many ways reproved and tried his disciples, and repeated that which he had before taught, for the perfection of doctrine and right faith

He gereordode hine æfter his æriste, na forði þæt he syððan eorðlices bigleofan behófode, ac to ði þæt he geswutelode his soðan lichaman
He ate and drank after his resurrection, not because he then had need of earthly food, but because he would manifest his true body

He æt þurh mihte, na for neode
He ate through power, not for need

Swa swa fyr fornimð wæteres dropan, swa fornam Cristes godcundlice miht ðone geðigedan mete
As fire consumes drops of water, so did the divine power of Christ consume the received meat

Soðlice æfter ðam gemænelicum æriste ne behófiað ure lichaman nanre strangunge eorðlicra metta, ac se Hælend us deð ealle ure neoda mid heofenlicum ðingum, and we beoð mid wuldre gewelgode, and mihtige to gefremmenne swa hwæt swa us licað, and we beoð ful swyfte to farenne geond ealle wídgylnyssa Godes rices
Verily after the universal resurrection our bodies will require no strengthening of earthly meats, for Jesus will supply all our needs with heavenly things, and we shall be enriched with glory, and mighty to execute whatsoever is pleasing to us, and we shall be full swift to go through all the immensities of the kingdom of God

He behét his gingrum nu and gelome þæt he wolde him sendan þone Halgan Gast, and þus cwæð
He promised to his disciples then and frequently that he would send to them the Holy Ghost, and thus said

Þonne he cymð he eow tiht and gewissað to eallum ðam ðingum ðe ic eow sæde
When he comes he will stimulate and direct you to all the things which I have said unto you

Þa com se Halga Gast on fyres hiwe to ðam halgum hyrede on þam endleoftan dæge Cristes upstiges, and hi ealle onælde mid úndergendlicum fyre, and hí wurdon afyllede mid þære heofonlican láre, and cuðon ealle woruldlice gereord, and bodedon unforhtlice geleafan and fulluht ricum and reðum
Then came the Holy Ghost in semblance of fire to the holy company on the eleventh day after Christ's ascension, and inflamed them all with innoxious fire, and they were filled with heavenly lore, and knew all worldly tongues, and fearlessly preached faith and baptism to the powerful and cruel

Se halga heap befrán Crist, hwæðer he wolde on ðam timan þisne middangeard geendian
The holy company asked Christ, whether he would at that time put an end to this world

He ða cwæð him to andsware
He said to them in answer

Nis na eower mǽð to witenne þone timan, þe min Fæder þurh his mihte gesette
It is not for you to know the time which my Father hath through his power appointed

He cwæð eac on oðre stowe
He said also in another place

Nát nán man ðone dæg ne ðone timan ðysre worulde geendunge, ne englas, ne nan halga, buton Gode anum
No man knoweth the day or the time of the ending of this world, nor the angels, nor any saint, save God only

Þeah-hwæðere, be ðam tacnum þe Crist sæde, we geseoð þæt seo geendung is swiðe gehende, þeah ðe heo us uncuð sy
Yet by the tokens which Christ mentioned, we see that the ending is very near at hand, though it be unknown to us

Þa apostoli wæron gewitan Cristes weorca, forðan ðe hí bodedon his ðrowunge, and his ærist, and upstige, ærst Iudeiscre ðeode, and syððan becom heora stemn to ælcum lande, and heora word to gemærum ealles ymbhwyrftes
The apostles were witnesses of Christ's works, for they preached his passion, and his resurrection, and ascension, first to the Jewish people, and afterwards their voice came to every land, and their words to the boundaries of the whole globe

forðan ðe hí awriton Cristes wundra, and ða bec þurhwuniað on cristenre ðeode, ægðer ge ðær þær ða apostoli lichamlice bodedon, ge þær ðær hí na ne becomon
for they recorded the miracles of Christ, and the books exist among christian people, both where the apostles bodily preached, and where they did not come

Ealle gesceafta ðeniað heora Scyppende
All creatures serve their Creator

Þaþa Crist acenned wæs, þa sende seo heofen niwne steorran, ðe bodade Godes acennednysse}}
When Christ was born, heaven sent forth a new star, which announced the birth of God

Eft, ðaða he to heofonum astah, þa abeah þæt heofonlice wolcn wið his, and hine underfeng: na þæt þæt wolcn hine ferede, forðan ðe he hylt heofona ðrymsetl, ac he siðode mid þam wolcne of manna gesihðum
Again, when he ascended to heaven, the heavenly cloud bowed down towards him, and received him: not that the cloud bare him, for he holds the throne of heaven, but he passed with the cloud from the sight of men

Þær wæron ða gesewene twegen englas on hwitum gyrelum
There were seen two angels in white garments

Eac swilce on his acennednysse wæron englas gesewene
In like manner at his birth angels were seen

ac þæt halige godspel ne ascyrde hu hi gefreatwode wæron
but the holy gospel has not explained how they were adorned

forðan ðe God com to us swiðe eadmod
for God came to us very humble

On his upstige wæron gesewene englas mid hwitum gyrlum geglengede
At his ascension were seen angels adorned with white garments

Bliss is getacnod on hwitum reafe, forðon ðe Crist ferde heonon mid micelre blisse and mid micclum ðrymme
Joy is betokened by white garments, for Christ departed hence with great joy and with great majesty

On his acennednysse wæs geðuht swilce seo Godcundnys wære geeadmet, and on his upstige wæs seo menniscnys ahafen and gemærsod
At his birth it seemed as though the Godhead were humbled, and at his ascension humanity was exalted and magnified

Mid his upstige is adylegod þæt cyrographum ure geniðerunge, and se cwyde ure brosnunge is awend
With his ascension is annulled the writ of our condemnation, and the sentence of our destruction is abrogated

Þaða Adam agylt hæfde, þa cwæð se Ælmihtiga Wealdend him to
When Adam had sinned, the Almighty Ruler said to him

Þu eart eorðe, and þu gewenst to eorðan
Thou art earth, and thou shalt to earth return

Ðu eart dust, and þu gewenst to duste
Thou art dust, and thou shalt return to dust

Nu to-dæg þæt ylce gecynd ferde unbrosnigendlic into heofenan rice
Now to-day that same nature went incorruptible into the kingdom of heaven

Þa twegen englas sædon þæt Crist cymð swa swa he uppferde, forðan ðe he bið gesewen on ðam micclum dome on menniscum hiwe, þæt his slagan hine magon oncnawan, þe hine ær to deaðe gedydon, and eac ða ðe his lare forsawon, þæt hi ðonne rihtlice onfón þæt ece wite mid deofle
The two angels said that Christ would come as he ascended, because at the great doom he will be seen in human form, that his slayers may recognize him whom they formerly put to death, and also that those who despised his precepts may then justly receive eternal punishment with the devil

Þæt halige gewrit cwyð
Holy writ says

Tollatur impius ne uideat gloriam Dei
Tollatur impius ne videat gloriam Dei

Sy ðam arleasan ætbroden seo gesihð Godes wuldres
Be the sight of God's glory taken away from the impious

Ne geseoð þa arleasan Cristes wuldor, ðe hine ær on life forsawon, ac hi geseoð þonne egefulne þone ðe hi eadmodne forhygedon
The impious will not see the glory of Christ, whom they had before despised in life, but they will then see him awful whom humble they had contemned

Recumbentibus undecim discipulis: et reliqua
We have now read the narrative of Luke concerning Christ's ascension

We habbað nu geræd Lucas gesetnysse embe Cristes upstige
we will now turn our consideration to the other evangelist Mark, who said in the present day's gospel, that Jesus appeared to his apostles, and chid them, because they would not at first believe his resurrection from death, when it was announced to them

nu wende we ure smeagunge to ðam oðrum godspellere Marcum, þe cwæð on ðisum dægðerlicum godspelle, þæt se Hælend æteowde hine sylfne his apostolum and cidde him, forðan ðe hi noldon æt fruman gelyfan his æristes of deaðe, ðaða hit him gecydd wæs
Then said the Lord to his disciples

Þa cwæð se Wealdend to his gingrum
Go over all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature: he who believeth and is baptized shall be saved

Farað geond ealne middangeard, and bodiað godspel eallum gesceafte: seðe gelyfð and bið gefullod, se bið gehealden
he who believeth not shall be damned

se ðe ne gelyfð, he bið genyðerod
These signs shall follow those men who believe

Ðas tacnu fyligað þam mannum þe gelyfað
etc

etc
This gospel is here now simply said, but we will now unfold its mysteries to you, according to the exposition of Gregory

Ðæra apostola tweonung be Cristes æriste næs na swa swiðe heora ungeleaffulnys, ac wæs ure trumnys
The apostles' doubt as to the resurrection of Christ was not so much their lack of faith, but was our confirmation

Læs us fremodon þa ðe hraðe gelyfdon, ðonne ða þe twynigende wæron
Less have benefited us those who quickly believed than those who were doubting

forðan ðe hi sceawedon and grapodon ða dolhswaðu Cristes wunda, and swa adræfdon ealle twynunga fram ure heortan
for they beheld and touched the scars of Christ's wounds, and so drove out all doubts from our hearts

Þa ðreade se Hælend his leorning-cnihta twynunge, ðaða hé lichamlice hí forlætan wolde, to ði þæt hí gemyndige wæron ðæra worda þe hé on his siðe him sæde
Jesus then reproved his disciples for their doubt, when he would bodily leave them, that they might be mindful of the words which he said to them on his way

He cwæð þa
He said

Farað geond ealne middangeard, and bodiað godspel eallum gesceafte
Go over all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature

Godspel is us to gehyrenne, and ðearle lufigendlic, þæt we moton forbugan helle-wite and ða hreowlican tintrega þurh ðæs Hælendes menniscnysse, and becuman to engla werode þurh his eadmodnysse
The gospel is for us to hear and exceedingly loving, that we may avoid hell-torment and cruel tortures through the incarnation of Jesus, and come to the host of angels through his humility

He cwæð
He said

Bodiað eallum gesceafte
Preach to every creature

ac mid þam naman is se mann ána getacnod
but by that name is man alone betokened

Stanas sind gesceafta, ac hí nabbað nan líf, ne hí ne gefredað
Stones are creatures, but they have no life, nor have they sense

Gærs and treowa lybbað butan felnysse
Grass and trees live without feeling

hí ne lybbað na ðurh sawle, ac ðurh heora grennysse
they live not by a soul, but by their greenness

Nytenu lybbað and habbað felnysse, butan gesceade: hí nabbað nan gescead, forðan ðe hí sind sawullease
Beasts live and have feeling without reason

Englas lybbað, and gefredað, and tosceadað
they have no reason, because they are soulless

Nu hæfð se mann ealra gesceafta sum ðing
Angels live, and have sense, and use reason

Him is gemæne mid stanum, þæt he beo wunigende
Now man has something of all creatures

him is gemæne mid treowum, þæt he lybbe
He has in common with the stones, that he is existing

mid nytenum, þæt he gefrede
he has in common with the trees, that he lives

mid englum, þæt he understande
with the beasts, that he has sense

Nu is se mann gecweden 'eall gesceaft,' forðan ðe he hæfð sum ðing gemæne mid eallum gesceafte
with angels, that he understands

Þæt godspel bið gebodad eallum gesceafte, þonne hit bið ðam menn anum gebodad, forðan ðe ealle eorðlice þing sind gesceapene for ðam men anum, and hí ealle habbað sume gelicnysse to ðam men, swa swa we ær sædon
Man is therefore called 'every creature,' because he has something in common with every creature

Se ðe gelyfð, and bið gefullod, he bið gehealden
He who believeth, and is baptized, shall be saved

and se ðe ne gelyfð, he bið geniðerod
and he who believeth not shall be damned

Se geleafa bið soð seðe ne wiðcwyð mid þweorum ðeawum þæt þæt he gelyfð
That faith is true which gainsays not by wicked practices that which it believes

be ðam cwæð Iohannes se apostol
of which spake John the apostle

Se geleafa ðe bið butan godum weorcum, se bið dead
Again, the apostle James says

Hwæt fremað þe þæt ðu hæbbe geleafan, gif ðu næfst ða godan weorc
Again, he said

Ne mæg se geleafa ðe gehealdan butan ðam weorcum
What profiteth it thee that thou have faith, if thou hast not good works

Deoflu gelyfað, ac hí forhtiað
Faith cannot save thee without works

Þu eart Godes Sunu, forði ðu come þæt ðu woldest us fordón
The devils saw Christ in this life, in his human state, but they fell at his feet, and cried, and said

Se ðe gelyfð, and hæfð ege, and nele ðeah-hwæðere gód wyrcan, se bið þonne deoflum gelic
The man who will not believe in God, nor has any awe of God, is worse than a devil

In quodam tractu, qui estimatur Sci Hilarii fuisse, sic inuenimus scriptum, sicut Anglice hic interpretauimus, et ad testimonium ipsam Latinitatem posuimus
He who rightly believes, and rightly lives his life, and with awe of God practises good works to the end of his life, shall be saved, and shall have everlasting life with God, and with all his saints

Demones credunt et contremescunt
The Lord said, these signs shall follow those who believe in him

qui autem non credit, et non contremescit demonibus deterior est: qui autem credit, et contremescit, et ueritatem operibus non agit demonibus similis est
In my name they shall cast out devils

Se ðe rihtlice gelyfð, and rihtlice his lif leofað, and mid Godes ege gód weorc begæð oð ende his lifes, se bið gehealden, and he hæfð ece líf mid Gode, and mid eallum his halgum
they shall drive away serpents

Drihten cwæð, þa ðe gelyfað, him fyligað þas tacnu
and though they drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them

On minum naman hí adræfað deoflu
they shall set their hands over sick men, and it shall be well with them

Þas wundra wæron nyd-behefe on anginne cristendomes, forðan ðurh ða tacna wearð þæt hæðene folc gebiged to geleafan
These wonders were needful at the beginning of christianity, for by these signs was the heathen folk inclined to faith

Se man ðe plantað treowa oððe wyrta, swa lange he hí wæterað oðþæt hí beoð ciðfæste
The man who plants trees or herbs, waters them so long until they have taken root

syððan hí growende beoð he geswycð þære wæterunge: swa eac se Ælmihtiga God, swa lange he æteowde his wundra ðam hæðenum folce, oðþæt hí geleaffulle wæron: syððan se geleafa sprang geond ealne middangeard, siððan geswicon ða wundra
when they are growing he ceases from watering: so also the Almighty God so long showed his miracles to the heathen folk, until they were believing: when faith had sprung up over all the world, then miracles ceased

Ac ðeah-hwæðere Godes gelaðung wyrcð gyt dæghwamlice þa ylcan wundra gastlice þe ða apostoli ða worhton lichamlice
But, nevertheless, God's church still works daily the same miracles spiritually which the apostles then wrought bodily

Þonne se preost cristnað þæt cild, þonne adræfð he ðone deofol of ðam cilde
When the priest christens the child, then casts he out the devil from that child

forðan ðe ælc hæðen man bið deofles, ac þurh þæt halige fulluht he bið Godes, gif he hit gehylt
for every heathen man is the devil's, but through the holy baptism he is God's, if he observe it

Se ðe forlæt bysmorlice spellunga, and talu, and derigendlice gaffetunga, and gebysegað his muð mid Godes herungum and gebedum, he sprecð þonne mid niwum gereordum
He who forsakes opprobrious speeches and calumnies, and injurious scoffings, and busies his mouth with the praises of God and with prayers, speaks then in new tongues

Se ðe ungeradum oððe ungeðyldigum styrð, and þa biternysse his heortan gestilð, he afyrsað þa næddran, forðan ðe he adwæscð þa yfelnyssa his modes
He who corrects thoughtlessness or impatience, and stills the bitterness of his heart, drives away serpents, for he extinguishes the evilnesses of his mind

Se ðe bið forspanen to forligre, and ðeah-hwæðere ne bið gebiged to ðære fremminge, he drincð unlybban, ac hit him ne derað, gif he mid gebédum to Gode flihð
He who is allured to fornication, but yet is not induced to its accomplishment, drinks a deadly drink, but it shall not hurt him, if with prayers he flees to God

Gif hwa bið geuntrumod on his anginne, and asolcen fram godre drohtnunge, gif hine hwa ðonne mid tihtinge and gebisnungum godra weorca getrymð and arærð, þonne bið hit swilce he sette his handa ofer untrumne and hine gehæle
If any-one be weakened in his purpose, and slothful for good living, then if any-one, with exhortation and examples of good works, strengthen and raise him up, it will be as though he set his hand over the sick and heal him

Þa gastlican wundra sind maran þonne þa lichamlican wæron, forðan ðe ðas wundra gehælað þæs mannes sawle, ðe is ece, and ða ærran tacna gehældon þone deadlican lichaman
The spiritual miracles are greater than the bodily ones were, for these miracles heal a man's soul, which is eternal, but the former signs healed the mortal body

Þa ærran wundra worhton ægðer ge góde men ge yfele
The former miracles were wrought both by good men and by evil

Yfel wæs Iudas, ðe Crist belæwde, þeah he worhte wundra æror ðurh Godes naman
Judas, who betrayed Christ, was evil, though he had previously wrought miracles in the name of God

Be swylcum mannum cwæð Crist on oðre stowe
Of such men Christ in another place said

Ic secge eow, manega cweðað to me on ðam micclan dæge, Drihten, Drihten, la hú ne witegode we on ðinum naman, and we adræfdon deoflo of wodum mannum, and we micele mihta on þinum naman gefremedon
I say unto you, many will say to me on that great day, Lord, Lord, lo

Þonne andette ic him, Ne can ic eow: gewitað fram me, ge unrihtwise wyrhtan
have we not prophesied in thy name, and have driven devils out of mad men, and have performed great miracles in thy name

Næfð se yfela ða soðan lufe, ne se góda nys hyre bedæled
My brothers, love not those miracles which may be common to the good and to the evil, but love those signs which are exclusively good men's, which are the signs of true love and of piety

Þas tacna sind digle and unpleolice, and hí habbað swa miccle maran edlean æt Gode, swa micclum swa heora wuldor is læsse mid mannum
The evil has not true love, nor is the good devoid of it

Se Wealdenda Drihten, æfter ðisum wordum, wæs genumen to heofonum, and sitt on ða swiðran hand his Fæder
These signs are mysterious and not perilous, and they have so much the greater reward with God as their glory is less with men

We rædað on ðære ealdan ǽ, þæt twegen Godes men, Enoh and Helias, wæron ahafene to heofonum butan deaðe: ac hí elciað ongean ðone deað, and mid ealle ne forfleoð
We read in the old law, that two men of God, Enoch and Elijah, were lifted up to heaven without death: but they await death, and will by no means escape from it

Hí sind genumene to lyftenre heofenan na to rodorlicere, and drohtniað on sumum diglan earde mid micelre strencðe lichaman and sawle, oðþæt hi eft ongean cyrron, on ende þisre worulde, togeanes Antecriste, and deaðes onfoð
They are taken to the aërial heaven, not to the ethereal, and continue in some secret dwelling-place with great strength of body and soul, until they shall return again, at the end of this world, against Antichrist, and shall receive death

Ure Ælmihtiga Alysend ne elcode na ongean þone deað, ac he hine oferswiðde mid his æriste, and geswutulode his wuldor þurh his upstige to ðam yfemystan þrymsetle
Our Almighty Redeemer waited not for death, but he overcame it with his resurrection, and manifested his glory by his ascension to the highest throne

We rædað be ðam witegan Heliam, þæt englas hine feredon on heofonlicum cræte, forðan ðe seo untrumnys his gecyndes behofode sumes byrðres
We read of the prophet Elijah, that angels conveyed him in a heavenly chariot, because the infirmity of his nature required some supporter

Ure Alysend Crist næs geferod mid cræte ne ðurh engla fultum
Our Redeemer Christ was not conveyed in a chariot nor by angels' help

forðan se ðe ealle ðing geworhte, he wæs geferod mid his agenre mihte ofer ealle gesceafta
for he who wrought all things was borne by his own might over all creatures

Se ærra man Enoh wæs geferod to lyftenre heofonan, and Helias wæs mid cræte up-awegen
The first-mentioned man, Enoch, was conveyed to the aërial heaven, and Elijah was borne up in a chariot

ac se Ælmihtiga Hælend næs gefered ne awegen, ac he ðurhferde ða roderlican heofonan þurh his agene mihte
but the Almighty Saviour was not conveyed nor borne, but he passed through the ethereal heaven by his own might

Us is to smeagenne hu seo clænnys wæs ðeonde geond þa geferedan ðenas, and þurh ðone astigendan Hælend
We have to consider how chastity was cherished by the ministers who were thus conveyed, and by the ascending Jesus

Enoh wæs geferod, seðe wæs mid hæmede gestryned, and mid hæmede wæs strynende
Enoch was conveyed, who was begotten by coition, and who begot by coition

Helias wæs on cræte geferod, seðe wæs þurh hæmed gestryned, ac he ne strynde þurh hæmed, forðan ðe he wunade on his life butan wife
Elijah was conveyed in a chariot, who was begotten by coition, but he begot not by coition, for he continued during his life without a wife

Se Hælend astah to heofonum, seðe næs mid hæmede gestryned, ne he sylf strynende næs
Jesus ascended to heaven, who was not begotten by coition, nor did he himself beget

forðan ðe he is ord and anginn ealra clænnyssa, and him is seo clænnys swiðe lufigendlic mægen, þæt he geswutulode ðaða he geceas him mæden-mann to meder
for he is the origin and beginning of all chastities, and to him chastity is a very amiable virtue, which he manifested when he chose him a maiden for mother

And eall se halga heap ðe him fyligde wæs on clænnysse wunigende, swa swa he cwæð sumum godspelle
And all the holy company which followed him was living in chastity, as he says in one of his gospels

Se ðe to me cymð, ne mæg he beon min leorning-cniht, buton he his wif hatige
He who comes to me, may not be my disciple, unless he hate his wife

Se godspellere Marcus awrát on ðisum godspelle, þæt ure Drihten, æfter his upstige, sæte on his Fæder swiðran hand
The evangelist Mark wrote in this gospel, that our Lord, after his ascension, sat on the right hand of his Father

and se forma martyr Stephanus cwæð, þæt he gesawe heofonas opene, and ðone Hælend standan on his Fæder swiðran
and the first martyr, Stephen, said that he saw the heavens open, and Jesus standing on his Father's right

Nu cwyð se trahtnere
Now says the expounder

Þæt rihtlice is gecweden, þæt he sæte æfter his upstige, forðan ðe deman gedafnað setl
That is rightly said, that he sat after his ascension, because a seat is befitting a judge

Crist is se soða dema, þe demð and toscæt ealle ðing, nu and eac on ðam endenextan dæge
Christ is the true Judge, who will judge and decide all things, now, and also on the last day

Se martyr hine geseah standan, forðan ðe hé wæs his gefylsta on ðære ðrowunge his martyrdomes, and ðurh his gife he wæs gebyld ongean ða reðan ehteras, ðe hine wælhreowlice stændon
The martyr saw him standing, for he was his supporter in the suffering of his martyrdom, and through his grace he was rendered bold against the fierce persecutors, who cruelly stoned him

Se ende is ðises godspelles, Þæt Cristes apostoli
The end of this gospel is, that Christ's apostles

ferdon and bodedon gehwær, Drihtne samod wyrcendum, and ða spræce getrymmendum mid æfterfyligendum tacnum
went and preached everywhere, the Lord working with them, and confirming the word with signs following

Þa apostoli, þæt sind Godes bydelas, toferdon geond ealne middangeard
The apostles, that is, God's preachers, went over all the world

Petrus bodade on Iudea-lande, Paulus on hæðenum folce, Andreas on Scithia, Iohannes on Asia, Bartholomeus on India, Matheus on Ethiopia, and swa heora gehwilc on his dæle, and Godes miht him wæs mid, to gefremminge heora bodunga and ungerimra tacna
Peter preached in Judea, Paul among the heathen folk, Andrew in Scythia, John in Asia, Bartholomew in India, Matthew in Ethiopia, and so each of them in his part, and the might of God was with them, for the efficacy of their preaching and of numberless signs

forðan ðe Crist cwæð
for Christ said

Ne mage ge nán ðing dón butan me
Ye can do nothing without me

Eft he cwæð
Again he said

Ic beo mid eow eallum dagum, oð þisre worulde geendunge
I will be with you on all days, until the ending of this world

seðe lyfað and rixað mid þam Ælmihtigan Fæder and ðam Halgum Gaste á on ecnysse
who liveth and reigneth with the Almighty Father and the Holy Ghost ever to eternity

Amen
Amen

Fram ðam halgan easterlican dæge sind getealde fiftig daga to þysum dæge, and þes dæg is geháten Pentecostes, þæt is, se fifteogoða dæg ðære easterlican tide
From the holy day of Easter are counted fifty days to this day, and this day is called Pentecost, that is, the fiftieth day of Easter-tide

Þes dæg wæs on ðære ealdan ǽ gesett and gehalgod
This day was in the old law appointed and hallowed

God bebead Moyse, on Egypta-lande, þæt hé and eall Israhela folc sceoldon offrian æt ælcum híwisce Gode an lamb anes geares, and mearcian mid þam blode rode-tacn on heora gedyrum and oferslegum, ða on ðære nihte ferde Godes engel, and acwealde on ælcum huse ðæs Egyptiscan folces þæt frumcennyde cild and þæt leofoste
God commanded Moses in Egypt, that he and all the people of Israel should offer, for every household, a lamb of one year to God, and mark with the blood the sign of the cross on their door-posts and lintels, as on that night God's angel went and slew in every house of the Egyptian folk the firstborn child and the dearest

And Israhela folc ferde on ðære ylcan nihte of ðam leodscipe, and God hí lædde ofer ða Readan sǽ mid drium fotum
And the people of Israel went on the same night from the nation, and God led them over the Red sea with dry feet

Þa tengde se Pharao æfter mid mycelre fyrde
Pharaoh then hastened after them with a great army

Ðaða he com on middan ðære sǽ, þa wæs þæt Godes folc up-agán, and God ða besencte ðone Pharao and eal his werod
When he came into the middle of the sea, the people of God were gone up, and God then sank Pharaoh and all his host

Ða bebead God Moyse and þam folce þæt hí heoldon ða tid mid micelre arwurðnysse, on ælces geares ymbrene
God then commanded Moses and the people that they should keep that tide with great reverence in the circuit of every year

Þa wæs seo tid þam folce geset to Easter-tide, forðan ðe God hí hredde wið heora fynd, and heora ehteras fordyde
The tide was then appointed to the people for Easter-tide, because God had saved them from their foes, and destroyed their persecutors

Þa þæs ymbe fiftig daga sette God þam folce ǽ, and wæs gesewen Godes wuldor upp on anre dune þe is geháten Synáy
Then fifty days after this God appointed a law for the people, and the glory of God was seen on a hill which is called Sinai

Þær com micel leoht, and egeslic sweg, and blawende byman
There came a great light, and an awful sound, and blowing trumpets

Þa clypode God þone Moysen him to, and he wæs mid Gode feowertig daga, and awrát ða ealdan ǽ be Godes dihte
Then God called Moses to him, and he was with God forty days, and wrote down the old law by God's direction

Þa wæs se dæg Pentecostes geháten on ðære Ealdan Gesetnysse
Then was the day called Pentecost in the Old Testament

Þæt geoffrode lámb getacnode Cristes slege, seðe unscæððig wæs his Fæder geoffrod for ure alysednysse
The offered lamb betokened the slaying of Christ, who innocent was offered to his Father for our redemption

Nu is his ðrowung and his ærist ure Easter-tíd, forðan ðe he us alysde fram deofles þeowdome, and ure ehteras beoð besencte þurh þæt halige fulluht, swa swa wæs Pharao mid his leode on ðære Readan sǽ
Now is his passion and his resurrection our Easter-tide, because he redeemed us from the thraldom of the devil, and our persecutors are sunk by the holy baptism, as Pharaoh was with his people in the Red sea

Þas fiftig daga fram ðam easterlican dæge sind ealle gehalgode to anre mærsunge, and þes dægðerlica dæg is ure Pentecostes, þæt is, se fifteogoða dæg fram ðam Easter-dæge
These fifty days from the day of Easter are all hallowed to one celebration, and this present day is our Pentecost, that is, the fiftieth day from Easter-day

On ðam ealdan Pentecosten sette God ǽ ðam Israhela folce, and on ðisum dæge com se Halga Gast on fyres hiwe to Godes hirede
On the old Pentecost God appointed a law to the people of Israel, and on this day the Holy Ghost came in semblance of fire to God's company

forði ealswa þæt lamb getacnode Cristes ðrowunge, swa eac seo ealde ǽ getacnode godspel-bodunge under Godes gife
for as the lamb betokened the passion of Christ, so also the old law betokened the preaching of the gospel under the grace of God

Þreo tida sind on ðysre worulde: án is seo ðe wæs butan ǽ
There are three periods in this world: one is that which was without law

oðer is seo ðe wæs under ǽ
the second is that which was under the law

seo ðridde is nu æfter Cristes to-cyme
the third is now after the advent of Christ

Þeos tíd is gecweden 'under Godes gife
This period is called 'under God's grace

' We ne sind na butan ǽ, ne we ne moton healdan Moyses ǽ lichamlice, ac Godes gifu ús gewissað to his willan, gif we gemyndige beoð Cristes bebodum and ðæra apostola lare
' We are not without law, nor may we hold bodily the law of Moses, but God's grace directs us to his will, if we be mindful of Christ's commandments and of the precepts of the apostles

Hit is gereht on ðyssere pistol-rædinge, hu se Halga Gast on ðisum dæge com to ðam geleaffullan heape Cristes hyredes
It is related in this epistolary lesson, how the Holy Ghost on this day came to the faithful company of Christ's followers

Lucas se Godspellere awrát on ðære béc 'Actus Apostolorum,' þæt
Luke the Evangelist wrote in the book 'The Acts of the Apostles,' that

se halga hyred wæs wunigende ánmodlice on gebedum on anre upflora, æfter Cristes upstige, anbidigende his behates
the holy company was living unanimously in prayers on an upper floor, after Christ's ascension, awaiting his behest

þa on ðisum dæge, þe is Pentecostes gecweden, com færlice micel sweg of heofonum and gefylde ealle ða upfleringe mid fyre
when, on this day, which is called Pentecost, there came suddenly a great sound from heaven, and filled all the upper flooring with fire, and there appeared above each of them as it were fiery tongues, and they were then all filled with the Holy Ghost, and begun to speak with divers tongues, according as the Holy Ghost taught them

and wæs æteowed bufon heora ælcum swylce fyrene tungan, and hí wurdon ða ealle gefyllede mid þam Halgum Gaste, and ongunnon to sprecenne mid mislicum gereordum, be ðam þe se Halga Gast him tæhte
Then there were gathered within the city of Jerusalem pious men of every nation dwelling under heaven

Þa wæron gegaderode binnan ðære byrig Hierusalem eawfæste weras of ælcere ðeode ðe under heofonum eardiað
and the apostles spake to the gathering of people, and every of them recognized his own tongue

Ða wearð seo menigu swiðe ablicged, and mid wundrunge cwædon, La hú, ne sind þas ðe her sprecað Galileisce
Then was the multitude greatly amazed, and with wonder said, Lo, are not these which here speak Galileans

And ure ælc gehyrde hu hi spræcon urum gereordum, on ðam ðe we acennede wæron
And each of us hath heard how they speak in our tongues, in which we were born

We gehyrdon hí sprecan Godes mærða mid urum gereordum
We have heard them declare the glories of God in our tongues

La hwæt ðis beon sceole
Lo, what should this be

Þa cwædon ða Iudeiscan mid hospe, Þas men sindon mid muste fordrencte
Then said the Jews in mockery, These men are drunken with new wine

Þa andwyrde Petrus, Hit is undern-tíd
But Peter answered, It is the third hour

hu mihte we on ðysre tide beon fordrencte
how might we at this time be drunken

Ac ðæs witegan cwyde Ioheles is nu gefylled
But the saying of the prophet Joel is now fulfilled

God cwæð þurh ðæs witegan muð, þæt he wolde his Gast asendan ofer mennisc flæsc
God spake through the prophet's mouth, that he would send his spirit over human flesh, and the children of men shall prophesy, and I will give my foretokens from heaven above, and my signs on earth beneath

and manna bearn sceolon witigian, and ic sylle mine forebeacn ufan of heofonum, and mine tácna niðer on eorðan
For know ye that Christ arose from death, and in our sight ascended to heaven, and sitteth on his Father's right, as David had prophesied concerning him, thus saying, The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit on my right until I lay thy foes under thy footstool

Wite ge soðlice þæt Crist arás of deaðe, and on ure gewitnysse astah to heofonum, and sitt æt his Fæder swiðran, swa swa Dauid be him witegode, þus cweðende, Drihten cwæð to minum Drihtne, Site to minre swiðran, oðþæt ic alecge ðine fynd under þinum fot-scamele
When the people heard this they were stimulated, and said to the apostles, Alas

Þa þæt folc ðis gehyrde, ða wurdon hí onbryrde, and cwædon to ðam apostolon, La leof, hwæt is us to donne
what have we to do

Þa andwyrde Petrus, Behreowsiað eowre synna, and underfoð fulluht on Cristes naman, and eowre synna beoð adylegode, and ge underfoð þone Halgan Gast
Then Peter answered, Repent of your sins, and receive baptism in the name of Christ, and your sins shall be blotted out, and ye shall receive the Holy Ghost

Þa underfengon hi his lare, and bugon to fulluhte on ðam dæge ðreo ðusend manna
They then received his doctrine, and there submitted to baptism on that day three thousand men

Þa wæron ealle on annysse mid þam apostolum, and beceapodon heora æhta, and þæt feoh betæhton ðam apostolum, and hi dældon ælcum be his neode
And they were all in unity with the apostles, and sold their possessions, and delivered the money to the apostles, and they distributed to each according to his need

Eft on oðre bodunge gelyfdon fif ðusend wera on Crist, and wearð eall seo geleaffulle menigu swa anmod swilce hí ealle hæfdon ane heortan and ane sawle
Again, at another preaching, five thousand men believed in Christ, and all the believing multitude was as unanimous as if they all had one heart and one soul

ne heora nan næfde synderlice æhta, ac him eallum wæs gemæne heora ðing, ne ðær næs nán wædla betwux him
not one of them had separate possessions, but their things were common to them all, nor was there any poor person among them

Þa ðe land-are hæfdon hi hit beceapodon, and þæt wurð brohton to ðæra apostola fotum: hí ða dældon ælcum be his neode
Those who had land-property sold it, and brought the worth to the feet of the apostles: they then distributed it to each according to his need

Þa worhte God fela tacna on ðam folce ðurh ðæra apostola handa, swa þæt hi gelogodon ða untruman be ðære stræt þær Petrus forð eode, and swa hraðe swa his sceadu hi hreopode, hi wurdon gehælede fram eallum untrumnyssum
Then God wrought many signs among the people by the hands of the apostles, so that they placed the sick along the street where Peter passed, and as his shadow touched them, they were healed of all sicknesses

Þa arn micel menigu to of gehendum burgum, and brohton heora untruman and ða deofol-seocan, and hí ealle wurdon gehælede æt ðæra apostola handum
Then ran a great multitude from the neighbouring towns, and brought their sick and those possessed with devils, and they were all healed at the hands of the apostles

Hi setton heora handa ofer gelyfede men, and hí underfengon þone Halgan Gast
They set their hands on believing men, and they received the Holy Ghost

Þa wæs sum ðegen, Annanias geháten, and his wíf Saphíra: hí cwædon him betweonan, þæt hí woldon bugan to ðæra apostola geferrædene
Then was a thane, called Ananias, and his wife Sapphira: they said between themselves, that they would incline to the fellowship of the apostles

Namon ða to ræde, þæt him wærlicor wære, þæt hí sumne dæl heora landes wurðes æthæfdon, weald him getimode
They then resolved, that it would be safer to withhold a portion of the worth of their land, in case aught befell them

Com ða se ðegen mid feo to ðam apostolum
The thane then came with the money to the apostles

Þa cwæð Petrus, Annania, deofol bepæhte ðine heortan, and ðu hæfst alogen þam Halgan Gaste
Then said Peter, Ananias, the devil hath cheated thy heart, and thou hast lied to the Holy Ghost

Hwí woldest ðu swician on ðinum agenum
Why wouldst thou deceive in thine own

Ne luge ðu na mannum, ac Gode
Thou hast not lied to men, but to God

Þa hé þas word gehyrde, þa feol hé adúne and gewát
When he had heard these words, he fell down and departed

Þaða he bebyrged wæs, þa com his wif Saphíra, and nyste hu hire were gelumpen wæs
When he was buried, his wife Sapphira came, and knew not how it had befallen her husband

Ða cwæð Petrus, Sege me, beceapode ge ðus micel landes
Then Peter said, Tell me, sold ye thus much land

Heo andwyrde, Gea, leof, swa micel
She answered, Yes, sir, so much

Eft ða cwæð Petrus, Hwí gewearð inc swa, þæt gyt dorston fandian Godes
Again said Peter, Why have ye so done, that ye durst tempt God

Heo feoll ðærrihte and gewát, and hí man bebyrigde to hyre were
She straightways fell down and departed, and they buried her by her husband

Þa wearð micel ege on Godes gelaðunge and on eallum þe þæt geaxodon
Then there was great fear in God's church, and on all those who heard of it

Þa apostoli siððan, ærðam ðe hi toferdon, gesetton Iacobum, þe wæs geháten Rihtwís, on Cristes setle, and eal seo geleaffulle gelaðung him gehyrsumode, æfter Godes tæcunge
The apostles afterwards, before they separated, set James, who was called Righteous, on the seat of Christ, according to God's instruction

He ða gesæt þæt setl ðritig geara, and æfter him Symeon, þæs Hælendes mæg
He sat on that seat thirty years, and after him Simeon, the kinsman of Jesus

Æfter ðære gebysnunge wurdon arærede munec-líf mid þære gehealdsumnysse, þæt hi drohtnian on mynstre, be heora ealdres dihte, on clænnesse, and him beon heora æhta eallum gemæne, swa ða apostoli hit astealdon
From that example monastic life arose with abstinence, so that they live in a monastery, according to the direction of their principal, in chastity, and their possessions are common to them all, as the apostles established it

Ge gehyrdon lytle ǽr, on ðisre rædinge, þæt se Halga Gast com ofer ða apostolas on fyrenum tungum, and him forgeaf ingehyd ealra gereorda
Ye heard a little before, in this lesson, that the Holy Ghost came over the apostles as fiery tongues, and gave them knowledge of all languages

forðan ðe se eadmoda heap geearnode æt Gode þæt iú ǽr þæt modige werod forleas
for the humble company merited of God that which long of yore the proud host had lost

Hit getimode æfter Noes flode, þæt entas woldon aræran ane burh, and ænne stypel swa heahne, þæt his hrof astige oð heofon
It happened after Noah's flood, that giants would raise up a city, and a tower so high, that its roof should ascend to heaven

Þa wæs an gereord on eallum mancynne, and þæt weorc wæs begunnen ongean Godes willan
There was then one language among all mankind, and the work was begun against the will of God

God eac forði hí tostencte, swa þæt he forgeaf ælcum ðæra wyrhtena seltcuð gereord, and heora nán ne cuðe oðres spræce tocnawan
God therefore scattered them, so that he gave to each of the workmen an unknown language, and not one of them could understand another's speech

Hí ða geswicon ðære getimbrunge, and toferdon geond ealne middangeard
They then ceased from the building, and went divers ways over all the world

and wæron siððan swa fela gereord swa ðæra wyrhtena wæs
and there were afterwards as many languages as there were workmen

Nu eft on ðisum dæge, þurh ðæs Halgan Gastes to-cyme, wurdon ealle gereord ge-anlæhte and geðwære
Now again, on this day, through the advent of the Holy Ghost, all languages became united and concordant

forðan ðe eal se halga heap Cristes hyredes wæs sprecende mid eallum gereordum
for all the holy company of Christ's followers were speaking in all languages

and eac þæt wunderlicor wæs, ðaða heora án bodade mid anre spræce, ælcum wæs geðuht, ðe ða bodunge gehyrde, swilce he spræce mid his gereorde, wæron hí Ebreisce, oððe Grecisce, oððe Romanisce, oððe Egyptisce, oððe swa hwilcere ðeode swa hí wæron þe ða lare gehyrdon
and also, what was more wonderful, when one of them preached in one tongue, it seemed to everyone who heard the preaching as though he spake in his language, whether they were Hebrews, or Greeks, or Romans, or Egyptians, or of whatsoever nation they might be who heard that doctrine

On ðysre geferrædene geearnode heora eadmodnys þas mihte, and ðæra enta modignys geearnode gescyndnysse
In this fellowship their humility gained them this power, and the pride of the giants gained shame

Se Halga Gast wæs æteowod ofer ða apostolas on fyres hiwe, and ofer Criste, on his fulluhte, on anre culfran anlicnysse
The Holy Ghost appeared over the apostles in semblance of fire, and over Christ, at his baptism, in likeness of a dove

Hwí ofer Criste on culfran hiwe
Why over Christ in semblance of a dove

Hwí ofer Cristes hirede on fyres gelicnysse
Why over the followers of Christ in likeness of fire

On bocum is gerædd be ðam fugelcynne þæt his gecynd is swiðe bilewite, and unscæððig, and gesibsum
In books it is read concerning that kind of birds that its nature is very meek, and innocent, and peaceful

Se Hælend is ealles mancynnes dema, ac he ne com na to demenne mancynn, swa swa he sylf cwæð, ac to gehælenne
The Saviour is the Judge of all mankind, but he came not to judge mankind, as he himself said, but to save

Gif he ða wolde deman mancynn, ðaða he ærest to middangearde com, hwa wurde þonne gehealden
If he then would have judged mankind, when he first came on earth, who would have been saved

Ac he nolde mid his to-cyme ða synfullan fordeman, ac wolde to his rice gegaderian
But he would not by his advent condemn the sinful, but would gather them to his kingdom

Ærest he wolde us mid liðnysse styran, þæt he siððan mihte on his dome us gehealdan
He would first with gentleness direct us, that he might afterwards preserve us at his judgement

Forði wæs se Halga Gast on culfran anlicnysse gesewen bufan Criste, forðan ðe hé wæs drohtnigende on ðisre worulde mid bilewitnysse, and unscæððignysse, and gesibsumnysse
Therefore was the Holy Ghost seen in likeness of a dove above Christ, because he was living in this world in meekness, and innocence, and peacefulness

He ne hrymde, ne he biterwyrde næs, ne he sace ne astyrede, ac forbær manna yfelnysse þurh his liðnysse
He cried not out, nor was he inclined to bitterness, nor did he stir up strife, but endured man's wickedness through his meekness

Ac se ðe on ðam ærran to-cyme liðegode, þam synfullum to gecyrrednysse, se demð stiðne dom þam receleasum æt ðam æfteran to-cyme
But he who at his first advent mitigated, for the conversion of the sinful, will deem stern doom to the reckless at his second advent

Se Halga Gast wæs gesewen on fyrenum tungum bufon ðam apostolon, forðan ðe hé dyde þæt hi wæron byrnende on Godes willan, and bodigende ymbe Godes rice
The Holy Ghost was seen as fiery tongues above the apostles

Fyrene tungan hí hæfdon, ðaða hí mid lufe Godes mærða bodedon, þæt ðæra hæðenra manna heortan, ðe cealde wæron þurh geleaflæste and flæsclice gewilnunga, mihton beon ontende to ðam heofenlicum bebodum
for he effected that they were burning in God's will, and preaching of God's kingdom

Gif se Halga Gast ne lærð þæs mannes mód wiðinnan, on idel beoð þæs bydeles word wiðutan geclypode
They had fiery tongues when with love they preached the greatness of God, that the hearts of the heathen men, which were cold through infidelity and fleshly desires, might be kindled to the heavenly commands

Fyres gecynd is þæt hit fornimð swa hwæt swa him gehende bið: swa sceal se láreow dón, seðe bið mid þam Halgan Gaste onbryrd, ærest on him sylfum ælcne leahter adwæscan, and siððan on his underðeoddum
If the Holy Ghost teach not a man's mind within, in vain will be the words of the preacher proclaimed without

On culfran anlicnysse and on fyres hiwe wæs Godes Gast æteowod
In likeness of a dove and in semblance of fire was the Spirit of God manifested

forðan ðe hé deð þæt ða beoð bilewite on unscæððignysse, and byrnende on Godes willan, þe he mid his gife gefylð
for he causes those to be meek in innocence, and burning in the will of God, whom he fills with his grace

Ne bið seo bilewitnys Gode gecweme butan snoternysse, ne seo snoternys butan bilewitnysse
Meekness is not pleasing to God without wisdom, nor wisdom without meekness

swa swa gecweden is be ðam eadigan Iób, þæt he wæs bilewite and rihtwis
as it is said by the blessed Job, that he was meek and righteous

Hwæt bið rihtwisnys butan bilewitnysse
What is righteousness without meekness

Oððe hwæt bið bilewitnys butan rihtwisnysse
Or what is meekness without righteousness

Ac se Halga Gast, ðe tæhð rihtwisnysse and bilewitnysse, sceolde beon æteowod ægðer ge on fyre ge on culfran, forðan ðe hé deð þæra manna heortan ðe hé onliht mid his gife, þæt hi beoð liðe þurh unscæððignysse, and onælede ðurh lufe and snoternysse
But the Holy Ghost, who teaches both righteousness and meekness, should be manifested both as fire and as a dove, for he causes the hearts of those men whom he enlightens with his grace to be meek through innocence, and kindled by love and wisdom

God is, swa swa Paulus cwæð, fornymende fyr
God is, as Paul said, a consuming fire

He is únasecgendlic fyr, and ungesewenlic
He is a fire unspeakable and invisible

Be ðam fyre cwæð se Hælend
Concerning that fire Jesus said

Ic com to ði þæt ic wolde sendan fyr on eorðan, and ic wylle þæt hit byrne
I come because I would send fire on earth, and I will that it burn

He sende ðone Halgan Gast to eorðan, and he mid his blæde onælde eorðlicra manna heortan
He sent the Holy Ghost on earth, and he by his inspiration kindled the hearts of earthly men

Þonne byrnð seo eorðe, þonne ðæs eorðlican mannes heorte bið ontend to Godes lufe, seoðe ær wæs ceald þurh flæsclice lustas
Then burns the earth, when the earthly man's heart is kindled to love of God, which before was cold through fleshly lusts

Nis na se Halga Gast wunigende on his gecynde, swa swa hé gesewen wæs, forðan ðe he is ungesewenlic
The Holy Ghost is not in his nature existing as he was seen, for he is invisible

ac for ðære getacnunge, swa we ær cwædon, he wæs æteowod on culfran, and on fyre
but for the sign, as we before said, he appeared as a dove and as fire

He is gehaten on Greciscum gereorde, Paraclitus, þæt is, Frofor-gast, forði ðe he frefrað þa dreorian, þe heora synna behreowsiað, and sylð him forgyfenysse hiht, and heora unrotan mód geliðegað
He is called in the Greek tongue Παρακλητος, that is, Comforting Spirit, because he comforts the sad, who repent of their sins, and gives them hope of forgiveness, and alleviates their sorrowful minds

He forgyfð synna, and he is se weg to forgyfenysse ealra synna
He forgives sins, and he is the way to forgiveness of all sins

He sylð his gife ðam ðe he wile
He gives his grace to whom he will

Sumum men he forgifð wisdom and spræce, sumum gód ingehyd, sumum micelne geleafan, sumum mihte to gehælenne untruman, sumum witegunge, sumum toscead godra gasta and yfelra
To one man he gives wisdom and eloquence, to one good knowledge, to one great faith, to one power to heal the sick, to one prophetic power, to one discrimination of good and evil spirits

sumum he forgifð mislice gereord, sumum gereccednysse mislicra spræca
to one he gives divers tongues, to one interpretation of divers sayings

Ealle ðas ðing deð se Halga Gast, todælende æghwilcum be ðam ðe him gewyrð
The Holy Ghost does all these things, distributing to everyone as to him seems good

forðam ðe he is Ælmihtig Wyrhta, and swa hraðe swa he þæs mannes mod onliht, he hit awent fram yfele to gode
for he is the Almighty Worker, and as soon as he enlightens the mind of a man, he turns it from evil to good

He onlihte Dauides heortan, ðaða he on iugoðe hearpan lufode, and worhte hine to psalm-wyrhtan
He enlightened the heart of David, when in youth he loved the harp, and made him to be a psalmist

Amos hatte sum hryðer-hyrde, þone awende se Halga Gast to mærum witegan
There was a cow-herd called Amos, whom the Holy Ghost turned to a great prophet

Petrus wæs fiscere, þone awende se ylca Godes Gast to apostole
Peter was a fisher, whom the same Spirit of God turned to an apostle

Paulus ehte cristenra manna, þone he geceas to lareowe eallum ðeodum
Paul persecuted christian men, whom he chose for instructer of all nations

Matheus wæs tollere, þone he awende to godspellere
Matthew was a toll-gatherer, whom he turned to an evangelist

Þa apostoli ne dorston bodian þone soðan geleafan, for ógan Iudeisces folces
The apostles durst not preach the true faith, for fear of the Jewish folk

ac siððan hí wæron onælede þurh ðone Halgan Gast, hí forsawon ealle lichamlice pinunga, and orsorhlice Godes mærða bodedon
but after that they were fired by the Holy Ghost, they despised all bodily tortures, and fearlessly preached the greatness of God

Þyses dæges wurðmynt is to mærsigenne, forðan ðe se Ælmihtiga God, þæt is se Halga Gast, gemedemode hine sylfne þæt he wolde manna bearn on ðisre tide geneosian
The dignity of this day is to be celebrated, because Almighty God, that is the Holy Ghost, himself vouchsafed to visit the children of men at this time

On Cristes acennednysse wearð se Ælmihtiga Godes Sunu to menniscum men gedon, and on ðisum dæge wurdon geleaffulle men godas, swa swa Crist cwæð
At the birth of Christ the Almighty Son of God became human man, and on this day believing men became gods, as Christ said

An God is gecyndelice on ðrim hadum, Fæder, and his Sunu, þæt is his Wisdom, and se Halga Gast, seðe is heora begra Lufu and Willa
The chosen are children of God, and also gods, not naturally, but through grace of the Holy Ghost

Heora gecynd is untodæledlic, æfre wunigende on anre Godcundnysse
One God is naturally in three persons, the Father, and his Son, that is, his Wisdom, and the Holy Ghost, who is the Love and Will of them both

Se ylca cwæð þeah-hwæðere be his gecorenum
Their nature is indivisible, ever existing in one Godhead

Ge sint godas
The same has, nevertheless, said of his chosen

Crist underfeng menniscnysse on his to-cyme, and men underfengon God þurh neosunge þæs Halgan Gastes
Through Christ's humanity men were redeemed from the thraldom of the devil, and through the coming of the Holy Ghost human men were made gods

Se man ðe næfð Godes Gast on him nis hé Godes
Christ received human nature at his advent, and men received God through visitation of the Holy Ghost

Ælces mannes weorc cyðað hwilc gast hine wissað
The man who has not in him the Spirit of God is not God's

Godes Gast wissað symble to halignysse and gódnysse
Every man's works show what spirit directs him

deofles gast wissað to leahtrum and to mándædum
The Spirit of God ever directs to holiness and goodness

Se Halga Gast becom tuwa ofer ða apostolas
The Holy Ghost came twice over the apostles

Crist ableow ðone Halgan Gast upon ða apostolas ǽr his upstige, þus cweðende
Christ blew the Holy Ghost on the apostles before his resurrection, thus saying

Onfoð Haligne Gast
Receive the Holy Ghost

Eft, on ðisum dæge, asende se Ælmihtiga Fæder and se Sunu heora begra Gast to ðam geleaffullan heape, on ðysre worulde wunigende
Again, on this day, the Almighty Father and the Son sent the Spirit of both to the faithful company dwelling in this world

Se Hælend ableow his Gast on his gingran, for ðære getacnunge þæt hí and ealle cristene men sceolon lufigan heora nehstan swa swa hí sylfe
Jesus blew his Spirit on his disciples for a sign that they and all christian men should love their neighbours as themselves

He sende eft, swa swa hé ǽr behet, ðone ylcan Gast of heofonum, to ði þæt we sceolon lufian God ofer ealle oðre ðing
He sent afterwards, as he had before promised, the Holy Ghost from heaven, to the end that we should love God above all other things

An is se Halga Gast, þeah ðe he tuwa become ofer ða apostolas
The Holy Ghost is one, though he came twice over the apostles

Swa is eac án lufu and twa bebodu, Þæt we sceolon lufian God and menn
So also there is one love and two commandments, That we should love God and men

Ac we sceolon leornian on mannum hu we magon becuman to Godes lufe, swa swa Iohannes se apostol cwæð
But we should learn by men how we may come to the love of God, as John the apostle said

Se ðe ne lufað his broðor, ðone ðe he gesihð, hu mæg hé lufian God, þone þe he ne gesihð lichamlice
He who loveth not his brother, whom he seeth, how can he love God, whom he seeth not bodily

We wurðiað þæs Halgan Gastes to-cyme mid lofsangum seofon dagas, forðan ðe he onbryrt ure mód mid seofonfealdre gife, þæt is, mid wisdome and andgyte, mid geðeahte and strencðe, mid ingehyde and arfæstnysse, and he us gefylð mid Godes ege
We celebrate the advent of the Holy Ghost with hymns for seven days, because he stimulates our mind with a sevenfold gift, that is, with wisdom and understanding, with counsel and strength, with knowledge and piety, and he fills us with awe of God

Se ðe þurh gode geearnunga becymð to ðissum seofonfealdum gifum þæs Halgan Gastes, he hæfð þonne ealle geðincðe
He who through good deserts attains to these sevenfold gifts of the Holy Ghost will have all honour

Ac se ðe wile to ðisre geðincðe becuman, he sceal gelyfan on ða Halgan Ðrynnysse, and on Soðe Annysse, þæt se Fæder, and his Sunu, and heora begra Gast syndon ðry on hadum, and án God untodæledlic, on anre Godcundnysse wunigende
But he who will attain to this honour shall believe in the Holy Trinity, and in True Unity, that the Father, and his Son, and the Spirit of them both are three in persons, and one God indivisible, existing in one Godhead

Þysne geleafan getacnodon ða ðreo ðusend þe ærest gebugon to geleafan, æfter ðæs Halgan Gastes to-cyme
This faith was betokened by the three thousand who first inclined to belief, after the advent of the Holy Ghost

Swa swa ða ðreo þusend wæron án werod, swa is seo Halige Ðrynnys án God
As those three thousand were one company, so is the Holy Trinity one God

And þæt werod wæs swa ánmod swilce him eallum wære án heorte and án sawul
And that company was as unanimous as though they all had one heart and one soul

forðan ðe þære Halgan Þrynnysse is án godcundnyss, and án gecynd, and án willa, and án weorc unascyrigendlice
for of the Holy Trinity there is one Godhead, and one nature, and one will, and one work inseparable

Þa geleaffullan brohton heora feoh, and ledon hit æt ðæra apostola foton
The faithful brought their money, and laid it at the feet of the apostles

Mid þam is geswutelod þæt cristene men ne sceolon heora hiht besettan on woroldlice gestreon, ac on Gode anum
By this is manifested that christian men should not set their delight in worldly treasure, but in God alone

Se gítsere ðe beset his hiht on his goldhord, he bið swa swa se apostol cwæð
The covetous who sets his delight in his gold-hoard, is, as the apostle said

þam gelíc þe deofolgyld begæð
like unto him who practiseth idolatry

Hi heoldon þæt gold unwurðlice, forðan ðe seo gitsung næfde nænne stede on heora heortan: forði hí dydon heora ðing him gemæne, þæt hí on soðre sibbe butan gytsunge beon mihton
They held the gold as worthless, because covetousness had no place in their hearts: they made their goods in common, that they might be in true peace without covetousness

Hí setton heora handa ofer geleaffulle men, and him com to se Halga Gast ðurh heora biscepunge
They set their hands over believing men, and the Holy Ghost came to them through their bishoping

Biscopas sind þæs ylcan hádes on Godes gelaðunge, and healdað þa gesetnysse on heora biscepunge, swa þæt hí settað heora handa ofer gefullude menn, and biddað þæt se Ælmihtiga Wealdend him sende ða seofonfealdan gife his Gastes, seðe leofað and rixað á butan ende
Bishops are of the same order in God's church, and hold that institution in their bishoping, so that they set their hands over baptized men, and pray the Almighty Ruler to send them the sevenfold gift of his Spirit, who liveth and reigneth ever without end

Amen
Amen

Se Wealdenda Drihten sæde ðis bígspell his gingrum, þus cweðende
The Sovereign Lord spake this parable to his disciples, thus saying

Sum welig man wæs mid purpuran and godewebbe geglenged, and dæghwamlice mærlice leofode
There was a certain rich man adorned with purple and fine linen, and daily lived sumptuously

Þa læg sum wædla at his geate, and his nama wæs Lazarus, se wæs lic-ðrowere
A certain poor man lay at his gate, and his name was Lazarus, who was a leper

et reliqua
etc

Þis godspel is nu anfealdlice gesǽd
This gospel is now simply said

Se halga papa Gregorius us onwreah ða digelnysse ðisre rædinge
The holy pope Gregory has revealed to us the mystery of this text

He cwæð
He said

Ne sæde þæt halige godspel þæt se ríca reafere wære, ac wæs uncystig and modegode on his welum
The holy gospel did not express that the rich man was a robber, but that he was parsimonious, and exulted in his wealth

Be ðisum is to smeagenne, hu se beo gewitnod þe oðerne berypð, þonne se bið to helle fordemed se his agen nolde for Godes lufon syllan
By this it is to be considered how he will be punished who bereaves another, when he is condemned to hell, who would not give his own for love of God

Ðises mannes uncyst and up-ahefednys hine besencte on cwycsusle, forðan ðe he næfde nane mildheortnysse, þæt he mid his gestreone his agene sawle alysde
This man's parsimony and pride sank him into quick torment, because he had no compassion, so that with his treasure he might have redeemed his own soul

Nu wenað sume menn þæt nan pleoh ne sy on deorwurðum gyrlum
Now some men will imagine that there is no peril in precious garments, but if there were no sin, the holy gospel would not have so evidently manifested with respect to the rich man, that he was adorned with purple and with fine linen

ac gif hit gylt nære, þonne ne geswutulode þæt halige godspel swa gewislice be ðam rican, þæt he wære mid purpuran and mid godewebbe geglencged
No man heeds precious garments save for vain pride, verily that he may through his splendour be accounted before other men

Ne cepð nan man deorwyrðra reafa buton for ydelum gylpe, soðlice þæt he sy toforan oðrum mannum þurh his glencge geteald
The Lord in another place praised John the Baptist for the rudeness of his garment, because he was clothed with camel's hair, poorly and ruggedly

Þaða se Hælend spræc be ðam rican, þa cwæð he
When Jesus spake of the rich man he said

Sum rice man wæs
There was a certain rich man

Eft be ðam wædlan
Again, of the poor man

Sum ðearfa wæs geháten Lazarus
There was a certain poor man called Lazarus

Cuð is eow þæt se rica bið namcuðre on his leode þonne se þearfa
It is known to you that a rich man is more known by name among his people than a poor one

þeah-hwæðere ne nemde se Hælend þone welegan, ac ðone wædlan
nevertheless Jesus named not the wealthy man, but the needy one

forðan ðe him is cuð þæra eadmodra manna naman ðurh gecorennysse, ac he ne cann ða modigan ðurh heora aworpennysse
because the names of humble men are known to him through election, but he knows not the proud through their rejection

Sume beladunge mihte se rica habban his uncyste, gif se reoflia wædla ne læge ætforan his gesihðe: eac wære ðam earman leohtre on mode, gif he ðæs rican mannes welan ne gesawe
Some excuse the rich man might have had for his parsimony, if the leprous beggar had not lain before his sight: the mind of the poor man would also have been easier, if he had not seen the rich man's wealth

Mislice angsumnyssa he forbær, ðaða he næfde ne bigleofan, ne hælðe, ne hætera, and geseah ðone rican halne and deorweorðlice geglencgedne brucan his estmettas
Divers afflictions he endured, seeing that he had neither nourishment, nor health, nor garments, and saw the rich man, hale and sumptuously decorated, enjoying his luxuries

Genoh wære þam wædlan his untrumnys, þeah ðe he wiste hæfde
For the beggar his infirmity had been enough, though he had had food

and eft him wære genoh his hafenleast, ðeah ðe he gesundful wære
and again, his indigence had been enough for him, although he had been healthful

Ac seo menigfealde earfoðnys wæs his sawle clænsung, and ðæs rican uncyst and up-ahefednys wæs his geniðerung
But the manifold hardship was the cleansing of his soul, and the parsimony and pride of the rich man were his condemnation

forðon ðe he geseah ðæs oðres yrmðe, and hine mid toðundenum mode forseah
because he saw the other's misery, and with inflated mind despised him

Ac ðaða he wæs fram mannum forsewen, ða genealæhton ða hundas, and his wunda geliccedon
But when he was despised of men, the dogs approached, and licked his wounds

Hundes liccung gehælð wunda
The licking of a dog heals wounds

Þa gelamp hit þæt se wædla gewát, and englas ferodon his sawle to ðæs heahfæderes wununge Abrahámes
It then happened that the beggar died, and angels bare his soul to the dwelling of the patriarch Abraham

and ðæs rican gast æfter forðsiðe wearð on helle besenct
and the rich man's spirit after death was sunk into hell

and he ða ðone wolde habban him to mundboran, þam ðe he nolde ǽr his cruman syllan
and he then wished to have him for protector, to whom he would not before give his crumbs

He bæd þa Abraham mid earmlicre stemne þæt Lazarus moste his tungan drypan
He then bade Abraham with piteous voice, that Lazarus might moisten his tongue

ac him næs getiðod ðære lytlan lisse, forðan ðe Lazarus ne moste ǽr on life hedan ðæra crumena his mysan
but that little favour was not granted him, because Lazarus might not before in life gather the crumbs of his table

His tungan he mænde swiðost, forðan ðe hit is gewunelic þæt ða welegan on heora gebeorscipe begað derigendlice gafetunge
He particularly complained of his tongue, because it is usual that the wealthy in their feasting practise pernicious scoffing

þa wæs seo tunge, ðurh rihtwisnysse edlean, teartlicor gewítnod for his gegafspræce
therefore was his tongue, through righteous retribution, more harshly punished for his scoffing speech

Se heahfæder Abraham him cwæð to
The patriarch Abraham said to him

Ðu, mín bearn, beo ðe gemyndig þæt ðu underfenge welan on ðinum life, and Lazarus yrmðe
My son, be thou mindful that thou receivedst riches in thy life, and Lazarus misery

Þes cwyde is swiðor to ondrædenne þonne to trahtnigenne
This saying is rather to be feared than expounded

Ðam rican wæs forgolden mid ðam hwilwendlicum spedum, gif he hwæt to gode gefremode
The rich man was requited with transitory prosperity, if he did aught of good

and ðam ðearfan wæs forgolden mid ðære yrmðe, gif he hwæt to yfle gefremode
and the poor man was requited with misery, if he had perpetrated aught of evil

Þa underfeng se welega his gesælðe to edleane to sceortum brice, and þæs ðearfan hafenleast aclænsode his lytlan gyltas
Then the wealthy man received his happiness in reward for short enjoyment, and the indigence of the needy one cleansed away his little sins

Hine geswencte seo wædlung, and afeormode
Poverty afflicted and purified him

þone oðerne gewelgode his genihtsumnys, and bepæhte
his abundance enriched and deceived the other

Ic bidde eow, men ða leofostan, ne forseo ge Godes ðearfan, ðeah ðe hi tallice hwæt gefremman
I pray you, men most beloved, despise not God's poor, though they perpetrate anything reprehensible

forðan ðe heora yrmð afeormað þæt þæt seo gehwæde oferflowendnys gewemð
because their misery cleanses that which a little superfluity corrupts

Háwiað be gehwilcum, forðan ðe oft getimað yfelum teala for life
Observe each one, for good often befalls the evil for life

Se heahfæder cwæð to ðam welegan
The patriarch said to the wealthy man

Betwux us and eow is gefæstnod micel ðrosm
Betwixt us and you is fixed a great vapour

þeah hwa wille fram ús to eow, he ne mæg
though any-one will pass from us to you, he cannot

ne eac fram eow to ús
nor also from you to us

Mid micelre geornfulnysse gewilniað þa wiðercoran þæt hi moton of ðære susle ðe hi on cwylmiað, ac seo fæstnung ðære hellican clysinge ne geðafað þæt hi æfre ut-abrecon
With great eagerness the wicked desire to pass from the torment in which they suffer, but the fastening of the hellish enclosure never allows them to break out

Eac ða halgan beoð mid heora Scyppendes rihtwisnysse swa afyllede, þæt hi nateshwon ne besargiað ðæra wiðercorenra yrmðe
Also the holy are so filled with their Creator's righteousness, that they in no wise lament the misery of the wicked

forðan ðe hi geseoð þa fordónan swa micclum fram him geælfremode, swa micclum swa hi beoð fram heora leofan Drihtne ascofene
because they see the fordone ones as greatly estranged from them, as they are thrust away from their beloved Lord

Siððan se rica wearð orwene his agenre alysednysse, ða beárn him on mod his gebroðra gemynd
When the rich man became hopeless of his own deliverance, the remembrance of his brothers entered into his mind

forðan ðe ðæra wiðercorenra wite tiht for wel oft heora mod unnytwurðlice to lufe, swilce hi þonne lufian heora siblingas, ðe ǽr on life ne hi sylfe ne heora magas ne lufedon
for the punishment of the wicked very often uselessly stimulates their minds to love, so that they then love their relatives, who before in life loved neither themselves nor their kinsmen

Ne lufað se hine sylfne seðe hine mid synnum bebint
He loves not himself who binds himself with sins

He oncneow Lazarum, ðone ðe he ǽr forseah, and he gemunde his gebroðra, ða ðe he bæftan forlet
He recognized Lazarus, whom he had before despised, and he remembered his brothers, whom he had left behind

forðan ðe se ðearfa nære fullice gewrecen on ðam rican, gif he on his wite hine ne oncneowe
for the needy one would not have been fully avenged on the rich, if he in his punishment had not recognized him

and eft nære his wite fulfremed on ðam fyre, buton he ða ylcan pinunga his siblingum gewende
and again, his punishment would not have been complete in the fire, unless he had expected the same torments for his relatives

Þa synfullan geseoð nu hwiltidum ða gecorenan on wuldre, ðe hi forsawon on worulde, þæt seo angsumnys heora modes ðe mare sy: and ða rihtwisan symle geseoð ða unrihtwisan on heora tintregum cwylmigende, þæt heora bliss ðe mare sy, and lufu to heora Drihtne, þe hi ahredde fram deofles anwealde, and fram ðam mánfullum heape
The sinful will now sometimes see the chosen in glory, whom they in the world despised, that the affliction of their minds may be the greater: and the righteous will ever see the unrighteous suffering in their torments, that their bliss and love to their Lord may be the greater, who rescued them from the power of the devil, and from the wicked band

Ne astyrað þæra rihtwisra gesihð him nænne ógan, ne heora wuldor ne wanað
That spectacle will excite no terror to the righteous, nor will their glory wane

forðan ðe ðær ne bið nán besargung ðæra mánfulra yrmðe, ac heora tintrega becymð þam gecorenum to maran blisse, swa swa on metinge bið forsewen seo blace anlicnys, þæt seo hwite sy beorhtre gesewen
for there will be no sorrowing for the misery of the wicked, but their torments will turn to the greater bliss of the chosen, as in a picture a dark likeness is provided, that the white may appear the brighter

Þa gecorenan geseoð symle heora Scyppendes beorhtnysse, and forði nis nan ðing on gesceaftum him bediglod
The chosen will constantly see their Creator's brightness, and therefore there is nothing in creation concealed from him

Se welega nolde on life gehyran ðone lareow Moysen, ne Godes witegan: ða wende he eac þæt his gebroðra hí woldon forseon, swa swa he dyde, and gyrnde forði þæt Lazarus hí moste warnigan, þæt hí ne becomon to his susle
The rich man would not in life hear the teacher Moses, or God's prophets: then he thought that his brothers would also despise them as he did, and desired therefore that Lazarus might warn them, so that they came not to his torment

Se heahfæder him andwyrde
The patriarch answered him

Gif hi forseoð Moyses ǽ and ðæra witegena bodunga, nellað hí gelyfan, þeah hwá of deaðe arise
If they despise the law of Moses and the preachings of the prophets, they will not believe, though one arose from death

Þa ðe forgimeleasiað þa eaðelican beboda þære ealdan ǽ, hu willað hí ðonne gehyrsumian þam healicum bebodum Cristes lare, ðe of deaðe arás
Those who neglect the easy commandments of the old law, how will they obey the sublime commandments of Christ's doctrine, who arose from death

Ic bidde eow, mine gebroðra, þæt ge beon gemyndige ðæs Lazares reste and ðæs rican wite, and doð swa swa Crist sylf tæhte
I pray you, my brethren, that ye be mindful of Lazarus's rest and of the rich man's punishment, and do as Christ himself taught

Tiliað eow freonda on Godes ðearfum, þæt hí on eowrum geendungum onfon eow into ecum eardung-stowum
Gain to yourselves friends among God's poor, that they at your end may receive you into eternal dwelling-places

Manega Lazaras ge habbað nu licgende æt eowrum gatum, biddende eowre oferflowendnysse
Many Lazaruses ye have now lying at your gates, begging for your superfluity

Ðeah ðe hí syn wáclice geðuhte, þeah-hwæðere hí beoð eft eowre ðingeras wið ðone Ælmihtigan
Though they are esteemed as vile, they will, nevertheless, be hereafter your interceders with the Almighty

Soðlice we sceoldon beodan þam ðearfum þæt hí us biddað, forðan ðe hí beoð ure mundboran, þa ðe nu wædligende æt us bigleofan wilniað
Verily we ought to enjoin the poor to pray for us, because they will be our protectors, who, now begging, desire sustenance of us

Ne sceole we forseon heora wácnysse, forðan ðe Criste bið geðenod þurh ðearfena anfenge, swa swa he sylf cwæð
We should not despise their vileness, for Christ himself is served through reception of the poor, as he himself said

Me hingrode, and ge me gereordodon
I was hungry, and ye fed me

me ðyrste, and ge me scencton
I was thirsty, and ye gave me to drink

ic wæs nacod, and ge me scryddon
I was naked, and ye clothed me

Nu cweð se halga Gregorius, þæt sum arwurðe munuc wæs on ðam earde Licaonia, swiðe eawfæst, his nama wæs Martirius
Now says the holy Gregory, there was a reverend monk in the country of Lycaonia, very pious, his name was Martyrius

Se ferde, be his abbudes hæse, to sumum oðrum mynstre, on his ærende: ða gemette he be wege sumne lic-ðrowere licgende eal tocínen, and nahte his feðes geweald: cwæð þæt he wolde genealæcan his hulce, gif he mihte
He went by order of his abbot to some other monastery, on his errand, when he found a leper lying by the way all chapped, and having no power of his feet: he said he wished to reach his hut, if he could

Þa ofhreow ðam munece þæs hreoflian mægenleast, and bewand hine mid his cæppan and bær to mynstreweard
Then the monk was grieved for the helplessness of the leper, and he wrapt him in his cloak and bare him towards his monastery

Þa wearð his abbude geswutelod hwæne he bær, and hrymde mid micelre stemne, and cwæð
Then it was disclosed to his abbot whom he was bearing, and he cried with a loud voice, and said

Yrnað, yrnað, and undoð þæs mynstres geat ardlice, forðan ðe ure broðor Martyrius berð þone Hælend on his bæce
Run, run, and undo the gate of the monastery quickly, for our brother Martyrius bears Jesus on his back

Þaða se munuc genealæhte ðæs mynstres geate, þa wánd se of his swuran þe wæs hreoflig geðuht, and wearð gesewen on Cristes gelicnysse
When the monk had reached the gate of the monastery, he who seemed a leper quitted his neck, and appeared in the likeness of Christ

Ða beseah se munuc up, and beheold hu he to heofonum astah
The monk then looked up, and beheld how he ascended to heaven

Þa cwæð se Hælend mid ðam upstige
Then said Jesus, while ascending

Martíri, ne sceamode ðe mín ofer eorðan, ne me ne sceamað þin on heofonum
Martyrius, thou wast not ashamed of me on earth, nor will I be ashamed of thee in heaven

Þa efste se abbud wið þæs muneces, and neodlice cwæð
Then the abbot hastened towards the monk, and eagerly said

Broðor min, hwær is se ðe ðu feredest
My brother, where is he whom thou didst carry

He cwæð
He said

Gif ic wiste hwæt he wære, ic wolde licgan æt his fotum
If I had known who he was, I would have lain at his feet

Þaða ic hine bær ne gefredde ic nanre byrðene swærnysse
When I bore him I felt no heaviness of any burthen

Hu mihte hé gefredan æniges hefes swærnysse, ðaða he ðone ferode ðe hine bær
How could he feel the heaviness of any weight, when he carried one who bore him

Nu cweð se halga Gregorius, þæt se Hælend ða geseðde ðone cwyde þe he sylf cwæð
Now says the holy Gregory, Jesus verified the saying which he himself said

Þæt þæt ge doð þearfum on minum naman, þæt ge doð me sylfum
That which ye do for the poor in my name, that ye do for myself

Hwæt is on menniscum gecynde swa mærlic swa Cristes menniscnys
What is there in human nature so glorious as the humanity of Christ, and what is esteemed more foul in human nature than the carcase of the leper, with tumours, and ulcers, and reeking stench

and hwæt is atelicor geðuht on menniscum gecynde þonne is ðæs hreoflian líc, mid toðundennesse, and springum, and reocendum stence
But he who is to be venerated above all creatures, vouchsafed to appear in that foul form, to the end that we might pity the misery of human beings, and according to our power comfort them, for love of the merciful and humble Jesus

Ac se ðe is arwurðful ofer ealle gesceafta, he gemedemode hine sylfne þæt he wære gesewen on ðam atelican híwe, to ði þæt we sceolon besargian menniscra manna yrmðe, and be ure mihte gefrefrian, for lufe ðæs mildheortan and ðæs eadmodan Hælendes
that he may grant us a dwelling in his kingdom to eternal life, who rescued us from the devil's thraldom

þæt he us getiðige wununge on his rice to ecum life, seðe us ahredde fram deofles hæftnydum
who reigneth to eternity with the Almighty Father and the Holy Ghost, those three existing in one Godhead, without beginning and end, ever to eternity

seðe rixað on ecnysse mid þam Ælmihtigan Fæder and þam Halgan Gaste, hi ðry on anre Godcundnysse wunigende, butan anginne and ende, á on worulde
Amen

Ðæt hálige godspel us segð, þæt
The holy gospel tells us, that

gerefan and synfulle men genealæhton ðam Hælende, and woldon his lare gehyran
publicans and sinners approached Jesus, and desired to hear his doctrine

Þa ceorodon ða sunder-halgan and ða boceras Iudeiscre ðeode, forðan ðe se Hælend underfeng ða synfullan, and him mid gereordode
Then the pharisees and the scribes of the Jewish people murmured, because Jesus received the sinful, and ate and drank with them

Þa sæde se Hælend ðam Iudeiscum bocerum ðis bigspel, Hwilc eower hæfð hund-teontig sceapa
Then said Jesus to the Jewish scribes this parable, Which of you hath an hundred sheep

et reliqua
etc

Þas word sind digle, ac se trahtnere Gregorius us geopenode þæt gastlice andgit
