These words are obscure, but the expounder Gregory has opened to us the ghostly meaning

Mine gebroðra þa leofostan, ge gehyrdon on ðyssere godspellican rædinge, þæt ða synfullan genealæhton to ðæs Hælendes spræce, and eac to his gereorde
My dearest brothers, ye have heard in this evangelical lesson, that the sinful approached to the speech of Jesus, and also to his refection

and ða Iudeiscan boceras mid héte þæt tældon: ac heora tál næs na of rihtwisnysse, ac of niðe
and the Jewish scribes censured that with heat

Hi wæron untrume, ðeah ðe hi ðæs ne gymdon
but their censure was not from righteousness, but from envy

Þa wolde se heofenlica læce mid geswæsum bigspelle þæt geswell heora heortan welwyllendlice gelacnian, and ðus cwæð
They were sick, though they observed it not

Hwilc eower hæfð hund-teontig sceapa, and gif he forlysð án ðæra sceapa, ðonne forlæt he ða nigon and hund-nigontig on westene, and gæð secende þæt án ðe him losode
Then would the heavenly leech with a pleasant parable benevolently heal the swelling of their hearts, and thus said

Þa forlet se Ælmihtiga Godes Sunu eal engla werod on heofonum, and ferde to eorðan, and sohte þæt án sceap ðe him ætwunden wæs
An hundredfold number is perfect, and the Almighty had an hundred sheep, when the host of angels and mankind were his possessions: but he lost one sheep, when the first-created man Adam through sin lost the food of Paradise

Ðaða he hit gemette, he hit bær on his exlum to ðære eowde blissigende
Then the Almighty Son of God left all the host of angels in heaven, and went to earth, and sought that one sheep that had escaped from him

Þaða he underfeng ure mennisce gecynd, and ure synna abær, þa wæs þæt dweligende sceap ongean fered on his halgum exlum
When he had found it, he bare it on his shoulders to the flock rejoicing

Ðæra sceapa hlaford com ham, afundenum sceape
When he assumed our human nature, and bare our sins, then was the wandering sheep brought back on his holy shoulders

forðan ðe Crist, æfter ðære ðrowunge, ðe he mancyn mid alysde, arás of deaðe, and astah to heofonum blissigende
The master of the sheep came home, having found his sheep

He gelaðode his frynd and his nehgeburas
He invited his friends and his neighbours

His frynd sind engla heapas, forðan ðe hi healdað on heora staðelfæstnysse singallice his willan
His friends are companies of angels, because they in their steadfastness constantly observe his will

Hi sind eac his nehgeburas, forðan ðe hi brucað þære wulderfullan beorhtnysse his gesihðe on heora andweardnysse
They are also his neighbours, because they enjoy the glorious brightness of his sight in their presence

He cwæð
He said

Blissiað mid me, forðan ðe ic gemette min forlorene sceap
Rejoice with me, for I have found my lost sheep

Ne cwæð he, 'Blissiað mid þam sceape,' ac 'mid me,' forðan ðe ure alysednys soðlice is his bliss
He said not, 'Rejoice with the sheep,' but 'with me,' because our redemption is truly his joy

and ðonne we beoð to ðære heofonlican eardung-stowe gelædde, þonne gefylle we ða micclan mærsunge his gefean
and when we are led to the heavenly dwelling-place, we then complete the great celebration of his gladness

He cwæð
He said

Ic secge eow, mare bliss bið on heofonum be anum synfullan men, gif he his synna mid dǽdbote behreowsað, ðonne sy be nigon and hund-nigontig rihtwisum ðe nanre behreowsunge ne behofiað
I say unto you, there is more joy in heaven over one sinful man, if he rue his sins with repentance, than there is over ninety and nine righteous, who need no repentance

Þis is to smeagenne, hwi sy mare bliss be gecyrredum synfullum, þonne be unscyldigum rihtwisum
This is to be investigated, why there is more joy over a converted sinner, than over the innocent righteous

We habbað gelomlice gesewen, þæt gehwylce gebroðra, ðe ne befeollon on healice gyltas, þæt hí ne beoð ealles swa carfulle to beganne ða earfoðlican drohtnunge, swilce hi orsorge beon, forðan ðe hi ða healican leahtras ne gefremedon
We have frequently seen that those brethren, who have not fallen into deadly sins, are not altogether so careful to practise a hard course of life, as though they were careless because they had not perpetrated deadly sins

and gehwilce oðre ðe oncnawað þa swæran gyltas ðe hi on geogoðe adrugon, beoð mid micelre sarnysse onbryrde
and that others who acknowledge the grievous sins that they have committed in youth, are pricked with great affliction

Hi forseoð alyfedlice ðing and gesewenlice, and mid wope gewilniað þa ungesewenlican and ða heofonlican
They despise permitted and visible things, and with weeping desire those invisible and heavenly

Hí forseoð hí sylfe, and geeadmettað on eallum ðingum
They despise and humble themselves in all things

and forði ðe hí dweligende fram heora Scyppende gewiton, hí willað geinnian ða æftran hinðe mid þam uferan gestreonum
and because through error they have departed from their Creator, they desire to repair the consequent injury with heavenly gains

Mare bliss bið on heofonum be ðam gecyrredum synfullum, ðurh swilce drohtnunga, þonne sy be ðam asolcenum þe truwað be him sylfum þæt he lytle and feawa gyltas gefremode, and eac hwonlice carað ymbe Godes beboda and his sawle ðearfe
Greater joy there will be in heaven over the converted sinner, through such endurances, than over a remiss one who is confident in himself, that he has perpetrated little and few sins, and at the same time cares but little about God's commandments and his soul's need

Maran lufe nimð se heretoga on gefeohte to ðam cempan, þe æfter fleame his wiðerwinnan ðegenlice oferwinð, þonne to ðam þe mid fleame ne ætwánd, ne ðeah on nanum gecampe naht ðegenlices ne gefremode
Greater love a general feels in battle for the soldier who after flight boldly overcomes his adversary, than for him who never took to flight, nor yet in any conflict performed any deed of valour

Ealswa se yrðling lufað ðone æcer, ðe æfter ðornum and bremelum genihtsume wæstmas agifð, swiðor þonne he lufige ðone ðe ðornig næs, ne wæstmbære ne bið
In like manner the husbandman loves the field which after thorns and brambles yields abundant fruits, more than he loves that which was not thorny nor is fruitful

Sind ðeah-hwæðere forwel mænige rihtwise unscyldige wið heafod-leahtras, and habbað hwæðere ealswa stiðe drohtnunge swylce hi mid eallum synnum geancsumede wæron
There are, nevertheless, very many righteous guiltless of deadly sins, and yet practise as severe a course of life as though they were troubled with all sins

Þam ne mæg nan dǽdbeta beon geefenlæht, forðan ðe hí sind rihtwise and behreowsigende
With these can no penitent sinner be compared, because they are righteous and repentant

Be ðam is to smeagenne hu micclum se rihtwisa mid eadmodre heofunge God gegladige, gif se unrihtwisa mid soðre dǽdbote hine gegladian mæg
By this is to be judged how greatly the righteous with humble lamentation gladdens God, if the unrighteous with true penitence can gladden him

Drihten rehte ða-gyt oðer bígspel be tyn scyllingum, and ðæra án losode and wearð gemet
The Lord yet said another parable concerning ten shillings, and of which one was lost and was found

Þæt bígspel getacnað eft nigon engla werod
That parable again betokens the nine hosts of angels

To ðam teoðan werode wæs mancyn gesceapen
Instead of the tenth host mankind was created

forðan ðe þæt teoðe wearð mid modignysse forscyldigod, and hi ealle to awyrgedum deoflum wurdon awende, and of ðære heofonlican blisse to helle suslum bescofene
for the tenth had been found guilty of pride, and thrust from heavenly bliss to hell torments

Nu sind ða nigon heapas genemnede, angeli, archangeli, uirtutes, potestates, principatus, dominationes, throni, cherubin, seraphin
There are now nine companies, named, angeli, archangeli, virtutes, potestates, principatus, dominationes, throni, cherubim, seraphim

Þæt teoðe forwearð
The tenth perished

Þa wæs mancynn gesceapen to ge-edstaðelunge ðæs forlorenan heapes
Then was mankind created to supply the place of the lost company

Angeli sind gecwedene Godes bodan
Angeli are interpreted, God's messengers

archangeli, healice bodan
archangeli, high messengers

uirtutes, mihta, ðurh ða wyrcð God fela wundra
virtutes, powers, by which God works many miracles

Potestates sind ánwealdu, ðe habbað anweald ofer ða awyrgedan gastas, þæt hi ne magon geleaffulra manna heortan swa micclum costnian swa hi willað
Potestates are powers which have power over the accursed spirits, that they may not tempt the hearts of believing men so much as they desire

Principatus sind ealdorscipas, ðe ðæra godra engla gymað, and hi be heora dihte ða godcundlican gerynu gefyllað
Principatus are authorities which have charge of the good angels, and they by their direction fulfil the divine mysteries

Dominationes sind hlafordscypas gecwedene, forðan ðe him gehyrsumiað oðra engla werod mid micelre underðeodnysse
Dominationes are interpreted, lordships, because the other hosts of angels obey them with great subjection

Throni sind þrymsetl, þa beoð gefyllede mid swa micelre gife ðære Ælmihtigan Godcundnysse, þæt se Eallwealdenda God on him wunað, and ðurh hi his domas tosceat
Throni are thrones which are filled with such great grace of the Almighty Godhead, that the All-powerful God dwells on them, and through them decides his dooms

Cherubin is gecweden gefyllednys ingehydes, oððe gewittes: hi sind afyllede mid gewitte swa miccle swiðor, swa hi gehendran beoð heora Scyppende, ðurh wurðscipe heora geearnunga
Cherubim are interpreted, fullness of knowledge or understanding: they are filled with so much the more understanding as they are nearer to their Creator through the worthiness of their deserts

Seraphim sind gecwedene byrnende, oððe, onælende: hi sind swa miccle swiðor byrnende on Godes lufe, swa micclum swa hi sind to him geðeodde
Seraphim are interpreted burning, or inflaming: they are so much the more burning in love of God as they are associated with him

forðan ðe nane oðre englas ne sind betweonan him and ðam Ælmihtigan Gode
for there are no other angels between them and the Almighty God

Hi sind byrnende na on fyres wisan, ac mid micelre lufe þæs Wealdendan Cyninges
They are burning, not in wise of fire, but with great love of the Powerful King

Godes rice bið gelogod mid engla weredum and geðungenum mannum, and we gelyfað þæt of mancynne swa micel getel astige þæt uplice rice, swa micel swa on heofonum beláf haligra gasta æfter ðam hryre ðæra awyrgedra gasta
God's kingdom is composed of hosts of angels and of religious men, and we believe that of mankind as great a number will ascend to that sublime realm as there remained of holy spirits in heaven after the fall of the accursed spirits

Nigon engla werod þær wæron to lafe, and þæt teoðe forferde
Nine hosts of angels were left, and the tenth perished

Nu bið eft seo micelnys geðungenra manna swa micel swa ðæra staðelfæstra engla wæs
Now the multitude of religious men will be as great as was that of the steadfast angels

and we beoð geendebyrde to heora weredum, æfter urum geearnungum
and we shall be annexed to their hosts, according to our deserts

Menige geleaffulle men sind þe habbað lytel andgit to understandenne ða deopnysse Godes lare, and willað þeah-hwæðere oðrum mannum mid arfæstnysse cyðan ymbe Godes mærða, be heora andgites mæðe: þas beoð geendebyrde to englum, þæt is, to Godes bydelum
Many faithful men there are who have little intellect to understand the deepness of God's lore, and will, nevertheless, with piety declare to other men concerning the glories of God, according to the measure of their intellect: these will be annexed to the angels, that is, to God's messengers

Þa gecorenan ðe magon asmeagan Godes digelnysse, and oðrum bodian mid gastlicre lare, hi beoð getealde to heah-englum, þæt is to healicum bodum
The chosen, who can investigate the mysteries of God, and preach with ghostly lore to others, will be numbered with the archangels, that is, with the high messengers

Þa halgan, ðe on life wundra wyrceað, beoð geendebyrde betwux ðam heofenlicum mihtum þe Godes tacna gefremmað
The holy, who work wonders in life, will be disposed among the heavenly powers who execute God's miracles

Sind eac sume gecorene menn ðe aflyað þa awyrgedan gastas fram ofsettum mannum, ðurh mihte heora bena: hwærto beoð þas geendebyrde buton to ðam heofenlicum anwealdum, be gewyldað þa feondlican costneras
There are also some chosen men who drive out the accursed spirits from men possessed, by power of their prayers: whereto shall these be annexed except to the heavenly powers, who control the fiendlike tempters

Þa gecorenan ðe ðurh healice geearnunga þa læssan gebroðru oferstigað mid ealdorscipe, þa habbað eac heora dæl betwux ðam heofenlicum ealderdomum
Those chosen ones, who through high deserts excel their humbler brethren in authority, will have their portion also among the heavenly princes

Sume beoð swa geðungene þæt hí wealdað mid heora hlafordscipe ealle uncysta and leahtras on him sylfum, swa þæt hi beoð godas getealde ðurh ða healican clænnysse: be ðam cwæð se Ælmihtiga to Moysen
Some there are so pious that they control with their authority all vices and sins in themselves, so that they are accounted gods through their exalted purity: of these the Almighty said to Moses

Ic ðe gesette, þæt þu wære Pharaones god
I will set thee that thou be Pharaoh's god

Þas Godes ðegnas, þe beoð on swa micelre geðincðe on gesihðe þæs Ælmihtigan þæt hi sind godas getealde, hwider gescyt ðonne heora endebyrdnysse, buton to ðam werode ðe sind hlafordscipas gecwedene
These servants of God, who are in so great honour in the sight of the Almighty that they are accounted gods, to what order are they assigned, unless to the host which is called lordships

forðan ðe him oðre englas underðeodde beoð
for to them other angels are subordinate

On sumum gecorenum mannum, ðe mid micelre gimene on andweardum life drohtniað, bið Godes Gastes gifu swa micel, þæt he on heora heortan swilce on ðrimsetle sittende toscǽt and démð wundorlice oðra manna dæda
In some chosen men, who live with great heedfulness in the present life, the grace of God's Spirit is so great, that he, sitting on their hearts as it were on a throne, decides and judges wondrously the deeds of other men

Hwæt sind þas buton ðrymsetl heora Scyppendes, on ðam ðe he wunigende mannum démð
What are these but thrones of their Creator, on which abiding he judges men

Seo soðe lufu is gefyllednys Godes ǽ, and se ðe on his ðeawum hylt Godes lufe and manna, he bið þonne cherubim rihtlice geháten
True love is the completion of God's law, and he who in his moral conduct holds love of God and of men, will be rightly called cherubim

forðan ðe eal gewitt and ingehyd is belocen on twam wordum, þæt is Godes lufu and manna
for all understanding and knowledge is contained in two words, namely, love of God and of men

Sume Godes ðeowan sind onælede mid swa micelre gewilnunge heora Scyppendes neawiste, þæt hi forseoð ealle woruldlice ymbhydignysse, and mid byrnendum mode ealle ða ateorigendlican geðincðu oferstigað, and mid ðam micclan bryne ðære heofenlican lufe oðre ontendað, and mid larlicre spræce getrymmað
Some servants of God are inflamed with so great a desire for the presence of their Creator, that they despise all worldly care, and with burning mind rise above all perishing honours, and with the great heat of heavenly love enkindle others, and with instructive speech confirm them

Hu magon ðas beon gecigede buton seraphim, þonne hi ðurh ðone micclan bryne Godes lufe sind toforan oðrum eorðlicum his neawiste gehendost
How may these be called but seraphim, when through the great heat of love of God they are before other mortals nearest to his presence

Nu cweð se eadiga Gregorius
Now says the blessed Gregory

Wa ðære sawle ðe orhlyte hyre lif adrihð þæra haligra mihta
Woe to the soul that passes its life devoid of the holy virtues

þe we nu sceortlice eow gerehton
which we have just shortly explained to you

Ac seo ðe bedæled is þam godnyssum, heo geomrige and gewilnige þæt se cystiga Wealdend þurh his gife hí geðeode þam hlyte his gecorenra
But let the soul which is deprived of those excellences mourn, and desire that the bountiful Ruler will, through his grace, associate it to the lot of his chosen

Nabbað ealle menn gelice gife æt Gode, forðan ðe he forgifð ða gastlican geðincðu ælcum be his gecneordnyssum
All men have not like grace from God, for he gives ghostly honours to every one according to his endeavours

Se ðe læssan gife hæbbe, ne ándige he on ðam foreðeondum, forðan ðe ða halgan ðreatas ðæra eadigra engla sind swa geendebyrde, þæt hi sume mid underþeodnysse oðrum hyrsumiað, and sume mid oferstigendre wurðfulnysse ðam oðrum sind foresette
Let him who has less grace envy not those more excellent, because the holy companies of blessed angels are so ordered, that some in subordination obey others, and some with transcending dignity are set before others

Micel getel is ðæra haligra gasta, þe on Godes rice eardiað, be ðam cwæð se witega Daniel
Great is the number of the holy spirits which dwell in God's kingdom, of whom the prophet Daniel said

Þusend ðusenda ðenodon þam Heofonlican Wealdende, and ten ðusend siðan hundfealde ðusenda him mid wunodon
Thousand thousands ministered to the Heavenly Ruler, and ten thousand times hundredfold thousands dwelt with him

Oðer is ðenung, oðer is mid-wunung
One thing is ministry, another is, co-dwelling

Þa englas ðeniað Gode þe bodiað his willan middangearde, and ða ðing gefyllað þe him liciað
Those angels minister to God who announce his will to the world, and perform the things which are pleasing to him

Ða oðre werod, þe him mid wuniað, brucað þære incundan embwlátunge his godcundnysse, swa þæt hí nateshwon fram his andweardnysse asende ne gewitað
The other hosts, that dwell with him, enjoy the closest contemplation of his Godhead, so that they on no account, sent forth, withdraw from his presence

Soðlice ða ðe to us asende becumað, swa hí gefremmað heora Scyppendes hæse wiðutan, þæt hi ðeah-hwæðere næfre ne gewitað fram his godcundan myrhðe
But those who are sent to us so execute their Creator's behest without, that they, nevertheless, depart never from his divine joy

forðam ðe God is æghwær, þeah ðe se engel stowlic sy
for God is everywhere, though the angel be local

Nis se Ælmihtiga Wealdend stowlic, forðan ðe he is on ælcere stowe, and swa hwider swa se stowlica engel flihð, he bið befangen mid his andwerdnysse
The Almighty Ruler is not local, for he is in every place, and whithersoever the local angel flieth, he will be surrounded with His presence

Hi habbað sume synderlice gife fram heora Scyppende, and ðeah-hwæðere heora wurðscipe him bið eallum gemæne, and þæt þæt gehwilc on him sylfum be dæle hæfð, þæt he hæfð on oðrum werode fulfremodlice
Some of them have especial grace from their Creator, and yet their dignity is common to all, and that which each one has in himself partially, he has in another host perfectly

be ðam cwæð se sealm-wyrhta
of which the psalmist said

Drihten, ðu ðe sitst ofer cherubin, geswutela ðe sylfne
Lord, thou who sittest above the cherubim, manifest thyself

We sædon litle ær on ðisre rædinge, þæt þæs Ælmihtigan ðrymsetl wære betwux ðam werode ðe sind throni gecigede: ac hwá mæg beon eadig, buton he his Scyppendes wununge on him sylfum hæbbe
We said a little before in this lesson, that the throne of the Almighty was among the host which are called throni: but who may be happy, unless he have his Creator's dwelling in himself

Seraphim sind ða gastas gecigede, ðe beoð on Drihtnes lufe byrnende, and ðeah-hwæðere eal þæt heofonlice mægen samod beoð onælede mid his lufe
Seraphim the spirits are called who are burning with love of the Lord, and yet all the heavenly power together is inflamed with his love

Cherubim is gecweden gefyllednys ingehydes oððe gewittes, and ðeah hwilc engel is on Godes andwerdnysse ðe ealle ðing nyte
Cherubim is interpreted fullness of knowledge or understanding, and yet what angel is there in God's presence who knows not all things

Ac forði is gehwilc ðæra weroda þam naman geciged, ðe ða gife getacnað þe he fulfremedlicor underfeng
But each of those hosts is therefore called by the name which betokens the gift that it has more perfectly received

Ac uton suwian hwæthwega be ðam digelnyssum ðæra heofenlicra ceastergewarena, and smeagan be us sylfum, and geomrian mid behreowsunge ure synna, þæt we, ðurh Drihtnes mildheortnysse, ða heofonlican wununge, swa swa he us behét, habban moton
But let us cease a little from speaking of the mysteries of the heavenly inhabitants, and meditate on ourselves, and bewail with repentance our sins, that we, through the Lord's mercy, may, as he has promised us, attain to the heavenly dwelling

He cwæð on sumere stowe
He said in some place

On mines Fæder huse sind fela wununga
In my Father's house are many dwellings

Se miltsienda Drihten cwæð, þæt micel blis wære on heofonum be anum dǽdbetan
The merciful Lord said, that there was great joy in heaven for one penitent

ac se ylca cwæð þurh his witegan
but the Same said through his prophet

Gif se rihtwisa gecyrð fram his rihtwisnysse, and begæð unrihtwisnysse arleaslice, ealle his rihtwisnysse ic forgyte
If the righteous turn from his righteousness, and impiously commit unrighteousness, all his righteousness I will forget

and gif se arleasa behreowsað his arleasnysse, and begæð rihtwisnysse, ne gemune ic nanra his synna
and if the impious repent of his impiety, and do righteousness, I will not remember any of his sins

Behreowsigendum mannum he miltsað, ac hé ne behét þam elcigendum gewiss líf oð merigen
To repentant men he is merciful, but to the procrastinating he promises not certain life till the morrow

Nis forði nanum synfullum to yldigenne agenre gecyrrednysse, ðylæs ðe he mid sleacnysse forleose ða tíd Godes fyrstes
No sinner ought therefore to procrastinate his own repentance, lest he by remissness lose the time of God's respite

Smeage gehwilc man his ærran dæda, and eac his andweardan drohtnunge, and fleo to ðam mildheortan Deman mid wópe, ða hwile ðe he anbidað ure betrunge, seðe is rihtwis and mildheort
Let every man meditate on his former deeds, and also on his present conduct, and fly to the merciful Judge with weeping, while he, who is righteous and merciful, awaits our bettering

Soðlice behreowsað his gedwyld seðe ne ge-edlæhð þa ærran dæda
He truly repents of his sins who repeats not his former deeds

be ðam cwæð se Hælend to ðam gehæledan bedredan
concerning which Jesus said to the healed bedridden

Efne nu ðu eart gehæled, ne synga ðu heonon-forð, þylæs ðe ðe sum ðing wyrse gelimpe
Behold, now thou art healed, sin not henceforth, lest something worse befall thee

Geleaffullum mannum mæg beon micel truwa and hopa to ðam menniscum Gode Criste, seðe is ure Mundbora and Dema, seðe leofað and rixað mid Fæder, on annysse þæs Halgan Gastes, on ealra worulda woruld
Believing men may have great trust and hope to the human God Christ, who is our Protector and Judge, who liveth and reigneth with the Father, in unity of the Holy Ghost, for ever and ever

Amen
Amen

Se godspellere Lucas awrát on Cristes béc be acennednysse Iohannes ðæs Fulluhteres, þus cweðende
The evangelist Luke wrote in the book of Christ concerning the birth of John the Baptist, thus saying

Sum eawfæst Godes ðegen wæs geháten Zacharias, his gebedda wæs geciged Elisabeth
There was a certain pious servant of God called Zacharias, his wife was called Elizabeth

Hí butu wæron rihtwise ætforan Gode, on his bebodum and rihtwisnyssum forðstæppende butan tále
They were both righteous before God, walking forth in his commandments and righteousnesses without blame

Næs him cild gemæne
They had no child in common

et reliqua
etc

Eal his reaf wæs awefen of olfendes hǽrum, his bigleofa wæs stiðlic
All his garment was woven of camel's hair, his food was coarse

ne dranc he wines drenc, ne nanes gemencgedes wætan, ne gebrowenes: ofet hine fedde, and wude-hunig, and oðre waclice ðigena
he drank not drink of wine, nor of any mixed or prepared fluid: fruit fed him and wood-honey, and other common things

On ðam fifteoðan geare ðæs caseres rices Tyberii com Godes word ofer Iohannem, on ðam westene
In the fifteenth year of the reign of the emperor Tiberius, the word of God came upon John, in the waste, and he went into the presence of people, and preached to the Jewish folk baptism for the forgiveness of sins, as it is written in the prophecy of Isaiah

Cristes fulluht he bodade toweard eallum geleaffullum, on ðam is synna forgyfenys þurh ðone Halgan Gást
The baptism of Christ to come he preached to all believers, in which is forgiveness of sins through the Holy Ghost

Iohannes eac be Godes dihte fullode ða ðe him to comon ðæra Iudeiscra ðeoda, ac his fulluht ne dyde nánre synne forgyfenysse, forðan ðe he wæs Godes bydel, and na God
John also, by God's direction, baptized those who came to him of the Jewish nations, but his baptism wrought no forgiveness of sin, for he was God's messenger, and not God

He bodade mannum þæs Hælendes to-cyme mid wordum, and his halige fulluht mid his agenum fulluhte, on ðam he gefullode ðone unsynnian Godes Sunu, ðe nánre synne forgyfenysse ne behófade
He announced to men the advent of Jesus with words, and His holy baptism with his own baptism, with which he baptized the sinless Son of God, who needed no forgiveness of sin

Rihtlice weorðað Godes gelaðung ðisne dæg þæs mæran Fulluhteres gebyrd-tide, for ðam manegum wundrum ðe gelumpon on his acennednysse
Rightly does God's church honour this day, the birth-tide of the great Baptist, for the many wonders which happened at his birth

Godes heah-engel Gabrihel bodade ðam fæder Zacharían his acennednysse, and his healican geðincðu, and his mærlican drohtnunge
God's archangel Gabriel announced his birth to Zacharias his father, and his high honours, and his illustrious life

Þæt cild on his modor innoðe oncneow Marian stemne, Godes cynnestran
The child in his mother's womb knew the voice of Mary, the parent of God

and on innoðe ða-gyt beclysed, mid wítigendlicre fægnunge getácnode þone halwendan to-cyme ures Alysendes
and in the womb yet closed, betokened with prophetic joy the salutary advent of our Redeemer

On his acennednysse he ætbræd þære meder hire unwæstmbærnysse, and þæs fæder tungan his nama unbánd, þe mid his agenre geleafleaste adumbod wæs
At his birth he removed from his mother her barrenness, and his name unbound the tongue of his father, who by his own want of belief had been made dumb

Ðreora manna gebyrd-tide freolsað seo halige gelaðung: ðæs Hælendes, seðe is God and mann, and Iohannes his bydeles, and ðære eadigan Marian his moder
The holy church celebrates the birth-tide of three persons,—of Jesus, who is God and man, and of John his messenger, and of the blessed Mary his mother

Oðra gecorenra manna, ðe ðurh martyrdom, oððe þurh oðre halige geearnunga, Godes rice geferdon, heora endenextan dæg, seðe hí æfter gefyllednysse ealra earfoðnyssa sigefæste to ðam ecan life acende, we wurðiað him to gebyrd-tide
Of other chosen persons, who, through martyrdom, or through other holy merits, have gone to the kingdom of God, we celebrate as their birth-tide their last day, which, after the fulfilment of all their labours, brought them forth victorious to eternal life

and ðone dæg, ðe hí to ðisum andweardan life acennede wæron, we lætað to gymeleaste, forðan ðe hí comon hider to earfoðnyssum, and costnungum, and mislicum fræcednyssum
and the day on which they were born to this present life we let pass unheeded, because they came hither to hardships, and temptations, and divers perils

Se dæg bið gemyndig Godes ðeowum ðe ða halgan, æfter gewunnenum sige, asende to ecere myrhðe fram eallum gedreccednyssum, and se is heora soðe acennednys
The day is memorable to the servants of God which sends his saints, after victory won, to eternal joy from all afflictions, and which is their true birth

na wóplic, swa swa seo ærre, ac blissigendlic to ðam ecum life
not tearful as the first, but exulting in eternal life

Ac us is to wurðigenne mid micelre gecnyrdnysse Cristes gebyrd-tide, ðurh ða us com alysednys
But the birth-tide of Christ is to be celebrated with great care, through which came our redemption

Iohannes is geendung ðære ealdan ǽ and anginn ðære níwan, swa swa se Hælend be him cwæð
John is the ending of the old law and the beginning of the new, as Jesus said of him

Seo ealde ǽ and wítegan wæron oð Iohannes to-cyme
The old law and the prophets were till the coming of John

Siððan ongann godspel-bodung
Afterwards began the gospel-preaching

Nu for his micclan halignysse is gewurðod his acennednys, swa swa se heah-engel behet his fæder mid ðisum wordum
Now, on account of his great holiness, his birth is honoured, as the archangel promised his father with these words

Manega blissiað on his gebyrd-tide
Many shall rejoice in his birth-tide

María, Godes cynnestre, nis nanum oðrum gelic, forðan ðe heo is mæden and modor, and ðone abǽr ðe hí and ealle gesceafta gesceop: is heo forði wel wyrðe þæt hire acennednys arwurðlice gefreolsod sy
Mary, the parent of God, is like to none other, for she is maiden and mother, and bare him who created her and all creatures: therefore is she well worthy that her birth should be honourably celebrated

Þa magas setton ðam cilde naman, Zacharias, ac seo modor him wiðcwæð mid wordum, and se dumba fæder mid gewrite
The relatives bestowed on the child the name of Zacharias, but the mother contradicted them by words, and the dumb father by writing

forðan ðe se engel, ðe hine cydde toweardne, him gesceop naman be Godes dihte, Iohannes
because the angel who had announced that he was to come, had, by God's direction, given him the name of John

Ne mihte se dumba fæder cyðan his wife hu se engel his cilde naman gesette, ac, ðurh Godes Gastes onwrigenysse, se nama hire wearð cuð
The dumb father could not have informed his wife how the angel had bestowed a name on his child, but by revelation of the Spirit of God the name was known to her

Zacharias is gereht, 'Gemindig Godes
Zacharias is interpreted, 'Mindful of God

' and Iohannes, 'Godes gifu
' and John, 'God's grace

' forðan ðe he bodade mannum Godes gife, and Crist toweardne, þe ealne middangeard mid his gife gewissað
' because he preached to men the grace of God, and that Christ was to come, who directs all the earth with his grace

He wæs asend toforan Drihtne, swa swa se dægsteorra gæð beforan ðære sunnan, swa swa bydel ætforan deman, swa swa seo Ealde Gecyðnys ætforan ðære Niwan
He was sent before the Lord, as the day-star goes before the sun, as the beadle before the judge, as the Old Testament before the New

forðan ðe seo ealde ǽ wæs swilce sceadu, and seo Niwe Gecyðnys is soðfæstnys ðurh ðæs Hælendes gife
for the Old Law was as a shadow, and the New Testament is truth through the grace of Jesus

Anes geares cild hí wæron, Crist and Iohannes
They were children of the same year, Christ and John

On ðisum dæge acende seo unwæstmbære moder ðone mæran witegan Iohannem, se is gehérod mid þisum wordum, ðurh Cristes muð
On this day the barren mother brought forth the great prophet John, who is praised in these words by the mouth of Christ

Betwux wifa bearnum ne arás nan mærra man ðonne is Iohannes se Fulluhtere
Among the children of men there hath not arisen a greater man than is John the Baptist

On middes wintres mæsse-dæge acende þæt halige mæden Maria þone Heofenlican Æðeling, se nis geteald to wifa bearnum, forðon ðe he is Godes Sunu on ðære Godcundnysse, and Godes and mædenes Bearn ðurh menniscnysse
On the mass-day of midwinter the holy maiden Mary brought forth the Heavenly Prince, who is not numbered with the children of men, because he is the Son of God in his Godhead, and the Son of God and of a maiden by his human nature

Iohannes forfleah folces neawiste on geogoðe, and on westene mid stiðre drohtnunge synna forbeah
John fled from the presence of people in his youth, and in the waste, with austere life-course, avoided sin

Se Hælend betwux synfullum unwemme fram ælcere synne ðurhwunode
Jesus continued among the sinful pure from every sin

Se bydel gebigde on ðam timan micelne heap Israhela ðeode to heora Scyppende mid his bodunge
The crier inclined, at that time, a great body of the people of Israel to their Creator by his announcement

Drihten dæghwamlice of eallum ðeodum to his geleafan, ðurh onlihtinge ðæs Halgan Gastes, ungerim sawla gebigð
The Lord daily inclines souls without number of all nations to his faith, through enlightening of the Holy Ghost

Þæt halige godspel cwyð be ðam Fulluhtere, þæt he forestope ðam Hælende on gaste and on mihte þæs witegan Helian
The holy gospel says of the Baptist, that he preceded Jesus in spirit and in power of the prophet Elias

forðan ðe he wæs his forrynel æt ðam ærran to-cyme, swa swa Helias bið æt ðam æftran togeanes Antecriste
because he was his forerunner at his first advent, as Elias will be at the second against Antichrist

Nis butan getacnunge þæt ðæs bydeles acennednys on ðære tide wæs gefremod ðe se woruldlica dæg wanigende bið, and on Drihtnes gebyrd-tide weaxende bið
It is not without signification that the birth of the crier was completed on the day when the worldly day is waning, and that it is waxing on the birth-tide of the Lord

Þas getacnunge onwreah se ylca Iohannes mid ðisum wordum
This signification the same John revealed in these words

Criste gedafenað þæt he weaxe, and me þæt ic wanigende beo
It is befitting Christ that he wax, and me that I be waning

Iohannes wæs hraðor mannum cuð þurh his mærlican drohtnunga, þonne Crist wære, forðan ðe hé ne æteowde his godcundan mihte, ærðam ðe hé wæs ðritig geara on ðære menniscnysse
John was sooner known to men, through his illustrious life-course, than Christ was, for He manifested not his divine power, ere that he had been thirty years in human nature

Þa wæs he geðuht ðam folce þæt hé witega wære, and Iohannes Crist
Then it seemed to the people that he was a prophet, and that John was Christ

Hwæt ða Crist geswutelode hine sylfne ðurh miccle tacna, and his hlisa weox geond ealne middangeard, þæt he soð God wæs, seðe wæs ærðan witega geðuht
But Christ manifested himself by many great miracles, and his fame waxed through all the world, that he was true God, who before that had seemed a prophet

Iohannes soðlice wæs wanigende on his hlisan, forðan ðe he wearð oncnawen witega, and bydel ðæs Heofonlican Æðelinges, seðe wæs lytle ær Crist geteald mid ungewissum wenan
But John was waning in his fame, for he was acknowledged a prophet, and the proclaimer of the Heavenly Prince, who a little before had by uncertain supposition been accounted Christ

Þas wanunge getacnað se wanigenda dæg his gebyrd-tide, and se ðeonda dæg ðæs Hælendes acennednysse gebícnað his ðeondan mihte æfter ðære menniscnysse
The waning day of his birth-tide betokens this waning, and the increasing day of the birth of Jesus signifies his increasing power according to his human nature

Fela witegan mid heora witegunge bodedon Drihten toweardne, sume feorran sume neán, ac Iohannes his to-cyme mid wordum bodade, and eac mid fingre gebicnode, ðus cweðende
Many prophets by their prophecy announced the Lord to come, some from afar some near, but John announced his advent by words, and also with his finger signified it, thus saying

Loca nu
Look now

Efne her gæð Godes Lamb, seðe ætbret middangeardes synna
Behold here goeth the Lamb of God, who shall take away the sins of the world

Crist is manegum naman genemned
Christ is named by many names

He is Wisdom geháten, forðan ðe se Fæder ealle gesceafta þurh hine geworhte
He is called Wisdom, because the Father wrought all things through him

He is Word gecweden, forðan þe word is wisdomes geswutelung
He is called Word, because a word is the manifestation of wisdom

Be ðam Worde ongann se godspellere Iohannes þa godspellican gesetnysse, ðus cweðende
The evangelist John began the evangelical memorial with the Word, thus saying

On frymðe wæs Word, and þæt Word wæs mid Gode, and þæt Word wæs God
In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God

He is Lamb geháten, for ðære unscæððignysse lambes gecyndes
He is called Lamb, from the innocence of the lamb's nature

and wæs unscyldig, for ure alysednysse, his Fæder liflic onsægednys, on lambes wisan geoffrod
and was guiltless, for our redemption, offered a living sacrifice to his Father in the manner of a lamb

He is Leo geciged of Iudan mægðe, Dauides wyrtruma, forðan ðe he, ðurh his godcundlican strencðe, þone miclan deofol mid sige his ðrowunge oferswiðde
He is called the Lion of the tribe of Judah, the Root of David, because, through his godly strength he overcame the great devil by the victory of his passion

Se halga Fulluhtere, ðe we ymbe sprecað, astealde stiðlice drohtnunge, ægðer ge on scrude ge on bígwiste, swa swa we hwene æror rehton
The holy Baptist of whom we are speaking, established a rigid life-course, both in raiment and in food, as we have mentioned a little before

forðan ðe se Wealdenda Hælend þus be him cweðende wæs
for the Mighty Jesus was thus saying of him

Fram Iohannes dagum Godes rice ðolað neadunge, and ða strecan-mód hit gegripað
From the days of John the kingdom of God suffereth compulsion, and the violent seize it

Cuð is gehwilcum snoterum mannum, þæt seo ealde ǽ wæs eaðelicre þonne Cristes Gesetnys sy, forðan ðe on ðære næs micel forhæfednys, ne ða gastlican drohtnunga þe Crist siððan gesette, and his apostoli
It is known to every intelligent man, that the old law was easier than the Institute of Christ is, for in it there was no great continence nor the ghostly courses which Christ and his apostles afterwards established

Oðer is seo gesetnys ðe se cyning bytt ðurh his ealdormenn oððe gerefan, oðer bið his agen gebann on his andweardnysse
One thing is the institute which the king ordains through his nobles or officials, another is his own edict in his presence

Godes rice is gecweden on ðisre stowe seo hálige gelaðung, þæt is eal cristen folc, þe sceal mid neadunge and strecum mode þæt heofonlice rice geearnian
The holy church is in this place called God's kingdom, that is, all christian people, who shall with force and violence earn the heavenly kingdom

Hu mæg beon butan strece and neadunge, þæt gehwá mid clænnysse þæt gále gecynd þurh Godes gife gewylde
How can it be without violence and compulsion, that any one by chastity overcomes libidinous nature through God's grace

Oððe hwá gestilð hatheortnysse his modes mid geðylde, butan earfoðnysse
Or who shall still the frenzy of his mind with patience, without difficulty

oððe hwá awent modignysse mid soðre eadmodnysse
or who shall exchange pride for true humility

oððe hwá druncennysse mid syfernysse
or who drunkenness for soberness

oððe hwá gitsunge mid rúmgifulnysse, butan strece
or who covetousness for munificence, without violence

Ac se ðe his ðeawas mid anmodnysse, þurh Godes fultum, swa awent, he bið ðonne to oðrum menn geworht
But he who, through God's support, so changes his ways with steadfastness, will then be made another man

oðer he bið þurh gódnysse, and se ylca ðurh edwiste, and he gelæcð ðonne ðurh strece þæt heofenlice rice
another he will be in goodness, and the same in substance, and he will then by violence seize the heavenly kingdom

Twa forhæfednysse cynn syndon, án lichamlic, oðer gastlic
There are two kinds of continence, one bodily, the other ghostly

An is, þæt gehwá hine sylfne getemprige mid gemete on ǽte and on wæte, and werlice ða oferflowendlican ðygene him sylfum ætbrede
One is, that everyone govern himself with moderation in food and in drink, and manfully remove from himself superfluous aliment

Oðer forhæfednysse cynn is deorwurðre and healicre, ðeah seo oðer gód sy: styran his modes styrunge mid singalre gemetfæstnysse, and campian dæghwamlice wið leahtras, and hine sylfne ðreagian mid styrnysse ðære gastlican steore, swa þæt hé ða reðan deor eahta heafod-leahtra swilce mid isenum midlum gewylde
The second kind of continence is more precious and exalted,—though the other is good,—to guide the agitation of his mind with constant moderation, and fight daily against sins, and chastise himself with the sternness of ghostly correction, so that he restrain the fierce beast of the eight capital sins as it were with iron bonds

Deorwyrðe is þeos forhæfednys, and wulderfull ðrowung on Godes gesihðe, ða yfelan geðohtas and unlustas mid agenre cynegyrde gestyran, and fram derigendlicere spræce, and pleolicum weorce hine sylfne forhabban, swa swa fram cwylmbærum mettum
Precious is this continence and glorious suffering in the sight of God, to govern evil thoughts and sinful pleasures with our own sceptre, and to abstain from injurious speech and perilous work, as from death-bearing meats

Se ðe ðas ðing gecneordlice begæð, he gripð untweolice þæt behátene ríce mid Gode and eallum his halgum
He who sedulously performs these things, seizes undoubtedly the promised kingdom with God and all his saints

Micel strec bið, þæt mennisce menn mid eadmodum geearnungum ða heofenlican myrhðe begytan, ðe ða heofenlican englas ðurh modignysse forluron
Great violence it is through which human beings with humble merits obtain that heavenly joy, which the heavenly angels lost through pride

Us gelustfullað gyt furður to sprecenne be ðan halgan were Iohanne, him to wurðmynte and ús to beterunge
It delights us to speak yet further of the holy man John, for his honour and our bettering

Be him awrát se witega Isaias, þæt he is
Of him the prophet Isaiah wrote, that he is

stemn clypigendes on westene, Gearciað Godes weig, doð rihte his paðas
the voice of one crying in the waste, Prepare the way of God, make right his paths

Ælc dene bið gefylled, and ælc dún bið geeadmet, and ealle wohnyssa beoð gerihte, and scearpnyssa gesmeðode
Every valley shall be filled, and every hill shall be lowered, and all crookednesses shall be straightened, and sharpnesses smoothed

Se witega hine het stemn, forðan ðe he forestóp Criste, ðe is Word gehaten: na swilc word swa menn sprecað, ac he is ðæs Fæder Wisdom, and word bið wisdomes geswutelung
The prophet called himself a voice, because he preceded Christ, who is called the Word: not such a word as men speak, but he is the Wisdom of the Father, and a word is the manifestation of wisdom

Þæt Word is Ælmihtig God, Sunu mid his Fæder
The Word is Almighty God, the Son with his Father

On ælcum worde bið stemn gehyred, ǽr þæt word fullice gecweden sy
In every word the voice is heard before the word is fully spoken

Swa swa stemn forestæpð worde, swa forestóp Iohannes ðam Hælende on middangearde
As the voice precedes the word, so did John precede Jesus on earth

forðan ðe God Fæder hine sende ætforan gesihðe his Bearnes, þæt he sceolde gearcian and dæftan his weig
for God the Father sent him before the sight of his Son, that he might prepare and make ready his way

Hwæt ða Iohannes to mannum clypode þas ylcan word
But John cried these same words to men

Gearciað Godes weig
Prepare the way of God

Se bydel ðe bodað rihtne geleafan and gode weorc, he gearcað þone weig cumendum Gode to ðæra heorcnigendra heortan
The crier who announces right belief and good works, prepares the way for the coming God to the heart of the hearkeners

Godes weg bið gegearcod on manna heortan, þonne hí ðære Soðfæstnysse spræce eadmodlice gehyrað, and gearuwe beoð to Lifes bebodum
The way of God is prepared in the heart of men, when they humbly hear the speech of Truth, and are ready to the commandments of Life

be ðam cwæð se Hælend
of whom Jesus said

Se ðe me lufað, he hylt min bebod, and min Fæder hine lufað, and wit cumað to him, and mid him wuniað
He who loveth me holdeth my commandment, and my Father loveth him, and we will come to him, and will dwell with him

His paðas beoð gerihte, þonne ðurh gode bodunge aspringað clæne geðohtas on mode ðæra hlystendra
His paths shall be straight, when, through good preaching, pure thoughts spring up in the mind of the listeners

Dena getácniað þa eadmodan, and dúna ða modigan
Valleys betoken the humble, and hills the proud

On Drihtnes to-cyme wurdon dena afyllede, and dúna geeadmette, swa swa he sylf cwæð
At the Lord's advent valleys shall be filled, and hills lowered, as he himself said

Ælc ðæra ðe hine onhefð bið geeadmet, and se ðe hine geeadmet bið geuferod
Everyone of them who exalteth himself shall be humbled, and he who humbleth himself shall be exalted

Swa swa wæter scyt of ðære dúne, and ætstent on dene, swa forflihð se Halga Gast modigra manna heortan, and nimð wununge on ðam eadmodan, swa swa se witega cwæð
As water rushes from the hill and stands in the valley, so flees the Holy Ghost from the heart of proud men, and takes his dwelling in the humble, as the prophet said

On hwam gerest Godes Gast buton on ðam eadmodan
In whom resteth the Spirit of God but in the humble

Ðwyrnyssa beoð gerihte, þonne ðwyrlicra manna heortan, þe beoð ðurh unrihtwisnysse hócas awegde, eft ðurh regol-sticcan ðære soðan rihtwisnysse beoð geemnode
Crookednesses shall be straight, when the hearts of perverse men, which are agitated by the hooks of unrighteousness, are again made even by the ruling-rods of true righteousness

Scearpnyssa beoð awende to smeðum wegum, ðonne ða yrsigendan mod, and unliðe gecyrrað to manðwærnysse, þurh ongyte ðære upplican gife
Sharpnesses shall be turned to smooth ways, when angry and ungentle minds turn to gentleness through infusion of the heavenly grace

Langsumlic bið us to gereccenne, and eow to gehyrenne ealle ða deopnyssa ðæs mæran Fulluhteres bodunge: hu he ða heardheortan Iudeiscre ðeode mid stearcre ðreale and stiðre myngunge to lífes wege gebigde, and æfter his ðrowunge hellwarum Cristes to-cyme cydde, swa swa he on life mancynne agene alysednysse mid hludre stemne bealdlice bodade
Tedious it would be for us to recount and for you to hear all the depths of the great Baptist's preaching: how with strong reproof and severe admonition he inclined the hard-hearted of the Jewish people to the way of life, and after his suffering announced Christ's advent to the inhabitants of hell, as he in life had with loud voice boldly preached their own redemption to mankind

Uton nu biddan ðone Wealdendan Hælend, þæt he, ðurh his ðæs mæran Forryneles and Fulluhteres ðingunge, ús gemiltsige on andweardum lífe, and to ðam ecan gelæde, ðam sy wuldor and lóf mid Fæder and Halgum Gaste á on ecnysse
Let us now pray the Powerful Saviour, that he, through the mediation of the great Forerunner and Baptist, be merciful to us in the present life, and lead us to the life eternal, to whom be glory and praise with the Father and the Holy Ghost, ever to eternity

Amen
Amen

Matheus se Godspellere awrát on ðære godspellican gesetnysse, ðus cweðende
Matthew the Evangelist wrote in the evangelical Testament, thus saying

Drihten com to anre burhscire, ðe is geciged Cesarea Philippi, and befrán his gingran hu menn be him cwyddedon
The Lord came to a district, which is called Cæsarea Philippi, and asked his disciples how men spake concerning him

Hí andwyrdon, Sume menn cweðað þæt ðu sy Iohannes se Fulluhtere, sume secgað þæt ðu sy Helías, sume Hieremias, oððe sum oðer witega
They answered, Some men say that thou art John the Baptist

Se Hælend ða cwæð, Hwæt secge ge þæt ic sy
some men say that thou art Elias

Petrus him andwyrde, Þu eart Crist, ðæs lifigendan Godes Sunu
some Jeremias, or some other prophet

Drihten him cwæð to andsware, Eadig eart ðu, Simon, culfran bearn, forðan ðe flæsc and blod þe ne onwreah ðisne geleafan, ac min Fæder seðe on heofonum is
Jesus then said, What say ye that I am

Ic ðe secge, þæt þu eart stænen, and ofer ðysne stán ic timbrige mine cyrcan, and helle gatu naht ne magon ongean hí
Peter answered him, Thou art Christ, Son of the living God

Ic betæce ðe heofonan rices cæge
The Lord said to him in answer, Blessed art thou, Simon, son of a dove, for flesh and blood hath not revealed to thee this belief, but my Father who is in heaven

and swa hwæt swa ðu bintst on eorðan, þæt bið gebunden on heofonum
I say to thee, thou art of stone, and on this stone I will build my church, and the gates of hell may not aught against it

and swa hwæt swa ðu unbintst ofer eorðan, þæt bið unbunden on heofonum
I will commit to thee the key of the kingdom of heaven, and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth, that shall be bound in heaven

Beda se trahtnere us onwrihð þa deopnysse ðysre rædinge, and cwyð, þæt Philippus se fyðerríca ða buruh Cesarea getimbrode, and on wurðmynte þæs caseres Tiberii, ðe he under rixode, ðære byrig naman gesceop, 'Cesaream,' and for his agenum gemynde to ðam naman geyhte, 'Philippi,' ðus cweðende, 'Cesarea Philippi,' swilce seo burh him bám to wurðmynte swa genemned wære
Beda the expositor reveals to us the mystery of this reading, and says, that Philip the tetrarch built the city of Cæsarea, and, in honour of the emperor Tiberius, under whom he governed, devised for the city the name of Cæsarea, and in memorial of himself added to the name, 'Philippi,' thus saying, 'Cæsarea Philippi,' as though the city were so named in honour of them both

Þaða se Hælend to ðære burhscire genealæhte, þa befrán hé, hu woruld-menn be him cwyddedon: na swilce hé nyste manna cwyddunga be him, ac hé wolde, mid soðre andetnysse ðæs rihtan geleafan, adwæscan ðone leasan wenan dweligendra manna
When Jesus drew near to the district, he asked, how the men of the world spake of him: not as though he knew not the speeches of men concerning him, but he would, by a true confession of the right belief, destroy the false imagination of erring men

His apostoli him andwyrdon
His apostles answered him

Sume men cwyddiað þæt ðu sy Iohannes se Fulluhtere, sume secgað þæt ðu sy Helias, sume Hieremias, oððe án ðæra witegena
Some men say that thou art John the Baptist, some say that thou art Elias, some Jeremias, or one of the prophets

Drihten ða befrán
The Lord then asked

Hwæt secge ge þæt ic sy
What say ye that I am

swylce he swa cwæde, 'Nu woruld-menn ðus dwollice me oncnawað, ge ðe godas sind, hu oncnawe ge me
as if he had thus said, 'Now the men of the world thus erroneously know me, how do ye, who are gods, know me

' Se trahtnere cwæð 'godas,' forðan ðe se soða God, seðe ana is Ælmihtig, hæfð geunnen ðone wurðmynt his gecorenum, þæt hé hí godas gecigð
' The expositor said 'gods,' because the true God, who alone is Almighty, has granted that dignity to his chosen, that he calls them gods

Him andwyrde se gehyrsuma Petrus
The obedient Peter answered him

Ðu eart Crist, þæs lifigendan Godes Sunu
Thou art Christ, Son of the living God

He cwæð 'þæs lifigendan Godes,' for twæminge ðæra leasra goda, ða ðe hæðene ðeoda, mid mislicum gedwylde bepæhte, wurðodon
He said 'of the living God,' in distinction from the false gods, which the heathen nations, by various error deceived, worshipped

Sume hí gelyfdon on deade entas, and him deorwurðlice anlicnyssa arærdon, and cwædon þæt hí godas wæron, for ðære micelan strencðe ðe hí hæfdon: wæs ðeah heora líf swiðe mánfullic and bysmurfull
Some of them believed in dead giants, and raised precious idols to them, and said that they were gods, on account of the great strength they had: yet were their lives very criminal and opprobrious

be ðam cwæð se witega
of whom the prophet said

Ðæra hæðenra anlicnyssa sind gyldene and sylfrene, manna handgeweorc: hí habbað dumne muð and blinde eagan, deafe earan and ungrapigende handa, fét butan feðe, bodig butan life
The idols of the heathen are of gold and of silver, men's handiwork: they have a dumb mouth and blind eyes, deaf ears and unhandling hands, feet without pace, body without life

Sume hí gelyfdon on ða sunnan, sume on ðone monan, sume on fyr, and on manega oðre gesceafta: cwædon þæt hí for heora fægernysse godas wæron
Some of them believed in the sun, some in the moon, some in fire, and in many other creatures: they said that on account of their fairness they were gods

Nu todælde Petrus swutelice ðone soðan geleafan, ðaða he cwæð
Now Peter manifestly distinguished the true belief, when he said

Þu eart Crist, ðæs lifigendan Godes Sunu
Thou art Christ, Son of the living God

Se is lybbende God þe hæfð líf and wununge ðurh hine sylfne, butan anginne, and seðe ealle gesceafta þurh his agen Bearn, þæt is, his Wisdom, gesceop, and him eallum líf forgeaf ðurh ðone Halgan Gast
He is the living God who has life and existence through himself, without beginning, and who created all creatures through his own Son, that is, his Wisdom, and to them all gave life through the Holy Ghost

On ðissum ðrym hádum is an Godcundnys, and án gecynd, and án weorc untodæledlice
In these three persons is one Godhead, and one nature, and one work indivisibly

Drihten cwæð to Petre
The Lord said to Peter

Eadig eart ðu, culfran sunu
Blessed art thou, son of a dove

Se Halga Gast wæs gesewen ofer Criste on culfran anlicnysse
The Holy Ghost appeared over Christ in likeness of a dove

Nu gecigde se Hælend Petrum culfran bearn, forðan ðe he wæs afylled mid bilewitnysse and gife ðæs Halgan Gastes
Now Jesus called Peter the child of a dove, because he was filled with meekness and with the grace of the Holy Ghost

He cwæð
He said

Ne onwreah ðe flæsc ne blod þisne geleafan, ac min Fæder seðe on heofenum is
Neither flesh nor blood hath revealed unto thee this belief, but my Father who is in heaven

Flæsc and blod is gecweden, his flæsclice mæið
His fleshly condition is called flesh and blood

Næfde he þæt andgit ðurh mæglice lare, ac se Heofenlica Fæder, ðurh ðone Halgan Gast, ðisne geleafan on Petres heortan forgeaf
He had not that intelligence through parental love, but the Heavenly Father gave this belief into Peter's heart through the Holy Ghost

Drihten cwæð to Petre
The Lord said to Peter

Þu eart stænen
Thou art of stone

For ðære strencðe his geleafan, and for anrædnysse his andetnysse he underfencg ðone naman, forðan ðe he geðeodde hine sylfne mid fæstum mode to Criste, seðe is 'stán' gecweden fram ðam apostole Paule
For the strength of his belief, and for the steadfastness of his profession he received that name, because he had attached himself with firm mind to Christ, who is called 'stone' by the apostle Paul

And ic timbrige mine cyrcan uppon ðisum stane
And I will build my church upon this stone

þæt is, ofer ðone geleafan ðe ðu andetst
that is, on that faith which thou professest

Eal Godes gelaðung is ofer ðam stane gebytlod, þæt is ofer Criste
All God's church is built on that stone, that is, upon Christ

forðan ðe he is se grundweall ealra ðæra getimbrunga his agenre cyrcan
for he is the foundation of all the fabrics of his own church

Ealle Godes cyrcan sind getealde to anre gelaðunge, and seo is mid gecorenum mannum getimbrod, na mid deadum stanum
All God's churches are accounted as one congregation, and that is constructed of chosen men, not of dead stones

and eal seo bytlung ðæra liflicra stana is ofer Criste gelogod
and all the building of those living stones is founded on Christ

forðan ðe we beoð, þurh ðone geleafan, his lima getealde, and hé ure ealra heafod
for we, through that belief, are accounted his limbs, and he is the head of us all

Se ðe ne bytlað of ðam grundwealle, his weorc hryst to micclum lyre
He who builds not from that foundation, his work falls to great perdition

Se Hælend cwæð
Jesus said

Ne magon helle gatu naht togeanes minre cyrcan
The gates of hell may not aught against my church

Leahtras and dwollic lár sindon helle gatu, forðan ðe hí lædað þone synfullan swilce ðurh geat into helle wite
Sins and erroneous doctrine are the gates of hell, because they lead the sinful, as it were through a gate, into hell-torment

Manega sind ða gatu, ac heora nan ne mæg ongean ða halgan gelaðunge, ðe is getimbrod uppon ðam fæstan stane, Criste
Many are the gates, but none of them can do aught against the holy church, which is built upon that fast stone, Christ

forðan ðe se gelyfeda, þurh Cristes gescyldnysse, ætwint ðam frecednyssum ðæra deoflicra costnunga
for the faithful man, through the protection of Christ, avoids the perils of diabolical temptations

He cwæð
He said

Ic ðe betæce heofonan rices cæge
I will commit to thee the key of the kingdom of heaven

Nis seo cæig gylden, ne sylfren, ne of nanum antimbre gesmiðod, ac is se anweald þe him Crist forgeaf, þæt nan man ne cymð into Godes rice, buton se halga Petrus him geopenige þæt infær
That key is not of gold nor of silver, nor forged of any substance, but is the power which Christ gave him, that no man shall come into God's kingdom, unless the holy Peter open to him the entrance

And swa hwæt swa ðu bintst ofer eorðan, þæt bið gebunden on heofonum
And whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth, that shall be bound in heaven

and swa hwæt swa ðu unbintst ofer eorðan, þæt bið unbunden on heofenan
and whatsoever thou shalt unbind on earth, that shall be unbound in heaven

Þisne anweald he forgeaf nu Petre, and eac syððan, ǽr his upstige, eallum his apostolum, ðaða he him on-ableow, ðus cwæðende
This power he then gave to Peter and likewise afterwards, ere his ascension, to all his apostles, when he blew on them, thus saying

Onfoð Haligne Gast: ðæra manna synna þe ge forgyfað, beoð forgyfene
Receive the Holy Ghost: the sins of those men which ye forgive shall be forgiven

and ðam ðe ge forgifenysse ofunnon, him bið oftogen seo forgyfenys
and from those to whom ye refuse forgiveness, forgiveness shall be withdrawn

Nellað ða apostoli nænne rihtwisne mid heora mansumunge gebindan, ne eac ðone mánfullan miltsigende unbindan, butan he mid soðre dǽdbote gecyrre to lifes wege
The apostles will not bind any righteous man with their anathema, nor also mercifully unbind the sinful, unless he with true repentance return to the way of life

Þone ylcan andweald hæfð se Ælmihtiga getiðod biscopum and halgum mæsse-preostum, gif hí hit æfter ðære godspellican gesetnysse carfullice healdað
The same power has the Almighty granted to bishops and holy mass-priests, if they carefully hold it according to the evangelical volume

Ac forði is seo cæig Petre sinderlice betæht, þæt eal ðeodscipe gleawlice tocnáwe, þæt swa hwá swa oðscyt fram annysse ðæs geleafan ðe Petrus ða andette Criste, þæt him ne bið getiðod naðor ne synna forgyfenys ne infær þæs heofenlican rices
But the key is especially committed to Peter, that every people may with certainty know, that whosoever deviates from the unity of the faith which Peter then professed to Christ, to him will be granted neither forgiveness of sins nor entrance into the kingdom of heaven

We wyllað æfter ðisum godspelle eow gereccan ðæra apostola drohtnunga and geendunge, mid scortre race
We will after this gospel relate to you the lives and end of those apostles in a short narrative, because their passion is everywhere fully set forth in the English tongue

Æfter Drihtnes upstige wæs Petrus bodigende geleafan ðam leodscipum ðe sind gecwedene Galatia, Cappadocia, Bithinia, Asia, Italia
After the Lord's ascension Peter was preaching the faith to the nations which are called Galatia, Cappadocia, Bithynia, Asia, Italy

Syððan, ymbe tyn geara fyrst, hé gewende to Romebyrig, bodigende godspel
Afterwards, after a space of ten years, he returned to Rome, preaching the gospel

and on ðære byrig hé gesette his biscop-setl, and ðær gesæt fif and twentig geara, lærende ða Romaniscan ceastregewaran Godes mærða, mid micclum tacnum
and in that city he set his episcopal seat, and there sat five and twenty years, teaching the Roman citizens the glories of God, with many miracles

His wiðerwinna wæs on eallum his færelde sum drý, se wæs Simon geháten
His adversary in all his course was a certain magician, who was called Simon

Þes drý wæs mid ðam awyrgedum gaste to ðam swyðe afylled, þæt he cwæð þæt he wære Crist, Godes Sunu, and mid his drycræfte ðæs folces geleafan amyrde
This magician was filled with the accursed spirit to that degree, that he said that he was Christ, the Son of God, and with his magic corrupted the faith of the people

Þa gelámp hit þæt man ferede anre wuduwan suna líc ðær Petrus bodigende wæs
Then it happened that the corpse of a widow's son was borne where Peter was preaching

He ða cwæð to ðam folce and to ðam drý
He said to the people and to the magician

Genealǽcað ðære bære, and gelyfað þæt ðæs bodung soð sy, ðe ðone deadan to life arærð
Draw near to the bier, and believe that his preaching is true who raises the dead to life

Hwæt ða Simon wearð gebyld þurh deofles gast, and cwæð
Simon was hereupon emboldened by the spirit of the devil, and said

Swa hraðe swa ic þone deadan arǽre, acwellað minne wiðerwinnan Petrum
As soon as I shall have raised the dead, kill my adversary Peter

Þæt folc him andwyrde
The people answered him

Cucenne we hine forbærnað
We will burn him alive

Simon ða mid deofles cræfte dyde þæt ðæs deadan líc styrigende wæs
Simon then, through the devil's craft, made the corpse of the dead to move

Þa wende þæt folc þæt he geedcucod wære
The people then imagined that he was restored to life: but Peter cried above all

Petrus ða ofer eall clypode
If he be restored to life, let him speak to us, and stand up

Gif he geedcucod sy, sprece to ús, and astande
let him taste food, and return home

Þæt folc ða hrymde hlúddre stemne
If Simon do this not, he shall undergo the punishment which he devised for thee

Se Godes apostol ða genealæhte ðam lice mid aðenedum earmum, ðus biddende
The apostle of God then drew near to the corpse with outstretched arms, thus praying

Ðu, leofa Drihten, ðe ús sendest to bodigenne ðinne geleafan, and ús behete þæt we mihton, ðurh ðinne naman, deoflu todræfan, and untrume gehælan, and ða deadan aræran, arǽr nu ðisne cnapan, þæt ðis folc oncnáwe þæt nan God nys buton ðu ana, mid ðinum Fæder, and ðam Halgan Gaste
Thou, beloved Lord, who hast sent us to preach thy faith, and hast promised us that we might, through thy name, drive away devils, and heal the sick, and raise up the dead, raise up now this lad, that this people may know that there is no God but thou alone, with thy Father and the Holy Ghost

Æfter ðisum gebede arás se deada, and gebígedum cneowum to Petre cwæð
After this prayer the dead rose up, and with bended knees said to Peter

Ic geseah Hælend Crist, and hé sende his englas forð for ðinre bene, þæt hí me to life gelæddon
I saw Jesus Christ, and he sent his angels forth at thy prayer, that they might lead me to life

Þæt folc ða mid anre stemne clypigende cwæð
The people then crying with one voice said

An God is ðe Petrus bodað
There is one God that Peter preaches

and woldon forbǽrnan ðone drý, ac Petrus him forwyrnde
and would burn the magician, but Peter forbade them, saying, that Jesus had taught them the rule, that they should requite evil with good

Simon, ðaða he ðam folce ætwunden wæs, getígde ænne ormǽtne ryððan innan ðam geate þær Petrus inn hæfde, þæt he fǽrlice hine abítan sceolde
Simon, when he had escaped from the people, tied a huge mastiff within the gate where Peter had his dwelling, that he might suddenly devour him

Hwæt ða Petrus cóm, and ðone ryððan untígde mid ðisum bebode
But Peter came and untied the mastiff with this injunction

Yrn, and sege Simone, þæt he leng mid his drycræfte Godes folc ne bepæce, ðe hé mid his agenum blode gebohte
Run, and say to Simon, that he no longer with his magic deceive God's people, whom he bought with his own blood

And hé sona getengde wið þæs drýs, and hine on fleame gebrohte
And he forthwith hastened towards the magician, and put him to flight

Petrus wearð æfterweard þus cweðende
Peter afterwards thus spake

On Godes naman ic ðe bebeode, þæt ðu nænne toð on his lice ne gefæstnige
In the name of God I command thee that thou fasten no tooth on his body

Se hund, ðaða hé ne moste his lichaman derian, totær his hæteru sticmælum of his bæce, and hine dráf geond ða weallas, ðeotende swa swa wulf, on ðæs folces gesihðe
The dog, when he might not hurt his body, tore his garments piecemeal from his back, and, howling like a wolf, drove him along the walls, in sight of the people

He ða ætbærst ðam hunde, and to lángum fyrste siððan, for ðære sceame, næs gesewen on Romana-byrig
He then escaped from the dog, and for a long time after, for shame, was not seen in Rome

Syððan eft on fyrste he begeat sumne ðe hine bespræc to ðam casere Nerone, and gelámp ða þæt se awyrgeda ehtere þone deofles ðen his freondscipum geðeodde
After a time he got some one to speak of him to the emperor Nero, and it happened that the accursed persecutor associated the devil's minister in his friendship

Mid ðam ðe hit ðus gedón wæs, ða æteowde Crist hine sylfne Petre on gastlicere gesihðe, and mid ðyssere tihtinge hine gehyrte
When this had taken place, Christ appeared to Peter in a ghostly vision, and encouraged him with this incitement

Se drý Simon and se wælhreowa Nero sind mid deofles gaste afyllede, and syrwiað ongean ðe
The magician Simon and the cruel Nero are filled with the spirit of the devil, and machinate against thee, but be thou not afraid

ac ne beo ðu afyrht
I will be with thee, and I will send my servant Paul for thy comfort, who shall enter into Rome to-morrow, and ye shall fight in ghostly conflict against the magician, and shall cast him into the abyss of hell, and ye shall afterwards together come to my kingdom with the triumph of martyrdom

Non passus est Paulus, quando uinctus Romam perductus est, sed post aliquot annos, quando sponte illuc iterum reuersus est
This in sooth so happened

Þis gelámp swa soðlice
On the next day Paul came into the city, and each of them received the other with great joy, and they were together seven months preaching within the city the way of life to the people

On ðone oðerne dæg com Paulus into ðære byrig, and heora ægðer oðerne mid micelre blisse underfeng, and wæron togædere bodigende binnan ðære byrig seofon monðas þam folce lifes weig
People without number then inclined to christianity through the teaching of Peter

Beah ða ungerim folces to cristendome þurh Petres lare
and also Livia the emperor's consort, and the wife of his chief officer, Agrippina, were so imbued with the faith, that they eschewed the intercourse of their husbands

and eac ðæs caseres gebedda Libia, and his heah-gerefan wíf Agrippina wurdon swa gelyfede þæt hí forbugon heora wera neawiste
Through the preaching of Paul the servants and domestics of the emperor believed, and after their baptism would not return to his family

Simon se drý worhte ða ærene næddran, styrigende swylce heo cucu wære
Simon the magician then wrought a brazen serpent, moving as if it were alive, and made the idols of the heathens laughing and moving

and dyde þæt ða anlicnyssa ðæra hæðenra hlihhende wæron and styrigende
and he himself suddenly appeared up in the air

and he sylf wearð færlice upp on ðære lyfte gesewen
On the other hand Peter healed the blind, and the halt, and the possessed of devils, and raised up the dead, and said to the people that they should flee from the magic of the devil, lest they should be deceived by his wiles

Þær-to-geanes gehælde Petrus blinde, and healte, and deofol-seoce, and ða deadan arærde, and cwæð to ðam folce þæt hí sceoldon forfleon þæs deofles drýcræft, ðylæs ðe hí mid his lotwrencum bepæhte wurdon
This was then made known to the emperor, and he commanded the magician to be fetched to him, and also the apostles

Þa wearð ðis ðam casere gecydd, and he het ðone drý him to gefeccan, and eac ða apostolas
Simon changed his appearance before the emperor, so that he suddenly seemed a boy, and afterwards a hoary man

Simon bræd his hiw ætforan ðam casere, swa þæt he wearð færlice geðuht cnapa, and eft hárwenge
sometimes in a woman's person, and again instantly in childhood

Þa Nero þæt geseah, ða wende hé þæt he Godes Sunu wære
When Nero saw that, he imagined that he was the Son of God

Petrus cwæð þæt hé Godes wiðersaca wære, and mid leasum drýcræfte forscyldigod, and cwæð þæt he wære gewiss deofol on menniscre edwiste
Peter said that he was God's adversary, and guilty of false magic, and said that he was certainly the devil in human substance

Simon cwæð
Simon said

Nis na gedafenlic þæt ðu, cyning, hlyste anes leases fisceres wordum
It is not fitting that thou, king, shouldst listen to the words of a false fisher

ac ic ðisne hosp leng ne forbere: nu ic beode minum englum þæt hí me on ðisum fiscere gewrecon
but I will no longer bear this contumely: I will now command my angels to avenge me on this fisher

Petrus cwæð
Peter said

Ne ondræde ic ðine awyrgedan gastas, ac hí weorðað afyrhte þurh mines Drihtnes geleafan
I fear not thy accursed spirits, but they will become terrified through the faith of my Lord

Nero cwæð
Nero said

Ne ondrætst ðu ðe, Petrus, Simones mihta, ðe mid wundrum his godcundnysse geswutelað
Fearest thou not, Peter, the powers of Simon, who manifests to thee his divinity by miracles

Petrus cwæð
Peter said

Gif he godcundnysse hæbbe, ðonne secge he hwæt ic ðence, oððe hwæt ic dón wylle
If he have divinity, then let him say what I think, or what I will do

Nero cwæð
Nero said

Sege me, Petrus, on sundor-spræce hwæt ðu ðence
Tell me, Peter, in speech apart, what thou thinkest

He ða leat to ðæs caseres eare, and het him beran diglice berenne hláf
He then bent to the emperor's ear, and ordered a barley loaf to be privately brought to him

and he bletsode ðone hláf, and tobræc, and bewand on his twam slyfum, ðus cweðende
and he blessed the loaf, and brake, and wrapt it in his two sleeves, thus saying

Sege nu, Simon, hwæt ic ðohte, oððe cwæde, oþþe gedyde
Say now, Simon, what I thought, or said, or did

He ða gebealh hine, forðan þe he ne mihte geopenian Petres digelnysse, and dyde þa mid drýcræfte þæt ðær comon micele hundas, and ræsdon wið Petres weard
He was then wroth, for he could not open Peter's secret, and caused by magic large dogs to come, and rush towards Peter

ac Petrus æteowde ðone gebletsodan hláf ðam hundum, and hí ðærrihte of heora gesihðe fordwinon
but Peter showed the blessed bread to the dogs, and they straightways vanished from their sight

He ða cwæð to ðam casere
He then said to the emperor

Simon me mid his englum geðiwde, nu sende he hundas to me
Simon threatened me with his angels, now he sends dogs to me

forðan ðe he næfð godcundlice englas, ac hæfð hundlice
because he has not divine angels, but has doglike

Nero cwæð
Nero said

Hwæt is nu, Simon
What is now, Simon

Ic wene wit sind oferswiðde
I ween we are overcome

Simon andwyrde
Simon answered

Þu goda cyning, nat nán man manna geðohtas buton Gode anum
Thou good king, no one knows men's thoughts but God alone

Petrus andwyrde
Peter answered

Untwylice þu lihst þæt þu God sy, nu ðu nast manna geðohtas
Undoubtedly thou liest that thou art God, now thou knowest not men's thoughts

Þa bewende Nero hine to Paulum, and cwæð
Nero then turned to Paul, and said

Hwí ne cwest ðu nán word
Why sayest thou no word

Oððe hwa teah ðe
Or who has taught thee

oððe hwæt lærdest ðu mid þinre bodunge
or what hast thou taught with thy preaching

Paulus him andwyrde
Paul answered him

La leof, hwæt wille ic ðisum forlorenum wiðersacan geandwyrdan
O sir, why shall I answer this lost adversary

Gif ðu wilt his wordum gehyrsumian, þu amyrst ðine sawle and eac ðinne cynedom
If thou wilt obey his words, thou wilt injure thy soul, and also thy kingdom

Be minre lare, þe ðu axast, ic ðe andwyrde
Concerning my teaching, which thou askest, I will answer thee

Se Hælend, þe Petrum lærde on his andweardnysse, se ylca me lærde mid onwrigenysse
Jesus, who while present taught Peter, the same by revelation taught me

and ic gefylde mid Godes lare fram Hierusalem, oðþæt ic com to Iliricum
and I have filled with the precepts of God from Jerusalem until I came to Illyricum

Ic lærde þæt men him betweonan lufodon and geárwurðedon
I taught that men should love and honour each other

Ic tæhte ðam rícan, þæt hí ne onhofon hí, ne heora hiht on leasum welan ne besetton, ac on Gode anum
I taught the rich not to exalt themselves, nor to place their hope in false wealth, but in God alone

Ic tæhte ðam medeman mannum, þæt hí gehealdene wæron on heora bigwiste and scrude
I taught men of moderate means to be frugal in their food and clothing

Ic bebead þearfum, þæt hí blissodon on heora hafenleaste
I enjoined the poor to rejoice in their indigence

Fæderas ic manode, þæt hí mid steore Godes eges heora cild geðeawodon
Fathers I exhorted to bring up their children in the fear of God

Þam cildum ic bead, þæt hí gehyrsume wæron fæder and meder to halwendum mynegungum
Children I enjoined to be obedient to the salutary admonitions of father and mother

Ic lærde weras, þæt hí heora ǽwe heoldon, forðan þæt se wer gewitnað on æwbræcum wife, þæt wrecð God on ǽwbræcum were
I taught husbands to keep inviolate their wedlock, because that which a man punishes in an adulterous wife, God will avenge in an adulterous husband

Ic manode ǽwfæste wíf, þæt hí heora weras inweardlice lufodon, and him mid ege gehyrsumodon, swa swa hlafordum
I exhorted pious wives inwardly to love their husbands, and with awe obey them as masters

Ic lærde hlafordas, þæt hí heora ðeowum liðe wæron
I taught masters to be kind to their servants

forðan ðe hí sind gebroðru for Gode, se hlaford and se ðeowa
because they are brothers before God, the master and the servant

Ic bebead ðeowum mannum, þæt hí getreowlice, and swa swa Gode heora hlafordum þeowdon
I commanded serving men faithfully and as God to serve their masters

Ic tæhte eallum geleaffullum mannum, þæt hí wurðian ænne God Ælmihtigne and ungesewenlicne
I taught all believing men to worship one God Almighty and invisible

Ne leornode ic ðas lare æt nanum eorðlicum menn, ac Hælend Crist of heofonum me spræc to, and sende me to bodigenne his láre eallum ðeodum, ðus cweðende, 'Far ðu geond þas woruld, and ic beo mid þe
I learned not this lore of any earthly man, but Jesus Christ spake to me from heaven, and sent me to preach his doctrine to all nations, thus saying, 'Go thou throughout the world, and I will be with thee, and whatsoever thou sayest or doest, I will justify it

Simon cwæð
Simon said

Ðu góda cyning, ne understenst ðu ðisra twegra manna gereonunge ongean me
Thou good king, thou understandest not the plot of these two men against me

Ic com Soðfæstnys, ac ðas ðweorigað wið me
I am the Truth, but these thwart me

Hát nu aræran ænne heahne torr, þæt ic ðone astige
Command now a high tower to be raised, that I may ascend it

forðan ðe mine englas nellað cuman to me on eorðan betwux synfullum mannum: and ic wylle astigan to minum fæder, and ic bebeode minum englum, þæt hi ðe to minum rice gefeccan
for my angels will not come to me on earth among sinful men: and I will ascend to my father, and I will command my angels to fetch thee to my kingdom

Nero ða cwæð
Nero then said

Ic wylle geseon gif ðu ðas behát mid weorcum gefylst
I will see if thou fulfillest these promises by deeds

and het ða ðone torr mid micclum ofste on smeðum felda aræran, and bebead eallum his folce þæt hi to ðyssere wæfersyne samod comon
and then bade the tower be raised with great haste on the smooth field, and commanded all his people to come together to this spectacle

Se drý astah ðone torr ætforan eallum ðam folce, and astrehtum earmum ongann fleogan on ða lyft
The magician then ascended the tower before all the people, and with outstretched arms began to fly in the air

Paulus cwæð to Petre
Paul said to Peter

Broðer, þu wære Gode gecoren ær ic, ðe gedafnað þæt þu ðisne deofles ðen mid ðinum benum afylle
Brother, thou wast chosen of God before me, to thee it is fitting that thou cast down this minister of the devil with thy prayers

and ic eac mine cneowu gebige to ðære bene
and I will also bend my knees to that prayer

Þa beseah Petrus to ðam fleondan drý, þus cweðende
Peter then looked towards the flying magician, thus saying

Ic halsige eow awirigede gastas, on Cristes naman, þæt ge forlæton ðone drý ðe ge betwux eow feriað
I conjure you, accursed spirits, in the name of Christ, to forsake the magician whom ye bear betwixt you

and ða deoflu þærrihte hine forleton, and he feallende tobærst on feower sticca
and the devils instantly forsook him, and he falling brake into four pieces

Þa feower sticca clifodon to feower stanum, ða sind to gewitnysse ðæs apostolican siges oð þisne andweardan dæg
The four pieces clave to four stones, which are for witness of the apostolic triumph to this day

Petres geðyld geðafode þæt ða hellican fynd hine up geond þa lyft sume hwile feredon, þæt he on his fylle þy hetelicor hreosan sceolde
Peter's patience allowed the hellish fiends to bear him somewhile up through the air, that in his fall he might descend the more violently

and se ðe lytle ær beotlice mid deoflicum fiðerhaman fleon wolde, þæt he ða færlice his feðe forlure
and that he, who menacingly a little before would fly with devilish wings, might suddenly lose his footing

Him gedafenode þæt hé on heannysse ahafen wurde, þæt hé on gesihðe ealles folces hreosende ða eorðan gesohte
It was befitting him to be raised up on high, that, in the sight of all the people, falling down, he might seek the earth

Hwæt ða, Nero bebead Petrum and Paulum on bendum gehealdan, and ða sticca Simones hreawes mid wearde besettan: wende þæt hé of deaðe on ðam ðriddan dæge arisan mihte
Nero then commanded Peter and Paul to be held in bonds, and the pieces of Simon's carcase to be guarded by a watch: he weened that he could arise from death on the third day

Petrus cwæð
Peter said

Ðes Simon ne ge-edcucað ǽr ðam gemǽnum æriste, ac he is to ecum witum geniðerod
This Simon will not be requickened before the general resurrection, but he is condemned to everlasting torments

Se Godes wiðerwinna ða, Nero, mid geðeahte his heah-gerefan Agrippan, het Paulum beheafdian, and Petrum on rode ahón
Then God's adversary, Nero, with the counsel of his chief officer Agrippa, commanded Paul to be beheaded, and Peter hanged on a cross

Paulus ða, be ðæs cwelleres hæse, underbeah swurdes ecge, and Petrus rode-hengene astah
Paul then, at the executioner's command, bowed his neck under the sword's edge, and Peter ascended the cross

Þaða hé to ðære rode gelæd wæs, he cwæð to ðam cwellerum
While he was being led to the cross, he said to the executioners

Ic bidde eow, wendað min heafod adúne, and astreccað mine fét wið heofonas weard: ne eom ic wyrðe þæt ic swa hangige swa min Drihten
I beseech you, turn my head down, and stretch my feet towards heaven: I am not worthy to hang as my Lord

He astah of heofonum for middangeardes alysednysse, and wæron forði his fét niðer awende
He descended from heaven for the redemption of the world, and therefore were his feet turned downwards

Me he clypað nu to his rice
He now calls me to his kingdom

awendað forði mine fótwelmas to ðan heofonlican wege
turn therefore my foot-soles to the heavenly way

And ða cwelleras him ða þæs getiðodon
And the executioners granted him this

Þa wolde þæt cristene folc ðone casere acwellan, ac Petrus mid þisum wordum hí gestilde
Then would the christian people slay the emperor, but Peter stilled them with these words

Mín Drihten for feawum dagum me geswutelode þæt ic sceolde mid þysre ðrowunge his fótswaðum fylian: nu, mine bearn, ne gelette ge minne weg
My Lord a few days ago manifested to me that I should follow his footsteps with this suffering: now, my children, hinder not my way

Mine fét sind nu awende to ðam heofenlican life
My feet are now turned to the heavenly life

Blissiað mid me
Rejoice with me

nu to-dæg ic onfó minre earfoðnysse edlean
