now to-day I shall receive the reward of my tribulation

He wæs ða biddende his Drihten mid þisum wordum
He was then praying his Lord with these words

Hælend mín, ic ðe betæce ðine scep, þe ðu me befæstest: ne beoð hi hyrdelease þonne hí ðe habbað
My Saviour, I commit to thee thy sheep, which thou didst entrust to me: they will not lack a shepherd when they have thee

And hé mid þisum wordum ageaf his gast
And with these words he gave up his ghost

Samod hí ferdon, Petrus and Paulus, on ðisum dæge, sigefæste to ðære heofonlican wununge, on þam syx and þrittegoðan geare æfter Cristes ðrowunge, mid þam hí wuniað on ecnysse
Together they went, Peter and Paul, on this day, triumphant to the heavenly dwelling, in the six and thirtieth year after Christ's passion, with whom they continue to eternity

Igitur Hieronimus et quique alii auctores testantur, quod in una die simul Petrus et Paulus martirizati sunt
Igitur Hieronymus et quique alii auctores testantur, quod in una die simul Petrus et Paulus martyrizati sunt

Æfter heora ðrowunge þærrihte comon wlitige weras, and uncuðe eallum folce: cwædon þæt hi comon fram Hierusalem, to ðy þæt hi woldon ðæra apostola líc bebyrian
Immediately after their passion there came beauteous men, and unknown to all the people: they said that they came from Jerusalem, that they might bury the bodies of the apostles

and swa dydon mid micelre arwurðnysse, and sædon þam folce, þæt hí micclum blissian mihton, forðan ðe hi swylce mundboran on heora neawiste habban moston
and so did with great honour, and said to the people, that they might greatly rejoice at having such patrons in their proximity

Wite ge eac þæt ðes wyrresta cyning Nero rice æfter cwale þisra apostola healdan ne mót
Know ye also that this worst of kings, Nero, could not hold his realm after the death of these apostles

Hit gelámp ða þæt eal ðæs wælhreowan caseres folc samod hine hatode, swa þæt hi ræddon anmodlice þæt man hine gebunde, and oð deað swunge
It befell that all the people together of the cruel emperor hated him, so that they resolved unanimously to bind and scourge him to death

Nero, ðaða he ðæs folces ðeaht geacsode, wearð to feore afyrht, and mid fleame to wuda getengde
When Nero heard of the people's counsel he was mortally afraid, and hastened in flight to the wood

Þa sprang þæt word þæt hé swa lange on ðam holte on cyle and on hungre dwelode, oðþæt hine wulfas totæron
Then the rumour sprang up that he continued so long in the wood, in cold and hunger, until wolves tore him in pieces

Þa gelámp hit æfter ðam, þæt Grecas gelæhton ðæra apostola lichaman, and woldon east mid him lædan
It happened after that, that Greeks seized the bodies of the apostles, and would take them with them eastward

Þa færinga gewearð micel eorð-styrung, and þæt Romanisce folc ðyder onette, and ða líc ahreddan, on ðære stowe ðe is geháten Catacumbas
There then was suddenly a great earthquake, and the Roman people hastened thither, and rescued the bodies, in the place which is called the Catacombs, and they preserved them there a year and a half, until the places were built in which they were afterwards laid, with glory and hymns

and hí ðær heoldon oðer healf gear, oðþæt ða stowa getimbrode wæron, ðe hí siððan on aléde wæron, mid wuldre and lófsangum
It is known among all nations that many wonders happened at the tombs of those apostles, through permission of Jesus, to whom be glory and praise ever to eternity

Cuð is geond ealle ðeodscipas þæt fela wundra gelumpon æt ðæra apostola byrgenum, ðurh ðæs Hælendes tiðe, ðam sy wuldor and lóf á on ecnysse
Amen

Godes gelaðung wurðað þisne dæg ðam mæran apostole Paule to wurðmynte, forðam ðe he is gecweden ealra ðeoda láreow: þurh soðfæste lare wæs ðeah-hwæðere his martyrdóm samod mid ðam eadigan Petre gefremmed
The church of God celebrates this day in honour of the great Apostle Paul, for he is called the teacher of all nations: though his martyrdom, for true doctrine, was accomplished with the blessed Peter's

Hé wæs fram cildháde on ðære ealdan ǽ getogen, and mid micelre gecnyrdnysse on ðære begriwen wæs
He had from childhood been bred up in the old law, and by great diligence was therein deeply imbued

Æfter Cristes ðrowunge, ðaða se soða geleafa aspráng þurh ðæra apostola bodunge, ða ehte he cristenra manna þurh his nytennysse, and sette on cwearterne, and eac wæs on geðafunge æt ðæs forman cyðeres Stephanes slege: nis ðeah-hwæðere be him geræd, þæt hé handlinga ænigne man acwealde
After Christ's passion, when the true faith had sprung up through the preaching of the apostles, he persecuted christian men through his ignorance, and set them in prison, and was also consenting to the slaying of the first martyr Stephen: it is not, however, read of him that he killed any man with his own hands

He nam ða gewrit æt ðam ealdor-biscopum to ðære byrig Damascum, þæt hé moste gebindan ða cristenan ðe hé on ðære byrig gemette, and gelædan to Hierusalem
He took then letters of the high priests for the city of Damascus, that he might bind the christians that he found in the city, and lead them to Jerusalem

Þa gelamp hit on þam siðe þæt him com færlice to micel leoht, and hine astrehte to eorðan, and he gehyrde stemne ufan þus cweðende, Saule, Saule, hwí ehtst ðu mín
Then it happened on the journey that a great light came suddenly on him, and prostrated him on the earth, and he heard a voice from above thus saying, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me

Yfel bið ðe sylfum þæt ðu spurne ongean ða gáde
Evil will it be to thee to spurn against the goad

He ða mid micelre fyrhte andwyrde þære stemne, Hwæt eart ðu, leof Hlaford
He then in great fright answered the voice, Who art thou, dear Lord

Him andwyrde seo clypung þære godcundan stemne, Ic eom se Hælend þe ðu ehtst: ac arís nu, and far forð to ðære byrig
The calling of the divine voice answered him, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest: but arise now, and go forth to the city

þær ðe bið gesǽd hwæt ðe gedafenige to donne
there shall it be said unto thee what it befitteth thee to do

Hé arás ða, ablendum eagum, and his geferan hine swa blindne to ðære byrig gelæddon
He arose then with blinded eyes, and his companions led him thus blind to the city

And he ðær andbidigende ne onbyrigde ætes ne wætes binnan ðreora daga fæce
And there abiding he tasted neither meat nor drink for a space of three days

Wæs ða sum Godes ðegen binnan ðære byrig, his nama wæs Annanías, to ðam spræc Drihten ðysum wordum, Annanía, arís, and gecum to minum ðeowan Saulum, se is biddende minre miltsunge mid eornestum mode
There was then a servant of God within the city, his name was Ananias, to whom the Lord spake in these words, Ananias, arise, and go to my servant Saul, who is praying for my mercy with earnest mind

He andwyrde ðære drihtenlican stemne, Min Hælend, hu mæg ic hine gesprecan, seðe is ehtere ðinra halgena, ðurh mihte ðæra ealdor-biscopa
He answered the divine voice, My Saviour, how may I speak to him who is the persecutor of thy saints, through the power of the chief priests

Drihten cwæð, Far swa ic ðe sæde, forðan ðe hé is me gecoren fætels, þæt hé tobere minne naman ðeodum, and cynegum, and Israhela bearnum
The Lord said, Go as I have said to thee, for he is to me a chosen vessel, to bear my name to nations, and to kings, and to the children of Israel

and he sceal fela ðrowian for minum naman
and he shall suffer much for my name

Annanías ða becom to ðam gecorenan cempan, and sette his handa him on-uppan mid þisre gretinge, Saule, min broðor, se Hælend, þe ðe be wege gespræc, sende me wið ðín, þæt þu geseo, and mid þam Halgan Gaste gefylled sy
Ananias went then to the chosen champion, and set his hands upon him with this greeting, Saul, my brother, Jesus, who spake to thee on the way, hath sent me to thee, that thou mayest see, and be filled with the Holy Ghost

Þa, mid ðisum wordum, feollon swylce fylmena of his eagum, and he ðærrihte gesihðe underfeng, and to fulluhte beah
Then with these words there fell as it were films from his eyes, and he straightways received sight, and submitted to baptism

Wunode ða sume feawa daga mid þam Godes ðeowum binnan ðære byrig, and mid micelre bylde þam Iudeiscum bodade, þæt Crist, ðe hí wiðsocon, is ðæs Ælmihtigan Godes Sunu
He continued then some few days with the servants of God within the city, and with great boldness preached to the Jews, that Christ, whom they had denied, is the Son of Almighty God

Hí wurdon swiðlice ablicgede, and cwædon, La hú, ne is ðes se wælhreowa ehtere cristenra manna: húmeta bodað he Cristes geleafan
They were greatly astonished, and said, What

Saulus soðlice micclum swyðrode, and ða Iudeiscan gescende, mid anrædnysse seðende, þæt Crist is Godes Sunu
is not this the cruel persecutor of christian men: how preacheth he the faith of Christ

Hwæt ða, æfter manegum dagum gereonodon ða Iudeiscan, hú hí ðone Godes cempan acwellan sceoldon, and setton ða weardas to ælcum geate ðære ceastre
Then after many days the Jews deliberated how they might kill the champion of God, and set wards at every gate of the city

Paulus ongeat heora syrwunge, and ða cristenan hine genamon, and on anre wilian aleton ofer ðone weall
Paul got knowledge of their machination, and the christians took him, and let him down over the wall in a basket

And he ferde ongean to Hierusalem, and hine gecuðlæhte to ðam halgan heape Cristes hiredes, and him cydde hú se Hælend hine of heofenum gespræc
And he went again to Jerusalem, and announced himself to the holy fellowship of Christ's family, and made known to them how Jesus had spoken to him from heaven

Syððan, æfter sumum fyrste, com clypung of ðam Halgan Gaste to ðam geleaffullan werode, þus cweðende, Asendað Paulum and Barnaban to ðam weorce ðe ic hí gecoren hæbbe
After some time a voice came from the Holy Ghost, to the faithful company, thus saying, Send Paul and Barnabas to the work for which I have chosen them

Se halga heap ða, be Godes hæse and gecorennysse, hí asendon to lærenne eallum leodscipum be Cristes to-cyme for middangeardes alysednysse
The holy fellowship then, by God's command and election, sent them to teach all countries concerning the coming of Christ for the redemption of the world

Barnabas wæs ða Paules gefera æt ðære bodunge to langum fyrste
Thus was Barnabas Paul's companion in preaching for a long time, when at last it seemed good to them to go apart, and they did so

Ða æt nextan wearð him geðuht þæt hi ontwa ferdon, and swa dydon
Paul was then filled and comforted with the grace of the Holy Ghost, and went to many countries, sowing God's seed

Paulus wearð þa afylled and gefrefrod mid þæs Halgan Gastes gife, and ferde to manegum leodscipum, sawende Godes sæd
In one city he was twelve months, in one two years, in one three, and appointed bishops, and mass-priests, and servants of God

On sumere byrig he wæs twelf monað, on sumere twa gear, on sumere ðreo, and gesette biscopas, and mæsse-preostas, and Godes ðeowas
he went afterwards to another country, and did in like manner

ferde siððan forð to oðrum leodscipe, and dyde swa gelice
But he sent back letters to those whom he before had taught, and so by those letters stimulated and confirmed them in the way of life

We willað nu mid sumere scortre trahtnunge þas rædinge oferyrnan, and geopenian, gif heo hwæt digles on hyre hæbbende sy
We will now run over this reading with a short exposition, and explain any obscurity there may be contained in it

Paulus ehte cristenra manna, na mid niðe, swa swa ða Iudeiscan dydon, ac he wæs midspreca and bewerigend þære ealdan ǽ mid micelre anrædnysse: wende þæt Cristes geleafa wære wiðerwinna ðære ealdan gesetnysse: ac se Hælend ðe gesette ða ealdan ǽ mid mislicum getacnungum, se ylca eft on his andweardnysse hí awende to soðfæstnysse æfter gastlicre getacnunge
Paul persecuted christian men, not with hate, as the Jews did, but he was a partizan and defender of the old law with great steadfastness: he thought that the faith of Christ was an adversary to the old covenant: but Jesus who had established the old law by divers miracles, the same afterwards by his presence changed it to truth, according to its ghostly signification

Þa nyste Paulus ða gastlican getacnunge ðære ǽ, and wæs forði hyre forespreca, and ehtere Cristes geleafan
Now Paul knew not the ghostly signification of that law, and was therefore its advocate, and a persecutor of the faith of Christ

God Ælmihtig, þe ealle ðing wát, geseah his geðanc, þæt hé ne ehte geleaffulra manna ðurh andan, ac ðurh ware ðære ealdan ǽ, and hine ða gespræc of heofonum, ðus cweðende
God Almighty, who knows all things, saw his thoughts, that he did not persecute faithful men from rancour, but for the defence of the old law, and spake to him from heaven, thus saying

Saule, hwí ehtst ðu mín
Saul, why persecutest thou me

Ic eom seo Soðfæstnys ðe ðu werast
I am the Truth which thou defendest

geswic ðære ehtnysse: derigendlic bið ðe þæt þu spurne ongean þa gáde
cease from persecution: hurtful will it be to thee to spurn against the goad

Gif se oxa spyrnð ongean ða gáde, hit dereð him sylfum
If the ox spurneth against the goad, it hurteth himself

swa eac hearmað þe ðin gewinn togeanes me
so also harmeth thee thy warfare against me

He cwæð
He said

Hwí ehtst ðu mín
Why persecutest thou me

forðan ðe he is cristenra manna heafod, and besargað swa hwæt swa his lima on eorðan ðrowiað, swa swa he ðurh his witegan cwæð
because he is the head of christian men, and bewails whatsoever his limbs suffer on earth, as he said through his prophet

Se ðe eow hrepað, hit me bið swa egle swylce he hreppe ða seo mines eagan
He who toucheth you, it shall be to me as painful as if he touched the sight of my eye

He wearð astreht, þus cweðende
He was prostrated, thus saying

Hwæt eart ðu, Hlaford
Who art thou, Lord

His modignes wearð astreht, and seo soðe eadmodnys wearð on him aræred
His pride was prostrated, and true humility was raised up in him

He feoll unrihtwis, and wearð aræred rihtwis
He fell unrighteous, and was raised righteous

Feallende he forleas lichamlice gesihðe, arisende he underfeng his modes onlihtinge
Falling he lost bodily sight, rising he received his mind's enlightening

Þry dagas he wunode butan gesihðe, forðan ðe he wiðsóc Cristes ærist on ðam ðriddan dæge
Three days he continued without sight, because he had denied the resurrection of Christ on the third day

Annanias is gereht, on Hebreiscum gereorde, 'scép
Ananias signifies in the Hebrew tongue, sheep

' Þæt bilewite scép ða gefullode ðone arleasan Saulum, and worhte hine arfæstne Paulum
The gentle sheep then baptized the impious Saul, and made him the pious Paul

He gefullode ðone wulf and geworhte to lambe
He baptized the wolf and made him a lamb

He awende his naman mid ðeawum
He changed his name with his character

and wæs ða soðfæst bydel Godes gelaðunge, seðe ær mid reðre ehtnysse hi geswencte
and he was then a true proclaimer of God's church, who had before afflicted it with fierce persecution

He wolde forfleon syrewunge Iudeiscre ðeode, and geðafode þæt hine man on anre wilian ofer ðone weall nyðer alét: na þæt hé nolde for Cristes geleafan deað þrowian, ac forði he forfleah ðone ungeripedan deað, forðan ðe he sceolde ærest menigne mann mid his micclum wisdome to Gode gestrynan, and syððan mid micelre geðincðe to martyrdome his swuran astreccan
He would flee from the machination of the Jewish people, and consented to be let down in a basket over the wall: not because he would not suffer death for the faith of Christ, but because he would flee from immature death

Micele maran witu he ðrowode siððan for Cristes naman, ðonne he ǽr his gecyrrednysse cristenum mannum gebude
for he had first to gain many a man to God by his great wisdom, and afterwards with great honour stretch out his neck to martyrdom

Saulus se arleasa beswáng ða cristenan, ac æfter ðære gecyrrednysse wæs se arfæsta Paulus for Cristes naman oft beswungen
Much greater torments he suffered afterwards for Christ's name, than he had ordered for christian men before his conversion

Æne hé wæs gestæned oð deað, swa þæt ða ehteras hine for deadne leton, ac ðæs on merigen hé arás, and ferde ymbe his bodunge
Saul the impious scourged the christians, but after his conversion the pious Paul for the name of Christ was often scourged

He wæs gelomlice on mycelre frecednysse, ægðer ge on sǽ ge on lánde, on westene, betwux sceaðum, on hungre and on ðurste, and on manegum wæccum, on cyle, and on næcednysse, and on manegum cwearternum: swa hé onette mid þære bodunge, swylce hé eal mennisc to Godes ríce gebringan wolde: ægðer ge mid láre, ge mid gebedum, ge mid gewritum hé symle tihte to Godes willan
Once he was stoned almost to death, so that his persecutors left him for dead, but in the morning he arose and went about his preaching

He wæs gelæd to heofonan oð ða ðriddan fleringe, and þær hé geseh and gehyrde Godes digelnysse, ða hé ne moste nanum men cyðan
He was frequently in great peril, both by sea and by land, in the waste, among thieves, from hunger and from thirst, and from many watchings, from cold, and from nakedness, and from many prisons: he so hastened with his preaching, as though he would bring all mankind to God's kingdom: as well with precepts as with prayers and with letters, he ever stimulated to the will of God

Hé besargode mid wope oðra manna synna, and eallum geleaffullum hé æteowde fæderlice lufe
He was led to heaven as far as the third flooring, and there he saw and heard God's secret, which he might not make known to any man

Mid his hand-cræfte he teolode his and his geferena forðdæda, and ðær-to-eacan nis nan ðing tocnawen on soðre eawfæstnysse þæt his lareowdom ne gestaðelode
He bewailed with weeping the sins of other men, and to all the faithful he showed fatherly love

Þa oðre apostoli, be Godes hæse, leofodon be heora láre unpleolice
By his handicraft he toiled for his own and his companions' support, and in addition thereto there was nothing known in true piety which his instruction did not confirm

ac ðeah-hwæðere Paulus ana, seðe wæs on woruld-cræfte teld-wyrhta, nolde ða alyfdan bigleofan onfón, ac mid agenre teolunge his and his geferena neode foresceawode
The other apostles lived, by God's command, by their teaching, free from danger

His lára and his drohtnunga sind ús unasmeagendlice, ac se bið gesælig þe his mynegungum mid gecneordnysse gehyrsumað
but, nevertheless, Paul alone, who by worldly craft was a tent-wright, would not receive the sustenance allowed, but by his own toil provided for his own and his companions' need

He forlét ealle woruld-ðing, and ðam Hælende anum folgode
He forsook all worldly things, and followed Jesus only

swa swa ðis godspel cwyð, ðe ge nú æt ðisre ðenunge gehyrdon
as this gospel says, which ye now at this service have heard

On ðære tíde cwæð Petrus se apostol to ðam Hælende, Efne we forleton ealle woruld-ðing, and ðe ánum fyligað: hwæt dest ðu us þæs to leane
At that time Peter the apostle said to Jesus, Behold we have left all worldly things, and follow thee only: what wilt thou do for us in reward thereof

et reliqua
etc

Micel truwa hwearftlode on Petres heortan: he ána spræc for ealne ðone heap
Great trust revolved in the heart of Peter: he alone spake for the whole company

We forleton ealle ðing
We have forsaken all things

Hwæt forlet Petrus
What did Peter forsake

He wæs fiscere, and mid ðam cræfte his teolode, and ðeah hé spræc mid micelre bylde
He was a fisher, and by that craft provided for himself, and yet he spake with great boldness

We forleton ealle ðing
We have forsaken all things

Ac micel he forlét, and his gebroðru, ðaða hí forleton ðone willan to agenne
But he and his brothers forsook much, when they forsook the will to possess

Þeah hwá forlæte micele æhta, and ne forlæt ða gitsunge, ne forlæt he ealle ðing
Though any one forsake great possessions, and forsake not avarice, he forsakes not all things

Petrus forlet lytle ðing, scripp and net, ac he forlet ealle ðing, ðaða he, for Godes lufon, nan ðing habban nolde
Peter forsook little things, scrip and net, but he forsook all things, when, for love of God, he would have nothing

He cwæð
He said

We fyligað ðe
We follow thee

Nis na fulfremedlic fela æhta to forlætenne, buton he Gode folgige
It is not complete to forsake many possessions, unless a man follow God

Soðlice ða hæðenan uðwitan fela ðinga forleton, swa swa dyde Socrates, seðe ealle his æhta behwyrfde wið anum gyldenum wecge, and syððan awearp ðone wecg on wídre sǽ, þæt seo gitsung ðæra æhta his willan ne hrémde, and abrude fram ðære woruldlican lare ðe he lufode: ac hit ne fremede him swa gedón, forðan ðe he ne fyligde Gode, ac his agenum willan, and forði næfde ða heofenlican edlean mid þam apostolum, þe ealle woruld-ðing forsawon for Cristes lufon, and mid gehyrsumnysse him fyligdon
For the heathen philosophers forsook many things, as Socrates did, who exchanged all his possessions for a wedge of gold, and then cast the wedge into the wide sea, that desire of possessions might not obstruct his will, and draw it from the worldly lore that he loved: but it profited him not so to do, because he did not follow God, but his own will, and had not therefore heavenly reward with the apostles, who, for love of Christ, despised all worldly things, and with obedience followed him

Petrus ða befrán
Peter then asked

Hwæt sceal us getimian
What shall become of us

We dydon swa swa ðu us hete, hwæt dest ðu us to edleane
We have done as thou commandedst us, what wilt thou do for us in reward

Se Hælend andwyrde, Soð ic eow secge, þæt ge ðe me fyligað sceolon sittan ofer twelf dómsetl on ðære edcynninge, ðonne ic sitte on setle mines mægenðrymmes
Jesus answered, Verily I say unto you, that ye who follow me shall, at the regeneration, sit on twelve judgement-seats, when I shall sit on the seat of my majesty

and ge ðonne demað twelf Israhela mægðum
and ye then shall judge the twelve tribes of Israel

Edcynninge he het þæt gemænelice ærist, on ðam beoð ure lichaman ge-edcynnede to unbrosnunge, þæt is to ecum ðingum
He called the common resurrection, regeneration, at which our bodies will be regenerated to incorruption, that is to eternity

Tuwa we beoð on ðisum life acennede: seo forme acennednys is flæsclic, of fæder and of meder
Twice we are born in this life: the first birth is fleshly, of father and of mother

seo oðer acennednys is gastlic, ðonne we beoð ge-edcennede on ðam halgan fulluhte, on ðam us beoð ealle synna forgyfene, ðurh ðæs Halgan Gastes gife
the second birth is ghostly, when we are regenerated at the holy baptism, in which all our sins will be forgiven us, through grace of the Holy Ghost

Seo ðridde acennednys bið on ðam gemænelicum æriste, on ðam beoð ure lichaman ge-edcennede to unbrosnigendlicum lichaman
The third birth is at the common resurrection, at which our bodies will be regenerated to incorruptible bodies

On ðam æriste sittað þa twelf apostoli mid Criste on heora domsetlum, and demað þam twelf mæigðum Israhela ðeode
At the resurrection the twelve apostles will sit with Christ on their judgement-seats, and will judge the twelve tribes of the people of Israel

Þis twelffealde getel hæfð micele getacnunge
This twelvefold number has great signification

Gif ða twelf mægða ána beoð gedemede æt ðam micclum dome, hwæt deð þonne seo ðreotteoðe mæigð, Leui
If the twelve tribes only will be judged at the great doom, what then will the thirteenth tribe, Levi, do

Hwæt doð ealle ðeoda middangeardes
What will do all the nations of the world

Wenst ðu þæt hí beoð asyndrode fram ðam dome
Thinkest thou that they will be sundered from the doom

Ac ðis twelffealde getel is geset for eallum mancynne ealles ymbhwyrftes, for ðære fulfremednysse his getacnunge
But this twelvefold number is set for all mankind of all the orb, for the perfectness of its signification

Twelf tida beoð on ðam dæge, and twelf monðas on geare
There are twelve hours in the day, and twelve months in the year

twelf heahfæderas sind, twelf witegan, twelf apostoli
there are twelve patriarchs, twelve prophets, twelve apostles

and ðis getel hæfð maran getacnunge ðonne ða ungelæredan undergitan magon
and this number has a greater import than the unlearned may understand

Is nu forði mid ðisum twelffealdum getele ealles middangeardes ymbhwyrft getacnod
By this twelvefold number therefore the orb of the whole earth is now signified

Þa apostoli and ealle ða gecorenan ðe him geefenlæhton beoð deman on ðam micclum dæge mid Criste
The apostles and all the chosen who imitated them will be judges on the great day with Christ

Þær beoð feower werod æt ðam dome, twa gecorenra manna, and twa wiðercorenra
There will be four assemblages at the great doom, two of chosen men, and two of rejected

Þæt forme werod bið þæra apostola and heora efenlæcendra, þa ðe ealle woruld-ðing for Godes naman forleton: hí beoð ða demeras, and him ne bið nan dóm gedemed
The first assemblage will be of the apostles and their imitators, who forsook all worldly things for the name of God: they will be the judges, and to them shall no judgement be judged

Oðer endebyrdnys bið geleaffulra woruld-manna: him bið dóm gesett, swa þæt hi beoð asyndrede fram gemanan ðæra wiðercorenra, þus cweðendum Drihtne
The second class will be of faithful men of this world: on them will doom be set, so that they will be sundered from the fellowship of the rejected, the Lord thus saying

Cumað to me, ge gebletsode mines Fæder, and onfoð þæt ríce ðe eow is gegearcod fram frymðe middangeardes
Come to me, ye blessed of my Father, and receive the kingdom which is prepared for you from the beginning of the world

An endebyrdnys bið þæra wiðercorenra, þa þe ciððe hæfdon to Gode, ac hí ne beeodon heora geleafan mid Godes bebodum: ðas beoð fordemede
One class will be of those rejected, who had knowledge of God, but did not cultivate their faith with God's commandments: these will be condemned

Oðer endebyrdnys bið þæra hæðenra manna, þe nane cyððe to Gode næfdon: þisum bið gelæst se apostolica cwyde
The other class is of those heathen men, who have had no knowledge of God: on these will be fulfilled the apostolic sentence

Ða ðe butan Godes ǽ syngodon, hí eac losiað butan ælcere ǽ
Those who have sinned without God's law, shall perish also without any law

To ðisum twam endebyrdnyssum cweð þonne se rihtwisa Dema
To these two classes the righteous Judge will then say

Gewitað fram me, ge awyrigedan, into ðam ecum fyre, þe is gegearcod deofle and his awyrgedum gastum
Depart from me, ye accursed, into the everlasting fire, which is prepared for the devil and his accursed spirits

Þæt godspel cwyð forð gyt
The gospel says yet further

Ælc ðæra ðe forlæt, for minum naman, fæder oððe moder, gebroðru oððe geswystru, wíf oððe bearn, land oððe gebytlu, be hundfealdum him bið forgolden, and he hæfð ðær-to-eacan þæt ece líf
Everyone who forsaketh, for my name, father or mother, brothers or sisters, wife or children, land or dwellings, shall be requited an hundredfold, and he shall have, in addition thereunto, everlasting life

Hundfeald getel is fulfremed, and se ðe forlæt ða ateorigendlican ðing for Godes naman, he underfehð þa gastlican mede be hundfealdum æt Gode
An hundredfold number is perfect, and he who forsakes perishable things for the name of God, will receive from God ghostly meed an hundredfold

Ðes cwyde belimpð swyðe to munuchádes mannum, ða ðe for heofenan ríces myrhðe forlætað fæder, and moder, and flæsclice siblingas
This saying is especially applicable to men of monastic order, who, for the joy of heaven's kingdom, forsake father, and mother, and fleshly relations

Hí underfoð manega gastlice fæderas and gastlice gebroðru, forðan ðe ealle þæs hádes menn, ðe regollice lybbað, beoð him to fæderum and to gebroðrum getealde, and þær-to-eacan hí beoð mid edleane þæs ecan lifes gewelgode
They receive many ghostly fathers and ghostly brothers, for all men of that order, who live after rule, are accounted as their fathers and brothers, and, in addition thereto, they will be enriched with the reward of everlasting life

Þa ðe ealle woruld-ðing be Godes hæse forseoð, and on gemænum ðingum bigwiste habbað, hí beoð fulfremede, and to ðam apostolum geendebyrde
Those who, at God's behest, despise all worldly things, and have their subsistence in common, are perfect, and will be classed with the apostles

Ða oðre ðe ðas geðincðe nabbað, þæt hi ealle heora æhta samod forlætan magon, hí dón þonne ðone dæl for Godes naman ðe him to onhagige, and him bið be hundfealdum écelice geleanod swa hwæt swa hí be anfealdum hwilwendlice dælað
Others, who have not the merit of being able to forsake all their possessions together, let them then give, for the name of God, what portion it may please them, and they will be eternally rewarded an hundredfold for whatsoever they singly and temporarily distribute

Micel todál is betwux þam gecyrredum mannum: sume hí geefenlæcað þam apostolum, sume hí geefenlæcað Iudan, Cristes belǽwan, sume Annanian and Saphiran, sume Giezi
There is a great difference among converted men: some imitate the apostles, some imitate Judas the betrayer of Christ, some Ananias and Sapphira, some Gehazi

Þa ðe ealle gewitendlice ðing to ðæra apostola efenlæcunge forseoð, for intingan þæs écan lifes, hí habbað lóf and ða écan edlean mid Cristes apostolum
Those who, in imitation of the apostles, despise all transitory things for the sake of everlasting life, shall have praise and everlasting reward with Christ's apostles

Se ðe betwux munecum drohtnigende, on mynstres æhtum mid fácne swicað, he bið Iudan gefera, ðe Crist belæwde, and his wite mid hellwarum underfehð
He who, living among monks, guilefully deceives in the property of the monastery, will be the companion of Judas, who betrayed Christ, and will receive his punishment with the inmates of hell

Se ðe mid twyfealdum geðance to mynsterlicre drohtnunge gecyrð, and sumne dæl his æhta dælð, sumne him sylfum gehylt, and næfð nænne truwan to ðam Ælmihtigan, þæt he him foresceawige andlyfene and gewǽda and oðere neoda, he underfehð þone awyrgedan cwyde mid Annanian and Saphiran, þe swicedon on heora agenum æhtum, and mid færlicum deaðe ætforan ðam apostolum steorfende afeollon
He who with twofold thoughts turns to monastic life, and bestows one part of his property, holds one to himself, and has no trust in the Almighty, that he will provide for him food and garments and other needs, will receive the accursed sentence with Ananias and Sapphira, who deceived in their own property, and fell dying with sudden death before the apostles

Se ðe on muneclicere drohtnunge earfoðhylde bið, and gyrnð ðæra ðinga ðe hé on woruldlicere drohtnunge næfde, oððe begitan ne mihte, buton twyn him genealæhð se hreofla Giezi, þæs witegan cnapan, and þæt þæt he on lichaman geðrowade, þæt ðrowað þes on his sawle
He who in monastic life is ill-inclined, and yearns for the things which he had not in worldly life nor could obtain, without doubt to him approximates the leper Gehazi, the prophet's servant, and that which he suffered in body, this suffers in his soul

Se cnapa folgode ðam mæran witegan Eliseum: þa com him to sum rice mann of þam leodscipe þe is Siria geháten, his nama wæs Náámán, and he wæs hreoflig
The servant followed the great prophet Elisha: then there came to him a rich man of the nation which is called Syria, his name was Naaman, and he was leprous

Þa becom hé to ðam Godes witegan Eliseum, on Iudea lande, and he ðurh Godes mihte fram ðære coðe hine gehælde
He came then to God's prophet, Elisha, in Judea, and he, through God's might, healed him from that disease

Þa bead he ðam Godes menn, for his hælðe, deorwurðe sceattas
He then offered to the man of God, for his health, precious treasures

Se witega him andwyrde
The prophet answered him

Godes miht þe gehælde, na ic
God's might hath healed thee, not I

Ne underfó ic ðin feoh: ðanca Gode ðinre gesundfulnysse, and brúc ðinra æhta
I will not receive thy money: thank God for thy health, and enjoy thy possessions

Náámán ða gecyrde mid ealre his fare to his agenre leode
Naaman then returned with all his company to his own people

Þa wæs ðæs witegan cnapa, Gyezi, mid gitsunge undercropen, and of-arn, ðone ðegen Náámán ðus mid wordum liccetende
Then was the prophet's servant, Gehazi, beguiled by avarice, and he ran off, the officer Naaman thus deceiving by words

Nu færlice comon tweigra witegena bearn to minum lareowe: asend him twa scrud and sum pund
Now suddenly the sons of two prophets are come to my master: send him two garments and a pound

Se ðegen him andwyrde
The officer answered him

Waclic bið him swa lytel to sendenne
It will be mean to send him so little

ac genim feower scrud and twa pund
but take four garments and two pounds

He ða gewende ongean mid þam sceattum, and bediglode his fær wið þone witegan
He then returned with the treasures, and concealed his journey from the prophet

Se witega hine befrán
The prophet asked him

Hwanon come ðu, Giezi
Whence comest thou, Gehazi

He andwyrde
He answered

Leof, næs ic on nanre fare
Sir, I was on no journey

Se witega cwæð
The prophet said

Ic geseah, ðurh Godes Gást, þa se ðegen alyhte of his cræte, and eode togeanes ðe, and ðu name his sceattas on feo and on reafe
I saw through the Spirit of God, that the officer alighted from his chariot, and went towards thee, and thou tookest his treasures in money and in raiment

Hafa ðu eac forð mid ðam sceattum his hreoflan, ðu and eal ðin ofspring on ecnysse
Have also henceforth with the treasures his leprosy, thou and all thy offspring for ever

And hé gewende of his gesihðe mid snaw-hwitum hreoflan beslagen
And he turned from his sight stricken with snow-white leprosy

Is nu forði munuchádes mannum mid micelre gecnyrdnysse to forbugenne ðas yfelan gebysnunga, and geefenlæcan þam apostolum, þæt hí, mid him and mid Gode, þæt éce líf habban moton
Now it is therefore for monastic men to shun with great care these evil examples, and to imitate the apostles, that they, with them and with God, may have everlasting life

Amen
Amen

On sumere tide wæs se Hælend farende to Hierusalem: ðaða he genealæhte þære ceastre and hé hí geseah, ða weop hé ofer hí
On a time Jesus was going to Jerusalem: when he came near to the city and saw it, he wept over it

et reliqua
etc

Gregorius se trahtnere cwæð, þæt se Hælend beweope ðære ceastre toworpennysse, ðe gelamp æfter his ðrowunge, for ðære wrace heora mándæda, þæt hí ðone heofenlican Æðeling mánfullice acwellan woldon
Gregory the expounder said, that Jesus bewailed the overthrow of the city, which happened after his passion, in vengeance of their crimes, because they would sinfully slay the heavenly Prince

He spræc mid woplicre stemne, na to ðam weorc-stánum, oððe to ðære getimbrunge, ac spræc to ðam ceastergewarum, þa hé mid fæderlicere lufe besargode, forðan ðe hé wiste heora forwyrd hrædlice toweard
He spake with weeping voice, not to the work-stones, nor to the building, but spake to the inhabitants, whom he bewailed with fatherly love, because he knew that their destruction was speedily to take place

Feowertig geara fyrst Godes mildheortnys forlét ðam wælhreowum ceastergewarum to behreowsunge heora mándæda, ac hí ne gymdon nanre dædbote, ac maran mándæda gefremedon, swa þæt hí oftorfodon mid stanum ðone forman Godes cyðere Stephanum, and Iacobum, Iohannes broðer, beheafdodon
A space of forty years the mercy of God left the cruel inhabitants for repentance of their crimes, but they cared for no penitence, but perpetrated greater crimes, so that they slew with stones Stephen, the first martyr of God, and beheaded James, the brother of John

Eac ðone rihtwisan Iacobum hí ascufon of ðam temple, and acwealdon, and ehtnysse on ða oðre apostolas setton
The righteous James also they thrust from the temple, and slew, and raised persecution against the other apostles

Seo Godes gelaðung, þe on ðære byrig, æfter Cristes ðrowunge, under þam rihtwisan Iacobe drohtnigende wæs, ferde eal samod of ðære byrig to anre wíc wið ða éá Iordanen
The congregation of God which, after Christ's passion, was continuing in the city under the righteous James, went all together from the city to a village on the river Jordan

forðan ðe him com to Godes hǽs, þæt hi sceoldon fram ðære mánfullan stowe faran, ærðam ðe seo wracu come
for God's command had come to them, that they should go from the wicked place, ere the vengeance came

God ða oncneow þæt ða Iudeiscan nanre dǽdbote ne gymdon, ac má and má heora mándæda geyhton: sende him ða to Romanisc folc, and hí ealle fordyde
God knew then that the Jews cared for no penitence, but more and more increased their crimes: he therefore sent to them the Roman people, and they ruined them all

Uespasianus hatte se casere, ðe on ðam dagum geweold ealles middangeardes cynedomes
Vespasian the emperor was called, who in those days ruled the kingdom of the whole world

Sé asende his sunu Titum to oferwinnenne ða earman Iudeiscan
He sent his son Titus to conquer the miserable Jews

Þa gelámp hit swa þæt hí wæron gesamnode binnan ðære byrig Hierusalem, six hund ðusend manna, swylce on anum cwearterne beclysede
It then so happened that they were assembled within the city of Jerusalem, six hundred thousand men, enclosed as it were in a prison

and hí wurdon ða utan ymbsette mid Romaniscum here swa lange þæt ðær fela ðusenda mid hungre wurdon acwealde
and they were surrounded without by the Roman army so long that many thousands were killed by hunger

and for ðære menigu man ne mihte hí bebyrigan, ac awurpon ða líc ofer ðone weall
and they could not bury them by reason of the number, but cast the corpses over the wall

Sume ðeah for mæiglicre sibbe hí bebyrigan woldon, ac hí hrædlice for mægenleaste swulton
Some, however, would bury them for the sake of kinship, but they soon died from weakness

Gif hwa hwæt lytles æniges bigwistes him sylfum gearcode, him scuton sona to reaferas, and ðone mete him of ðam muðe abrudon
If any one had provided any little sustenance for himself, robbers would suddenly rush on him, and pull the meat from his mouth

Sume hí cuwon heora gescý, sume heora hætera, sume streaw, for ðære micclan angsumnysse ðæs hatan hungres
Some chewed their shoes, some their garments, some straw, for the great anguish of hot hunger

Hit nis na gedafenlic þæt we on ðisum halgan godspelle ealle ða sceamlican yrmðu gereccan þe gelumpon ðam ymbsettum Iudeiscum, ærðan ðe hi on hand gán woldon
It is not fitting that we, in this holy gospel, recount all the shameful miseries which befell the besieged Jews before they would yield

Wearð ða se mæsta dæl ðæra arleasra mid þam bysmerlicum hungre adyd, and þa lafe ðæs hungres ofsloh se Romanisca here, and ða burh grundlunga towurpon, swa þæt ðær ne beláf stán ofer stáne, swa swa se Hælend ǽr mid wope gewítegode
The greater part of the wicked ones was then destroyed by the ignominious famine, and the Roman host slew the leavings of the famine, and razed the city to the ground, so that there remained not stone over stone, as Jesus had erewhile with weeping prophesied

Þæra cnapena ðe binnan syxtyne geara ylde wæron, hund-nigontig ðusenda hí tosendon to gehwylcum leodscipum to ðeowte, and on ðam earde ne beláf nan ðing ðæs awyrgedan cynnes
Of boys who were within sixteen years of age, they sent ninety thousand to all nations in slavery, and in the country there remained nothing of the accursed race

Seo burh wearð syððan on oðre stówe getimbrod, and mid ðam Sarasceniscum gesett
The city was afterwards built in another place, and peopled with Saracens

Se Hælend geswutelode for hwilcum intingan ðeos tostencednys þære byrig gelumpe, ðaða hé cwæð
Jesus showed for what cause this dispersion of the city happened, when he said

Forðan þe ðu ne oncneowe ðone timan ðinre geneosunge
Because thou knewest not the time of thy visitation

He geneosode ða buruhware ðurh his menniscnysse, ac hí næron his gemyndige, naðor ne ðurh lufe ne þurh ege
He visited the inhabitants in his humanity, but they were not mindful of him, neither by love nor by fear

Be ðære gymeleaste spræc se witega mid ceorigendre stemne, ðus cweðende
Of that heedlessness the prophet spake with lamenting voice, thus saying

Storc and swalewe heoldon ðone timan heora to-cymes, and þis folc ne oncneow Godes dóm
The stork and the swallow keep the time of their coming, and this people knew not the doom of God

Drihten cwæð to ðære byrig
The Lord said to the city

Gif þu wistest hwæt þe toweard is, þonne weope ðu mid me
If thou knewest what is to befall thee, then wouldst thou weep with me

Witodlice on ðisum dæge þu wunast on sibbe, ac ða toweardan wraca sind nu bediglode fram ðinum eagum
Verily on this day thou dwellest in peace, for the vengeances to come are now hidden from thine eyes

Seo buruhwaru wæs wunigende on woruldlicere sibbe, þaþa heo orsorhlice wæs underðeodd flæsclicum lustum, and hwonlice hógode ymbe ða toweardan yrmða, ðe hyre ða-gyt bediglode wæron
The inhabitants were dwelling in worldly peace, while they were heedlessly subservient to fleshly lusts, and little thought of the miseries to come, which were yet hidden from them

Gif heo ðære yrmðe forewittig wære, ne mihte heo mid orsorgum mode ðære gesundfulnysse andweardes lifes brucan
If they had been foreknowing of that misery, they could not with heedless mind have enjoyed the prosperity of the present life

Drihten adræfde of ðam temple ða cýpmen, þus cweðende
The Lord drove the chapmen from the temple, thus saying

Hit is awriten, þæt min hús is gebed-hús, and ge hit habbað gedon sceaðum to screafe
It is written, that my house is a house of prayer, and ye have made it a den for thieves

Þæt tempel wæs Gode gehalgod, to his ðenungum and lofsangum, and to gebedum ðam geleaffullum
The temple was hallowed to God, for his services, and songs of praise, and prayers of the faithful

ac ða gytsigendan ealdor-biscopas geðafedon þæt ðær cyping binnan gehæfd wære
but the covetous high-priests allowed chapping to be held therein

Drihten, ðaða he þæt unriht geseah, he worhte áne swipe of rápum, and hí ealle mid gebeate út-ascynde
The Lord, when he saw that wickedness, made a scourge of ropes, and with beating hurried them all out

Þeos todræfednys getacnode ða toweardan toworpennysse ðurh þone Romaniscan here, and se hryre gelámp swyðost þurh gyltas ðæra ealdor-biscopa ðe, binnan ðam temple wunigende, mid gehywedre halignysse þæs folces lác underfengon, and ðæra manna ehton ðe butan lace þæt tempel gesohton
This dispersion betokened the future destruction by the Roman army, and the ruin happened chiefly through the sins of the high-priests, who, dwelling within the temple, with pretended holiness received the people's offerings, and persecuted those men who sought the temple without offerings

Hwæt wæs þæt tempel buton swylce sceaðena scræf, þaþa ða ealdor-biscopas mid swylcere gytsunge gefyllede wæron, and ða leaslican ceapas binnan ðam Godes huse geðafedon
What was that temple but, as it were, a den of thieves, when the chief priests were filled with such covetousness, and allowed false bargains within the house of God

Hit is on oðrum godspelle awriten, þæt ðær sæton myneteras, and ðær wæron gecype hryðeru, and scép, and culfran
It is written in another gospel, that there sat moneyers, and there were oxen for sale, and sheep, and doves

On ðam dagum, æfter gesetnysse ðære ealdan ǽ, man offrode hryðeru, and scép, and culfran, for getacnunge Cristes ðrowunge: ða tihte seo gitsung þa sacerdas þæt man ðillic orf þær to ceape hæfde, gif hwá feorran come, and wolde his lác Gode offrian, ðæt hé on gehendnysse to bicgenne gearu hæfde
In those days, according to the institute of the old law, they offered oxen, and sheep, and doves, in token of Christ's passion: then covetousness stimulated the priests to have such animals there for sale, that, if any one came from afar, and would offer his gift to God, he might have it ready at hand to buy

Drihten ða adræfde ðillice cypan of ðam halgan temple, forðan ðe hit næs to nanum ceape aræred, ac to gebedum
The Lord then drove such chapmen from the holy temple, because it was not raised for any trading, but for prayers

Him ða to genealæhton blinde and healte, and he hi gehælde, and wæs lærende þæt folc dæghwomlice binnan ðam temple
Then the blind and the halt drew near unto him, and he healed them, and was teaching the folk daily within the temple

Se mildheorta Drihten, ðe læt scinan his sunnan ofer ða rihtwisan and unrihtwisan gelice, and sent renas and eorðlice wæstmas gódum and yfelum, nolde ofteon his lare þam ðwyrum Iudeiscum, forðan ðe manega wæron góde betwux þam yfelan, þe mid ðære lare gebeterode wæron, þeah ðe ða þwyran hyre wiðcwædon
The merciful Lord, who lets his sun shine over the righteous and unrighteous alike, and sends rains and earthly fruits to the good and evil, would not withdraw his instruction from the perverse Jews, because many were good among the evil, who were bettered by that instruction, although the perverse opposed it

Hé eac mid wundrum ða lare getrymde, þæt ða gecorenan ðy geleaffulran wæron: and ða wiðercorenan nane beladunge nabbað, forðan ðe hí ne ðurh godcunde tacna, ne þurh líflice lare, þam soðfæstan Hælende gelyfan noldon
He also confirmed his instruction by miracles, that the chosen might be the more believing: and the rejected shall have no excuse, because they neither by divine signs, nor by vital lore, would believe in the true Saviour

Nu cwyð se eadiga Gregorius, þæt heora toworpennys hæfð sume gelicnysse to gehwilcum þwyrlicum mannum, þe blissiað on yfel-dædum, and on ðam wyrstan ðingum fægniað
Now the blessed Gregory says, that their desolation has some likeness to all perverse men, who exult in evil deeds, and rejoice in the worst things

Swilcera manna besargað se mildheorta Drihten dæghwomlice, seðe ða þa losigendlican buruhware mid tearon bemǽnde
Such men the merciful Lord bewails daily, who then the perishing townsfolk with tears bemoaned

Ac gif hí oncneowon ða geniðerunge þe him onsihð, hí mihton hí sylfe mid sarigendre stemne heofian
But if they knew the condemnation that hangs over them, they would themselves lament with sorrowing voice

Soðlice ðære losigendlican sawle belimpð þes æfterfiligenda cwyde
Verily this following sentence applies to the perishing soul

On ðysum dæge þu wunast on sibbe, ac seo towearde wracu is nu bediglod fram ðinum eagum
On this day thou dwellest in peace, for the vengeance to come is now hidden from thine eyes

Witodlice seo ðwyre sawul is on sibbe wunigende on hire dæge, þonne heo on gewitendlicere tide blissað, and mid wurðmyntum bið up-ahafen, and on hwilwendlicum bricum bið ungefoh, and on flæsclicum lustum bið tolysed, and mid nanre fyrhte þæs toweardan wites ne bið geegsod, ac bedygelað hire sylfre ða æfterfiligendan yrmða
The perverse soul is indeed dwelling in peace in its day, when in transient time it rejoices, and is exalted with dignities, and in temporary enjoyments is immoderate, and is dissolved in fleshly lusts, and is awed by no fear of future punishment, but hides from itself the miseries following after

forðan gif heo embe ða smeað, þonne bið seo woruldlice bliss mid þære smeagunge gedrefed
because if it reflect on them, then will worldly bliss be troubled by that reflection

Heo hæfð ðonne sibbe on hire dæge, ðonne heo nele ða andweardan myrhðe gewǽcan mid nánre care þære toweardan ungesælðe, ac gæð mid beclysedum eagum to ðam witnigendlicum fyre
It has then peace in its day, when it will not afflict the present mirth with any care for the future unhappiness, but goes with closed eyes to the penal fire

Seo sawul ðe on ðas wisan nu drohtnað, heo is to geswencenne ðonne ða rihtwisan blissiað
The soul which in this wise now lives, shall be afflicted when the righteous rejoice

and ealle ða ateorigendlican ðing, þe heo nu to sibbe and blisse talað, beoð hire ðonne to byternysse and to ceaste awende
and all the perishable things, which it now accounts as peace and bliss, shall then be turned for it to bitterness and strife

forðan ðe heo micele sace wið hí sylfe hæfð, hwí heo ða geniðerunge, ðe heo ðonne ðolað, nolde ær on life mid ænigre carfulnysse foresceawian
for it will have great contention with itself, why it would not before in life with any carefulness foresee the condemnation which it then is suffering

Be ðam is awriten
Concerning which it is written

Eadig bið se man þe symle bið forhtigende
Blessed is the man who is ever fearing

and soðlice se heardmoda befylð on yfel
and verily the hardened shall fall into evil

Eft on oðre stowe mynegað þæt halige gewrit
Again in another place holy writ admonishes

On eallum ðinum weorcum beo ðu gemyndig þines endenextan dæges, and on ecnysse ðu ne syngast
In all thy works be thou mindful of thy last day, and in eternity thou wilt not sin

Seo halige ræding cwyð
The holy lesson says

Se tyma cymð þæt ðine fynd ðe ymbsittað mid ymbtrymminge, and ðe on ælce healfe genyrwiað, and to eorðan þe astreccað, and ðine bearn samod ðe on ðe sind
The time cometh that thy foes shall encompass thee with a leaguer, and shall straiten thee on every side, and shall prostrate thee to earth, together with thy children which are in thee

Þæra sawla fynd sind ða hellican gastas þe besittað þæs mannes forðsið, and his sawle, gif heo fyrenful bið, to ðære geferrǽdene heora agenre geniðerunge mid micelre angsumnysse lædan willað
The foes of the soul are the hellish spirits which beset a man's departure, and with great tribulation will lead his soul, if it be sinful, to the fellowship of their own damnation

Þa deoflu æteowiað þære synfullan sawle ægðer ge hyre yfelan geðohtas, and ða derigendlican spræca, and ða mánfullan dæda, and hí mid mænigfealdum ðreatungum geangsumiað, þæt heo on ðam forðsiðe oncnáwe mid hwilcum feondum heo ymbset bið, and ðeah nán ut-fær ne gemet, hu heo ðam feondlicum gastum oðfleon mage
The devils show to the sinful soul its evil thoughts, and pernicious speeches, and wicked deeds, and with manifold reproaches afflict it, that on its departure it may know by what foes it is beset, and yet find no outlet whereby it may flee from the hostile spirits

To eorðan heo bið astreht ðurh hire scylda oncnawennysse, ðonne se lichama þe heo on leofode to duste bið formolsnod
To earth it shall be prostrated by a knowledge of its sins, when the body in which it lived shall be rotted to dust

Hire bearn on deaðe hreosað, ðonne ða únalyfedlican geðohtas, ðe heo nu acenð, beoð on ðære endenextan wrace eallunga toworpene, swa swa se sealm-sceop be ðam gyddigende sang
Its children shall fall in death, when the unallowed thoughts, which it now gives birth to, shall, in the last vengeance, be wholly rendered vain, as the psalmist melodiously sang

Nellað ge getruwian on ealdormannum, ne on manna bearnum, on ðam nis nan hǽl
Trust not in princes, nor in the children of men, in whom there is no health

Heora gast gewit, and hí to eorðan gehwyrfað, and on ðam dæge losiað ealle heora geðohtas
Their spirit departs, and they return to earth, and in that day all their thoughts perish

Soðlice on ðam godspelle fyligð
Verily in the gospel it follows

And hí ne forlǽtað on ðe stán ofer stáne
And they shall not leave in thee stone over stone

Þæt ðwyre mod, þonne hit gehýpð yfel ofer yfele, and þwyrnysse ofer þwyrnysse, hwæt deð hit buton swilce hit lecge stán ofer stáne
The perverse mind, when it heaps evil over evil, and perversity over perversity, what does it, but as though it lay stone over stone

Ac ðonne seo sawul bið to hire witnunge gelæd, ðonne bið eal seo getimbrung hire smeagunge toworpen
But when the soul shall be led to its punishment, then will all the structure of its cogitation be overthrown

forðan ðe heo ne oncneow ða tíd hire geneosunge
for it knew not the time of its visitation

On manegum gemetum geneosað se Ælmihtiga God manna sawla
In many ways the Almighty God visits the souls of men

hwiltidum mid lare, hwilon mid wundrum, hwilon mit untrumnyssum
sometimes with instruction, sometimes with miracles, sometimes with diseases

ac gif heo ðas geneosunga forgymeleasað, ðam feondum heo bið betæht on hire geendunge, to ecere witnunge, þam ðe heo ǽr on life mid healicum leahtrum gehyrsumode
but if it neglect these visitations, it will be at its end delivered for eternal punishment to fiends, whom it had previously with deadly sins obeyed in life

Þonne beoð ða hire witneras on ðære hellican susle, ða ðe ǽr mid mislicum lustum hi to ðam leahtrum forspeonon
Then shall those be its tormentors in hell-torment, who had before allured it by divers pleasures to those sins

Drihten eode into ðam temple, and mid swipe ða cypan ut-adræfde
The Lord went into the temple, and with a scourge drove out the chapmen

Þa cypmen binnon ðam temple getacnodon unrihtwise láreowas on Godes gelaðunge
The chapmen within the temple betokened unrighteous teachers in God's church

Ðær wæron gecype oxan, and scép, and culfran, and þær sæton myneteras
There were for sale oxen, and sheep, and doves, and there sat moneyers

Oxa teolað his hlaforde, and se lareow sylð oxan on Godes cyrcan, gif he begæð his hlafordes teolunga, þæt is, gif he bodað godspel his underðeoddum, for eorðlicum gestreonum, and na for godcundre lufe
The ox toils for his lord, and the teacher sells oxen in God's church, if he perform his Lord's tillage, that is, if he preach the gospel to those under his care, for earthly gains, and not for godly love

Mid sceapum he mangað, gif he dysigra manna herunga cepð on arfæstum weorcum
With sheep he traffics, if he seek after the praises of foolish men in pious works

Be swylcum cwæð se Hælend
Of such Jesus said

Hi underfengon edlean heora weorca
They have received the reward of their works

þæt is se hlisa idelre herunge, ðe him gecweme wæs
that is the fame of idle praise, which was pleasing to them

Se láreow bið culfran cypa, þe nele ða gife, ðe him God forgeaf butan his geearnungum, oðrum mannum butan sceattum nytte dón
The teacher is a chapman of doves, who will not without money give for use of other men, the gift which God, without his deserts, has given to him

swa swa Crist sylf tæhte
as Christ himself taught

Butan ceape ge underfengon ða gife, syllað hí oðrum butan ceape
Without price ye have received the gift, give it to others without price

Se ðe mid gehywedre halignysse him sylfum teolað on Godes gelaðunge, and nateshwón ne carað ymbe Cristes teolunge, se bið untwylice mynet-cypa getalod
He who with assumed holiness toils for himself in God's church, and cares nothing for Christ's tillage, will undoubtedly be accounted a money-chapman

Ac se Hælend todræfð swylce cypan of his huse, ðonne hé mid geniðerunge fram geferrædene his gecorenra hí totwæmð
But Jesus will drive such chapmen from his house, when, with condemnation, he shall separate them from the fellowship of his chosen

Min hús is gebed-hús, and ge hit habbað gedón sceaðum to scræfe
My house is a prayer-house, and ye have made it a den for thieves

Hit getímað forwel oft þæt ða ðwyran becumað to micclum háde on Godes gelaðunge, and hí ðonne gastlice ofsleað mid heora yfelnysse heora underðeoddan, ða ðe hí sceoldon mid heora benum gelíffæstan
It happens too often that the perverse come to great dignity in God's church, and they then, with their evilness, spiritually slay those placed under their care, whom they ought with their prayers to quicken

Hwæt sind ðyllice buton sceaðan
What are such but thieves

Anes gehwilces geleaffulles mannes mód is Godes hús, swa swa se apostol cwæð
The mind of every believing man is a house of God, as the apostle said

Godes tempel is halig, þæt ge sind
The temple of God is holy, which ye are

Ac þæt mód ne bið na gebed-hús, ac sceaðena scræf, gif hit forlysð unscæððignysse and bilewitnysse soðre halignysse, and mid ðwyrlicum geðohtum hógað oðrum dara
But the mind will be no prayer-house, but a den of thieves, if it lose the innocence and meekness of true holiness, and with perverse thoughts meditate harm to others

And he wæs tæcende dæghwomlice binnan ðam temple
And he was teaching daily within the temple

Crist lærde ða þæt folc on his andweardnysse, and he lærð nu dæghwomlice geleaffulra manna mód mid godcundre láre smeaðancellice, þæt hí yfel forbugon and gód gefremman
Christ then taught the people in his presence, and he now daily teaches the minds of believing men with godly lore, by meditation, to eschew evil and perform good

Ne bið na fulfremedlic þam gelyfedan þæt hé yfeles geswice, buton hé gód gefremme
It is not perfect for the believing man to cease from evil, unless he performs good

Se eadiga Gregorius cwæð
The blessed Gregory said

Mine gebroðru, ic wolde eow ane lytle race gereccan, seo mæig ðearle eower mód getimbrian, gif ge mid gymene hí gehyran wyllað
My brothers, I would relate to you a little narrative, which may greatly edify your minds, if ye with heedfulness will hear it

Sum æðelboren mann wæs on ðære scire Ualeria, se wæs geháten Crisaurius, se wæs swa micclum mid leahtrum afylled swa micclum swa hé wæs mid eorðlicum welum gewelgod
There was a certain nobleman in the province of Valeria, who was called Chrysaurius, who was as much filled with sins as he was enriched with earthly riches

He wæs toðunden on modignysse, and his flæsclicum lustum underðeod, and mid ungefohre gytsunge ontend
He was inflated with pride, and a slave to his fleshly lusts, and inflamed with excessive covetousness

Ac ðaða God gemynte his yfelnysse to geendigenne, ða wearð hé geuntrumod, and to forðsiðe gebroht
But when God designed to put an end to his wickedness, he became sick, and brought to departure hence

Þa on ðære ylcan tide þe hé geendian sceolde, ða beseah hé up, and stodon him abutan swearte gastas, and mid micclum ðreate him onsigon, þæt hí his sawle on ðam forðsiðe mid him to hellicum clysungum gegripon
Then at the very time that he should die, he looked up, and there stood about him swart spirits, and in a great company descended on him, that they might snatch his soul, on its departure, with them to the barriers of hell

He ongánn ða bifian and blácian, and ungefohlice swætan, and mid micclum hreame fyrstes biddan, and his sunu Maximus, ðone ic geseah munuc syððan, mid gedrefedre stemne clypode, and cwæð, Min cild, Maxime, gehelp min
He began then to tremble and grow pale, and incredibly to sweat, and with great cry to pray for a respite, and with troubled voice called his son Maximus, whom I afterwards saw as a monk, and said, My child, Maximus, help me

onfoh me on ðinum geleafan: næs ic ðe derigende on ænigum ðingum
receive me in thy faith: I have not in any way been hurtful to thee

Se sunu ða Maximus mid micclum heofe gedrefed, him to cóm
The son Maximus then, troubled with great sorrowing, came to him

Hé wand þa swa swa wurm
He was then turning like a worm

ne mihte geðolian þa egeslican gesihðe ðæra awyrgedra gasta
he could not endure the dreadful sight of the accursed spirits

Hé wende hine to wage, ðær hi him ætwæron
He turned himself to the wall, there they were present to him

he wende eft ongean, þær hé hí funde
he turned back again, there he found them

Þaða hé swa swiðe geancsumod his sylfes órwene wæs, ða hrymde hé mid micelre stemne, and ðus cwæð, Lætað me fyrst oð to merigen, huru-ðinga fyrst oð to merigen: ac mid ðisum hreame ða blacan fynd tugon ða sawle of ðam lichaman, and awég gelæddon
When he, so greatly afflicted, was hopeless of himself, he cried with a loud voice, and thus said, Grant me a respite till to-morrow, at least a respite till to-morrow: and with this cry the black fiends drew the soul from the body, and led it away

Be ðam is swutol, þæt seo gesihð him wearð æteowod for oðra manna beterunge, na for his agenre
From this it is manifest, that the vision was shown to him for the bettering of other men, not for his own

La hwæt fremode him, ðeah ðe hé on forðsiðe þa sweartan gastas gesawe, ðonne he ne moste þæs fyrstes habban ðe he gewilnode
Alas, what did it profit him, though, on his departure, he saw the swart spirits, when he might not have the respite which he desired

Ac uton we beon carfulle, þæt ure tima mid ydelnysse ús ne losige, and we ðonne to wel-dædum gecyrran willan, ðonne us se deað to forðsiðe geðreatað
But let us be careful, that our time escape not from us in vanity, and we turn to good deeds, when death urges us to departure

Þu, Ælmihtiga Drihten, gemiltsa us synfullum, and urne forðsið swa gefada, þæt we, gebettum synnum, æfter ðisum frecenfullum life, ðinum halgum geferlæhte beon moton
Thou, Almighty Lord, have mercy on us sinful, and so order our departure, that we, having atoned for our sins, may, after this perilous life, be associated with thy saints

Sy ðe lóf and wuldor on ealra worulda woruld
To thee be praise and glory for ever and ever

Amen
Amen

On Decies dæge, þæs wælhreowan caseres, wæs se halga biscop Sixtus on Romana byrig drohtnigende
In the time of Decius, the cruel emperor, the holy bishop Sixtus was dwelling in Rome

Ða færlice het hé his gesihum, ðone biscop mid his preostum samod geandwerdian
Then he suddenly commanded his counts to bring the bishop together with his priests before him

Sixtus ða unforhtmod to his preostum clypode
Sixtus then with fearless mind called to his priests

Mine gebroðra, ne beo ge afyrhte, cumað, and eower nan him ne ondræde ða scortan tintregunga
My brothers, be ye not afraid, come, and let none of you dread short torments

Þa halgan martyras geðrowodon fela pinunga, þæt hí orsorge becomon to wulder-beage þæs ecan lifes
The holy martyrs suffered many tortures, that they might fearless come to the glory-crown of everlasting life

Þa andwyrdon his twegen diaconas, Felicissimus and Agapitus
His two deacons, Felicissimus and Agapetus, then answered

Ðu, ure fæder, hwider fare we butan ðe
Thou, our father, whither shall we go without thee

On ðære nihte wearð se biscop mid his twám diaconum hrædlice to ðam reðum ehtere gebroht
On that night the bishop with his two deacons was quickly brought to the cruel persecutor

Se casere Decius him cwæð to
The emperor Decius said to him

Geoffra ðine lác ðam undeadlicum godum, and beo ðu þæra sacerda ealdor
Offer thy gift to the immortal gods, and be thou the chief of the priests

Se eadiga Sixtus him andwyrde
The blessed Sixtus answered him

Ic symle geoffrode, and gýt offrige mine lác ðam Ælmihtigan Gode, and his Suna, Hælendum Criste, and ðam Halgum Gaste, hluttre onsægednysse and ungewemmede
I have ever offered and will yet offer my gift to the Almighty God, and his Son, Jesus Christ, and to the Holy Ghost, in pure and unpolluted sacrifice

Decius cwæð
Decius said

Gebeorh ðe and ðinum preostum, and geoffra
Take heed for thyself and thy priests, and offer

Soðlice gif ðu ne dest, þu scealt beon eallum oðrum to bysne
for if thou dost not, thou shalt be an example to all others

Sixtus soðlice andwyrde
But Sixtus answered

Hwene ær ic ðe sæde, þæt ic symle geoffrige ðam Ælmihtigum Gode
A little before I said to thee, that I always offer to Almighty God

Decius ða cwæð to his cempum
Decius then said to his soldiers

Lædað hine to ðam temple Martis, þæt he ðam gode Marti geoffrige: gif he nelle offrian, beclysað hine on ðam cwearterne Mamortini
Lead him to the temple of Mars, that he may offer to the god Mars: if he will not offer, shut him in the prison Mamortinum

Þa cempan hine læddon to ðam deofolgylde, and hine ðreatodon þæt he ðære deadan anlicnysse his lác offrian sceolde
The soldiers led him to the temple, and urged him to offer his gift to the dead image

Þaða he ðæs caseres hæse forseah, and ðam deofolgylde offrian nolde, ða gebrohton hi hine mid his twam diaconum binnan ðam blindan cwearterne
When he despised the emperor's command, and would not offer to the idol, they brought him with his two deacons into the dark prison

Þa betwux ðam com Laurentius, his erce-diacon, and ðone halgan biscop mid ðisum wordum gespræc
Then among them came his archdeacon Lawrence, and spake to the holy bishop in these words

Ðu, mín fæder, hwider siðast ðu butan ðinum bearne
Thou, my father, whither goest thou without thy child

Þu halga sacerd, hwider efst ðu butan ðinum diacone
Thou holy priest, whither hastenest thou without thy deacon

Næs ðin gewuna þæt ðu butan ðinum diacone Gode geoffrodest
It was not thy wont to offer to God without thy deacon

Hwæt mislicode ðe, min fæder, on me
What has displeased thee, my father, in me

Geswutela ðine mihte on ðinum bearne, and geoffra Gode þone ðe ðu getuge, þæt þu ðy orsorglicor becume to ðam æðelan wulder-beage
Show thy power on thy child, and offer to God him whom thou hast trained up, that thou the less sorrowfully attain to the noble crown of glory

Þaða se eadiga Laurentius mid þisum wordum and ma oðrum bemǽnde þæt he ne moste mid his lareowe ðrowian, ða andwyrde se biscop
When the blessed Lawrence had, with these words and others more, lamented that he might not suffer with his teacher, the bishop answered

Min bearn, ne forlæte ic ðe, ac ðe gerist mara campdom on ðinum gewinne
My child, I forsake thee not, but thee befits a greater struggle in thy conflict

We underfoð, swa swa ealde men, scortne ryne þæs leohtran gewinnes
We, as old men, shall undergo the short course of a lighter conflict: but thou, a young man, wilt undergo a much more glorious triumph from this cruel king

soðlice þu geonga underfehst miccle wulderfulran sige æt ðisum reðan cyninge
My child, cease thy weeping: after three days thou wilt come to me triumphant to everlasting life

Min cild, geswic ðines wopes: æfter ðrim dagum ðu cymst sigefæst to me to ðam ecum life
Take thou our church's treasures, and distribute to christian men, as it may seem good unto thee

Se erce-diacon ða, Laurentius, be ðæs biscopes hæse ferde and dælde þære cyrcan maðmas preostum, and ælðeodigum ðearfum, and wudewum, ælcum be his neode
The archdeacon Lawrence then, at the bishop's command, went and distributed the church's treasures to priests, and poor strangers, and widows, to each according to his need

He com to sumere wudewan, hire nama wæs Quiriaca, seo hæfde behyd on hire hame preostas and manega læwede cristenan
He came to a widow, whose name was Quiriaca, who had hidden in her dwelling priests and many lay christians

Ða se eadiga Laurentius ðwoh heora ealra fét, and ða wudewan fram hefigtimum heafod-ece gehælde
Then the blessed Lawrence washed the feet of them all, and healed the widow of a wearisome headache

Eac sum ymesene man mid wope his fét gesohte, biddende his hæle
A blind man also with weeping sought his feet, praying for his cure

Laurentius ða mearcode rode-tacen on ðæs blindan eagan, and he ðærrihte beorhtlice geseah
Lawrence then marked the sign of the rood on the blind man's eyes, and he straightways saw brightly

Se erce-diacon ða-gyt geaxode má cristenra manna gehwær, and hí ær his ðrowunge mid gastlicere sibbe and mid fót-ðweale geneosode
The archdeacon heard yet of more christian men elsewhere, and before his passion visited them with ghostly peace and with foot-washing

Þaða hé ðanon gewende, ða wæs his láreow Sixtus mid his twam diaconum of ðam cwearterne gelædd, ætforan ðam casere Decium
When he returned thence, his teacher Sixtus with his two deacons was led from the prison, before the emperor Decius

He wearð þa geháthyrt ongean ðone halgan biscop, ðus cweðende
He was then exasperated against the holy bishop, thus saying

Witodlice we beorgað ðinre ylde: gehyrsuma urum bebodum, and geoffra ðam undeaðlicum godum
Verily we have regard for thy age: obey our commands, and offer to the immortal gods

Se eadiga biscop him andwyrde
The holy bishop answered him

Ðu earming, beorh ðe sylfum, and wyrc dædbote for ðæra halgena blode ðe ðu agute
Thou wretch, have regard for thyself, and make atonement for the blood of the saints which thou hast shed

Se wælhreowa cwellere mid gebolgenum mode cwæð to his heah-gerefan, Ualeriane
The bloodthirsty executioner with wrathful mind said to his chief officer Valerianus

Gif ðes bealdwyrda biscop acweald ne bið, siððan ne bið ure ege ondrædendlic
If this audacious bishop be not slain, awe for us will be no longer formidable

Ualerianus him andwyrde
Valerianus answered him

Beo he heafde becorfen
Let his head be cut off

Hat hí eft to ðæs godes temple Martis gelǽdan, and gif hí nellað to him gebigedum cneowum gebiddan, and heora lác offrian, underfón hí beheafdunge on ðære ylcan stowe
Order them again to the temple of the god, and if they will not pray to him with bended knees, and offer their gifts, let them suffer decapitation on the same place

Þæs caseres cempan hine læddon to ðam deofolgylde mid his twam diaconum: ða beseah se biscop wið ðæs temples, and ðus cwæð
The emperor's soldiers led him to the temple with his two deacons: then the bishop looked towards the temple, and thus said

Þu dumba deofolgyld, þurh ðe forleosað earme menn þæt ece lif: towurpe ðe se Ælmihtiga Godes Sunu
Thou dumb idol, through thee miserable men lose everlasting life: may the Almighty Son of God overthrow thee

Þa mid þam worde tobærst sum dæl ðæs temples mid færlicum hryre
Then at that word a part of the temple burst asunder with a sudden fall

Laurentius ða clypode to ðam biscope
Lawrence then cried to the bishop

Þu halga fæder, ne forlǽt ðu me, forðan ðe ic aspende ðære cyrcan maðmas swa swa ðu me bebude
Thou holy father, forsake me not, for I have distributed the church's treasures as thou commandedst

Hwæt ða cempan ða hine gelæhton, forðan ðe hí gehyrdon hine be ðam cyrclicum madmum sprecan
At this the soldiers seized him, for they heard him speak of the church's treasures

Sixtus ða soðlice underhnáh swurdes ecge, and his twegen diaconas samod, Felicissimus and Agapitus, ætforan ðam temple, on ðam sixtan dæge þyses monðes
Sixtus then sank under the sword's edge, and his two deacons with him, Felicissimus and Agapetus, before the temple, on the sixth day of this month

Laurentius witodlice wearð siððan gebroht to ðam casere, and se reða cwellere hine ða befrán
But Lawrence was afterwards brought to the emperor, and the fierce executioner asked him

Hwær sind ðære cyrcan madmas ðe ðe betæhte wæron
Where are the church's treasures which were committed to thee

Se eadiga Laurentius mid nanum worde him ne geandwyrde
The blessed Lawrence answered him not a word

On ðam ylcan dæge betæhte se Godes feond ðone halgan diacon his heah-gerefan Ualeriane, mid ðysum bebode
On the same day the foe of God committed the holy deacon to his chief officer Valerianus, with this command

Ofgang ða madmas mid geornfulnysse, and hine gebig to ðam undeadlicum godum
Exact the treasures with importunity, and make him bow to the immortal gods

Se gerefa ða hine betæhte his gingran, ðæs nama wæs Ypolitus, and he hine beclysde on cwearterne mid manegum oðrum
The officer then committed him to his junior, whose name was Hippolytus, and he shut him in a prison with many others

Þa gemette hé on ðam cwearterne ænne hæðenne man, se wæs ðurh micelne wóp ablend
He found in the prison a heathen man, who was blind through great weeping

Ða cwæð he him to
He said to him

Lucille, gif ðu gelyfst on Hælend Crist, he onliht ðine eagan
Lucillus, if thou wilt believe in Jesus Christ, he will enlighten thine eyes

He andwyrde
He answered

Æfre ic gewilnode þæt ic on Cristes naman gefullod wære
I have ever desired to be baptized in the name of Christ

Laurentius him to cwæð
Lawrence said to him

Gelyfst ðu mid ealre heortan
Believest thou with all thy heart

He andwyrde mid wope
He answered with weeping

Ic gelyfe on Hælend Crist, and ðam leasum deofolgyldum wiðsace
I believe in Jesus Christ, and renounce the false idols

Ypolitus mid geðylde heora wordum heorcnode
Hippolytus with patience listened to their words

Se gesæliga Laurentius tæhte ða ðam blindan soðne geleafan ðære Halgan Þrynnysse, and hine gefullode
The blessed Lawrence then taught the blind man true belief in the Holy Trinity, and baptized him

Lucillus æfter ðam fulluht-bæðe mid beorhtre stemne clypode
Lucillus, after the baptismal bath, cried with clear voice

Sy gebletsod se Eca God, Hælend Crist, ðe me ðurh his diacon onlihte
Blessed be the Eternal God, Jesus Christ, who has enlightened me through his deacon

Ic wæs blind bám eagum, nu ic beorhtlice leohtes bruce
I was blind with both eyes, now I clearly enjoy the light

Witodlice ða fela oðre blinde mid wope comon to ðam eadigan diacone, and hé asette his handa ofer heora eagan, and hí wurdon onlihte
Then there came many other blind with weeping to the blessed deacon, and he set his hand over their eyes, and they were enlightened

Se tún-gerefa Ypolitus cwæð ða to ðam diacone
The town-reeve, Hippolytus, said to the deacon

Geswutela me ðære cyrcan madmas
Show me the church's treasures

Laurentius cwæð
Lawrence answered

Eala ðu Ypolite, gif ðu gelyfst on God Fæder, and on his Sunu Hælend Crist, ic ðe geswutelige ða madmas, and þæt ece líf behate
O thou Hippolytus, if thou wilt believe in God the Father, and in his Son Jesus Christ, I will show thee the treasures, and promise thee everlasting life

Ypolitus cwæð
Hippolytus said

Gif ðu ðas word mid weorcum gefylst, ðonne do ic swa ðu me tihst
If thou wilt indeed fulfil those words, I will do as thou exhortest me

Laurentius ða halgode fant, and hine gefullode
Lawrence then hallowed a font, and baptized him

Soðlice Ypolitus æfter ðam fulluht-bæðe wæs clypigende mid beorhtre stemne
Verily Hippolytus, after the baptismal bath, cried with a clear voice

Ic geseah unscæððigra manna sawla on Gode blissigan
I saw the souls of innocent men rejoicing in God

And he mid tearum to ðam eadigan diacone cwæð
And he said with tears to the blessed deacon

Ic halsige ðe on ðæs Hælendes naman, þæt eal min híwræden gefullod wurðe
I beseech thee, in the name of Jesus, that all my household might be baptized

Witodlice Laurentius mid bliðum mode him ðæs getiðode, and nigontyne wera and wifa his híwisces mid wuldre gefullode
Lawrence granted him this with cheerful mind, and with glory baptized nineteen men and women of his family

Æfter ðisum sende se heah-gerefa, and bebead Ypolite þæt he Laurentium to ðæs cynges cafer-tune gelædde
After this the chief officer sent, and commanded Hippolytus to lead Lawrence to the king's court

Ypolitus þæt bebod mid eadmodre spræce cydde ðam eadigan Laurentie
Hippolytus with humble speech made known that command to the blessed Lawrence

He cwæð
He said

Uton faran, forðan ðe me and ðe is wuldor gegearcod
Let us go, for glory is prepared for me and for thee

Hi ða hrædlice comon, and unforhte him ætforan stodon
They went quickly, and stood fearless before him

Þa cwæð Ualerianus to ðam halgan cyðere
Then said Valerianus to the holy martyr

Awurp nu ðine anwilnysse, and agif ða madmas
Cast away now thy obstinacy, and give up the treasures

Se Godes cyðere him andwyrde
The martyr of God answered him

On Godes ðearfum ic hí aspende, and hí sind ða ecan madmas, ðe næfre ne beoð gewanode
On God's poor I have spent them, and they are the everlasting treasures which will never be diminished

Se gerefa cwæð
The officer said

Hwæt fagettest ðu mid wordum
Why playest thou with words

Geoffra ðine lác urum gudum, and forlǽt ðone drycræft ðe ðu on getruwast
Offer thy gift to our gods, and forsake the magic in which thou trustest

Laurentius cwæð
Lawrence said

For hwilcum ðingum neadað se deofol eow þæt ge cristene men to his biggengum ðreatniað
For what reason does the devil compel you to urge christian men to his worship

Gif hit riht sy þæt we to deoflum us gebiddon swiðor þonne to ðam Ælmihtigan Gode, deme ge hwá þæs wurðmyntes wurðe sy, se ðe geworht is, oððe se ðe ealle ðing gesceop
If it be right that we should pray to devils rather than to the Almighty God, judge which is worthy of that honour, he who is made, or he who created all things

Se casere ða andwyrde
The emperor then answered

Hwæt is se ðe geworht is, oððe hwæt is se ðe geworhte
What is he who is made, or what is he who made

Godes cyðere cwæð
God's martyr said

Se Ælmihtiga Fæder ures Hælendes is Scyppend ealra gesceafta, and ðu cwyst þæt ic me gebiddan sceole to dumbum stanum, ða ðe sind agrafene ðurh manna handa
The Almighty Father of our Saviour is the Creator of all creatures, and thou sayest that I shall pray to dumb stones, which are carved by the hands of men

Hwæt se casere ða hine gebealh, and het on his gesihðe ðone diacon unscrydan, and wælhreowlice swingan, and se casere sylf clypode
The emperor was then wroth, and commanded the deacon to be unclothed in his sight, and cruelly scourged, and the emperor himself cried

Ne hyrw ðu ure godas
Insult not our gods

Se eadiga Laurentius on ðam tintregum cwæð
The blessed Lawrence said in torments

Witodlice ic ðancige minum Gode, þe me gemedemode to his halgum
Verily I thank my God, who has vouchsafed to number me with his holy

and ðu, earming, eart geancsumod on ðinre gewitleaste
and thou, wretch, art afflicted in thy foolishness

Decius cwæð to ðam cwellerum
Decius said to the executioners

Arærað hine upp, and æteowiað his gesihðum eal þæt wita-tól
Raise him up, and manifest to his sight all the torture-tools

Þa wurdon hrædlice forðaborene isene clutas, and isene clawa, and isen bedd, and leadene swipa and oðre gepilede swipa
Then were quickly brought forth iron plates, and iron claws, and an iron bed, and leaden whips, and other leaded whips

Þa cwæð se casere
Then said the emperor

Geoffra ðine lác urum godum, oððe þu bist mid eallum ðisum pinung-tólum getintregod
Offer thy gift to our gods, or thou shalt be tortured with all these torture-tools

Se eadiga diacon cwæð
The blessed deacon said

Þu ungesæliga, þas estmettas ic symle gewilnode: hí beoð me to wuldre, and ðe to wite
Thou unblessed, these luxuries I have ever desired

Geswutela us ealle ða mánfullan ðine gelican, þæt ðeos burh beo geclænsod
The emperor said

and ðu sylf geoffra urum godum, and ne truwa ðu nateshwon on ðinum gold-hordum
Declare to us all the wicked thy like, that this city may be cleansed

Soðlice ic truwige, and ic eom orsorh be minum hordum
Then said the holy martyr

Wenst ðu la þæt þu beo alysed mid ðinum hordum fram ðisum tintregum
Decius answered

Witodlice Laurentius on ðam gebeate clypode
and then in angry mood commanded the executioners to beat him with stout clubs

Þu earming, undergyt huru nu þæt ic sígrige be Cristes madmum, and ic ðine tintregu naht ne gefrede
But Lawrence, during the beating, cried

Lecgað ða isenan clutas hate glowende to his sidan
Decius said

Hælend Crist, God of Gode, gemiltsa þinum ðeowan, forðan ðe ic gewreged ðe ne wiðsoc, befrinen ic ðe geandette
The blessed martyr then was praying to his Lord, and said

Þa het se casere hine aræran, and cwæð
questioned, I acknowledged thee

ðeah-hwæðere ne scealt ðu me gebysmrian
Then the emperor commanded him to be raised, and said

Ic swerige ðurh ealle godas and gydena, þæt þu scealt geoffrian, oððe ic ðe mid mislicum pinungum acwelle
I see that thou, through thy magic, mockest these torments

Laurentius ða bealdlice clypode
I swear by all the gods and goddesses, that thou shalt offer, or I will slay thee by divers tortures

Þa wearð se casere mid swyðlicere hátheortnysse geyrsod, and het ðone halgan diacon mid leadenum swipum langlice swingan
Then was the emperor excited with violent fury, and commanded the holy deacon to be scourged a long time with leaden whips

Laurentius ða clypode
Lawrence then cried

Hælend Crist, þu ðe gemedemodest þæt ðu to menniscum menn geboren wære, and us fram deofles ðeowte alysdest, onfoh minne gást
Saviour Christ, thou who hast vouchsafed to be born a mortal man, and hast redeemed us from the devil's thraldom, receive my spirit

On ðære ylcan tide him com andswaru of heofonum, þus cweðende
