At the same time an answer came to him from heaven, thus saying

Gyt ðu scealt fela gewinn habban on ðinum martyrdome
Yet thou shalt have much affliction in thy martyrdom

Decius ða geháthyrt clypode
Decius then furious cried

Romanisce weras, gehyrde ge ðæra deofla frofor on ðisum eawbræcum, ðe ure godas geyrsode ne ondræt, ne ða asmeadan tintregan
Roman men, heard ye the comfort of the devils to this impious, who dreads not our irritated gods, nor the devised torments

Astreccað hine, and mid gepiledum swipum swingende geangsumiað
Stretch him, and, scourging with leaded whips, afflict him

Laurentius ða astreht on ðære hengene, mid hlihendum muðe ðancode his Drihtne
Lawrence then, stretched on the cross, with laughing mouth thanked his Lord

Drihten God, Fæder Hælendes Cristes, sy ðu gebletsod, þe us forgeafe ðine mildheortnysse
Lord God, Father of Jesus Christ, be thou blessed, who hast given us thy mercy

cyð nu ðine arfæstnysse, þæt ðas ymbstandendan oncnawon þæt ðu gefrefrast ðine ðeowan
manifest now thy favour, that these standing about may know that thou comfortest thy servants

On ðære tide gelyfde án ðæra cempena, ðæs nama wæs Romanus, and cwæð to ðam Godes cyðere
At that time one of the soldiers, whose name was Romanus, believed, and said to the martyr of God

Laurentie, ic geseo Godes engel standende ætforan ðe mid hand-claðe, and wipað ðine swatigan limu
Lawrence, I see God's angel standing before thee with a hand-cloth, and wiping thy sweating limbs

Nu halsige ic ðe, þurh God, þæt þu me ne forlæte
I now beseech thee, through God, that thou forsake me not

Þa wearð Decius mid facne afylled, and cwæð to his heah-gerefan
Then was Decius filled with guile, and said to his chief officer

Me ðincð þæt we sind ðurh drycræft oferswiðde
Methinks that we are overcome by magic

And he het ða alysan ðone diacon of ðære hengene, and betæcan ðam tún-gerefan Ypolite, and nyste ða-gýt þæt hé cristen wæs
And he then ordered the holy deacon to be loosened from the cross, and delivered to the town-reeve Hippolytus, and knew not yet that he was a christian

Þa betwux ðam brohte se gelyfeda cempa Romanus ceacfulne wæteres, and mid wope ðæs halgan Laurenties fét gesohte, fulluhtes biddende
Then meanwhile the believing soldier Romanus brought a jugful of water, and with weeping sought the feet of the holy Lawrence, craving baptism

Laurentius ða hrædlice þæt wæter gehalgode, and ðone geleaffullan ðegen gefullode
Lawrence then quickly hallowed the water, and baptized the believing servant

Þaða Decius þæt geaxode, ða het he hine wǽdum bereafian, and mid stearcum stengum beatan
When Decius heard of it, he ordered him to be stript of his garments and beaten with stout staves

Romanus ða ungeaxod clypode on ðæs caseres andwerdnysse
Romanus then unasked cried in the emperor's presence

Ic eom cristen
I am a christian

On ðære ylcan tide het se reða cwellere hine underhnígan swurdes ecge
At the same time the fierce executioner ordered him to fall under the sword's edge

Eft on ðære ylcan nihte, æfter ðæs cempan martyrdome, ferde Decius to ðam hatum baðum wið þæt botl Salustii, and het ðone halgan Laurentium him to gefeccan
Again, on the same night, after the soldier's martyrdom, Decius went to the hot baths, opposite the house of Sallust, and commanded the holy Lawrence to be fetched to him

Þa ongann Ypolitus sarlice heofian, and cwæð
Then Hippolytus began sorely to lament, and said

Ic wylle mid ðe siðian, and mid hluddre stemne hryman, þæt ic cristen eom, and mid þe licgan
I will go with thee, and with loud voice cry that I am a christian, and lie with thee

Laurentius cwæð
Lawrence said

Ne wep ðu, ac swiðor suwa and blissa, forðan ðe ic fare to Godes wuldre
Weep not, but rather be silent and rejoice, for I go to God's glory

Eft æfter lytlum fyrste, ðonne ic ðe clypige, gehyr mine stemne, and cum to me
After a little time hence, when I call, hear my voice, and come to me

Decius ða het gearcian eal þæt pinung-tól ætforan his dómsetle, and Laurentius him wearð to gelæd
Decius then commanded all the torture-tools to be prepared, before his doom-seat, and Lawrence was led to him

Decius cwæð
Decius said

Awurp ðone truwan ðines drycræftes, and gerece ús ðine mægðe
Cast away trust in thy magic, and recount to us of thy family

Se eadiga Laurentius andwyrde
The blessed Lawrence answered

Æfter menniscum gebyrde ic eom Hispanienscis, Romanisc fostor-cild, and cristen fram cild-cradole, getogen on ealre godcundre ǽ
According to human birth I am Spanish, a Roman foster-child, and a christian from my cradle, trained up in all divine law

Decius andwyrde
Decius answered

Soðlice is seo ǽ godcundlic ðe ðe swa gebylde þæt ðu nelt ure godas wurðian, ne ðu nanes cynnes tintregan þe ne ondrætst
In sooth the law is divine, which has so emboldened thee that thou wilt not worship our gods, nor dreadest any kind of torment

Laurentius cwæð
Lawrence said

On Cristes naman ne forhtige ic for ðinum tintregum
In the name of Christ I fear not for thy torments

Se wælhreowa casere ða cwæð
The cruel emperor then said

Gif ðu ne offrast urum godum, eall ðeos niht sceal beon aspend on ðe mid mislicum pinungum
If thou offerest not to our gods, all this night shall be spent on thee with divers tortures

Laurentius cwæð
Lawrence said

Næfð min niht nane forsworcennysse, ac heo mid beorhtum leohte scinð
My night has no darkness, but shines with bright light

Þa het se wælhreowa mid stanum ðæs halgan muð cnucian
Then the cruel one commanded the mouth of the saint to be struck with stones

Hwæt ða Laurentius wearð gestrangod ðurh Godes gife, and mid hlihendum muðe cwæð
But Lawrence was strengthened through the grace of God, and said with laughing mouth

Sy ðe lóf, Drihten, forðan ðe ðu eart ealra ðinga God
Lord, be to thee praise, for thou of all things art God

Decius cwæð to ðam cwellerum
Decius said to the executioners

Ahebbað þæt isene bed to ðam fyre, þæt se modiga Laurentius hine ðæron gereste
Raise the iron bed to the fire, that the proud Lawrence may rest thereon

Hí ðærrihte hine wædon bereafodon, and on ðam heardan bedde astrehton, and mid byrnendum gledum þæt bed undercrammodon, and hine ufan mid isenum geaflum ðydon
They straightways bereft him of his garments, and stretched him on the hard bed, and filled the bed underneath with burning coals, and from above pierced him with iron forks

Decius cwæð ða to þam Godes cyðere
Decius said to the martyr of God

Geoffra nu urum godum
Offer now to our gods

Laurentius andwyrde
Lawrence answered

Ic offrige me sylfne ðam Ælmihtigan Gode on bræðe wynsumnysse
I will offer myself to the Almighty God, in the odour of pleasantness

forðan þe se gedrefeda gast is Gode andfenge onsægednys
for the afflicted spirit is an acceptable sacrifice to God

Soðlice ða cwelleras tugon ða gleda singallice under þæt bedd, and wið-ufan mid heora forcum hine ðydon
But the executioners drew the burning coals constantly under the bed, and from above pierced him with their forks

Ða cwæð Laurentius
Then said Lawrence

Eala ge ungesæligan, ne undergyte ge þæt eowre gleda nane hǽtan minum lichaman ne gedoð, ac swiðor célinge
O ye unblessed, understand ye not that your glowing embers cause no heat to my body, but rather cooling

He ða eft mid þam wlitegostan nebbe cwæð
He then again with the most beautiful countenance said

Hælend Crist, ic ðancige ðe þæt ðu me gestrangian wylt
Saviour Christ, I thank thee that thou wilt strengthen me

He ða beseah wið þæs caseres, þus cweðende
He then looked towards the emperor, thus saying

Efne ðu, earming, bræddest ænne dæl mines lichaman, wend nu þone oðerne, and et
Behold, thou, wretch, hast roasted one part of my body, turn now the other, and eat

He cwæð ða eft
He then said again

Hælend Crist, ic ðancige ðe mid inweardre heortan, þæt ic mót faran into ðinum rice
Saviour Christ, I thank thee with inward heart, that I may go into thy kingdom

And mid þysum worde hé ageaf his gast, and mid swylcum martyrdome þæt uplice rice geferde, on ðam he wunað mid Gode á on ecnysse
And with these words he gave up his ghost, and with such martyrdom went to the realm on high, in which he dwelleth with God through all eternity

Þa forlét se wælhreowa casere ðone halgan lichaman uppon ðam isenan hyrdle, and tengde mid his heahgerefan to ðam botle Tyberianum
The cruel emperor then left the holy body on the iron hurdle, and with his chief officer hastened to the house of Tiberius

Ypolitus ða bebyrigde ðone halgan lichaman mid micelre arwurðnysse on ðære wudewan leger-stowe Quiriace, on ðysum dægðerlicum dæge
Hippolytus then buried the holy body with great reverence in the burial-place of the widow Quiriaca, on this present day

Witodlice æt ðære byrgene wacode micel menigu cristenra manna mid swiðlicere heofunge
But at the grave there watched a great many christian men with great lamentation

Se halga sacerd Iustinus ða him eallum gemæssode and gehuslode
The holy priest Justin celebrated mass to and houseled them all

Æfter ðisum gecyrde Ypolitus to his hame, and mid Godes sibbe his hywan gecyste, and hí ealle gehuslode
After this Hippolytus returned to his home, and with God's peace kissed his family, and houseled them all

Þa færlice, mid ðam ðe hé gesæt, comon ðæs caseres cempan, and hine gelæhton, and to ðam cwellere gelæddon
Then suddenly, while he was sitting, the emperor's soldiers came, and seized him, and led him to the executioner

Hine befrán ða Decius mid smercigendum muðe
Decius then asked him with smiling mouth

Hwæt la, eart ðu to dry awend, forðan ðe ðu bebyrigdest Laurentium
What, art thou turned magician, since thou hast buried Lawrence

He andwyrde
He answered

Þæt ic dyde na swa swa dry, ac swa swa cristen
I did not that as a magician, but as a christian

Decius ða yrsigende het mid stanum his muð cnucian, and hine unscrydan, and cwæð
Decius then in wrath ordered his mouth to be stricken with stones, and him to be stript, and said

La hú, nære ðu geornful biggenga ura goda
How, wast thou not a diligent worshiper of our gods

and nu ðu eart swa stunt geworden þæt furðon ðe ne sceamað ðinre næcednysse
and now thou art become so foolish that thou art not ashamed of thy nakedness

Ypolitus andwyrde
Hippolytus answered

Ic wæs stunt, and ic eom nu wís and cristen
I was foolish, and I am now wise and a christian

Þurh nytenysse ic gelyfde on þæt gedwyld þe ðu gelyfst
Through ignorance I believed in the error in which thou believest

Decius cwæð
Decius said

Geoffra ðam godum ðylæs ðe ðu þurh tintrega forwurðe, swa swa Laurentius
Offer to the gods, lest, as Lawrence, thou perish by torments

He andwyrde
He answered

Eala gif ic moste ðam eadigan Laurentium geefenlæcan
O, if I might imitate the blessed Lawrence

Decius cwæð
Decius said

Astreccað hine swa nacodne, and mid stiðum saglum beatað
Stretch him thus naked, and beat him with strong clubs

Þaða hé langlice gebeaten wæs, þa ðancode he Gode
When he had long been beaten he thanked God

Decius cwæð
Decius said

Ypolitus gebysmrað eowre stengas
Hippolytus mocks your staves, scourge him with leaded whips

Hi ða swa dydon, oðþæt hí ateorodon
Hippolytus cried with a loud voice

Ypolitus clypode mid hluddre stemne
I am a christian

On ðam ylcan dæge asmeade Ualerianus his æhta, and gemette nygontyne wera and wifa his híwisces, ðe wæron æt ðæs eadigan Laurenties handum gefullode
On the same day Valerianus took an account of his property, and found nineteen men and women of his family, who had been baptized at the hands of the blessed Lawrence

To ðam cwæð Ualerianus
To them said Valerianus

Sceawiað eowre ylde, and beorgað eowrum feore, ðylæs ðe ge samod losian mid eowrum hlaforde Ypolite
Consider your age, and have regard for your life, lest ye perish together with your lord Hippolytus

Hi ða anmodlice andwyrdon
They unanimously answered

We wilniað mid urum hlaforde clænlice sweltan, swiðor ðonne unclænlice mid eow lybban
We desire to die purely with our lord, rather than to live impurely with you

Þa wearð Ualerianus ðearle geháthyrt, and het lædan Ypolitum of ðære ceastre mid his hiwum
Then was Valerianus greatly irritated, and ordered Hippolytus to be led from the city with his household

Ða se eadiga Ypolitus gehyrte his hired, and cwæð
The blessed Hippolytus then cheered his household, and said

Mine gebroðra, ne beo ge dreorige ne afyrhte, forðan ðe ic and ge habbað ænne Hlaford, God Ælmihtigne
My brothers, be ye not sad nor afraid, for I and ye have one Lord, God Almighty

Soðlice Ualerianus het beheafdian on Ypolitus gesihðe ealle his hiwan, and hine sylfne het tigan be ðam fotum to ungetemedra horsa swuran, and swa teon geond ðornas and bremelas: and he ða mid þam tige his gast ageaf on ðam ðreotteoðan dæge þises monðes
So Valerianus ordered, in the sight of Hippolytus, all his domestics to be beheaded, and himself he ordered to be tied by the feet to the necks of untamed horses, and so to be drawn through thorns and brambles: and he with that binding gave up his ghost on the thirteenth day of this month

On ðære ylcan nihte gegaderode se halga Iustinus heora ealra lic, and bebyrigde
On the same night the holy Justin gathered the bodies of them all and buried them

Eornostlice æfter ðæra halgena ðrowunge, ferde Decius on gyldenum cræte and Ualerianus samod to heora hæðenum gylde, þæt hí ða cristenan to heora mánfullum offrungum geðreatodon
But after the passion of those saints, Decius and Valerianus went together in a golden chariot to their temple, that they might force the christians to their wicked offerings

Ða wearð Decius færlice mid feondlicum gaste awéd, and hrymde
Then became Decius suddenly frantic with a fiendlike spirit, and cried

Eala ðu, Ypolite, hwider tihst ðu me gebundenne mid scearpum racenteagum
O thou, Hippolytus, whither drawest thou me bound with sharp chains

Ualerianus eac awéd hrymde
Valerianus also frantic cried

Eala ðu, Laurentius, unsoftlice tihst ðu me gebundenne mid byrnendum racenteagum
O thou, Lawrence, unsoftly thou drawest me bound with burning chains

And he ðærrihte swealt
And he forthwith died

Witodlice Decius egeslice awedde, and binnon ðrym dagum mid deoflicre stemne singallice hrymde
But Decius became horribly frantic, and for three days, with fiendlike voice, constantly cried

Ic halsige ðe, Laurentius, ablín hwæthwega ðæra tintregena
I beseech thee, Lawrence, cease somewhat of those torments

Hwæt ða, la asprang micel heofung and sarlic wóp on ðam hame, and ðæs caseres wíf hét út-alædan ealle ða cristenan ðe on cwearterne wæron, and Decius on ðam ðriddan dæge mid micclum tintregum gewát
Hereupon great lamentation and sore weeping arose in the dwelling, and the emperor's wife ordered all the christians who were in prison to be led out, and on the third day Decius in great torments departed

Soðlice seo cwén Triphonia gesohte ðæs halgan sacerdes fét Iustines mid biterum tearum, and hire dohtor Cyrilla samod, biddende þæs halgan fulluhtes
But the queen Tryphonia, together with her daughter Cyrilla, sought the feet of the holy priest Justin with bitter tears, praying for holy baptism

Iustinus ða mid micelre blisse hí underfeng, and him bebead seofon dagena fæsten, and hí syððan mid þam halgum fulluht-bæðe fram eallum heora mándædum aðwoh
Justin then with great joy received them, and enjoined them a fast of seven days, and afterwards, by the holy baptismal bath, washed them from all their sins

Þaða þæs caseres ðegnas gehyrdon þæt seo cwén Triphonia and Decius dohtor Cyrilla to Cristes geleafan, and to ðam halwendum fulluhte gebogene wæron, hí ða mid heora wifum gesohton ðone halgan sacerd, and bædon miltsunge and fulluhtes
When the emperor's thanes heard that the queen Tryphonia and the daughter of Decius, Cyrilla, had turned to the faith of Christ and to the salutary baptism, they with their wives sought the holy priest, and prayed for mercy and baptism

Se eadiga Iustinus, ðisum gewordenum, rædde wið þa cristenan hwæne hí to bisceope ceosan woldon on Sixtes setle
The blessed Justin, these things being done, took counsel with the christians, whom they would choose for bishop in the chair of Sixtus

Hi ða anmodlice sumne arwurðfulne wer gecuron, ðæs nama wæs Dionisius, ðone gehadode se bisceop Maximus, of ðære byrig Ostiensis, to ðam Romaniscum bisceop-setle, wið wurðmynte
They then unanimously chose a venerable man whose name was Dionysius, whom the bishop Maximus, of the city of Ostia, consecrated to the Roman episcopal see with honour

Uton nu biddan mid eadmodre stemne ðone halgan Godes cyðere Laurentium, þæs freols-tíd geswutelað þes andwerda dæg ealre geleaffulre gelaðunge, þæt he us ðingige wið ðone Heofenlican Cyning, for ðæs naman he ðrowode mid cenum mode menigfealde tintregu, mid ðam he orsorhlice on ecnysse wuldrað
Let us now pray with humble voice the holy martyr of God, Lawrence, whose festival this present day makes known to all the faithful church, that he intercede for us with the Heavenly King, for whose name he suffered with bold mind many torments, with whom he free from care glorieth to eternity

Amen
Amen

Hieronimus se halga sacerd awrát ænne pistol be forðsiðe þære eadigan Marian, Godes cennestran, to sumum halgan mædene, hyre nama wæs Eustochium, and to hyre meder Paulam, seo wæs gehalgod wydewe
Jerome the holy priest wrote an epistle on the decease of the blessed Mary, the mother of God, to a holy maiden, whose name was Eustochium, and to her mother Paula, who was a hallowed widow

To þysum twam wifmannum awrát se ylca Hieronimus, menigfealde traht-bec, forðan ðe hi wæron haliges lifes men, and swiðe gecneordlæcende on boclicum smeagungum
To these two women the same Jerome wrote several treatises

Þes Hieronimus wæs halig sacerd, and getogen on Hebreiscum gereorde, and on Greciscum, and on Ledenum fulfremedlice
for they were persons of holy life, and very diligent in book-studies

and he awende ure bibliothecan of Hebreiscum bocum to Leden spræce
This Jerome was a holy priest, and instructed in the Hebrew tongue, and in Greek and Latin perfectly

He is se fyrmesta wealhstod betwux Hebreiscum, and Grecum, and Ledenwarum
and he turned our library of Hebrew books into the Latin speech

Twa and hund-seofontig boca þære ealdan ǽ and þære niwan he awende on Leden to anre Bibliothecan, buton oðrum menigfealdum traht-bocum ðe he mid gecneordum andgite deopðancollice asmeade
He is the first interpreter betwixt the Hebrews, and Greeks, and Latins

Ða æt nextan he dihte þisne pistol to þære halgan wydewan Paulam, and to þam Godes mædene Eustochium, hyre dehter, and to eallum þam mædenlicum werode, þe him mid drohtnigende wæron, þus cweðende
Seventy-two books of the old and of the new law he turned into Latin, to one 'Bibliotheca,' besides many other treatises which he profoundly devised with diligent understanding

Witodlice ge neadiað me þæt ic eow recce hu seo eadige Maria, on ðisum dægðerlicum dæge to heofonlicere wununge genumen wæs, þæt eower mædenlica heap hæbbe þas lac Ledenre spræce, hu þes mæra freolsdæg geond æghwylces geares ymbryne beo aspend mid heofonlicum lofe, and mid gastlicere blisse gemærsode sy, þylæs þe eow on hand becume seo lease gesetnys ðe þurh gedwolmen wide tosawen is, and ge þonne þa gehiwedan leasunge for soðre race underfon
Verily ye compel me to relate to you how the blessed Mary, on this present day was taken to the heavenly dwelling, that your maidenly society may have this gift in the Latin speech, how this great festival, in the course of every year, is passed with heavenly praise, and celebrated with ghostly bliss, lest the false account should come to your hand which has been widely disseminated by heretics, and ye then receive the feigned leasing for a true narrative

Soðlice fram anginne þæs halgan godspelles ge geleornodon hu se heah-engel Gabriel þam eadigan mædene Marian þæs heofonlican Æðelinges acennednysse gecydde, and þæs Hælendes wundra, and þære gesæligan Godes cennestran þenunge, and hyre lifes dæda on þam feower godspellicum bocum geswutollice oncneowon
Verily from the beginning of the holy gospel ye have learned how the archangel Gabriel declared to the blessed Mary the birth of the Heavenly Prince, and the miracles of Jesus, and the ministry of the blessed mother of God and the deeds of her life ye have manifestly known from the four evangelical books

Iohannes se Godspellere awrát on Cristes þrowunge, þæt he sylf and Maria stodon mid dreorigum mode wið ðære halgan rode, þe se Hælend on gefæstnod wæs
John the Evangelist wrote that, at Christ's passion, he himself and Mary stood with sorrowing mind opposite the holy rood, on which Jesus was fastened

Ða cwæð he to his agenre meder
Then said he to his own mother

Ðu fæmne, efne her is þin sunu
Thou woman, behold, here is thy son

Eft he cwæð to Iohanne
Again he said to John

Loca nu, her stent þin modor
Look now, here standeth thy mother

Syððan, of þam dæge, hæfde se Godspellere Iohannes gymene þære halgan Marian, and mid carfulre þenunge, swa swa agenre meder, gehyrsumode
Afterwards, from that day, the Evangelist John had charge of the holy Mary, and with careful ministry obeyed her as his mother

Drihten, þurh his arfæstnysse, betæhte þæt eadige mæden his cennestran þam clænan men Iohanne, seðe on clænum mægðhade symle wunode
The Lord, through his piety, committed the blessed maiden his mother to the chaste man John, who had ever lived in pure virginity

and he forðy synderlice þam Drihtne leof wæs, to ðan swiðe, þæt he him þone deorwurðan maðm, ealles middangeardes cwéne, betæcan wolde
and on that account he was especially dear to the Lord, so much so that he would commit to him that precious treasure, the queen of the whole world: no doubt, that her most pure virginity might be associated with that chaste man with grateful fellowship in pleasant converse

gewislice þæt hire clænesta mægðhád þam clænan men geþeod wære mid gecwemre geferrædene on wynsumre drohtnunge
In them both was one virtue of unbroken chastity, but a second attribute in Mary

On him bám wæs an miht ansundes mægðhades, ac oðer intinga on Marian
in her is fruitful virginity, so as in no other

on hire is wæstmbære mægðhád, swa swa on nanum oðrum
In no other person is there virginity, if there be fruitfulness

Nis on nanum oðrum men mægðhád, gif þær bið wæstmbærnys
nor fruitfulness, if there be perfect virginity

ne wæstmbærnys, gif þær bið ansund mægðhád
Therefore now are hallowed both the virginity of Mary and her fruitfulness through the divine birth

Nu is forði gehalgod ægðer ge Marian mægðhád ge hyre wæstmbærnys þurh þa godcundlican acennednysse
and she excels all others in virginity and in fruitfulness

and heo ealle oðre oferstihð on mægðhade and on wæstmbærnysse
Nevertheless, though she was especially committed to the care of John, yet she lived in common, after Christ's ascension, with the apostolic company, going in and going out among them, and they all with great piety and love ministered to her, and she fully informed them of all things touching Christ's humanity

Ðeah-hwæðere, þeah heo synderlice Iohannes gymene betæht wære, hwæðere heo drohtnode gemænelice, æfter Cristes upstige, mid þam apostolicum werode, infarende and utfarende betwux him, and hi ealle mid micelre arwurðnysse and lufe hire þenodon, and heo him cuðlice ealle þing ymbe Cristes menniscnysse gewissode
for she had from the beginning accurately learned them through the Holy Ghost, and seen them with her own sight

forðan þe heo fram frymðe gewislice þurh þone Halgan Gast hi ealle geleornode, and mid agenre gesihðe geseah
though the apostles understood all things through the same Ghost, and were instructed in all truth

þeah ðe þa apostoli þurh þone ylcan Gast ealle þing undergeaton, and on ealre soðfæstnysse gelærede wurdon
The archangel Gabriel held her uncorrupted, and she continued in the care of John and of all the apostles, in the heavenly company, meditating on God's law, until God, on this day, took her to the heavenly throne, and exalted her above the hosts of angels

Nis geræd on nanre bec nan swutelre gewissung be hire geendunge, buton þæt heo nu to-dæg wuldorfullice of þam lichaman gewát
There is not read in any book any more manifest information of her end, but that she on this day gloriously departed from the body

Hyre byrigen is swutol eallum onlociendum oð þysne andweardan dæg, on middan þære dene Iosaphat
Her sepulchre is visible to all beholders to this present day, in the midst of the valley of Jehosaphat

Seo dene is betwux þære dune Sion and þam munte Oliueti, and seo byrigen is æteowed open and emtig, and þær on-uppon on hire wurðmynte is aræred mære cyrce mid wundorlicum stán-geweorce
The valley is between Mount Sion and the mount of Olives, and the sepulchre appears open and empty, and thereupon is raised, in her honour, a large church, with wondrous stone-work

Nis nanum deadlicum men cuð hú, oððe on hwylcere tide hyre halga lichama þanon gebroden wære, oððe hwider he ahafen sy, oððe hwæðer heo of deaðe arise: cwædon þeah gehwylce lareowas, þæt hyre Sunu, seðe on þam þriddan dæge mihtilice of deaðe arás, þæt he eac his moder lichaman of deaðe arærde, and mid undeadlicum wuldre on heofonan rice gelogode
To no mortal man is it known how, or at what time her holy body was brought from thence, or whither it be borne, or whether she arose from death: though some doctors say, that her Son, who on the third day mightily from death arose, that he also raised his mother's body from death, and placed it with immortal glory in the kingdom of heaven

Eac swa gelice forwel menige lareowas on heora bocum setton, be ðam ge-edcucedum mannum þe mid Criste of deaðe arison, þæt hi ecelice arærede synd
In like manner very many doctors have set in their books concerning the requickened men who arose from death with Christ, that they are raised for ever

Witodlice hi andetton þæt ða aræredan men næron soðfæste gewitan Cristes æristes, buton hi wæron ecelice arærede
They profess verily that those raised men would not have been true witnesses of Christ's resurrection, unless they had been raised for ever

Ne wiðcweðe we be þære eadigan Marian þa ecan æriste, þeah, for wærscipe gehealdenum geleafan, us gedafenað þæt we hit wenon swiðor þonne we unrædlice hit geseþan þæt ðe is uncuð buton ælcere fræcednysse
Nor do we deny the eternal resurrection of the blessed Mary, though for caution, preserving our belief, it befits us that we rather hope it, than rashly assert what is unknown without any danger

We rædað gehwær on bocum, þæt forwel oft englas comon to godra manna forðsiðe, and mid gastlicum lofsangum heora sawla to heofonum gelæddon
We read here and there in books, that very often angels came at the departure of good men, and with ghostly hymns led their souls to heaven

And, þæt gyt swutollicor is, men gehyrdon on þam forðsiðe wæpmanna sang and wifmanna sang, mid micclum leohte and swetum breðe: on ðam is cuð þæt þa halgan men þe to Godes rice þurh gode geearnunga becomon, þæt hi on oðra manna forðsiðe heora sawla underfoð, and mid micelre blisse to reste gelædað
And, what is yet more certain, men, at their departure, have heard the song of men and women, with a great light and sweet odour: by which is known that those holy men who through good deserts come to God's kingdom, that they, at the departure of other men, receive their souls, and with great joy lead them to rest

Nu gif se Hælend swilcne wurðmynt on his halgena forðsiðe oft geswutelode, and heora gastas mid heofonlicum lofsange to him gefeccan het, hu miccle swiðor wenst þu þæt he nu to-dæg þæt heofonlice werod togeanes his agenre meder sendan wolde, þæt hi mid ormætum leohte and unasecgendlicum lofsangum hi to þam þrymsetle gelæddon þe hire gegearcod wæs fram frymðe middangeardes
Now if Jesus has often showed such honour at the death of his saints, and has commanded their souls to be conducted to him with heavenly hymn, how much rather thinkest thou he would now to-day send the heavenly host to meet his own mother, that they with light immense, and unutterable hymns might lead her to the throne which was prepared for her from the beginning of the world

Nis nan twynung þæt eall heofonlic þrym þa mid unasecgendlicere blisse hire to-cymes fægnian wolde
There is no doubt that all the heavenly host then with unspeakable bliss would rejoice in her advent

Soðlice eac we gelyfað þæt Drihten sylf hire togeanes come, and wynsumlice mid gefean to him on his þrymsetle hi gesette: witodlice he wolde gefyllan þurh hine sylfne þæt he on his ǽ bebead, þus cweðende
Verily we also believe that the Lord himself came to meet her, and benignly with delight placed her by him on his throne: for he would fulfil in himself what he had in his law enjoined, thus saying

Arwurða þinne fæder and þine moder
Honour thy father and thy mother

He is his agen gewita þæt he his Fæder gearwurðode, swa swa he cwæð to þam Iudeiscum
He is his own witness that he honoured his Father, as he said to the Jews

Ic arwurðige minne Fæder, and ge unarwurðiað me
I honour my Father, and ye dishonour me

On his menniscnysse he arwurðode his moder, þaða he wæs, swa swa þæt halige godspel segð, hire underðeod on his geogoðhade
In his human state he honoured his mother, when he was, as the holy gospel says, subjected to her in his youth

Micele swiðor is to gelyfenne þæt he his modor mid unasecgendlicere arwurðnysse on his rice gewurðode, þaða he wolde æfter ðære menniscnysse on þysum life hyre gehyrsumian
Much more is it to be believed that he honoured his mother with unspeakable veneration in his kingdom, when he would, according to human nature, obey her in this life

Ðes symbel-dæg oferstihð unwiðmetenlice ealra oðra halgena mæsse-dagas swa micclum swa þis halige mæden, Godes modor, is unwiðmetenlic eallum oðrum mædenum
This festival excels incomparably all other saints' mass-days, as much as this holy maiden, the mother of God, is incomparable with all other maidens

Ðes freolsdæg is us gearlic, ac he is heofonwarum singallic
This feast-day to us is yearly, but to heaven's inmates it is perpetual

Be ðysre heofonlican cwéne upstige wundrode se Halga Gast on lofsangum, ðus befrinende
At the ascension of this heavenly queen the Holy Ghost in hymns uttered his wonder, thus inquiring

Hwæt is ðeos ðe her astihð swilce arisende dæg-rima, swa wlitig swa móna, swa gecoren swa sunne, and swa egeslic swa fyrd-truma
What is this that here ascends like the rising dew of morn, as beauteous as the moon, as choice as the sun, and as terrible as a martial band

Se Halga Gast wundrode, forðan ðe he dyde þæt eal heofonwaru wundrode ðysre fæmnan upfæreldes
The Holy Ghost wondered, for he caused all heaven's inmates to wonder at the ascension of this woman

Maria is wlitigre ðonne se móna, forðan ðe heo scinð buton æteorunge hire beorhtnysse
Mary is more beauteous than the moon, for she shines without decrease of her brightness

Heo is gecoren swa swa sunne mid leoman healicra mihta, forðan ðe Drihten, seðe is rihtwisnysse sunne, hí geceas him to cennestran
She is choice as the sun with beams of holy virtues, for the Lord, who is the sun of righteousness, chose her for his mother

Hire fær is wiðmeten fyrdlicum truman, forðan ðe heo wæs mid halgum mægnum ymbtrymed, and mid engla þreatum
Her course is compared to a martial band, for she was surrounded with heavenly powers and with companies of angels

Be ðissere heofonlican cwéne is gecweden gyt þurh ðone ylcan Godes Gast: he cwæð
Of this heavenly queen it is yet said by the same Spirit of God

Ic geseah ða wlitegan swilce culfran astigende ofer streamlicum riðum, and unasecgendlic bræð stemde of hire gyrlum
I saw the beauteous one as a dove mounting above the streaming rills, and an ineffable fragrance exhaled from her garments

and, swa swa on lengctenlicere tide, rosena blostman and lilian hi ymtrymedon
and, so as in the spring-tide, blossoms of roses and lilies encircled her

Ðæra rosena blostman getacniað mid heora readnysse martyrdom, and ða lilian mid heora hwitnysse getacniað ða scinendan clænnysse ansundes mægðhádes
The blossoms of roses betoken by their redness martyrdom, and the lilies by their whiteness betoken the shining purity of inviolate maidenhood

Ealle ða gecorenan ðe Gode geþugon ðurh martyrdom oððe þurh clænnysse, ealle hi gesiðodon mid þære eadigan cwéne
All the chosen who have thriven to God through martyrdom or through chastity, they all journeyed with the blessed queen

forðan ðe heo sylf is ægðer ge martyr ge mæden
for she is herself both martyr and maiden

Heo is swa wlitig swa culfre, forðan ðe heo lufode ða bilewitnysse, þe se Halga Gast getacnode, ðaða he wæs gesewen on culfran gelicnysse ofer Criste on his fulluhte
She is as beauteous as a dove, for she loved meekness, which the Holy Ghost betokened, when he appeared in likeness of a dove over Christ at his baptism

Oðre martyras on heora lichaman þrowodon martyrdom for Cristes geleafan, ac seo eadige Maria næs na lichamlice gemartyrod, ac hire sawul wæs swiðe geangsumod mid micelre þrowunge, þaða heo stod dreorig foran ongean Cristes rode, and hire leofe cild geseah mid isenum næglum on heardum treowe gefæstnod
Other martyrs suffered martyrdom in their bodies for Christ's faith, but the blessed Mary was not bodily martyred, but her soul was sorely afflicted with great suffering, when she stood sad before Christ's rood, and saw her dear child fastened with iron nails on the hard tree

Nu is heo mare þonne martyr, forðan ðe heo ðrowode þone martyrdom on hire sawle ðe oðre martyras ðrowodon on heora lichaman
Therefore is she more than a martyr, for she suffered that martyrdom in her soul which other martyrs suffered in their bodies

Heo lufode Crist ofer ealle oðre men, and forðy wæs eac hire sarnys be him toforan oðra manna, and heo dyde his deað hire agenne deað, forðan ðe his ðrowung swa swa swurd ðurhferde hire sawle
She loved Christ above all other men, and, therefore, was her pain also for him greater than other men's, and she made his death as her own death, for his suffering pierced her soul as a sword

Nis heo nanes haliges mægnes bedæled, ne nanes wlites, ne nanre beorhtnysse
She is void of no holy virtue, nor any beauty, nor any brightness

and forðy heo wæs ymbtrymed mid rosan and lilian, þæt hyre mihta wæron mid mihtum underwriðode, and hire fægernys mid clænnysse wlite wære geyht
and therefore was she encircled with roses and lilies, that her virtues might be supported by virtues, and her fairness increased by the beauty of chastity

Godes gecorenan scinað on heofonlicum wuldre ælc be his geðingcðum
God's chosen shine in heavenly glory, each according to his merits

nu is geleaflic þæt seo eadige] cwén mid swa micclum wuldre and beorhtnysse oðre oferstige, swa micclum swa hire geðincðu oðra halgena unwiðmetenlice sind
it is therefore credible that the blessed] queen with so much glory and brightness excels others, as much as her merits are incomparable with those of the other saints

Drihten cwæð ær his upstige, þæt on his Fæder huse sindon fela wununga: soðlice we gelyfað þæt he nu to-dæg þa wynsumestan wununge his leofan meder forgeafe
The Lord said before his ascension, that in his Father's house are many dwellings: therefore we believe that he now to-day gave to his mother the most pleasant dwelling

Godes gecorenra wuldor is gemetegod be heora geearnungum, and nis hwæðere nán ceorung ne ánda on heora ænigum, ac hí ealle wuniað on soðre lufe and healicere sibbe, and ælc blissað on oðres geðincðum swa swa on his agenum
The glory of God's chosen is measured by their deserts, and yet there is no murmuring nor envy in any of them, but they all dwell in true love and profound peace, and each rejoices in another's honours as in his own

Ic bidde eow, blissiað on ðyssere freols-tide: witodlice nu to-dæg þæt wuldorfulle mæden heofonas astah, þæt heo unasecgendlice mid Criste ahafen on ecnysse rixige
I pray you, rejoice in this festival: verily now to-day that glorious maiden ascended to heaven, that she, ineffably exalted with Christ, may for ever reign

Seo heofenlice cwén wearð to-dæg generod fram ðyssere mánfullan worulde
The heavenly queen was to-day snatched from this wicked world

Eft ic cweðe, fægniað forðan ðe heo becom orsorhlice to ðam heofonlicum botle
Again I say, rejoice that she, void of sorrow, is gone to the heavenly mansion

Blissige eal middangeard, forðan ðe nu to-dæg us eallum is ðurh hire geearnunga hǽl geyht
Let all earth be glad, for now to-day, through her deserts, happiness is increased to us all

Þurh ure ealdan modor Euan us wearð heofonan rices geat belocen, and eft ðurh Marian hit is us geopenod, þurh þæt heo sylf nu to-dæg wuldorfullice inn-ferde
Through our old mother Eve the gate of heaven's kingdom was closed against us, and again, through Mary it is opened to us, by which she herself has this day gloriously entered

God ðurh his witegan us bebead þæt we sceolon hine herian and mǽrsian on his halgum, on ðam he is wundorlic: micele swiðor gedafenað þæt we hine on ðisre mæran freols-tide his eadigan meder mid lofsangum and wurðfullum herungum wurðian sceolon
God has commanded us through his prophets, that we should praise and magnify him in his saints, in whom he is wonderful: much more fitting is it that we, on this great festival of his blessed mother, should worship him with hymns and honourable praises

forðan ðe untwylice eal hire wurðmynt is Godes herung
for undoubtedly all honour to her is praise of God

Uton nu forði mid ealre estfulnysse ures modes ðas mæran freols-tide wurðian, forðan ðe þæt siðfæt ure hǽle is on lofsangum ures Drihtnes
Let us now, therefore, with all the devotion of our mind honour this great festival, for the way of our salvation is in hymns to our Lord

Þa ðe on mæigðháde wuniað blission hí, forðan ðe hí geearnodon þæt beon þæt hí heriað: habbon hí hóge þæt hí syn swilce þæt hí wurðfullice herigan magon
Let those who continue in maidenhood rejoice, for they have attained to be that which they praise: let them have care that they be such that they may praise worthily

Þa ðe on clænan wudewanháde sind, herion hí and arwurðion, forðan ðe swutol is þæt hí ne magon beon clæne buton ðurh Cristes gife, seoðe wæs fulfremedlice on Marian ðe hí herigað
Let those who are in pure widowhood praise and honour her, for it is manifest that they cannot be pure but through grace of Christ, which was perfect in Mary whom they praise

Herigan eac and wurðian ða ðe on sinscipe wuniað, forðan ðe ðanon flewð eallum mildheortnys and gifu þæt hí herigan magon
Let those also who are in wedlock praise and honour her, for thence flow mercy and grace to all that they may praise her

Gif hwa synful sy, he andette, and nalǽs herige, ðeah ðe ne beo wlitig lóf on ðæs synfullan muðe
If any one be sinful, let him confess, and not the less praise, though praise be not beautiful in the mouth of the sinful

hwæðere ne geswice hé ðære herunge, forðan ðe ðanon him is beháten forgyfenys
yet let him not cease from praise, for thence is promised to him forgiveness

Þes pistol is swiðe menigfeald ús to gereccenne, and eow swiðe deop to gehyrenne
This epistle is very complex for us to expound, and very deep for you to hear

Nu ne onhagað ús na swiðor be ðam to sprecenne, ac we wyllað sume oðre trimminge be ðære mæran Godes meder gereccan, to eowre gebetrunge
It does not now seem good to us to speak more concerning it, but we will relate for your bettering some other edifying matter of the great mother of God

Soðlice Maria is se mæsta frofer and fultum cristenra manna, þæt is forwel oft geswutelod, swa swa we on bocum rædað
Verily Mary is the greatest comfort and support of christian men, which is very often manifested, as we read in books

Sum man wæs mid drycræfte bepæht, swa þæt hé Criste wiðsóc, and wrát his hand-gewrit þam awyrgedan deofle, and him mannrædene befæste
Some man was so deluded by magic that he denied Christ, and wrote his chirograph to the accursed devil, and entered into a compact with him

His nama wæs Theophilus
His name was Theophilus

He ða eft syððan hine beðohte, and ða hellican pinunge on his mode weolc
He afterwards bethought himself, and revolved in his mind the torment of hell

and ferde ða to sumere cyrcan þe wæs to lofe ðære eadigan Marian gehalgod, and ðær-binnan swa lange mid wope and fæstenum hire fultumes and ðingunge bæd, oðþæt heo sylf mid micclum wuldre him to com, and cwæð, þæt heo him geðingod hæfde wið þone Heofenlican Deman, hire agenne Sunu
and went then to a church that was hallowed to the praise of the blessed Mary, and therein so long with weeping and fasts prayed for her aid and intercession, till she herself with great glory came to him, and said, that she had interceded for him with the Heavenly Judge, her own Son

We wyllað eac eow gereccan be geendunge ðæs arleasan Godes wiðersacan Iulianes
We will also relate to you concerning the end of the impious adversary of God, Julian

Sum halig biscop wæs Basilius geháten, se leornode on anre scole, and se ylca Iulianus samod
There was a certain bishop named Basilius, who had learned in a school together with this same Julian

Þa gelamp hit swa þæt Basilius wearð to biscope gecoren to anre byrig ðe is geháten Cappadocia, and Iulianus to casere, þeah ðe he æror to preoste bescoren wære
It so happened that Basilius was chosen to be bishop of a place called Cappadocia, and Julian to be emperor, though he earlier had been shorn for a priest

Iulianus ða ongann to lufigenne hæðengyld, and his cristendome wiðsóc, and mid eallum mode hæðenscipe beeode, and his leode to ðan ylcan genydde
Julian then began to love idolatry, and renounced his christianity, and with all his mind cultivated heathenism, and compelled his people to the same

Þa æt suman cyrre tengde hé to fyrde ongean Perscisne leodscipe, and gemette ðone biscop, and cwæð him to
Then at a certain time he went on an expedition against the Persian nation, and met the bishop, and said to him

Eala, ðu Basili, nu ic hæbbe ðe oferðogen on uðwitegunge
O thou Basilius, I have now excelled thee in philosophy

Se biscop him andwyrde
The bishop answered

God forgeafe þæt ðu uðwitegunge beeodest
God has granted to you to cultivate philosophy

and hé mid þam worde him bead swylce lác swa he sylf breac, þæt wæron ðry berene hlafas, for bletsunge
and with that word he offered him such a gift as he himself partook of, that was three barley loaves, for a blessing

Þa het se wiðersaca onfon ðæra hlafa, and agifan ðam biscope togeanes gærs, and cwæð
Then the apostate commanded the loaves to be received, and grass to be given to the bishop in return, and said

He bead ús nytena fódan, underfo hé gærs to leanes
He has offered us the food of beasts, let him receive grass in reward

Basilius underfeng þæt gærs, ðus cweðende
Basilius received the grass, thus saying

Eala ðu casere, soðlice we budon ðe ðæs ðe we sylfe brucað, and ðu us sealdest to edleane ungesceadwisra nytena andlyfene, na us to fódan, ac to hospe
O thou emperor, verily we have offered to thee what we ourselves partake of, and thou hast given us in reward the sustenance of irrational beasts, not as food for us but as insult

Se Godes wiðersaca hine ða gehathyrte, and cwæð
The adversary of God then became angry, and said

Þonne ic fram fyrde gecyrre ic towurpe ðas burh, and hi gesmeðige, and to yrðlande awende, swa þæt heo bið cornbære swiðor þonne mannbære
When I return from the expedition I will overthrow this city, and level it, and turn it to arable land, so that it shall be cornbearing rather than manbearing

Nis me uncuð þin dyrstignys, and ðissere burhware, ðe ðurh ðine tihtinge ða anlicnysse, ðe ic arærde and me to gebæd, tobræcon and towurpon
Thy audacity and that of these citizens is not unknown to me, who at thy instigation brake and cast down the image which I had raised and prayed to

And hé mid ðisum wordum ferde to Persciscum earde
And with these words he went to the Persian territory

Hwæt ða Basilius cydde his ceastergewarum ðæs reðan caseres ðeowrace, and him selost rædbora wearð, þus cweðende
Hereupon Basilius made known to his fellow-citizens the cruel emperor's threat, and was a most excellent counsellor to them, thus saying

Mine gebroðra, bringað eowre sceattas, and uton cunnian, gif we magon, ðone reðan wiðersacan on his geancyrre gegladian
My brothers, bring your treasures, and let us endeavour, if we can, to gladden the cruel apostate on his return

Hi ða mid glædum mode him to brohton goldes, and seolfres, and deorwurðra gimma ungerime hypan
They then with glad mind brought to him of gold, and silver, and precious gems an immense heap

Se bisceop ða underfeng ða madmas, and bebead his preostum and eallum ðam folce, þæt hí heora lác geoffrodon binnon ðam temple ðe wæs to wurðmynte ðære eadigan Marian gehalgod, and het hí ðær-binnon andbidigan mid ðreora daga fæstene, þæt se Ælmihtiga Wealdend, þurh his moder ðingrædene towurpe þæs unrihtwisan caseres andgit
Thereupon the bishop received the treasures, and commanded his priests and all the people to offer their gifts within the temple that was hallowed to the honour of the blessed Mary, and bade them therein abide, with a fast of three days, that the Almighty Ruler, through his mother's intercession, might turn to naught the resolve of the unrighteous emperor

Þa on ðære ðriddan nihte ðæs fæstenes geseah se bisceop micel heofenlic werod on ælce healfe ðæs temples, and on middan ðam werode sæt seo heofenlice cwén Maria, and cwæð to hire ætstandendum
Then on the third night of the fast the bishop saw a great heavenly host on each side of the temple, and in the midst of the host sat the heavenly queen Mary, and said to her attendants

Gelángiað me ðone martyr Mercurium, þæt he gewende wið ðæs arleasan wiðersacan Iulianes, and hine acwelle, seðe mid toðundenum mode God minne Sunu forsihð
Bring to me the martyr Mercurius, that he may go against the impious apostate Julian, and slay him, who with inflated mind despises God my Son

Se halga cyðere Mercurius gewǽpnod hrædlice cóm, and be hyre hæse ferde
The holy martyr Mercurius came armed speedily, and went by her command

Þa eode se bisceop into ðære oðre cyrcan, þær se martyr inne læig, and befrán ðone cyrcweard hwær ðæs halgan wæpnu wæron
The bishop then went into the other church, in which the martyr lay, and asked the churchward, where the weapons of the saint were

He swór þæt hé on æfnunge æt his heafde witodlice hí gesawe
He swore that he certainly saw them at his head in the evening

And he ðærrihte wende to Sca Marian temple, and ðam folce gecydde his gesihðe, and ðæs wælhreowan forwyrd
And he straightways returned to St

Þa eode hé eft ongean to ðæs halgan martyres byrgenne, and funde his spere standan mid blode begleddod
Mary's temple, and made known to the people what he had seen, and the destruction of the tyrant

Þa æfter ðrim dagum com án ðæs caseres ðegna, Libanius hatte, and gesohte ðæs bisceopes fét, fulluhtes biddende, and cydde him and ealre ðære buruhware þæs arleasan Iulianes deað: cwæð þæt seo fyrd wícode wið ða ea Eufraten, and seofon weard-setl wacodon ofer ðone casere
Then after three days came one of the emperor's officers called Libanius, and sought the bishop's feet, praying for baptism, and informed him and all the citizens of the death of the impious Julian: he said that the army was encamped on the river Euphrates, and seven watches watched over the emperor

Þa com ðær stæppende sum uncuð cempa, and hine hetelice ðurhðyde, and ðærrihte of hyra gesihðum fordwán
Then came there walking an unknown warrior, and violently pierced him through, and straightways vanished from their sight

and Iulianus ða mid anðræcum hreame forswealt
and Julian then with a horrible cry expired

Swa wearð seo burhwaru ahred þurh Sca Marian wið ðone Godes wiðersacan
So were the citizens saved through St

Þa bead se bisceop ðam ceastergewarum hyra sceattas, ac hi cwædon þæt hi uðon ðæra laca þam undeadlican Cyninge, ðe hi swa mihtelice generede, micele bet ðonne ðam deadlican cwellere
Mary from the adversary of God

Se bisceop ðeah nydde þæt folc þæt hi ðone ðriddan dæl þæs feos underfengon, and he mid þam twam dælum þæt mynster gegódode
Then the bishop offered their treasures to the citizens, but they said, that they would give those gifts to the Immortal King, who had so powerfully saved them, much rather than to the mortal murderer

Gif hwá smeage hu ðis gewurde, þonne secge we, þæt ðes martyr his líf adreah on læwedum hade
If any one ask how this happened, we say, that this martyr had spent his life in a lay condition, when, through the persecution of heathen men, for belief in Christ, he was martyred

ða wearð he ðurh hæðenra manna ehtnysse for Cristes geleafan gemartyrod
and christian men afterwards honourably deposited his holy body within the temple, together with his weapons

and cristene men syððan his halgan lichaman binnon ðam temple wurðfullice gelógedon, and his wæpna samod
Afterwards, when the holy queen sent him, as we have said a little before, his spirit swiftly went, and with a bodily weapon stabbed the foe of God, while his guards were looking on

Mine gebroðra ða leofostan, uton clypigan mid singalum benum to ðære halgan Godes meder, þæt heo ús on urum nydþearfnyssum to hire Bearne geðingige
My dearest brothers, let us call with constant prayers to the holy mother of God, that she may intercede for us in our necessities with her Son

Hit is swiðe geleaflic þæt he hyre miceles ðinges tiðian wylle, seðe hine sylfne gemedemode þæt he ðurh hí, for middangeardes alysednysse, to menniscum men acenned wurde, seðe æfre is God butan anginne, and nu ðurhwunað, on anum hade, soð man and soð God, á on ecnysse
It is very credible that he will grant much to her, who vouchsafed through her to be born a human being for the redemption of the world, who is ever God without beginning, and now exists, in one person, true man and true God, ever to eternity

Swa swa gehwilc man wunað on sawle and on lichaman án mann, swa is Crist, God and mann, án Hælend, seðe leofað and rixað mid Fæder and Halgum Gaste on ealra worulda woruld
So as every man exists in soul and body one man, so is Christ, God and man, one Saviour, who liveth and reigneth with the Father and the Holy Ghost for ever and ever

Amen
Amen

Wyrd-writeras secgað þæt ðry leodscipas sind gehátene India
Historians say that there are three nations called India

Seo forme India lið to ðæra Silhearwena rice, seo oðer lið to Medas, seo ðridde to ðam micclum garsecge
The first India lies towards the Ethiopians' realm, the second lies towards the Medes, the third on the great ocean

þeos ðridde India hæfð on anre sidan þeostru, and on oðere ðone grimlican garsecg
this third India has on one side darkness, and on the other the grim ocean

To ðyssere becóm Godes apostol Bartholomeus, and eode into ðam temple to ðam deofolgylde Astaroð, and swa swa ælðeodig ðær wunade
To this came the apostle of God Bartholomew, and went into the temple to the idol Ashtaroth, and as a stranger there remained

On ðam deofolgylde wunade swilc deofol ðe to mannum þurh ða anlicnysse spræc, and gehælde untruman, blinde and healte, þa ðe he sylf ǽr awyrde
In the idol dwelt a devil such that he spake to men through the image, and healed the sick, the blind and the halt, whom he had himself previously afflicted

He derode manna gesihðum, and heora lichaman mid mislicum untrumnyssum awyrde, and andwyrde him ðurh ða anlicnysse, þæt hi him heora lác offrian sceoldon, and he hi gehælde
He injured men's sight, and afflicted their bodies with divers diseases, and answered them through the image, that they should offer to him their gifts, and he would heal them

ac he him ne heolp mid nanre hæle, ac ðaða hi to him bugon, ða geswac he ðære lichamlican gedreccednysse, forðan ðe he ahte ða heora sawla
but he helped them not with any healing, but when they bowed to him, he ceased from the bodily affliction, for he then possessed their souls

Þa wendon dysige men þæt he hí gehælde, ðaða he ðære dreccednysse geswac
Then foolish men thought that he healed them, when he ceased from afflicting them

Þa mid þam ðe se apostol into ðam temple eode, ða adumbode se deofol Astaroð, and ne mihte nanum ðæra ðe hé awyrde gehelpan, for ðæs halgan Godes ðegnes neawiste
When the apostle went into the temple, the devil Ashtaroth became dumb, and could not help any of those whom he had afflicted, for the presence of the holy servant of God

Þa lagon ðær binnan ðam temple fela adligra manna, and dæghwomlice þam deofolgylde offrodon
There lay there within the temple many sick men, and offered daily to the idol

ac þaða hí gesawon þæt he heora helpan ne mihte, ne nanum andwyrdan, þa ferdon hí to gehendre byrig, þær ðær oðer deofol wæs gewurðod, þæs nama wæs Berið, and him offrodon, and befrunon, hwi heora god him andwyrdan ne mihte
but when they saw that he could not help them, nor answer any one, they went to a neighbouring city, where another devil was worshiped, whose name was Berith, and offered to him, and asked, why their god could not answer them

Se deofol ða Berið andwyrde, and cwæð
The devil Berith then answered, and said

Eower god is swa fæste mid isenum racenteagum gewriðen þæt he ne gedyrstlæcð þæt he furðon orðige oððe sprece syððan se Godes apostol Bartholomeus binnan þæt tempel becom
Your god is so fast bound with iron chains, that he dares not even breathe or speak since God's apostle Bartholomew came within the temple

Hí axodon
They asked

Hwæt is se Bartholomeus
Who is Bartholomew

Se deofol andwyrde
The devil answered

He is freond þæs Ælmihtigan Godes, and ði he com to ðyssere scire þæt he aidlige ealle ða hæðengyld þe ðas Indiscan wurðiað
He is a friend of the Almighty God, and he is come to this province that he may render vain all the idols which these Indians worship

Hí cwædon
They said

Sege us his nebwlite, þæt we hine oncnawan magon
Describe to us his countenance, that we may know him

Berið him andwyrde
Berith answered them

He is blæcfexede and cyrps, hwit on lichaman, and he hæfð steape eagan, and medemlice nosu, and side beardas, hwon hárwencge, medemne wæstm, and is ymbscryd mid hwitum oferslype, and binnan six and twentig geara fæce: næs his reaf hórig ne tosigen, ne his scos forwerode
He has fair and curling locks, is white of body, and has deep eyes and moderate sized nose, and ample beard, somewhat hoary, a middling stature, and is clad in a white upper garment, and is within six and twenty years old: his raiment is not dirty nor threadbare, nor are his shoes worn out

Hund siðon he bigð his cneowa on dæge, and hund siðon on nihte, biddende his Drihten
A hundred times he bows his knees by day, and a hundred times by night, praying to his Lord

His stemn is swylce ormæte byme, and him farað mid Godes englas, ðe ne geðafiað þæt him hunger derige, oððe ænig ateorung
His voice is as an immense trumpet, and God's angels go with him, who allow not hunger to hurt him, nor any faintness

Æfre he bið anes modes, and glæd þurhwunað
He is ever of one mind, and continues glad

Ealle ðing he foresceawað and wát, and ealra ðeoda gereord he cann
All things he foresees and knows, and he understands the tongues of all nations

Nu iu he wát hwæt ic sprece be him, forðan ðe Godes englas him ðeowiað, and ealle ðing cyðað
Now long ago he knows what I am saying of him, for God's angels minister and make known all things to him

Þonne ge hine secað, gif he sylf wyle, ge hine gemetað
When ye seek him, if he himself will, ye will find him

gif he nele, soðlice ne finde ge hine
if he will not, verily ye will find him not

Ic bidde eow þæt ge hine geornlice biddon þæt he hider ne gewende, þelæs ðe Godes englas ðe him mid synd me gebeodon þæt hi minum geferan Astaroð gebudon
I pray you that ye earnestly beseech him not to come hither, lest God's angels who are with him command to me what they have commanded to my companion Ashtaroth

And se deofol mid þisum wordum suwode
And with these words the devil was silent

Hi gecyrdon ongean, and sceawodon ælces ælðeodiges mannes andwlitan and gyrlan, and hi nateshwon, binnan twegra daga fæce, hine ne gemetton
They turned back, and beheld the countenance and garments of every man, and, during a space of two days, they did not find him

Þa betwux ðisum hrymde sum wód mann ðurh deofles gast, and cwæð
Then in the meanwhile some madman cried through the devil's spirit, and said

Eala ðu Godes apostol, Bartholomee, ðine gebedu geancsumiað me, and ontendað
O thou apostle of God, Bartholomew, thy prayers torment and exasperate me

Se apostol ða cwæð
The apostle then said

Adumba, ðu unclæna deofol, and gewit of ðam menn
Be dumb, thou unclean devil, and depart from the man

And ðærrihte wearð se mann geclænsod fram ðam fulan gaste, and gewittiglice spræc, seðe for manegum gearum awedde
And straightways the man was cleansed from the foul spirit, and spake rationally, who had been mad for many years

Þa geaxode se cyning Polimius be ðam witseocum menn, hu se apostol hine fram ðære wódnysse ahredde, and het hine to him gelangian, and cwæð
Then the king Polymius heard of the maniac, how the apostle had saved him from that madness, and he commanded him to be fetched to him, and said

Min dohtor is hreowlice awed: nu bidde ic ðe þæt þu hí on gewitte gebringe, swa swa ðu dydest Seustium, seðe for manegum gearum mid egeslicere wódnysse gedreht wæs
My daughter is cruelly frantic: now I beseech thee to bring her to her wits, as thou didst Seustius, who for many years had been afflicted with dreadful madness

Þaða se apostol þæt mæden geseah mid heardum racenteagum gebunden, forðan ðe heo bát and totær ælcne ðe heo geræcan mihte, and hire nan man genealæcan ne dorste, ða het se apostol hí unbindan
When the apostle saw the maiden bound with hard chains (because she bit and tore everyone whom she could reach, and no man durst approach her), he ordered her to be unbound

Þa ðenas him andwyrdon
The servants answered him

Hwa dearr hi hreppan
Who dares to touch her

Bartholomeus andwyrde
Bartholomew answered

Ic hæbbe gebunden ðone feond þe hi drehte, and ge gýt hi ondrædað
I have bound the fiend that tormented her, and ye yet fear her

Gað to and unbindað hi, and gereordigað, and on ærne merigen lǽdað hí to me
Go to and unbind her, and give her to eat, and to-morrow early lead her to me

Hi ða dydon be ðæs apostoles hæse, and se awyrigeda gast ne mihte na leng hi dreccan
They did then as the apostle ordered, and the accursed spirit could no longer torment her

Þa ðæs on merigen se cyning Polimius gesymde gold, and seolfor, and deorwurðe gymmas, and pællene gyrlan uppan olfendas, and sohte ðone apostol, ac he hine nateshwon ne gemette
Then on the morrow the king Polymius loaded gold, and silver, and precious gems, and purple garments upon camels, and sought the apostle, but he found him not

Eft ðæs on merigen com se apostol into ðæs cyninges bure, beclysedre dura, and hine befrán
On the morrow the apostle came into the king's bower, the door being closed, and asked him

Hwi sohtest ðu me mid golde, and mid seolfre, and mid deorwurðum gymmum and gyrlum
Why soughtest thou me with gold, and with silver, and with precious gems, and garments

Þas lác behofiað þa ðe eorðlice welan secað
These gifts those require who seek earthly wealth

ic soðlice nanes eorðlices gestreones, ne flæsclices lustes ne gewilnige
but I desire no earthly treasure, nor fleshly pleasure

ac ic wille þæt þu wite þæt ðæs Ælmihtigan Godes Sunu gemedemode hine sylfne þæt hé ðurh mædenlicne innoð acenned wearð, seðe geworhte heofonas and eorðan and ealle gesceafta
but I wish thee to know that the Son of Almighty God vouchsafed to be born of a maidenly womb, who wrought heaven and earth and all creatures

and he hæfde anginn on ðære menniscnysse, seðe næfre ne ongann on godcundnysse, ac he sylf is anginn, and eallum gesceaftum, ægðer ge gesewenlicum ge ungesewenlicum, anginn forgeaf
and he had beginning in humanity who never began in his divine nature, for he is himself beginning, and to all creatures, both visible and invisible, gave beginning

Þæt mæden ðe hine gebær forhogode ælces weres gemanan, and ðam Ælmihtigan Gode hire mægðhad behet
The maiden who bare him despised every man's fellowship, and to the Almighty God promised her maidenhood

Hire com to Godes heah-engel Gabriel, and hire cydde þæs heofonlican Æðelinges to-cyme on hire innoð, and heo his wordum gelyfde, and swa mid þam cilde wearð
To her came God's archangel, Gabriel, and announced to her the advent of the Heavenly Prince into her womb, and she believed his words, and so was with child

Se apostol ða þam cyninge bodade ealne cristendom, and middangeardes alysednysse ðurh ðæs Hælendes to-cyme, and hu he ðone hellican deofol gewylde, and him mancynnes benæmde, and cwæð
The apostle then preached to the king all christianity, and the redemption of the world through the advent of Jesus, and how he overcame the hellish devil, and deprived him of mankind, and said

Drihten Crist, seðe ðurh his unscyldigan deað þone deofol oferswiðde, sende us geond ealle ðeoda, þæt we todræfdon deofles ðenas, ða ðe on anlicnyssum wuniað, and þæt we ða hæðenan ðe hi wurðiað of heora anwealde ætbrudon
The Lord Christ, who through his innocent death overpowered the devil, has sent us among all nations, to drive away the devil's ministers, who dwell in images, and to withdraw the heathen who worship them from their power

Ac we ne underfoð gold ne seolfor, ac forseoð, swa swa Crist forseah
But we receive not gold nor silver, but despise, as Christ despised them

forðan ðe we gewilniað þæt we rice beon on his rice, on ðam næfð adl, ne untrumnyss, ne unrotnyss, ne deað, nænne stede, ac þær is ece gesælð and eadignys, gefea butan ende mid ecum welum
for we desire to be rich in his kingdom, in which neither sickness, nor infirmity, nor sadness, nor death, has any place, but there is eternal happiness and bliss, joy without end with eternal riches

Forði ic ferde to eowerum temple, and se deofol ðe eow ðurh ða anlicnysse geandwyrde, ðurh Godes englas ðe me sende, is gehæft
Therefore came I to your temple, and the devil, who answered you through the image, is made captive by the angels of God who sent me

And gif ðu to fulluhte gebihst, ic do þæt þu ðone deofol gesihst, and gehyrst mid hwilcum cræfte he is geðuht þæt he untrumnysse gehæle
And if thou consentest to be baptized, I will cause thee to see the devil, and to hear by what craft he appears to heal sickness

Se awyrigeda deofol, siððan he ðone frumsceapenan mann beswác, syððan he hæfde anweald on ungelyfedum mannum, on sumum maran, on sumum læssan: on ðam maran ðe swiðor syngað, on ðam læssan ðe hwonlicor syngað
The accursed devil, after that he had deceived the first-created man, had power over unbelieving men, over some greater, over some less: on those greater who sin more, on those less who sin in less degree

Nu deð se deofol mid his lotwrencum þæt ða earman men geuntrumiað, and tiht hí þæt hí sceolon gelyfan on deofolgyld: þonne geswicð he ðære gedreccednysse, and hæfð heora sawla on his anwealde
Now the devil by his wiles causes miserable men to fall sick, and instigates them to believe in an idol: then ceases he from afflicting them, and has their souls in his power

þonne hí cweðað to ðære deofollican anlicnysse, Þu eart min god
then they say to the image, Thou art my god

Ac ðes deofol, ðe binnan eowrum temple wæs, is gebunden, and ne mæg nateshwón andwyrdan ðam þe him to gebiddað
But the devil, which was within your temple, is bound, and cannot answer those who pray to him

Gif ðu wylt afandian þæt ic soð secge, ic hate hine faran into ðære anlicnysse, and ic do þæt he andet þis ylce, þæt he is gewriðen, and nane andsware syllan ne mæg
If thou wilt prove whether I speak truth, I will command him to go into the image, and I will make him confess the same, that he is bound and can give no answer

Þa andwyrde se cyning
Then the king answered

Nu to-merigen hæfð þis folc gemynt þæt hí heora lác him offrion, ðonne cume ic ðærto, þæt ic geseo ðas wunderlican dæda
Now to-morrow this folk has designed to offer him their gifts, then will I come thereto, that I may see these wonderful deeds

Witodlice on ðam oðrum dæge com se cyning mid þære burhware to ðam temple, and ða hrymde se deofol mid egeslicere stemne ðurh ða anlicnysse, and cwæð
So on the second day the king with the citizens came to the temple, and then the devil cried with terrific voice through the image, and said

Geswicað, earme, geswicað eowra offrunga, ðelæs ðe ge wyrsan pinunge ðrowion ðonne ic
Cease, ye miserable, cease your offerings, lest ye suffer worse torment than I

Ic eom gebunden mid fyrenum racenteagum fram Cristes englum, ðone ðe ða Iudeiscan on róde ahéngon: wendon þæt se deað hine gehæftan mihte
I am bound with fiery chains by the angels of Christ, whom the Jews hanged on a cross: they thought that death might hold him captive

he soðlice ðone deað oferswyðde, and urne ealdor mid fyrenum bendum gewrað, and on ðam ðriddan dæge sigefæst arás, and sealde his rode-tácen his apostolum, and tosende hí geond ealle ðeoda
but he overcame death, and bound our prince with fiery chains, and on the third day arose victorious, and gave his rood-sign to his apostles, and sent them among all nations

An ðæra is her, ðe me gebundenne hylt
One of them is here, who holds me bound

Ic bidde eow þæt ge me to him geðingion, þæt ic mote faran to sumere oðre scire
I pray you that ye intercede for me to him, that I may go to some other province

Þa cwæð se apostol Bartholomeus
Then said the apostle Bartholomew

Þu unclæna deofol, andette hwá awyrde ðas untruman menn
Thou unclean devil, confess who has afflicted these sick men

Se unclæna gast andwyrde
The unclean spirit answered

Ure ealdor, swa gebunden swa he is, sent us to mancynne, þæt we hí mid mislicum untrumnyssum awyrdon
Our prince, bound as he now is, sent us to mankind, that we might afflict them with divers infirmities

ærest heora lichaman, forðan ðe we nabbað nænne anweald on heora sawlum, buton hi heora lác us geoffrion
first their bodies, for we have no power over their souls, unless they offer us their gifts

Ac ðonne hí for heora lichaman hælðe us offriað, þonne geswice we ðæs lichaman gedreccednysse, forðan ðe we habbað syððan heora sawla on urum gewealde
But when they for their bodies' health offer to us, then cease we from afflicting the body, for we have then their souls in our power

Þonne bið geðuht swilce we hi gehælon, ðonne we geswicað þæra awyrdnyssa
Then it seems as though we heal them, when we cease from those afflictions

And menn us wurðiað for godas, þonne we soðlice deoflu sind, þæs ealdres gingran ðe Crist þæs mædenes Sunu gewrað
And men worship us for gods, while we truly are devils, disciples of the chief whom Christ, the maiden's Son, has bound

Fram ðam dæge þe his apostol Bartholomeus hider com, ic eom mid byrnendum racenteagum ðearle fornumen, and forði ic sprece ðe he me het
From the day on which his apostle Bartholomew came hither, I am grievously tormented with burning chains, and therefore I speak what he has commanded me

elles ic ne dorste on his andwerdnysse sprecan, ne furðon ure ealdor
else I durst not speak in his presence, nor even our chief

Þa cwæð se apostol
Then said the apostle

Hwi nelt ðu gehælan ðas untruman, swa swa ðin gewuna wæs
Why wilt thou not heal the sick, as thy custom was

Se sceocca andwyrde
The devil answered

Þonne we manna lichaman derigað, buton we ðære sawle derian magon, ða lichaman þurhwuniað on heora awyrdnysse
When we injure the bodies of men, unless we can injure the soul, the bodies continue in their affliction

Bartholomeus cwæð
Bartholomew said

And hú becume ge to ðære sawle awyrdnysse
And how come ye to the affliction of the soul

Se deofol andwyrde
The devil answered

Þonne hí gelyfað þæt we godas sind, and us offriað, þonne forlǽt se Ælmihtiga God hí, and we ðonne forlǽtað ðone lichaman ungebrocodne, and cepað ðære sawle þe ús to gebeah, and heo ðonne on ure anwealde bið
When they believe that we are gods, and offer to us, then the Almighty God forsakes them, and we then leave the body undiseased, and attend to the soul that has bowed to us, and which is then in our power

Þa cwæð se apostol to eallum ðam folce
Then said the apostle to all the people

Efne nu ge habbað gehyred hwilc ðes god is ðe ge wendon þæt eow gehælde
Lo, now ye have heard what sort of god this is that ye thought healed you

ac gehyrað nu ðone soðan God, eowerne Scyppend, þe on heofonum eardað
but hear now the true God your Creator, who dwells in heaven

and ne gelyfe ge heonon-forð on idele anlicnyssa: and gif ge willað þæt ic eow to Gode geðingige, and þæt ðas untruman hælðe underfon, towurpað þonne ðas anlicnysse, and tobrecað
and believe not henceforth in vain images: and if ye will that I intercede for you with God, and that these sick receive health, overthrow and break this image

Gif ge ðis doð, þonne halgige ic ðis tempel on Cristes naman, and eow ðær on-innan mid his fulluhte fram eallum synnum aðwea
If this ye do, then will I hallow this temple in the name of Christ, and therein wash you with his baptism from all sins

Þa het se cyning ða anlicnysse towurpan
The king then commanded the image to be cast down

Hwæt þæt folc ða caflice mid rapum hi bewurpon, and mid stengum awegdon
The people then promptly cast ropes about it, and plied it with poles, but they could not, for the devil, stir the image

Þa het se apostol tolysan ða rapas, and cwæð to ðam awyrgedan gaste ðe hire on sticode
Then the apostle commanded the ropes to be loosed, and said to the accursed spirit which staid in it

Gyf ðu wylle þæt ic ðe on niwelnysse ne asende, gewit of ðyssere anlicnysse, and tobrec hí, and far to westene, þær nan fugel ne flyhð, ne yrðling ne erað, ne mannes stemn ne swegð
If thou wilt that I send thee not into the abyss, depart from this image, and break it, and go to the waste, where no bird flies, nor husbandman ploughs, nor voice of man sounds

He ðærrihte út-gewát, and sticmælum tobræc ða anlicnysse, and ealle ða græftas binnon ðam temple tobrytte
He forthwith came out, and brake the image piecemeal, and crushed all the carvings within the temple

Þæt folc ða mid anre stemne clypode
The people then with one voice cried

An Ælmihtig God is, ðone ðe Bartholomeus bodað
There is one Almighty God, whom Bartholomew preaches

Se apostol ða astrehte his handa wið heofonas weard, þus biddende
The apostle then stretched out his hand towards heaven, thus praying

Þu Ælmihtiga God, on ðam ðe Abraham gelyfde, and Isaac, and Iacob
Thou Almighty God, in whom Abraham believed, and Isaac, and Jacob

þu ðe asendest ðinne ancennedan Sunu, þæt he us alysde mid his deorwurðan blode fram deofles ðeowdome, and hæfð us geworht ðe to bearnum
thou who hast sent thine only begotten Son, that he might redeem us with his precious blood from the devil's thraldom, and hath made us to be thy children

þu eart unacenned Fæder, he is Sunu of ðe æfre acenned, and se Halga Gast is æfre forðstæppende of ðe and of ðinum Bearne, se forgeaf us on his naman ðas mihte, þæt we untrume gehælon, and blinde onlihton, hreoflige geclænsian deoflu aflian, deade aræran, and cwæð to ús, Soð ic eow secge, Swa hwæt swa ge biddað on minum naman æt minum Fæder, hit bið eow getiðod
thou art the unbegotten Father, he is the Son ever of thee begotten, and the Holy Ghost is ever proceeding from thee and thy Son, who hath given us in his name this power, to heal the sick, and give light to the blind, cleanse lepers, drive out devils, raise the dead, and hath said unto us, Verily I say unto you, Whatsoever ye pray for in my name, of my Father, it shall be granted unto you

Nu bidde ic on his naman þæt þeos untrume menigu sy gehæled, þæt hi ealle oncnawon þæt ðu eart ana God on heofonan, and on eorðan, and on sǽ, þu ðe hælðe ge-edstaðelast ðurh ðone ylcan urne Drihten, seðe mid ðe and mid þam Halgan Gaste leofað and rixað on ealra worulda woruld
Now I pray in his name that this sick multitude be healed, that they all may know that thou alone art God in heaven, and on earth, and on sea, thou who restorest health through the same our Lord, who with thee and with the Holy Ghost liveth and reigneth for ever and ever

Mid þam ðe hí andwyrdon
While they were answering

Amen
Amen

þa wearð eall seo untrume menigu gehæled: and ðær com ða fleogende Godes engel scinende swa swa sunne, and fleah geond ða feower hwemmas þæs temples, and agrof mid his fingre rode-tacn on ðam fyðerscytum stánum, and cwæð
all the sick multitude was healed: and there came then flying God's angel shining as the sun, and flew over the four corners of the temple, and graved with his finger the sign of the cross on the four-cornered stones, and said

Se God ðe me sende cwæð, Þæt swa swa ðas untruman synd gehælede fram eallum coðum, swa he geclænsode þis templ fram þæs deofles fulnyssum, ðone ðe se apostol het to westene gewitan
The God who sendeth me said, That so as these sick are healed from all diseases, so hath he cleansed this temple from the devil's foulness, whom the apostle hath commanded to retire to the waste

And God bebead me þæt ic ðone deofol eowrum gesihðum ær æteowige
And God hath bidden me that I first make manifest the devil to your sights

Ne beo ge afyrhte þurh his gesihðe, ac mearciað rode-tacen on eowrum foreheafdum, and ælc yfel gewit fram eow
Be ye not afraid at the sight of him, but mark the sign of the rood on your foreheads, and every evil shall depart from you

And se engel ða æteowde þam folce ðone awyrigedan gast on ðyssere gelicnysse
And the angel then showed to the people the accursed spirit in this likeness

He wearð ða æteowod swylce ormæte Silhearwa, mid scearpum nebbe, mid sidum bearde
He appeared as an immense Ethiop, with sharp visage and ample beard

His loccas hangodon to ðam anccleowum, his eagan wæron fyrene spearcan sprengende
His locks hung to his ancles, his eyes were scattering fiery sparks

him stód swæflen líg of ðam muðe, he wæs egeslice gefiðerhamod, and his handa to his bæce gebundene
sulphureous flame stood in his mouth, he was frightfully feather-clad, and his hands were bound to his back

Þa cwæð se Godes engel to ðam atelican deofle
Then said God's angel to the hideous devil

Forðan ðe ðu wære gehyrsum ðæs apostoles hæsum, and tobræce þas deofellican anlicnysse, nu æfter his behate ic ðe unbinde, þæt þu fare to westene, þær ðær nanes mannes drohtnung nis
Because thou wast obedient to the apostle's commands, and didst break the diabolical image, now, according to his promise, I will unbind thee, that thou mayest go to the waste, there where no man's converse is

and ðu þær wunige oð þone micclan dom
and there dwell until the great doom

And se engel hine ða unband, and he mid hreowlicere wánunge aweg-gewát, and nawar siððan ne æteowde
And the angel then unbound him, and he with woful lamentation went away, and nowhere afterwards appeared

Se engel ða, him eallum onlocigendum, fleah to heofonum
The angel then, all looking on him, flew to heaven

Hwæt ða se cyning Polimius, mid his wife and his twam sunum, and mid ealre his leode, gelyfde on ðone soðan God, and wearð gefullod, and awearp his cynehelm samod mid his purpuran gyrlum, and nolde ðone Godes apostol forlætan, Æfter ðisum gesamnodon gehwylce ðwyrlice wiðercoran, and wrehton ðone cyning to his breðer Astrigem, se wæs cyning on oðrum leodscipe, and cwædon
Then the king Polymius, with his wife and his two sons, and with all his people, believed in the true God, and was baptized, and cast away his crown together with his purple garments, and would not let God's apostle depart

Þin broðer is geworden anes dryes folgere, se geagnað him ure tempel, and ure godas tobrycð
After this all the perverse and reprobate assembled, and accused the king to his brother Astryges, who was king in another country, and said

Þaða se apostol him to gelæd wæs, ða cwæð se cyning
Then was the king Astryges enraged, and sent a thousand armed soldiers, that they might bring the apostle to him bound

Hwí amyrdest ðu minne broðor mid þinum drycræfte
When the apostle was led to him, the king said

Ne amyrde ic hine, ac ic hine awende fram hæðenum gylde to ðam soðan Gode
Bartholomew answered

Hwí towurpe ðu ure godas
The king said to him

Ic sealde ða mihte ðam deoflum, þæt hí tocwysdon ða idelan anlicnysse þe hí on wunodon, þæt þæt mennisce folc fram heora gedwyldum gecyrde, and on ðone ecan God gelyfde
He answered

Swa swa ðu dydest minne broðor his god forlætan, and on ðinne god gelyfan, swa do ic eac ðe forlætan ðinne god, and on minne gelyfan
Then said the king

Ic æteowode þone god ðe ðin broðor wurðode him gebundenne, and ic het þæt he sylf his anlicnysse tobræce
Then answered the apostle

Gif ðu miht ðis dón minum Gode, þonne gebigst ðu me to ðines godes biggengum: gif ðu ðonne þis minum Gode dón ne miht, ic tobryte ealle ðine godas, and ðu ðonne gelyf on ðone soðan God þe ic bodige
The god that thy brother worshiped I showed to him bound, and I commanded that he should himself break his image

Mid þam ðe hí ðis spræcon, þa cydde sum man þam cyninge þæt his mæsta god Baldað feolle, and sticmælum toburste
While he was saying this, some man announced to the king that his greatest god Baldath had fallen, and burst asunder piecemeal

Se cyning ða totær his purpuran reaf, and het mid stiðum saglum ðone apostol beatan, and siððan beheafdian
The king then tore his purple robe, and commanded the apostle to be beaten with stiff clubs, and afterwards beheaded

And he ða on ðisum dæge swa gemartyrod to ðam ecan life gewát
And he on this day, so martyred, departed to the eternal life

Witodlice æfter ðisum com se broðor mid his folce, and ðone halgan lichaman mid wulderfullum lofsangum aweg ferodon, and getimbrodon mynster wundorlicere micelnysse, and on ðam his halgan reliquias arwurðlice gelogedon
But after this the brother came with his people and bore away the holy body with glorious hymns, and built a monastery of wondrous greatness, and in that honourably placed his holy remains

Eornostlice on ðam þrittigoðan dæge, se cyning Astriges, ðe ðone apostol ofslean het, wearð mid feondlicum gaste gegripen, and egeslice awedde: swa eac ealle ða ðwyran hæðengyldan, þe ðone apostol mid niðe to ðam cyninge gewregdon, aweddon samod mid him, and urnon hí and he to his byrgene, and ðær wedende swulton
But on the thirtieth day the king Astryges, who had commanded the apostle to be slain, was seized with a fiendlike spirit, and dreadfully became frantic: so also the perverse idolaters, who through envy had accused the apostle to the king, became frantic together with him, and they and he ran to his grave, and there raving died

Þa aspráng micel óga and gryre ofer ealle ða ungeleaffullan, and hi ða gelyfdon, and gefullode wurdon æt ðæra mæssepreosta handum, ðe se apostol ǽr gehádode
Then sprang up great dread and horror over all the unbelieving, and they then believed and were baptized at the hands of the mass-priests whom the apostle had before ordained

Þa onwreah se apostol Bartholomeus be ðam geleaffullan cyninge Polimius, þæt he biscophád underfenge
Then the apostle Bartholomew revealed respecting the believing king Polymius, that he should receive the episcopal order

and ða Godes ðeowan and þæt geleaffulle folc hine anmodlice to ðam háde gecuron
and the servants of God and the believing people chose him unanimously to that order

Hit gelamp ða, æfter ðære hádunge, þæt he worhte fela tácna on Godes naman, ðurh his geleafan, and ðurhwunode twentig geara on ðam biscopdome, and on godre drohtnunge
It happened then, after the ordination, that he wrought many miracles in the name of God through his belief, and continued twenty years in the episcopal office, and in good course of life

and fulfremedum geðincðum gewát to Drihtne, þam is wurðmynt and wuldor á on worulde
