and in full dignity departed to the Lord, to whom is honour and glory for ever and ever

We magon niman bysne be ðære apostolican lare, þæt nan cristen mann ne sceal his hæle gefeccan buton æt ðam Ælmihtigan Scyppende, ðam ðe gehyrsumiað lif and deað, untrumnys and gesundfulnys, seðe cwæð on his godspelle, þæt án lytel fugel ne befylð on deað butan Godes dihte
We may take example by the apostolic doctrine, that no christian man shall fetch his salvation save from the Almighty Creator, whom life and death, sickness and health obey, who hath said in his gospel, that a little bird falls not in death without God's direction

He is swa mihtig, þæt he ealle ðing gediht and gefadað butan geswince
He is so mighty, that he directs and orders without toil

ac he beswincgð mid untrumnyssum his gecorenan, swa swa he sylf cwæð
but he scourges his chosen with diseases, as he himself said

Þa ðe ic lufige, ða ic ðreage and beswinge
Those whom I love I chastise and scourge

For mislicum intingum beoð cristene men geuntrumode, hwilon for heora synnum, hwilon for fandunge, hwilon for Godes wundrum, hwilon for gehealdsumnysse gódra drohtnunga, þæt hí ðy eadmodran beon
For divers causes are christian men afflicted with disease, sometimes for their sins, sometimes for trial, sometimes for God's miracles, sometimes for preservation of good courses, that they may be the humbler

ac on eallum ðisum þingum is geðyld nyd-behefe
but in all these things patience is needful

Hwilon eac þurh Godes wrace becymð þam arleasan menn swiðe egeslic yfel, swa þæt his wite onginð on ðyssere worulde, and his sawul gewit to ðam ecum witum for his wælhreawnysse
Sometimes also through God's vengeance comes very dreadful evil to the impious man, so that his punishment begins in this world, and his soul departs to eternal punishments for his cruelty

swa swa Herodes ðe ða unscæððigan cild acwealde on Cristes acennednysse, and manega oðre to-eacan him
as Herod who slew the innocent children at the birth of Christ, and many others besides him

Gif se synfulla bið gebrocod for his unrihtwisnysse, þonne gif he mid geðylde his Drihten herað, and his miltsunge bitt, he bið ðonne aðwogen fram his synnum ðurh ða untrumnysse, swa swa horig hrægl þurh sapan
If the sinful be afflicted with disease for his unrighteousness, then if he with patience praise his Lord, and pray for his mercy, he shall be washed from his sins by that sickness, as a foul garment by soap

Gif he rihtwis bið, he hæfð þonne maran geðincðe þurh his brocunge, gif he geðyldig bið
If he be righteous, he shall have greater honour through his sickness, if he be patient

Se ðe bið ungeþyldig, and mid gealgum mode ceorað ongean God on his untrumnysse, he hæfð twyfealde geniðerunge, forðan ðe he geycð his synna mid þære ceorunge, and ðrowað naðelæs
He who is impatient, and with froward mind murmurs against God in his sickness, shall have double condemnation, for he increases his sins by that murmuring, and suffers nevertheless

God is se soða læce, þe ðurh mislice swingla his folces synna gehælð
God is the true leech, who by divers afflictions heals the sins of his people

Nis se woruld-læce wælhreow, ðeah ðe he þone gewundodan mid bærnette, oððe mid ceorfsexe gelácnige
The world's leech is not cruel, though he cure the wounded with burning or with the amputation-knife

Se læce cyrfð oððe bærnð, and se untruma hrymð, þeah-hwæðere ne miltsað he þæs oðres wánunge, forðan gif se læce geswicð his cræftes, þonne losað se forwundoda
The leech cuts or burns, and the patient cries, yet has he no mercy on the other's moaning, for if the leech desist from his craft, then will the wounded perish

Swa eac God gelácnað his gecorenra gyltas mid mislicum brocum
So also God cures the sins of his chosen with divers diseases

and þeah ðe hit hefigtyme sy ðam ðrowigendum, þeah-hwæðere wyle se góda Læce to ecere hælðe hine gelácnigan
and though it be wearisome to the sufferer, yet will the good Leech cure him to everlasting health

Witodlice se ðe náne brocunge for ðisum life ne ðrowað, he færð to ðrowunge
But he who suffers no sickness in this life, he goes to suffering

For agenum synnum bið se mann geuntrumod, swa swa Drihten cwæð to sumum bedridan, ðe him to geboren wæs
For his own sins a man is afflicted with disease, as the Lord said to one bedridden, who was borne to him

Min bearn, ðe synd þine synna forgifene: aris nu, and ber ham ðin leger-bed
My son, thy sins are forgiven thee: arise now, and bear home thy sick-bed

For fandunge beoð sume menn geuntrumode, swa swa wæs se eadiga Iob, ðaða he wæs rihtwis, and Gode gehyrsum
For trial are some men afflicted with disease, as was the blessed Job, when he was righteous and obedient to God

Þa bæd se deofol, þæt he his fandigan moste, and he ða anes dæges ealle his æhta amyrde, and eft hine sylfne mid þam mæstan broce geuntrumode, swa þæt him weollon maðan geond ealne ðone lichaman
Then the devil prayed that he might try him, and he in one day destroyed all his possessions, and afterwards afflicted himself with the greatest disease, so that worms rolled over all his body

Ac se geðyldiga Iob, on eallum ðisum ungelimpum, ne syngode mid his muðe, ne nan ðing stuntlices ongean God ne spræc, ac cwæð
But the patient Job, in all these calamities, sinned not with his mouth, nor spake anything foolish against God, but said

God me forgeaf ða æhta, and hí eft æt me genam
God gave me possessions, and afterwards took them from me

sy his nama gebletsod
be his name blessed

God eac ða hine gehælde, and his æhta mid twyfealdum him forgeald
God also then healed him, and restored him his possessions twofold

Sume menn beoð geuntrumode for Godes tácnum, swa swa Crist cwæð be sumum blindan men, ðaða his leorning-cnihtas hine axodon, for hwæs synnum se mann wurde swa blind acenned
Some men are afflicted for the miracles of God, as Christ said of some blind man, when his disciples asked him, for whose sins the man was thus born blind

Þa cwæð se Hælend, þæt he nære for his agenum synnum, ne for his maga, blind geboren, ac forði þæt Godes wundor þurh hine geswutelod wære
Then said Jesus, that he was born blind not for his own nor for his parents' sins, but because that God's miracles might be manifested through him

And he þærrihte mildheortlice hine gehælde, and geswutelode þæt he is soð Scyppend, ðe ða ungesceapenan eahhringas mid his halwendan spatle geopenode
And he forthwith mercifully healed him, and manifested that he is the true Creator, who opened the unshapen eye-rings with his salutary spittle

For gehealdsumnysse soðre eadmodnysse beoð forwel oft Godes gecorenan geswencte, swa swa Paulus se apostol be him sylfum cwæð
For preservation of true humility are God's chosen very often afflicted, as Paul the apostle said of himself

Me is geseald sticels mines lichaman, and se sceocca me gearplæt, þæt seo micelnys Godes onwrigenyssa me ne onhebbe
To me is given a goad of my body, and the devil buffeteth me, that the greatness of God's revelations may not exalt me

forðan ic bæd þriwa minne Drihten, þæt he afyrsode þæs sceoccan sticels fram me
for I thrice besought my Lord to remove the devil's goad from me

ac hé me andwyrde, Paule, ðe genihtsumað min gifu
but he answered me, Paul, my grace will suffice thee

Soðlice mægen bið gefremod on untrumnysse
Verily power is promoted in weakness

Nu wuldrige ic lustlice on minum untrumnyssum, þæt Cristes miht on me wunige
I now glorify joyfully in my weaknesses, that Christ's might may dwell in me

Se cristena mann ðe on ænigre þissere gelicnysse bið gebrocod, and he ðonne his hælðe secan wyle æt unalyfedum tilungum, oððe æt wyrigedum galdrum, oþþe æt ænigum wiccecræfte, ðonne bið he ðam hæðenum mannum gelíc, þe ðam deofolgylde geoffrodon for heora lichaman hælðe, and swa heora sawla amyrdon
The christian man, who in any of this like is afflicted, and he then will seek his health at unallowed practices, or at accursed enchantments, or at any witchcraft, then will he be like to those heathen men, who offered to an idol for their bodies' health, and so destroyed their souls

Se ðe geuntrumod beo, bidde his hæle æt his Drihtne, and geðyldelice þa swingla forbere
Let him who is sick pray for his health to his Lord, and patiently endure the stripes

loc hú lange se soða læce hit foresceawige, and ne beceapige na ðurh ænigne deofles cræft mid his sawle ðæs lichaman gesundfulnysse
let him behold how long the true Leech provides, and buy not, through any devil's craft, with his soul, his body's health

bidde eac góddra manna bletsunge, and æt halgum reliquium his hæle gesece
let him also ask the blessing of good men, and seek his health at holy relics

Nis nanum cristenum menn alyfed þæt he his hæle gefecce æt nanum stane, ne æt nanum treowe, buton hit sy halig rode-tacen, ne æt nanre stowe, buton hit sy halig Godes hus: se ðe elles deð, he begæð untwylice hæðengild
It is not allowed to any christian man to fetch his health from any stone, nor from any tree, unless it be the holy sign of the rood, nor from any place, unless it be the holy house of God: he who does otherwise, undoubtedly commits idolatry

We habbað hwæðere þa bysne on halgum bocum, þæt mot se ðe wile mid soðum læcecræfte his lichaman getemprian, swa swa dyde se wítega Isaias, þe worhte ðam cyninge Ezechie cliðan to his dolge, and hine gelácnode
We have, nevertheless, examples in holy books, that he who will may cure his body with true leechcraft, as the prophet Isaiah did, who wrought for the king Hezekiah a plaster for his sore, and cured him

Se wisa Augustinus cwæð, þæt unpleolic sy þeah hwá læce-wyrte ðicge
The wise Augustine said, that it is not perilous, though any one eat a medicinal herb

ac þæt hé tælð to unalyfedlicere wíglunge, gif hwá ða wyrta on him becnitte, buton he hí to ðam dolge gelecge
but he reprehends it as an unallowed charm, if any one bind those herbs on himself, unless he lay them on a sore

Þeah-hwæðere ne sceole we urne hiht on læce-wyrtum besettan, ac on ðone Ælmihtigan Scyppend, þe ðam wyrtum ðone cræft forgeaf
Nevertheless we should not set our hope in medicinal herbs, but in the Almighty Creator, who has given that virtue to those herbs

Ne sceal nan man mid galdre wyrte besingan, ac mid Godes wordum hí gebletsian, and swa ðicgan
No man shall enchant a herb with magic, but with God's words shall bless it, and so eat it

Wite ðeah-hwæðere gehwá, þæt nan man butan earfoðnyssum ne becymð to ðære ecan reste, þaða Crist sylf nolde his agen rice butan micelre earfoðnysse astigan: swa eac his apostoli, and ða halgan martyras mid heora agenum feore þæt heofonlice rice beceapodon: syððan eac halige andetteras, mid micelre drohtnunge on Godes ðeowdome, and þurh miccle forhæfednyssa and clænnysse, halige wurdon
Let every one, however, know, that no man comes to the eternal rest without tribulations, when Christ himself would not ascend to his own kingdom without great tribulation: so also his apostles, and the holy martyrs with their own lives bought the heavenly kingdom: afterwards also holy confessors with great perseverance in God's service, and through great privations and chastity became holy

Hwæt wylle we endemenn ðyssere worulde, gif we for urum synnum gebrocode beoð, buton herian urne Drihten, and eadmodlice biddan, þæt he us þurh ða hwilwendlican swingla to ðam ecan gefean gelæde
What shall we, the end-men of this world, desire, if for our sins we are with sickness afflicted, but to praise our Lord, and humbly pray that he through transient stripes lead us to everlasting joy

Sy him wuldor and lof on ealra worulda woruld
To him be glory and praise for ever and ever

Amen
Amen

Marcus se Godspellere awrát on Cristes béc be ðam mæran Fulluhtere Iohanne, þæt
Mark the Evangelist wrote in the book of Christ concerning the great Baptist John, that

se wælhreowa cyning Herodes hine gehæfte, and on cwearterne sette, for his broðor wife Herodiaden
the cruel king Herod bound him, and set him in prison, for the sake of his brother's wife Herodias

et reliqua
etc

Þes Iohannes wæs se mærosta mann, swa swa Crist be him cyðnysse gecydde
This John was the greatest man, as Christ bore witness concerning him

He cwæð
He said

Betwux wifa bearnum ne arás nán mærra man þonne Iohannes se Fulluhtere
Among the children of women there hath not arisen any greater man than John the Baptist

Nu hæbbe ge oft gehyred be his mæran drohtnunge and be his ðenunge, nu wylle we embe ðises godspelles trahtnunge sume swutelunge eow gereccan
Now ye have often heard of his great course and of his ministry, now we will relate to you some explanation touching the exposition of this gospel

Þes Herodes, ðe Iohannem beheafdian hét, and on ðæs Hælendes ðrowunge Pilate ðam ealdormenn geðafode, and hine to his dome betæhte, wæs ðæs oðres Herodes sunu, ðe on ðam timan rixode ðe Crist geboren wæs
This Herod, who commanded John to be beheaded, and agreed with Pilate the ealdorman in the suffering of Jesus, and delivered him to his judgement, was the son of the other Herod, who reigned at the time when Christ was born

ac hit wæs swa gewunelic on ðam timan þæt rice menn sceopon heora bearnum naman be him sylfum, þæt hit wære geðuht þæs ðe mare gemynd þæs fæder, ðaða se sunu, his yrfenuma, wæs geciged þæs fæder naman
for it was usual at that time for rich men to give their children names after themselves, that it might seem the greater remembrance of the father, when the son, his heir, was called by his father's name

Se wælhreowa fæder Herodes læfde fif suna, þry he hét acwellan on his feorh-adle, ærðan ðe he gewite
The cruel father, Herod, left five sons

Þa wearð he hreowlice and hrædlice dead æfter ðam ðe he ða cild acwealde for Cristes acennednysse
three he commanded to be slain in his last illness, ere he departed

Þa feng Archelaus his sunu to rice
Then he died miserably and suddenly after he had slain the children on account of the birth of Christ

Ða embe tyn geara fyrst wearð hé ascofen of his cynesetle, forðan þe þæt Iudeisce folc wrehton his modignysse to ðam casere, and he ða hine on wræcsið asende
when Archelaus his son succeeded to the kingdom

Þa dælde se casere þæt Iudeisce rice on feower, and sette ðærto feower gebroðra: ða sind gecwedene æfter Greciscum gereorde, tetrarche, þæt sind, fyðerrican
Then after a space of ten years he was driven from his throne, because the Jewish people complained of his pride to the emperor, and he then sent him into exile

Fyðerrica bið se ðe hæfð feorðan dæl rices
The emperor then divided the Jewish kingdom into four, and placed therein four brothers, who, according to the Greek tongue, are called 'tetrarchs,' that is, rulers over a fourth

Þa wæs án ðyssera gebroðra Philippus geháten, se gewifode on ðæs cyninges dehter Arethe, Arabiscre ðeode, seo hatte Herodias
A tetrarch is he who has a fourth part of a kingdom

Þa æfter sumum fyrste wurdon hí ungesome, Philippus and Arethe, and he genam ða dohtor of his aðumme, and forgeaf hí his breðer Herode
One of these brothers was called Philip, who took to wife the daughter of the king Arethe, of an Arabian people, who was called Herodias

forðan ðe he wæs furðor on hlisan and on mihte
Then after some time they, Philip and Arethe, were at variance, and he took his daughter from his son-in-law, and gave her to his brother Herod

Herodes ða awearp his riht æwe, and forligerlice mánfulles sinscipes breac
because he was greater in fame and in power

Þa on ðam timan bodade Iohannes se Fulluhtere Godes rihtwisnysse eallum Iudeiscum folce, and þreade ðone Herodem, for ðam fulan sinscipe
Then at that time John the Baptist preached God's righteousness to all the Jewish people, and reproved Herod for that foul union

Aecclesiastica historia ita narrat: Þa geseah Herodes þæt eal seo Iudeisce meniu arn to Iohannes lare, and his mynegungum geornlice gehyrsumodon, þa wearð hé afyrht, and wende þæt hí woldon for Iohannes lare his cynedom forseon, and wolde ða forhradian, and gebrohte hine on cwearterne on anre byrig þe is gecweden Macherunta
Ecclesiastica Historia ita narrat: When Herod saw that all the Jewish multitude ran to John's teaching, and zealously obeyed his admonitions, he was afraid, and imagined that through John's teaching they would despise his government, and would anticipate them, and brought him into prison in a town which is called Machæruntia

Hwæt ða Iohannes asende of ðam cwearterne twegen leorning-cnihtas to Criste, and hine befrán, þus cweðende
John sent then two disciples from the prison to Christ, and inquired of him, thus saying

Eart ðu se ðe toweard is, oþþe we oðres andbidian sceolon
Art thou he who is to come, or are we to await another

Swilce hé cwæde, Geswutela me, gyf ðu sylf wylle nyðer-astigan to hellwarum for manna alysednysse, swa swa ðu woldest acenned beon for manna alysednysse
As though he had said, Manifest to me whether thou thyself wilt descend to the inmates of hell for the redemption of men, as I have preached to the world that thou wast to come,—manifest

oððe gif ic sceole cyðan ðinne to-cyme hellwarum, swa swa ic middangearde þe toweardne bodade, geswutela
Jesus then, at the same time as the evangelist Luke wrote, was healing many sick from divers diseases, and giving reason to insane men, and sight to the blind, and said then to John's messengers

Hwæt ða se Hælend on ðære ylcan tide, swa swa Lucas se godspellere awrát, gehælde manega untruman fram mislicum coðum, and wodum mannum gewitt forgeaf, and blindum gesihðe
Go now to John, and make known to him the things which ye have seen and heard

and cwæð syððan to Iohannes ærendracum
Behold now blind see, and the halt go, and lepers are cleansed, deaf hear, and the dead arise, and poor preach the gospel

Farað nu to Iohanne, and cyðað him þa ðing þe ge gesawon and gehyrdon
and he is happy who shall not be offended in me

and se bið eadig þe on me ne bið geæswicod
As though he had said to John, Such wonders I work, and yet will I perish by death for the redemption of mankind, and follow thee dying, and happy shall he be who now praiseth my wonders, if he despise not my death, and on account of that death doubt not that I am God

Þa betwux ðisum gelamp þæt Herodes, swa we ǽr cwædon, his witan gefeormode on ðam dæge þe he geboren wæs
Then meanwhile it befell that Herod, as we before said, feasted his councillors on the day on which he was born

forðan ðe hi hæfdon on ðam timan micele blisse on heora gebyrd-tidum
for at that time they had great rejoicing on their birth-tides

Seo dohtor ða, swa swa we ǽr sædon, plegode mid hire mædenum on ðam gebeorscipe, him eallum to gecwemednysse, and se fæder ða mid aðe behét, þæt he wolde hire forgyfan swa hwæs swa heo gewilnode
The daughter then, as we before said, played with her maidens at the feast, to the pleasure of them all, and the father then promised on oath that he would give her whatsoever she desired

Þreo arleasa scylda we gehyrdon,—ungesælige mærsunge his gebyrd-tide, and ða unstæððigan hleapunge þæs mædenes, and ðæs fæder dyrstigan aðsware
Of three impious sins we have heard,—the unholy celebration of his birth-tide, and the giddy dancing of the maiden, and the father's presumptuous oath

Þam ðrim ðingum us gedafenað þæt we wiðcweðon on urum ðeawum
These three things it befitteth us to oppose in our conduct

We ne moton ure gebyrd-tide to nanum freols-dæge mid idelum mærsungum awendan, ne ure acennednysse on swilcum gemynde habban
We may not with vain celebrations turn our birth-tide to any holyday, nor have our birth in such remembrance

ac we sceolon urne endenextan dæg mid behreowsunge and dǽdbote forhradian, swa swa hit awriten is
but we should anticipate our last day with penitence and penance, so as it is written

On eallum ðingum beo ðu gemyndig þines endenextan dæges, and þu ne syngast on ecnysse
In all things be thou mindful of thy last day, and thou wilt sin not to eternity

Ne ús ne gedafenað þæt we urne lichaman, ðe Gode is gehalgod on ðam halwendan fulluhte, mid unþæslicum plegan and higleaste gescyndan
It is not fitting to us to pollute our body, which is hallowed to God in the salutary baptism, with indecent and foolish play

forðan ðe ure lichaman sind Godes lima, swa swa Paulus cwæð
for our bodies are limbs of God, as St

And he bebead, þæt we sceolon gearcian ure lichaman líflice onsægednysse, and halige, and Gode andfenge
Paul said

God sylf forbyt ælcne að cristenum mannum, þus cweðende
The body is a living sacrifice which is shielded against deadly sins, and through holy virtues is acceptable to God and holy

Ne swera ðu þurh heofenan, forðan ðe heo is Godes þrymsetl
God himself forbids every oath to christian men, thus saying

Ne swera ðu þurh eorðan, forðan ðe heo is Godes fotsceamol
Swear thou not by heaven, for it is God's throne

Ne swera þu ðurh ðin agen heafod, forðan ðe ðu ne miht wyrcan an hǽr þines feaxes hwít oððe blacc
Swear thou not by earth, for it is God's footstool

Ic secge eow, Ne swerige ge þurh nan þing, ac beo eower spræc ðus geendod, Hit is swa ic secge, oþþe hit nis swa
Swear thou not by thine own head, for thou canst not make one hair of thy locks white or black

Swa hwæt swa ðær mare bið þurh að, þæt bið of ðam yfelan
I say unto you, swear ye not by anything, but be your speech thus ended, It is as I say, or it is not so

Crist sylf gefæstnode his spræce, þaða hé spræc to anum Samaritaniscan wífe mid ðisum worde
Christ himself confirmed his speech, when he spake to a Samaritan woman with these words

Crede mihi
Crede mihi

þæt is
that is

Gelyf me
Believe me

Þeah-hwæðere gif we hwær unwærlice swerion, and se að ús geneadige to wyrsan dæde, þonne bið us rǽdlicor þæt we ðone maran gylt forbugon, and ðone að wið God gebétan
Yet if we anywhere heedlessly swear, and the oath compel us to a worse deed, then will it be more advisable for us to avoid the greater guilt, and atone to God for the oath

Witodlice Dauid swor þurh God þæt he wolde þone stuntan wer Nabal ofslean, and ealle his ðing adylegian
David, for example, swore by God that he would slay the foolish man Nabal, and destroy all his things

ac æt ðære forman þingunge þæs snoteran wifes Abigail, hé awende his swúrd into ðære sceaðe, and hérode ðæs wifes snoternysse, ðe him forwyrnde þone pleolican mannsliht
but at the first intercession of the prudent woman Abigail, he returned his sword into the sheath, and praised the woman's prudence, who forbade him that perilous murder

Herodes swór þurh stuntnysse þæt he wolde ðære hleapendan dehter forgyfan swa hwæt swa heo bæde: þa forðam ðe he nolde fram his gebeorum beon gecweden mánswara, ðone beorscipe mid blode gemencgde, and ðæs mæran witegan deað þære lyðran hoppystran hire glíges to mede forgeaf
Herod through folly swore that he would give the dancing daughter whatsoever she might ask: then, because he would not be called a perjurer by his guests, he stained the feast with blood, and gave the death of the great prophet to the lewd dancer in reward of her play

Micele selre him wære þæt he ðone að tobræce, þonne he swylcne witegan acwellan hete
Much better for him had it been to have broken the oath, than to have commanded such a prophet to be slain

On eallum ðingum we sceolon carfullice hógian, gif we awar, þurh deofles syrwunge, on twam frecednyssum samod befeallað, þæt we symle ðone maran gylt forfleon þurh útfære þæs læssan, swa swa deð se ðe his feondum ofer sumne weall ætfleon wile, ðonne cepð hé hwær se weall unhehst sy, and ðær oferscyt
In all things we should carefully consider, if we anywhere, through the devil's machinations, fall at once into two perils, that we always flee from the greater guilt by the outlet of the less, as he does who will flee from his foes over a wall, then observes he where the wall is lowest, and there darts over

Witodlice Herodes, ðaðe he nolde, þurh Iohannes mynegunge, þone unclænan sinscipe awendan, ða wearð hé to manslihte befeallen
But Herod, when he would not, through John's remonstrance, turn from the unclean connexion, fell into murder, and the smaller sin was the cause of the greater, so that he for his foul adultery, which he well knew was hateful to God, shed the prophet's blood, who he knew was acceptable to God

and wæs seo læsse synn intinga þære maran, þæt he for his fulan forlígre, ðe he georne wiste þæt Gode andsæte wæs, ðæs wítegan blod ageat, þe he wiste þæt Gode gecweme wæs
This is the sentence of the divine judgement, by which it is said

Þis is se cwyde þæs godcundlican domes, be ðam þe is gecweden
Let him who injureth, injure yet more

Se ðe derað, derige he gyt swyðor
and let him who liveth in foulness, defile himself yet more

Þes cwyde gelamp þam wælhreowan Herode
Now there is another sentence shortly said concerning good men

Nu is oðer cwyde be gódum mannum sceortlice gecweden
Let him who is holy be yet more hallowed

Þis gelamp þam Fulluhtere Iohanne, se ðe wæs halig þurh menigfealde geearnunga
and was yet more hallowed, when he through the preaching of truth came to triumphant martyrdom

Herodes híwode hine sylfne unrótne, ða seo dohtor hine þæs heafdes bæd
Herod feigned himself sad, when the daughter prayed him for the head

ac hé blissode on his digelnyssum, forðan ðe heo þæs mannes deað bæd ðe hé ǽr acwellan wolde, gif hé intingan hæfde
but he rejoiced in secret, because she prayed for the death of that man whom he would before have slain, if he had had a pretext

Witodlice gif þæt cild bǽde þæs wífes heafod, mid micclum graman hé wolde hire wiðcweðan
But if the child had prayed for the woman's head, he would with great anger have refused her

Næs Iohannes mid ehtnysse geneadod þæt he Criste wiðsoce, ac ðeah he sealde his líf for Criste, ðaða he wæs for soðfæstnysse gemartyrod
John was not by persecution compelled to deny Christ, but, nevertheless, he gave his life for Christ, when he was martyred for truth

Crist sylf cwæð
Christ himself said

Ic eom soðfæstnys
I am the truth

Iohannes wæs Cristes forrynel on his acennednysse and on his bodunge, on fulluhte, on ðrowunge, and hine to hellwarum mid deorwurðum deaðe forestóp
John was Christ's forerunner in his birth, and in his preaching, in baptism, in suffering, and in his precious death preceded him to hell

Þaða he beheafdod wæs, ða comon his leorning-cnihtas, and his halige líc ferodon to anre byrig seo is gecweden Sebaste, and hi ðær hine gelédon
When he was beheaded, his disciples came, and bare his holy body to a city which is called Sebastia, and they laid him there

Þæt hálige heafod wearð on Hierusalem bebyrged
The holy head was buried at Jerusalem

Sume gedwolmenn cwædon þæt þæt heafod sceolde abláwan ðæs cyninges wíf Herodiaden, ðe he fore acweald wæs, swa þæt heo ferde mid windum geond ealle woruld
Some heretics said that the head blew the king's wife Herodias, for whom he had been slain, so that she went with winds over all the world

ac hí dwelodon mid þære segene, forðan ðe heo leofode hire líf oð ende æfter Iohannes slege
but they erred in that saying, for she lived to the end of her life after the slaying of John

Soðlice Iohannes heafod wearð syððan geswutelod twam easternum munecum, þe mid gebedum ða burh geneosodon, and hi ðanon þone deorwurðan maðm feredon to sumere byrig þe is Edissa geháten
But John's head was afterwards manifested to two eastern monks, who with prayers visited that city, and they bare the precious treasure thence to a city which is called Edessa

and se Ælmihtiga God þurh þæt heafod ungerime wundra geswutelode
and the Almighty God, through that head, manifested innumerable miracles

His bán, æfter langum fyrste, wurdon gebrohte to ðære mæran byrig Alexandria, and þær mid micclum wurðmynte gelogode
His bones after a long time were brought to the great city of Alexandria, and there with great honour deposited

Nu is to besceawigenne húmeta se Ælmihtiga God, be his gecorenan and ða gelufedan ðenas, þa ðe he to ðam ecan life forestihte, geðafað þæt hí mid swa micclum witum beon fornumene and tobrytte on ðisum andweardan lífe
Now it is to be considered why the Almighty God allows that his chosen and his beloved servants, whom he has predestined to eternal life, be destroyed with so many pains, and broken in this present life

Ac se apostol Paulus andwyrde be ðisum, and cwæð, þæt
But the apostle Paul has answered concerning this, and said, that

God þreað and beswingð ælcne ðe he underfehð to his rice, and swa hé forsewenlicor bið gewitnod for Godes naman, swa his wuldor bið mare for Gode
God correcteth and chastiseth every one whom he receiveth into his kingdom, and the more ignominiously he is tortured for the name of God, so much shall his glory be greater before God

Eft cwæð se ylca apostol on oðre stowe
Again, the same apostle said in another place

Ne sind na to wiðmetenne ða þrowunga þyssere tide ðam toweardan wuldre þe bið on ús geswutelod
The sufferings of this life are not to be compared with the future glory which will be manifested in us

Nu cwyð se trahtnere, þæt nán wilde deor, ne on fyðerfotum ne on creopendum, nis to wiðmetenne yfelum wife
Now says the expositor, that no wild beast, neither among the four-footed nor the creeping, is to be compared with an evil woman

Hwæt is betwux fyðerfotum reðre þonne leo
What among the four-footed is fiercer than a lion

oððe hwæt is wælhreowre betwux næddercynne ðonne draca
or what among the serpent-kind is more cruel than a dragon

Ac se wisa Salomon cwæð, þæt selre wære to wunigenne mid leon and dracan þonne mid yfelan wífe and oferspræcum
But the wise Solomon said, that it were better to dwell with lion and dragon than with an evil and loquacious woman

Witodlice Iohannes on westene wunade betwux eallum deorcynne ungederod, and betwux dracum, and aspidum, and eallum wyrmcynne, and hí hine ondredon
Now John had dwelt in the waste unhurt among all the beast-kind, and among serpents, and asps, and all the worm-kind, and they dreaded him

Soðlice seo awyrigede Herodias mid beheafdunge hine acwealde, and swa mǽres mannes deað to gife hire dehter hleapunge underfeng
But the accursed Herodias slew him by beheading, and received the death of so great a man as a gift for her daughter's dancing

Danihel se witega læg seofan niht betwux seofan leonum on anum seaðe ungewemmed, ac þæt awyrigede wíf Gezabel beswác ðone rihtwisan Naboð to his feore, þurh lease gewitnysse
Daniel the prophet lay seven nights among seven lions in one den uninjured, but the accursed woman Jezabel betrayed the righteous Naboth to his death by false witness

Se witega Ionas wæs gehealden unformolten on ðæs hwæles innoðe ðreo niht, and seo swicole Dalila þone strangan Samson mid olæcunge bepæhte, and besceorenum fexe his feondum belæwde
The prophet Jonah was preserved unconsumed in the belly of the whale for three nights, and the treacherous Dalila deceived the strong Samson with flattery, and, his locks being shorn, betrayed him to his foes

Eornostlice nis nan wyrmcynn ne wilddeora cynn on yfelnysse gelíc yfelum wífe
Verily there is no worm-kind nor wild beast-kind like in evilness to an evil woman

Se wyrdwritere Iosephus awrát, on ðære cyrclican gereccednysse, þæt se wælhreowa Herodes lytle hwile æfter Iohannes deaðe rices weolde, ac wearð for his mándædum ærest his here on gefeohte ofslegen, and he sylf siððan of his cynerice ascofen, and on wræcsið asend, swiðe rihtwisum dome, ðaða he nolde hlystan Iohannes láre to ðam ecan life, þæt hé eac hrædlice his hwilwendan cynedom mid hospe forlure
The historian Josephus wrote in the ecclesiastical history, that the cruel Herod, a little while after the death of John, ruled his kingdom, but first for his wicked deeds his army was slain in battle, and himself afterwards driven from his kingdom, and sent into exile, by a very righteous judgement, when he would not listen to John's exhortations to eternal life, that he suddenly with disgrace should lose his transitory kingdom

Augustinus se wisa ús manað mid þisum wordum, and cwyð
The wise Augustine exhorts us with these words, and says

Besceawiað, ic bidde eow, mine gebroðra, mid gleawnysse hú wræcfull ðis andwyrde líf is
Consider, I pray you, my brethren, with understanding, how wretched is this present life, and yet ye dread leaving it too speedily

and ðeah ge ondrædað eow þæt ge hit to hrædlice forlæton
Ye love this life in which ye exist with toil

Ge lufiað þis líf, on ðam þe ge mid geswince wuniað
thou carest about thy need

ðu hógast embe ðine neode
thou runnest, and art filled with anxiety

ðu yrnst, and byst geancsumod
thou ploughest, and sowest, and afterwards gatherest

þu erast, and sæwst, and eft gegaderast
thou grindest, and bakest

þu grinst, and bæcst
thou weavest and preparest garments, and hardly knowest the number of all thy needs, both on sea and on land, and shalt end all these aforesaid things, and also thy life with tribulation

þu wyfst, and wæda tylast, and earfoðlice wast ealra ðinra neoda getel, ægðer ge on sǽ ge on lande, and scealt ealle þas foresædan ðing, and eac ðin agen líf mid earfoðnysse geendian
Learn now, therefore, that ye may be able to earn the eternal life, in which ye will suffer none of these toils, but with God will reign to eternity

On ðisum lífe we ateoriað, gif we ús mid bígleofan ne ferciað
In this life we faint, if we sustain not ourselves with food

gif we ne drincað, we beoð mid þurste fornumene
if we drink not, we are destroyed by thirst

gif we to lange waciað, we ateoriað
if we watch too long, we faint

gif we lange standað, we beoð gewæhte, and þonne sittað
if we stand long, we are fatigued, and then sit

eft, gif we to lange sittað, ús slapað ða lima
again, if we sit too long, our limbs sleep

Sceawiað eac æfter ðisum, þæt nán stede nis ures lichaman: cildhád gewit to cnihtháde, and cnihthád to geðungenum wæstme
Consider also after this, that there is no stability of our body: childhood passes to boyhood, and boyhood to full growth

se fulfremeda wæstm gebyhð to ylde, and seo yld bið mid deaðe geendod
full growth bows to age, and age is ended by death

Witodlice ne stent ure yld on nanre staþolfæstnysse, ac swa micclum swa se lichama wext swa micclum beoð his dagas gewanode
Verily our age stands on no stability, but so much as the body grows so greatly are its days diminished

Gehwær is on urum lífe ateorung, and werignys, and brosnung ðæs lichaman, and ðeah-hwæðere wilnað gehwá þæt he lange lybbe
Everywhere in our life are faintness and weariness, and decay of the body, and yet every one desires that he may live long

Hwæt is lange lybban buton lange swincan
What is to live long but long to toil

Feawum mannum gelimpð on ðisum dagum, þæt he gesundfull lybbe hund-eahtatig geara, and swa hwæt swa he ofer ðam leofað, hit bið him geswinc and sárnyss, swa swa se wítega cwæð
It happens to few men in these days to live eighty years in health, and whatsoever he lives over that, it is toil to him and pain, as the prophet said

Yfele sind ure dagas
Evil are our days

and ðæs þe wyrsan þe we hí lufiað
and the worse that we love them

Swa olæcð þes middangeard forwel menige, þæt hí nellað heora wræcfulle líf geendian
So this world flatters very many, that they are unwilling to end this life of exile

Soð líf and gesælig þæt is, þonne we arisað of deaðe, and mid Criste rixiað
A true and blessed life it will be, when we from death arise and reign with Christ

On ðam life beoð gode dagas, na swa-ðeah manega dagas, ac án, se nát nænne upspring ne nane geendunge, ðam ne fyligð merigenlic dæg, forðan ðe him ne forestóp se gysternlica
In that life will be good days, yet not many days, but one, which knows no rise nor no ending, which no tomorrow follows, because no yesterday preceded it

ac se án dæg bið ece æfre ungeendod butan ælcere nihte, butan gedreccednyssum, butan eallum geswincum, þe we hwene ǽr on ðyssere rædinge tealdon
but the one day will for ever be unended without any night, without afflictions, without all the toils, which we a little before in this lecture recounted

Þes dæg and þis líf is beháten rihtwisum cristenum, to ðam us gelæde se mildheorta Drihten, seðe leofað and rixað mid Fæder and mid Halgum Gaste á butan ende
This day and this life are promised to righteous christians, to whom may the merciful Lord lead us, who liveth and reigneth with the Father and the Holy Ghost ever without end

Amen
Amen

Ure Drihten ferde to sumere byrig seo is geháten Naim, and his gingran samod, and genihtsum menigu
Our Lord went to a city which is called Nain, and his disciples with him, and a copious multitude

Þaða he genealæhte þam port-geate, þa ferede man anes cnihtes líc to byrgene: et reliqua
When he approached the port-gate, the corpse of a young man was borne to the grave, etc

Beda se trahtnere cwæð, þæt seo burh Naim is gereht, 'yðung' oððe 'styrung
Beda the expositor said, that the city of Nain is interpreted 'inundation' or 'agitation

' Se deada cniht, ðe on manegra manna gesihðe wæs geferod, getácnað gehwylcne synfulne mannan þe bið mid healicum leahtrum on ðam inran menn adydd, and bið his yfelnys mannum cuð
' The dead youth, who was borne in sight of many men, betokens every sinful man who in the inward man is fordone with deadly sins, and his evilness is known to men

Se cniht wæs áncenned sunu his meder, swa bið eac gehwilc cristen man gastlice ðære halgan gelaðunge sunu, seo is ure ealra modor, and ðeah-hwæðere ungewemmed mæden
The youth was the only-born son of his mother, so is also every christian man spiritually a son of the holy church, which is the mother of us all, and, nevertheless, an undefiled maiden

forðan ðe hire team nis ná lichamlic ac gastlic
for her family is not bodily but spiritual

Gehwilc Godes ðeow, þonne he leornað, he bið bearn gecweden: eft, þonne he oðerne lærð, he bið modor, swa swa se apostol Paulus be ðam aslidenum mannum cwæð
Every servant of God, when he learns, is called a child: afterwards, when he teaches another, he is a mother, as the apostle Paul said of the fallen men

Ge synd mine bearn, ða ðe ic nu oðre siðe geeacnige, oðþæt Crist beo on eow geedníwod
Ye are my children, whom I now a second time conceive, until Christ is renewed in you

Þæt port-geat getácnað sum lichamlic andgit þe menn ðurh syngiað
The port-gate betokens some bodily sense through which men sin

Se mann ðe tosæwð ungeþwærnysse betwux cristenum mannum, oððe seðe sprecð unrihtwisnysse on heannysse ðurh his muðes geat, he bið dead geferod
The man that sows dissension among christian men, or who speaks unrighteousness in high places through his mouth's gate, he is borne dead

Se ðe behylt wimman mid galre gesihðe and fulum luste, ðurh his eagena geat, hé geswutelað his sawle deað
He who beholds a woman with libidinous eye and foul lust, through his eyes' gate, manifests his soul's death

Se ðe idele spellunge, oððe tállice word lustlice gehyrð, þonne macað hé his eare him sylfum to deaðes geate
He who with delight hears idle discourse or contumelious words, makes his ear a gate of death to himself

Swa is eac be ðam oðrum andgitum to understandenne
So is it also to be understood of the other senses

Se Hælend wearð astyred mid mildheortnysse ofer ðære meder, þæt he us bysene sealde his arfæstnysse
Jesus was moved with compassion for the mother, that he might give us an example of his piety

and he ðone deadan syððan arærde, þæt he us to his geleafan getrymede
and he afterwards raised the dead, that he might confirm us to his faith

He genealæhte and hreopode þa bǽre, and þa bǽrmenn ætstodon
He approached and touched the bier, and the biermen stood still

Seo bǽr ðe þone deadan ferode is þæt orsorge ingehyd þæs orwenan synfullan
The bier which bare the dead is the heedless mind of the hopeless sinful

Soðlice ða byrðeras, ðe hine to byrgenne feredon, synd olæcunga lyffetyndra geferena, þe mid olæcunge and geættredum swæsnyssum þone synfullan tihtað and heriað, swa swa se wítega cwæð
But the bearers, who bare him to the grave, are the blandishments of flattering companions, who with blandishment and envenomed suavities stimulate and praise the sinful, as the prophet said

Se synfulla bið geherod on his lustum, and se unrihtwisa bið gebletsod: þonne he bið mid idelum hlisan and lyffetungum befángen, þonne bið hit swylce he sy mid sumere mold-hypan ofhroren
The sinful is praised in his lusts, and the unrighteous is blessed: when he is surrounded by empty fame and flatteries, then is it as though he were overwhelmed by a mould-heap

Be swylcum cwæð se Hælend to ánum his gecorenan, ðaða hé wolde his fæder líc bebyrian: he cwæð
Of such Jesus said to one of his chosen, when he would bury his father's corpse: he said

Geðafa þæt ða deadan bebyrion heora deadan: far ðu, and boda Godes rice
Allow the dead to bury their dead: go thou, and preach God's kingdom

Witodlice ða deadan bebyriað oðre deadan, þonne gehwilce synfulle menn oðre heora gelícan mid derigendlicere herunge geólæcað, and mid gegaderodum hefe þære wyrstan lyffetunge ofðriccað
Verily the dead bury other dead, when sinful men court others their like with pernicious praise, and oppress with the accumulated weight of the worst flattery

Be swylcum is gecweden on oðre stowe
Of such it is said in another place

Lyffetyndra tungan gewriðað manna sawla on synnum
The tongues of flatterers bind the souls of men in sins

Mid þam ðe Drihten hrepode ða bære, ða ætstodon þa bǽrmenn
When the Lord touched the bier, the biermen stood still

Swa eac, gif ðæs synfullan ingehyd bið gehrepod mid fyrhte þæs upplican domes, þonne wiðhæfð he ðam unlustum and ðam leasum lyffeterum, and clypigendum Drihtne to ðam ecan life cáflice geandwyrt, swylce he of deaðe arise
So also, if the mind of the sinful is touched by fear of the heavenly doom, then he withstands evil lusts and false flatteries, and to the Lord calling to eternal life promptly answers, as if he had arisen from death

Drihten cwæð to ðam cnihte
The Lord said to the youth

Ic secge ðe, Aris, and he ðærrihte gesǽt and spræc, and se Hælend betæhte hine his meder
I say unto thee, Arise

He sprecð, þonne he mid Godes herungum his muð gebysgað, and mid soðre andetnysse Godes mildheortnysse secþ
The requickened sits, when the sinful with divine stimulation quickens

He bið his meder betæht, þonne he bið þurh sacerda ealdordóm gemǽnscipe ðære halgan gelaðunge geferlæht
He speaks, when he employs his mouth with God's praises, and with true confession seeks God's mercy

Þæt folc wearð mid micclum ege ablicged
He is delivered to his mother, when through the priest's authority he is associated in communion of the holy church

forðan swa swa mann fram marum synnum gecyrð to Godes mildheortnysse, and his ðeawas æfter Godes bebodum gerihtlæcð, swa má manna beoð gecyrrede ðurh his gebysnunge to Godes herunge
The folk was astonished with great awe

Þæt folc cwæð þæt mære witega arás betwux ús, and þæt God his folc geneosode
The folk said

Soð hí sædon be Criste, þæt he mære witega is
That a great prophet hath arisen among us

ac he is witegena Witega, and heora ealra witegung
and

forðan ðe ealle be him witegodon, and he ðurh his to-cyme heora ealra witegunge gefylde
That God hath visited his folk

We rædað gehwær on bocum, þæt se Hælend fela deade to lífe arærde, ac ðeah-hwæðere nis nán godspell gesett be heora nanum buton ðrim anum
We read everywhere in books, that Jesus raised many dead to life, but yet there is no gospel composed of any of them save three only

An is þes cniht þe we nu embe spræcon, oðer wæs anes ealdormannes dohtor, þridde wæs Lazarus, Marthan broðer and Marian
One is the youth of whom we have just spoken, the second was an ealdorman's daughter, the third was Lazarus, the brother of Martha and Mary

Þyssera ðreora manna ærist getácnað þæt ðryfealde ærist synfullra sawla
The resurrection of these three persons betokens the threefold resurrection of sinful souls

Þære sawle deað is þreora cynna: án is yfel geðafung, oðer is yfel weorc, ðridda is yfel gewuna
The soul's death is of three kinds: one is evil assent, the second is evil work, the third is evil habit

Ðæs ealdormannes dohtor læig æt forðsiðe, and se fæder gelaðode ðone Hælend þærto, forðan ðe he wæs on ðam timan þær on neawiste
The ealdorman's daughter lay at the point of death, and the father called Jesus thereto, because he was at that time there in the neighbourhood

Heo ða forðferde ærðan ðe he hire to come
She had departed before he came to her

Þaða he com, ða genam hé hí be ðære hánda, and cwæð
When he came, he took her by the hand, and said

Þu mæden, ic secge ðe, Arís
Thou maiden, I say unto thee, Arise

And heo ðærrihte arás, and metes bæd
And she straightways arose, and asked for meat

Þis mæden ðe inne læg on deaðe geswefod, getácnað þære synfullan sawle deað, ðe gelustfullað on yfelum lustum digellice, and ne bið gyt mannum cuð, þæt heo þurh synna dead is
This maiden, who lay therein sleeping in death, betokens the death of the sinful soul, which delights secretly in evil pleasures, and it is not yet known to men, that it, through sins, is dead

ac Crist geswutelode þæt hé wolde swa synfulle sawle gelíffæstan, gif hé mid geornfullum gebedum to gelaðod bið, þaða he arærde þæt mæden binnan ðam huse, swa swa digelne leahter on menniscre heortan lutigende
but Christ manifested that he would quicken so sinful a soul, if with fervent prayers he be thereto called, when he raised the maiden within the house, like as secret sin lurking in the human heart

Nu syndon oðre synfulle þe gelustfulliað on derigendlicum lustum mid geðafunge, and eac heora yfelnysse mid weorcum cyðað
Now there are other sinful, who delight in pernicious lusts by assent, and also manifest their evilness by works

swilce getácnode se deada cniht, ðe wæs on þæs folces gesihðe geférod
such the dead youth betokened, who was borne in sight of the people

Swilce synfulle arærð Crist, gif hí heora synna behreowsiað, and betæcð hí heora meder, þæt is, þæt he hi geferlæcð on annysse his gelaðunge
Such sinners Christ raises, if they repent of their sins, and delivers them to their mother, that is, he associates them in the unity of his church

Sume synfulle men geðafiað heora lustum, and ðurh yfele dæda mannum cyðað heora synna, and eac gewunelice syngigende hí sylfe gewemmað: þyllice getácnode Lazarus, þe læg on byrgene feower niht fule stincende
Some sinful men assent to their lusts, and by evil deeds manifest their sins to men, and also habitually sinning defile themselves: such Lazarus betokened, who lay four days foully stinking in the sepulchre

Witodlice Godes nama is Ælmihtig, forðan ðe hé mæg ealle ðing gefremman
Verily God's name is Almighty, for he can accomplish all things

He mæg ða synfullan sawle ðurh his gife geliffæstan, ðeah ðe heo on gewunelicum synnum fule stince, gif heo mid carfulre drohtnunge Godes mildheortnysse secð
He can through his grace quicken the sinful soul, though it foully stink in habitual sins, if with careful conduct it seek God's mercy

ac swa mare wund swa heo maran læcedomes behófað
but the more it is wounded so much more medicament does it require

Þæt geswutelode se Hælend, þaþa hé mid leohtlicere stemne þæt mæden arærde on feawra manna gesihðe
That Jesus manifested, when with clear voice he raised the maiden in sight of few persons

forðan ðe hé ne geðafode þæt ðæra má manna inne wære, buton se fæder, and seo modor, and his ðry leorning-cnihtas: and he cwæð ða
for he allowed not more persons to be therein than the father, and the mother, and his three disciples: and he said then

Þu mæden, Arís
Thou maiden, Arise

Swa bið eac se digla deað ðære sawle eaþelicor to arǽrenne, þe on geðafunge digelice syngað, þonne synd ða openan leahtras to gehælenne
So also is the secret death of the soul, which sins secretly by assent, easier to raise than open vices are to be healed

Þone cniht he arærde on ealles folces gesihðe, and mid þysum wordum getrymede
He raised the youth in sight of all the people, and confirmed by these words

Þu cniht, ic secge ðe, Arís
Thou youth, I say unto thee, Arise

Þa diglan gyltas man sceal digelice betan, and ða openan openlice, þæt ða beon getimbrode þurh his behreowsunge, ðe ǽr wæron þurh his mándæda geæswicode
Secret sins shall be expiated secretly, and open openly, that those may be edified by his repentance, who had ere been seduced by his sins

Drihten ðaða he Lazarum stincendne arærde, ða gedrefde he hine sylfne, and tearas ageat, and mid micelre stemne clypode
The Lord when he raised the stinking Lazarus was troubled and shed tears, and with a loud voice cried

Lazare, ga forð
Lazarus, go forth

ða he geswutelode þæt se ðe swiðe langlice and gewunelice syngode, þæt he eac mid micelre behreowsunge and wope sceal his yfelan gewunan to Godes rihtwisnysse gewéman
he then manifested that he who has very long and habitually sinned, shall also with great repentance and weeping turn his evil habits to God's righteousness

Nis nán synn swa micel þæt man ne mæge gebétan, gif he mid inneweardre heortan be ðæs gyltes mæðe on soðre dǽdbote þurhwunað
There is no sin so great that a man may not expiate it, if, with inward heart, according to the degree of the sin, he continue in true penitence

Is þeah-hwæðere micel smeagung be anum worde þe Crist cwæð: he cwæð
There is, nevertheless, great disquisition concerning one sentence which Christ said: he said

Ælc synn and tál bið forgífen behreowsigendum mannum, ac þæs Halgan Gastes tál ne bið næfre forgífen
Every sin and calumny shall be forgiven to repenting men, but calumny of the Holy Ghost shall never be forgiven

Þeah ðe hwá cweðe tállic word ongean me, him bið forgífen, gif he deð dǽdbote
Though any one speak a calumnious word against me, he shall be forgiven, if he do penance

soðlice se ðe cweð word ongan ðone Halgan Gast, ne bið hit him forgífen on ðyssere worulde, ne on ðære towerdan
but he who says a word against the Holy Ghost, shall not be forgiven in this world nor in that to come

Nis nán synna forgífenys buton ðurh ðone Halgan Gast
There is no forgiveness of sins but through the Holy Ghost

An Ælmihtig Fæder is, se gestrynde ænne Sunu of him sylfum
There is one Almighty Father, who begot a Son of himself

Nis se Fæder gehæfd gemænelice Fæder fram ðam Suna and þam Halgan Gaste, forðan ðe hé nis heora begra sunu
The Father is not called Father in common from the Son and the Holy Ghost, for the latter is not the son of them both

Se Halga Gast soðlice is gemænelice gehæfd fram ðam Fæder and þam Suna, forðan ðe hé is heora begra Gast, þæt is heora begra Lufu and Willa, þurh ðone beoð synna forgyfene
But the Holy Ghost is called in common from the Father and the Son, for he is the Spirit of them both, that is the Love and Will of them both, through whom sins are forgiven

Witodlice ðære Halgan Ðrynnysse weorc is æfre untodæledlic, þeah-hwæðere belimpð ælc forgífenys to ðam Halgan Gaste, swa swa seo acennednys belimpð to Criste ánum
Verily the work of the Holy Trinity is ever indivisible, yet all forgiveness belongs to the Holy Ghost, as birth belongs to Christ alone

Hí ne magon beon togædere genemnede, Fæder, and Sunu, and Halig Gast, ac hí ne beoð mid ænigum fæce fram him sylfum awar totwæmede
They may not be named together, Father, and Son, and Holy Ghost, but they are not by any space anywhere separated from themselves

On eallum weorcum hí beoð togædere, þeah ðe to ðam Fæder synderlice belimpe þæt he Bearn gestrynde, and to ðam Suna belimpe seo acennednys, and to þam Halgan Gaste seo forðstæppung
In all works they are together, though to the Father it exclusively belongs that he begot a Son, and to the Son belongs birth, and to the Holy Ghost procession

Se Sunu is ðæs Fæder Wisdom æfre of ðam Fæder acenned
The Son is the Wisdom of the Father ever begotten of the Father

se Halga Gast nis na acenned, forðan ðe he nis na sunu, ac he is heora begra Lufu and Willa, æfre of him bám forðstæppende, þurh ðone we habbað synna forgyfenysse, swa swa we habbað þurh Crist alysednysse
the Holy Ghost is not begotten, for he is not a son, but is the Love and Will of them both, ever proceeding from them both, through whom we have forgiveness of sins, as through Christ we have redemption

and þeah-hwæðere on ægðrum weorce is seo Halige Þrynnys wyrcende untodæledlice
and yet in either work is the Holy Trinity working indivisibly

Se cwyð tál ongean ðone Halgan Gast, seðe mid unbehreowsigendre heortan þurhwunað on mándædum, and forsihð þa forgyfenysse ðe stent on ðæs Halgan Gastes gife: þonne bið his scyld unalysendlic, forðan ðe he sylf him belicð þære forgífenysse weg mid his heardheortnysse
He speaks calumny against the Holy Ghost, who with unrepenting heart continues in deeds of wickedness, and despises the forgiveness which stands in the grace of the Holy Ghost: then shall his sin be unredeemable, for he himself besets the way of forgiveness with his hardheartedness

Behreowsigendum bið forgífen, forseondum næfre
The repenting shall be forgiven, the despising never

Uton we biddan þone Ælmihtigan Fæder, seðe us þurh his wisdom geworhte, and þurh his Halgan Gast geliffæste, þæt he ðurh ðone ylcan Gast us do ure synna forgyfenysse, swa swa he us ðurh his ænne áncennedan Sunu fram deofles ðeowte alysde
Let us pray to the Almighty Father, who hath through his Wisdom made us, and through his Holy Spirit quickened us, that he through the same Spirit grant us forgiveness of our sins, as, through his only begotten Son, he has redeemed us from the thraldom of the devil

Sy lof and wuldor þam ecan Fæder, seðe næfre ne ongann, and his ánum Bearne, seðe æfre of him is, and þam Halgan Gaste, seðe æfre is of him bám, hi ðry án Ælmihtig God untodæledlic, á on ecnysse rixigende
Be praise and glory to the eternal Father who never began, and to his only Son who ever is of him, and to the Holy Ghost who ever is of them both, those three one Almighty God indivisible, reigning ever to eternity

Amen
Amen

Manegum mannum is cuð seo halige stów Sce Michaheles, on þære dúne þe is geháten Garganus
To many men is known the holy place of St

Seo dún stent on Campania landes gemæron, wið þa sǽ Adriaticum, twelf mila on upstige fram anre byrig þe is geháten Sepontina
Michael, on the mountain which is called Garganus

Of ðære stowe wearð aræred þises dæges freols geond geleaffulle gelaðunge
The mountain stands on the borders of the land of Campania, towards the Adriatic sea, twelve miles in ascent from a town which is called Sepontina

Þær eardode sum þurhspedig mann Garganus geháten: of his gelimpe wearð seo dún swa gecíged
From that place originated this day's festival throughout the faithful church

Hit gelámp, þaþa seo ormæte micelnyss his orfes on ðære dune læswede, þæt sum modig fearr wearð ángencga, and þære heorde-drafe oferhógode
There dwelt a very rich man called Garganus: from his adventure the mountain was so named

Hwæt se hláford þa Garganus gegaderode micele menigu his in-cnihta, and ðone fearr gehwær on ðam westene sohte, and æt nextan hine gemette standan uppon ðam cnolle þære healican dune, æt ánes scræfes inngange
It happened when the immense multitude of his cattle was grazing on the mountain, that an unruly bull wandered alone and despised the drove

and he ða mid graman wearð astyred, hwí se fearr ángenga his heorde forsáwe, and gebende his bogan, and mid geættrode flan hine ofsceotan wolde
Hereupon the master Garganus gathered a great many of his household servants, and sought the bull everywhere in the waste, and at last found him standing on the knoll of the high mountain, at the entrance of a cavern

ac seo geættrode flá wende ongean swilce mid windes blæde aðrawen, and þone ðe hi sceat þærrihte ofsloh
and he was then moved with anger, because the solitary bull had despised his herd, and bent his bow, and would shoot him with a poisoned arrow

His magas ða and nehgeburas wurdon þearle þurh ða dæde ablicgede, and heora nán ne dorste ðam fearre genealæcan
And se heah-engel mid þisum wordum to heofonum gewát

Hí ða heora biscop rǽdes befrunon, hwæt him be ðam to donne wære
His kinsmen then and neighbours were greatly astonished by that deed, and not one of them durst approach the bull

Se biscop ða funde him to rǽde, þæt hí mid þreora daga fæstene, swutelunge þæs wundres æt Gode bædon
They then asked counsel of their bishop, what they should do in the matter

Þa on ðære ðriddan nihte þæs fæstenes æteowde se heah-engel Michahel hine sylfne þam biscope on gastlicere gesihðe, þus cweðende
The bishop then found it advisable, that they should ask from God an explanation of the miracle with a fast of three days

Wislice ge dydon, þæt ge to Gode sohton þæt þæt mannum digle wæs
On the third night of the fast the archangel Michael appeared to the bishop in a ghostly vision, thus saying

Wite ðu gewislice, þæt se mann ðe mid his agenre flán ofscoten wæs, þæt hit is mid minum willan gedón
Wisely ye did to seek at God that which was hidden to men

Ic eom Michahel se heah-engel Godes Ælmihtiges, and ic symle on his gesihðe wunige
Know thou for certain, that the man who was shot with his own arrow, that it was done with my will

Ic secge ðe, þæt ic ða stowe þe se fearr geealgode synderlice lufige, and ic wolde mid þære gebícnunge geswutelian þæt ic eom ðære stowe hyrde
I am Michael, the archangel of God Almighty, and I continue ever in his sight

and ealra ðæra tácna ðe ðær gelimpað, ic eom sceawere and gymend
I say to thee that I especially love the place which the bull defended, and I would by that sign manifest that I am the guardian of the place

Se biscop rehte his gesihðe þam burhwarum, and hi ða syððan gewunelice þider sohton, and þone lifigendan God and his heah-engel Michahel geornlice bædon
The bishop recounted his vision to the townsfolk, and they afterwards usually resorted thither, and fervently prayed the living God and his archangel Michael

Twá dura hí gesawon on ðære cyrcan, and wæs seo suþ duru sume dæle mare, fram ðære lagon stapas to ðam west-dæle
Two doors they saw in the church, and the south door was somewhat larger, from which there lay steps to the west part: but they durst not visit the holy house with entrance, but daily prayed fervently at the door

Þa on ðære ylcan tíde Neapolite, þe wæron ða-gyt on hæðenscipe wunigende, cwædon gefeoht togeanes þære burhware Sepontiniscre ceastre, þe þa halgan stowe wurðodon, and togeanes Beneuentanos
Then at the same time the Neapolitans, who yet continued in heathenism, declared war against the inhabitants of the city of Sepontina, who worshiped the holy place, and against those of Benevento

Hí ða, mid heora biscopes mynegungum gelærde, bædon þreora daga fæc, þæt hi binnon þam ðrim dagum mid fæstene þæs heah-engles Michaheles fultum bædon
They then, instructed by the admonitions of their bishop, prayed for a space of three days, that they might, in those three days, implore with fasting the succour of the archangel Michael

Þa hæðenan eac swilce mid lacum and offrungum heora leasra goda gecneordlice múnde and gescyldnysse bædon
The heathen also in like manner, with gifts and offerings, diligently implored the guardianship and protection of their false gods

Efne ða on ðære nihte þe þæt gefeoht on merigen toweard wæs, æteowde se heah-engel Michahel hine sylfne ðam biscope, and cwæð, þæt he heora bena gehyrde, and his fultum him behét, and het þæt hí ane tíd ofer undern hí getrymedon ongean heora fynd
Lo, on the night then on the morrow of which the fight was to take place, the archangel Michael appeared to the bishop, and said that he had heard their prayers, and promised them his succour, and commanded them to array themselves against their foes one hour after morning-tide

Hí ða on merigen bliðe and orsorge, þurh ðæs engles behát, and mid truwan his fultumes, ferdon togeanes ðam hæðenum
They then on the morrow blithe and free from care, through the angel's promise, and with confidence in his succour, marched against the heathen

Þa sona on anginne þæs gefeohtes wæs se múnt Garganus bifigende mid ormætre cwacunge, and micel liget fleah of ðære dúne swilce flán wið þæs hæðenan folces, and þæs múntes cnoll mid þeosterlicum genipum eal oferhangen wæs
Then immediately at the beginning of the fight the mount Garganus was trembling with immense quaking, and great lightning flew from the mountain as it were arrows against the heathen folk, and the knoll of the mount was all overhung with dark clouds

Hwæt ða hæðenan ða forhtmode fleames cepton, and gelice hí wurdon mid þam fyrenum flanum ofscotene, gelice mid þæra cristenra wæpnum hindan ofsette, oðþæt hi heora burh Neapolim sámcuce gesohton
Whereupon the heathen with affrighted mind took to flight, and at the same time that they were shot with fiery arrows, they were overwhelmed from behind by the weapons of the christians, until half-dead they sought their city Naples

Soðlice ða ðe ða frecednyssa ætflugon, oncneowon þæt Godes engel ðam cristenum to fultume becom, and hí ðærrihte heora swuran Criste underþeoddon, and mid his geleafan gewæpnode wurdon
But those who escaped from those perils, acknowledged that God's angel came to the succour of the christians, and they straightways subjected their necks to Christ, and became armed with his faith

Witodlice þæs wæles wæs geteald six hund manna mid þam fyrenum flanum ofsceotene
Verily in that slaughter there were counted six hundred men shot with the fiery arrows

Þa cristenan ða sigefæste mid micelre bylde and blisse hám gecyrdon, and ðam Ælmihtigan Gode and his heah-engle Michahele heora behát to ðam temple gebrohton
The christians then victorious returned home with great confidence and joy, and brought their promise to the temple to Almighty God and his archangel Michael

Þa gesawon hí ætforan ðære cyrcan norð-dura, on þam marmanstane, swilce mannes fótlæsta fæstlice on ðam stane geðyde, and hí ða undergeaton þæt se heah-engel Michahel þæt tácen his andwerdnysse geswutelian wolde
Then saw they before the north door of the church, on the marble stone, as it were a man's footsteps, firmly impressed on the stone, and they then understood that the archangel Michael would manifest that token of his presence

Hi ða sona ðær-ofer cyrcan arǽrdon and weofod, þam heah-engle to lofe, ðe him on þam stede fylstende stód
They then forthwith raised a church and an altar thereover, to the praise of the archangel, who had stood in that place succouring them

Þa wearð micel twynung betwux ðære burhware be ðære cyrcan, hwæðer hí inn-eodon, oððe hí halgian sceoldon
There was then a great doubt among the townsfolk concerning the church, whether they should go in, or should hallow it

Hwæt hí ða on þam east-dæle ðære stowe cyrcan arærdon, and þam apostole Petre to wurðmynte gehalgodon, and þær-binnan Sce Marian, and Iohanne ðam Fulluhtere weofod asetton
Whereupon they raised a church in the east part of the place, and hallowed it to the honour of the apostle Peter, and therein placed an altar to St

Þa æt nextan sende se biscop to ðam papan, and hine befrán, hú him embe þæs heah-engles getimbrunge to dónne wære
Mary and John the Baptist

Se papa þisum ærende ðus geandwyrde
Then at last the bishop sent to the pope, and asked him, how they were to do concerning the archangel's structure

Gif mannum alyfed is þæt hi ða cyrcan ðe se heah-engel sylf getimbrode halgian moton, þonne gebyrað seo halgung on ðam dæge þe hé eow sige forgeaf, þurh unnan ðæs Ælmihtigan
To this errand the pope answered thus

Gif ðonne hwæt elles þam heah-engle gelicige, axiað his willan on þam ylcan dæge
If it is allowed to men to hallow the church which the archangel himself constructed, then the hallowing ought to be on the day on which, through the grace of the Almighty, he gave you victory

Se heah-engel ða Michahel, on ðære ðriddan nihte þæs fæstenes, cwæð to ðam biscope on swefne
When this answer was announced to the bishop, he enjoined to his fellow-citizens a fast of three days, and prayed to the Holy Trinity that some certain sign might be shown him concerning their doubt

Nis eow nan neod þæt ge ða cyrcan halgion þe ic getimbrode
The archangel Michael then, on the third night of the fast, said to the bishop in a dream

Ic sylf hi getimbrode and gehalgode
There is no need for you to hallow the church which I have constructed

Ac gað eow into ðære cyrcan unforhtlice, and me ætstandendum geneosiað þa stowe æfter gewunan mid gebedum
I myself constructed and hallowed it

and þu þær to-merigen mæssan gesing, and þæt folc æfter godcundum ðeawe to husle gange
But go into the church fearlessly, and in my presence visit the place according to custom with prayers

and ic þonne geswutelige hú ic ða stowe ðurh me sylfne gehalgode
and do thou sing mass there to-morrow, and let the people, after the divine rites, go to housel

Hi ða sona þæs on merigen ðider mid heora offrungum bliðe comon, and mid micelre ánrædnysse heora bena on ðam suþ-dæle inn-eodon
They then straightways on the morrow went joyfully thither with their offerings, and with great unity of their prayers went in on the south part

Efne ða hí gesawon an láng portic on ðam norð-dæle astreht for nean to ðam marmanstane þe se engel onstandende his fótlæste æteowde
Lo then they saw a long portico on the north part stretching very near to the marble stone, on which the angel standing had manifested his foot-marks

On ðam east-dæle wæs gesewen micel cyrce to ðære hí stæpmælum astigon
On the east part was seen a great church to which they step by step ascended

Seo cyrce mid hire portice mihte fif hund manna eaðelice befón on hire rymette: and þær stód, gesett wið middan þæs suð-wages, arwurðe weofod, mid readum pælle gescrydd
The church with its portico could easily contain in its space five hundred men: and there stood, placed against the middle of the south wall, a venerable altar covered with a red pall

Næs þæt hús æfter manna gewunan getimbrod, ac mid mislicum torrum gehwemmed, to gelicnysse sumes scræfes
That house was not constructed after the fashion of men, but had divers towers at the corners, in likeness of a cave

Se hróf eac swylce hæfde mislice heahnysse: on sumere stowe hine man mihte mid heafde gerǽcan, on sumere mid handa earfoðlice
The roof also was of various height: in one place a man might reach it with his head, in another hardly with his hand

Ic gelyfe þæt se heah-engel mid þam geswutelode þæt he micele swiðor sohte and lufode þære heortan clænnysse þonne ðæra stána frætwunge
I believe that the archangel would thereby manifest that he much more sought and loved cleanness of heart than the adornment of stones

Þæs muntes cnoll wiðutan is sticmælum mid wuda oferwexen, and eft sticmælum mid grenum felda oferbræded
The mountain's knoll without is partly overgrown with wood, and again partly overspread with the green field

Soðlice æfter ðære mæssan and ðam halgan husel-gange gecyrde gehwá mid micclum gefean to his agenum
But after the mass and the holy housel every one with great joy returned to his own

Se biscop ða ðær Godes ðeowas gelogode, sangeras, and ræderas, and sacerdas, þæt hi dæghwomlice ðær Godes þenunge mid þæslicere endebyrdnysse gefyldon
The bishop then placed God's servants there, singers, and readers, and priests, that they might daily there perform God's service in a fitting manner

and him ðær mynsterlic botl timbrian hét
and commanded a monastic house to be there built for them

Nis þeah-hwæðere nan mann to ðam dyrstig þæt hé on nihtlicere tide binnan ðære cyrcan cuman durre, ac on dǽgrede, þa Godes þeowas þær-binnan Godes lof singað
There is, however, no man daring to that degree that he dares to come within the church in the night-time, but at dawn, when God's servants are singing God's praise therein

Of ðam hróf-stane on norþ-dæle þæs halgan weofodes yrnð dropmælum swiðe hluttor wæter, and wered, þæt gecigdon ða ðe on þære stowe wunodon, stillam, þæt is, dropa
From the roof-stone on the north part of the holy altar there runs drop by drop water very pure and sweet, which those who dwelt in the place called 'stilla,' that is drop

Þær is ahangen sum glæsen fǽt mid sylfrenne racenteage, and þæs wynsuman wætan onfehð
There is hung a glass vessel with a silver chain, which receives the pleasant fluid

Þæs folces gewuna is, þæt hí æfter þam halgan husel-gange stæpmælum to ðam fæte astigað, and þæs heofonlican wætan onbyriað
It is the people's wont, after the housel, to go up step by step to the vessel, and taste the heavenly fluid

Se wæta is swiðe wynsum on swæcce, and swiðe hálwende on hrepunge
The fluid is very pleasant of taste, and very salutary to the touch

Witodlice forwel menige æfter langsumum fefere and mislicum mettrumnyssum, þurh ðises wætan þigene hrædlice heora hæle brucað
Verily very many after a tedious fever and divers sicknesses, by drinking this fluid, speedily enjoy their health

Eac swilce on oðrum gemete, ungerime untruman þær beoð oft and gelome gehælede, and menigfealde wundra þurh ðæs heah-engles mihte ðær beoð gefremode
Also in another manner, innumerable sick are there often and frequently healed, and many miracles, through the archangel's power, are there performed

and ðeah swiðost on þysum dæge, ðonne þæt folc of gehwilcum leodscipe þa stowe geneosiað, and þæs engles andwerdnyss mid sumum gemete ðær swiðost bið, þæt ðæs apostoles cwyde beo lichamlice gefylled, þæt þæt hé gastlice gecwæð: he cwæð, þæt
but chiefly on this day, when the people from every nation visit the place, and the angel's presence is there in some measure most sensible, that the words of the apostle may be bodily fulfilled, that which he spake spiritually: he said, that

englas beoð to ðening-gastum fram Gode hider on worulde asende, þæt hi beon on fultume his gecorenum, þæt hi ðone ecan eðel onfón mid him
angels shall be sent as ministering spirits from God hither into the world, that they may be for a succour to his chosen, that they may receive the eternal country with him

Þis dægþerlice godspell cwyð, þæt
This day's gospel says, that

Drihtnes leorning-cnihtas to him genealæhton, þus cweðende, La leof, hwá is fyrmest manna on heofenan rice
The Lord's disciples approached him, thus saying, Sir, which is the first of men in the kingdom of heaven

Se Hælend him ða to clypode sum gehwǽde cild
Jesus then called to him a little child

et reliqua
etc

Hægmon trahtnað þis godspell, and segð, hú ðæs caseres tolleras axodon Petrus ðone apostol, ðaða hi geond ealne middangeard ðam casere toll gegaderodon
Haymo expounds this gospel, and says, that the emperor's tollgatherers asked Peter the apostle, when they were gathering toll for the emperor over all the world

hi cwædon
they said

Wyle eower láreow Crist ænig toll syllan
Will your lord Christ give any toll

Þa cwæð Petrus, þæt he wolde
Then Peter said that he would

Þa mid þam ðe Petrus wolde befrínan þone Hælend, þa forsceat se Hælend hine, ðe ealle ðing wát, þus cweðende, Hwæt ðincð þe, Petrus, æt hwam nimað eorðlice cynegas gafol oððe toll, æt heora gesiblingum, oþþe æt ælfremedum
Then when Peter would ask Jesus, Jesus, who knows all thing, prevented him, thus saying, What thinkest thou, Peter, of whom do earthly kings take tribute or toll, of their own relations, or of strangers

Petrus cwæð, Æt ælfremedum
Peter said, Of strangers

Se Hælend cwæð, Hwæt la synd heora siblingas frige
Jesus said, What, are their relations free

Þe lǽs ðe we hí æswicion, ga to ðære sǽ, and wurpe út ðinne angel, and þone fisc ðe hine hraðost forswelhð, geopena his muð, þonne fintst þu ðær-on ænne gyldenne wecg: nim ðone, and syle to tolle for me and for ðe
Lest we should offend them, go to the sea, and cast out thine hook, and of the fish which first swalloweth it, open the mouth, then wilt thou find therein a golden coin: take that, and give as toll for me and for thee

Þa for ðam intingan þe hé cwæð
Then for that reason, that he said

Syle for me and for ðe
Give for me and for thee

wendon þa apostolas þæt Petrus wære fyrmest, and axodon ða ðone Hælend
the apostles imagined that Peter was first, and asked Jesus

Hwá wære fyrmest manna on heofonan rice
Who was the first of men in the kingdom of heaven

Þa wolde se Hælend heora dwollican geþohtas mid soðre eadmodnysse gehælan, and cwæð, þæt hí ne mihton becuman to heofonan rice, buton hí wæron swa eadmode, and swa unscæððige swa þæt cild wæs ðe he him to clypode
Jesus would then heal their erroneous thoughts with true humility, and said, that they could not come to the kingdom of heaven, unless they were as humble and as innocent as the child was which he called to him

Bilewite cild ne gewilnað oðra manna æhta, ne wlitiges wifes
A meek child desires not other men's possessions, nor a beauteous woman

þeah ðe hit beo gegremod, hit ne hylt langsume ungeþwærnysse to ðam ðe him derode, ne hit ne híwað mid wordum, þæt hit oðer ðence, and oðer sprece
though it be vexed it holds no lasting animosity towards those who injured it, nor feigns it with words, so that it think one thing and say another

Swa eac sceolon Godes folgeras, þæt synd þa cristenan, habban þa unscæððignysse on heora mode þe cild hæfð on ylde
In like manner should God's followers, that is, christians, have that innocence in their mind which a child has in its age

Se Hælend cwæð
Jesus said

Soð ic eow secge, Ne becume ge to heofonan rice, buton ge beon awende, and gewordene swa swa lyttlingas
Verily I say unto you, ye shall not come to the kingdom of heaven, unless ye are changed and become as children

Ne bebead he his gingrum þæt hí on lichaman cild wæron, ac þæt hí heoldon bilewitra cildra unscæððignysse on heora þeawum
He did not enjoin to his disciples that they should be children in body, but that they should hold the innocence of meek children in their conduct

On sumere stowe he cwæð, þaða him man to bær cild to bletsigenne, and his gingran þæt bemændon
In one place he said, when a child was brought to him to be blessed, and his disciples reproved it

Geðafiað þæt ðas cild to me cumon
Suffer these children to come unto me, for of such is the kingdom of heaven

Be ðisum manode se apostol Paulus his underðeoddan, and cwæð
Be ye not children in understanding, but in evilnesses: be perfect in understanding

Se Hælend cwæð
Whosoever humbleth himself like this child, he shall be first in the kingdom of heaven

Uton habban ða soðan eadmodnysse on urum life, gif we willað habban ða healican geðincðe on Godes rice
Every one of those who exalt themselves shall be humbled, and he who humbleth himself shall be exalted

Ælc ðæra ðe hine onhefð bið geeadmet, and se ðe hine geeadmet, he bið aháfen
He has the innocence of a meek child, who is displeasing to himself that he may be pleasing to God

and he bið swa micele wlitegra ætforan Godes gesihðe, swa he swiðor ætforan him sylfum eadmodra bið
He who receives one such little one in my name, receives myself

Se ðe underfehð ænne swilcne lyttling on minum naman, hé underfehð me sylfne
To all God's poor we should minister benefactions, though above all to the humble and meek, who in their life's conduct conform to the commandments of Christ

He cwæð eac on oðre stowe
He said also in another place

Se ðe wítegan underfehð, he hæfð wítegan mede
He who receiveth a prophet shall have a prophet's meed

se ðe rihtwisne underfehð, he hæfð rihtwises mannes edlean
he who receiveth a righteous man shall have a righteous man's reward

Þæt is, Se ðe witegan, oððe sumne rihtwisne Godes ðeow underfehð, and him for Godes lufon bigwiste foresceawað, þonne hæfð he swa micele mede his cystignysse æt Gode, swilce hé him sylf wítega wære, oþþe rihtwis Godes þeow
That is, He who receives a prophet, or a righteous servant of God, and provides sustenance for him for love of God, shall then have as great a meed from God for his bounty, as if he himself were a prophet, or a righteous servant of God

Se ðe geǽswicað anum ðyssera lyttlinga, ðe on me gelyfað, selre him wære þæt him wære getiged án ormæte cwyrnstán to his swuran, and he swa wurde on deoppre sǽ besenced
He who offends one of these little ones, who believe in me, better were it for him that an immense millstone were tied to his neck, and he were so sunk in the deep sea

Se ǽswicað oðrum þe hine on Godes dæle beswicð, þæt his sawul forloren beo
He offends another who deceives him on the part of God, so that his soul be lost

Se cwyrnstán þe tyrnð singallice, and nænne færeld ne ðurhtihð, getácnað woruld-lufe, ðe on gedwyldum hwyrftlað, and nænne stæpe on Godes wege ne gefæstnað
The millstone which turns incessantly, and accomplishes no course, betokens love of the world, which circulates in errors, and fixes no step in the way of God

Be swylcum cwæð se witega
Of such the prophet said

Þa arleasan turniað on ymbhwyrfte
The wicked turn in a circle

Se ðe genealæhð halgum háde on Godes gelaðunge, and siððan mid yfelre tihtinge oþþe mid leahterfullre drohtnunge oðrum yfele bysnað, and heora ingehyd towyrpð, þonne wære him selre þæt he on woruldlicere drohtnunge ana losode, þonne hé on halgum híwe oðre mid him þurh his ðwyrlican þeawas to forwyrde getuge
He who enters upon a holy order in God's church, and afterwards by instigation or by sinful life gives evil example to others, and perverts their understanding, then better were it for him that he alone perished in his worldly life, than that he in holy guise should draw others with him to perdition through his depraved morals

Wá middangearde for ǽswicungum
Wo to the world for offences

Middangeard is her gecweden þa ðe þisne ateorigendlican middangeard lufiað swiðor þonne þæt ece líf, and mid mislicum swicdomum hí sylfe and oðre forpærað
The world are here called those who love this perishable world more than everlasting life, and with divers offences pervert themselves and others

Neod is þæt æswicunga cumon, ðeah-hwæðere wá ðam menn ðe hi ofcumað
It is needful that offences come, yet wo to the man from whom they come

Þeos woruld is swa mid gedwyldum afylled, þæt heo ne mæg beon butan ǽswicungum, and þeah wá ðam menn ðe oðerne æt his æhtum, oððe æt his feore beswicð, and ðam bið wyrs, þe mid yfelum tihtingum oþres mannes sawle to ecum forwyrdum beswicð
This world is so filled with errors, that it cannot be without offences, and yet wo to the man who deceives another in his property, or in his life, and for him it shall be worse, who with evil instigation deceives another man's soul to eternal destruction

Gif ðin hand oððe ðin fót þe ǽswicige, ceorf of þæt lim, and awurp fram ðe
If thine hand or thy foot offend thee, cut off the limb, and cast it from thee

Þis is gecweden æfter gastlicere getácnunge, na æfter lichamlicere gesetnysse
This is said according to a spiritual signification, not as a bodily precept

Ne bebead God nanum menn þæt he his lima awyrde
God commanded no man to destroy his limbs

Seo hánd getácnað urne nydbehefan freond, þe us dæghwomlice mid weorce and fultume ure neode deð
The hand betokens our needful friend, who with work and succour daily ministers to our need

ac ðeah, gif swilc freond us fram Godes wege gewémð, þonne bið us selre þæt we his flæsclican lufe fram ús aceorfon, and mid twǽminge awurpon, þonne we, þurh his yfelan tihtinge, samod mid him on ece forwyrd befeallon
but yet, if such friend entice us from the way of God, then will it be better for us that we cut off from us his fleshly love, and by separation cast it away, than that we, through his evil instigation, together with him fall into eternal perdition

Ealswa is be ðam fét and be ðam eagan
So is it also with the foot and the eye

Gif hwilc sibling þe bið swa deorwurðe swa ðin eage, and oðer swa behefe swa ðin hand, and sum swa geðensum swilce ðin agen fót, gif hi ðonne þe þwyrlice tihtað to ðinre sawle forwyrde, þonne bið þe selre þæt þu heora geðeodrædene forbúge, þonne hi ðe forð mid him to ðam ecan forwyrde gelædon
