If any relation be as dear to thee as thine eye, and another as needful to thee as thy hand, and one as serviceable as thy own foot, if they then perversely instigate thee to thy soul's destruction, better will it be for thee that thou shun their fellowship, than that they lead thee on with them to eternal perdition

Behealdað þæt ge ne forseon ænne of þysum lytlingum
Take heed that ye despise no one of these little ones

Se ðe bepæhð ænne Godes þeowena, he geǽbiligð ðone Hlaford, swa swa he sylf þurh his witegan cwæð
He who deceives one of God's servants angers the Lord, as he himself through his prophet said

Se ðe eow hrepað, hit bið me swa egle swilce hé hreppe mines eagan séo
He who toucheth you, it shall be to me as offensive as if he touched the sight of mine eye

Ic secge eow þæt heora englas symle geseoð mines Fæder ansyne seðe on heofonum is
I say unto you, that their angels ever see the countenance of my Father who is in heaven

Mid þisum wordum is geswutelod þæt ælcum geleaffullum men is engel to hyrde geset, þe hine wið deofles syrwunge gescylt, and on halgum mægnum gefultumað, swa swa se sealm-scóp be gehwilcum rihtwisum cwæð
By these words is manifested that over every believing man an angel is set as a guardian, who shields him against the devil's machination, and supports him in holy virtues, as the psalmist said of every righteous man

God bebead his englum be ðe, þæt hi ðe healdon, and on heora handum hebban, þelǽs ðe ðu æt stane þinne fót ætspurne
God hath commanded his angels concerning thee, that they may preserve thee, and lift thee in their hands, lest thou dash thy foot against a stone

Micel wurðscipe is cristenra manna, þæt gehwilc hæbbe fram his acennednysse him betæhtne engel to hyrdrædene, swa swa be ðam apostole Petre awriten is, þaða se engel hine of ðam cwearterne gelædde, and he to his geferum becom, and cnucigende inganges bæd
It is a great honour for christian men, that every one has from his birth an angel assigned to him in fellowship, as it is written of the apostle Peter, when the angel led him from the prison, and he came to his companions, and knocking prayed for admission

Þa cwædon þa geleaffullan
Then said the faithful

Nis hit na Petrus þæt ðær cnucað, ac is his engel
It is not Peter who there knocketh, but is his angel

Þa englas soðlice ðe God gesette to hyrdum his gecorenum, hí ne gewitað næfre fram his andweardnysse
But those angels, whom God has set as guardians over his chosen, never depart from his presence

forðan ðe God is æghwær, and swa hwider swa ða englas fleoð, æfre hí beoð binnan his andwerdnysse, and his wuldres brucað
for God is everywhere, and whithersoever}} the angels fly, they are ever in his presence, and partake of his glory

Hi bodiað ure weorc and gebedu þam Ælmihtigan, þeah ðe him nán ðing digle ne sy, swa swa se heah-engel Raphahel cwæð to ðam Godes menn, Tobían
They announce our works and prayers to the Almighty, though to him nothing is hidden, as the archangel Raphael said to the man of God, Tobias

Þaða ge eow gebædon, ic offrode eower gebedu ætforan Gode
When ye prayed, I offered your prayers before God

Seo Ealde Æ ús sægð, þæt heah-englas sind gesette ofer gehwilce leodscipas, þæt hi ðæs folces gymon, ofer ða oðre englas, swa swa Moyses, on ðære fiftan béc ðære Ealdan Æ, þysum wordum geswutelode
The Old Law informs us that archangels are set over every nation, that they may take care of the people, over the other angels, as Moses, in the fifth book of the Old Law, manifested in these words

Þaða se healica God todælde and tostencte Adames ofspring, þa sette he ðeoda gemæru æfter getele his engla
When God on high divided and scattered Adam's offspring, he set the boundaries of nations according to the number of his angels

Þisum andgite geþwærlæcð se witega Danihel on his witegunge
In this sense agrees the prophet Daniel in his prophecy

Sum Godes engel spræc to Danihele embe ðone heah-engel þe Perscisce ðeode bewiste, and cwæð
An angel of God spake to Daniel concerning the archangel who directed the Persian people, and said

Me com to se heah-engel, Greciscre þeode ealdor, and nis heora nán mín gefylsta, buton Michahel, Ebreisces folces ealdor
The archangel came to me, the prince of the Grecian people, and there is none of these my supporter, save Michael, the prince of the Hebrew folk

Efne nú Michahel, án ðæra fyrmestra ealdra, com me to fultume, and ic wunode ðær wið þone cyning Persciscre ðeode
Lo, Michael, one of the first princes, came to me in succour, and I continued there with the king of the Persian nation

Mid þisum wordum is geswutelod hú micele care ða heah-englas habbað heora ealdordomes ofer mancynn, ðaða he cwæð, þæt Michahel him come to fultume
By these words is manifested how great care the archangels have of their authority over mankind, when he said that Michael came to his succour

Is nu geleaflic þæt se heah-engel Michahel hæbbe gymene cristenra manna, seðe wæs ðæs Ebreiscan folces ealdor, þa hwile ðe hí on God belyfdon
It is now credible that the archangel Michael has care of christian men, who was prince of the Hebrew folk, while they believed in God

and þæt he geswutelode, þaða he him sylfum cyrcan getimbrode betwux geleaffulre ðeode, on ðam munte Gargano, swa swa we hwene ǽr ræddon
and that he manifested when he built himself a church among a faithful people on mount Garganus, as we have read a little before

Þæt is gedón be Godes fadunge, þæt se mǽra heofonlica engel beo singallice cristenra manna gefylsta on eorðan, and þingere on heofonum to ðam Ælmihtigan Gode, seðe leofað and rixað á on ecnysse
It is done by God's dispensation, that the great heavenly angel is the constant supporter of christian men on earth, and their intercessor in heaven with Almighty God, who liveth and reigneth to all eternity

Amen
Amen

Drihten wæs sprecende on sumere tide to his apostolum mid bigspellum, þus cweðende, Heofonan rice is gelíc sumum cyninge þe worhte his suna gyfte
The Lord was speaking at a certain time to his apostles in parables, thus saying, The kingdom of heaven is like unto a certain king who made a marriage for his son

Þa sende he his bydelas to gelaðigenne his underðeoddan
Then sent he his messengers to invite his subjects

et reliqua
etc

We folgiað þæs papan Gregories trahtnunge on þyssere rædinge
We follow in this text the exposition of pope Gregory

Mine gebroðra þa leofostan, gelomlice ic eow sæde, þæt gehwær on halgum godspelle þeos andwerde gelaðung is geháten heofenan rice
My dearest brothers, I have frequently told you, that everywhere in the holy gospel this present church is called the kingdom of heaven

Witodlice rihtwisra manna gegaderung is gecweden heofonan rice
Verily a gathering of righteous men is called the kingdom of heaven

God cwæð þurh his witegan
God said through his prophet

Heofon is min setl
Heaven is my seat

Paulus se Apostol cwæð, þæt
Paul the Apostle said that

Crist is Godes Miht and Godes Wisdom
Christ is God's Might and God's Wisdom

Swutelice we magon understandan þæt gehwilces rihtwises mannes sawul is heofon, þonne Crist is Godes Wisdom, and rihtwises mannes sawul is þæs wisdomes setl, and seo heofen is his setl
Clearly we may understand that the soul of every righteous man is heaven, when Christ is God's Wisdom, and the soul of a righteous man is the seat of wisdom, and heaven is his seat

Be þisum cwæð se sealm-scóp
Of this the psalmist said

Heofonas cyðað Godes wuldor
The heavens make known the glory of God

Godes bydelas he het heofonas
He calls the heavens God's messengers

Eornostlice haligra manna gelaðung is heofonan rice, forðan ðe heora heortan ne beoð begripene on eorðlicum gewilnungum, ac hí geomriað to ðam upplican
But the congregation of holy men is the kingdom of heaven, because their hearts are not occupied in earthly desires, but they sigh for that which is above

and God nu iu rixað on him, swa swa on heofenlicum wunungum
and God now long since reigns in them, as in the heavenly dwellings

Se cyning ðe worhte his suna gifta is God Fæder, þe ða halgan gelaðunge geðeodde his Bearne þurh geryno his flæsclicnysse
The king who made a marriage for his son is God the Father, who associated the holy church with his Son through the mystery of his incarnation

Seo halige gelaðung is Cristes bryd, þurh ða hé gestrynð dæghwomlice gastlice bearn, and heo is ealra cristenra manna modor, and ðeah-hwæðere ungewemmed mæden
The holy church is Christ's bride, by which he daily begets spiritual children, and she is the mother of all christian men, and, nevertheless, an undefiled maiden

Þurh geleafan and fulluht we beoð Gode gestrynde, and him to gastlicum bearnum gewiscede, þurh Cristes menniscnysse, and þurh gife þæs Halgan Gastes
Through belief and baptism we are begotten to God, and adopted as his spiritual children, through Christ's humanity, and through grace of the Holy Ghost

God sende his ærendracan, þæt hé gehwilce to ðisum giftum gelaðode
God sent his messengers, that he might invite everyone to this marriage

Æne hé sende and eft
He sent once and again

forðan ðe hé sende his witegan, þe cyddon his Suna menniscnysse towearde, and he sende eft siððan his apostolas, þe cyddon his to-cyme gefremmedne, swa swa ða witegan hit ǽr gewitegodon
for he sent his prophets, who announced his Son's humanity to come, and again, he afterwards sent his apostles, who announced his advent accomplished, as the prophets had erst prophesied it

Þaða hí noldon cuman to ðam giftum, ða sende hé eft, þus cweðende
When they would not come to the marriage, he sent again, thus saying

Secgað ðam gelaðodum, Efne, ic gegearcode mine gód, ic ofslóh mine fearras, and mine gemæstan fugelas, and ealle mine ðing ic gearcode: cumað to þam giftum
Say to those who are invited, Behold, I have prepared my meats, I have slain my oxen and my fatted fowls, and have prepared all my things: come to the marriage

Þa fearras getácniað ða heah-fæderas ðære ealdan ǽ, þe moston ða, be leafe ðære ealdan ǽ, on fearres wisan, heora fynd ofslean
The oxen betoken the patriarchs of the old law, who might then, by permission of the old law, slay their foes in the manner of an ox

Hit is þus awriten on þære ealdan ǽ
It is thus written in the old law

Lufa ðinne freond, and hata ðinne feond
Love thy friend, and hate thy foe

Þus wæs alyfed þam ealdum mannum, þæt hí moston Godes wiðerwinnan and heora agene fynd mid stranglicere mihte ofsittan, and mid wæpne acwellan
Thus it was allowed to men of old, that they might with strong might oppress, and with weapons slay the adversaries of God and their own foes

Ac se ylca God, þe þas leafe sealde þurh Moyses gesetnysse ǽr his to-cyme, se ylca eft, ðaða he þurh menniscnysse to middangearde com, awende ðone cwyde, þus cweðende
But the same God, who gave this permission through the law of Moses before his advent, the same afterwards, when he through human nature came to the world, changed the mandate, thus saying

Ic bebeode eow, Lufiað eowre fynd, and doþ tela þam ðe eow hátiað, and gebiddað for eowre ehteras, þæt ge beon bearn þæs Heofonlican Fæder, seðe lǽt his sunnan scinan ofer góde and yfele, and he sylð rén-scuras and wæstmas rihtwisum and unrihtwisum
I command you, Love your foes, and do good to those who hate you, and pray for your persecutors, that ye may be children of the Heavenly Father, who letteth his sun shine over good and evil, and he giveth rain-showers and fruits to the righteous and to the unrighteous

Hwæt getácniað þa fearras buton fæderas ðære ealdan ǽ
What betoken the oxen but the fathers of the old law

Hwæt wæron hí, buton fearra gelican, þaða hí, mid leafe þære ealdan ǽ, heora fynd mid horne lichamlicere mihte potedon
What were they but the like of oxen, when, by permission of the old law, they struck their foes with the horn of bodily might

Þa gemǽstan fugelas getácniað þa halgan láreowas þære Níwan Gecyðnysse
The fatted fowls betoken the holy teachers of the New Testament

Þa sind gemæste mid gife þæs Halgan Gastes to ðam swiðe, þæt hí wilniað þæs upplican færeldes mid fyðerum gastlicere drohtnunge
These are fatted with the grace of the Holy Ghost to that degree, that they desire the heavenly journey with the wings of spiritual life

Hwæt is þæt man besette his geðanc on nyðerlicum þingum, buton swilce modes hlænnys
What is it for a man to set his thoughts on sublunary things but, as it were, a tenuity of mind

Se ðe mid fódan þære upplican lufe bið gefylled, he bið swilce he sy mid rumlicum mettum gemæst
He who is filled with the food of heavenly love, is as though he were fatted with generous meats

Mid þyssere fætnysse wolde se sealm-wyrhta beon gemæst, ðaða hé cwæð
With this fatness the psalmist would be fatted, when he said

Beo min sawul gefylled swa swa mid rysle and mid ungele
Be my soul filled as with fat and with tallow

Hwæt is
What is

Mine fearras sind ofslagene, and mine gemæstan fugelas
My oxen and my fatted fowls are slain

buton swilce he cwæde, 'Behealdað ðæra ealdfædera drohtnunga, and understandað þæra wítegena gyddunge, and þæra apostola bodunge embe mines Bearnes menniscnysse, and cumað to ðam giftum'
but as though he had said, 'Behold the lives of the old fathers, and understand the singing of the prophets, and the preaching of the apostles concerning my Son's humanity, and come to the marriage'

Þæt is, 'Cumað mid geleafan, and geðeodað eow to ðære halgan gelaðunge, ðe is his bryd and eower modor
That is, 'Come with faith, and associate yourselves to the holy church, which is his bride and your mother

Hí hit forgymeleasodon, and ferdon, sume to heora tunum, sume to heora ceape
They neglected it, and went, some to their farms, some to their merchandise

Se færð to his tune and forsihð Godes gearcunge, seðe ungemetlice eorðlice teolunge begæð to ðan swiðe, þæt he his Godes dǽl forgymeleasað
He goes to his farm and neglects God's preparation, who immoderately attends to earthly pursuits to that degree that he neglects God's portion

Se færð embe his mangunge, seðe mid gytsunge woruldlicra gestreona cepð swiðor þonne ðæs ecan lifes welan
He goes about his traffic, who with covetousness heeds worldly gains more than the riches of eternal life

Eornostlice þonne hí sume mid eorðlicum teolungum ungefohlice hí gebysgiað, and sume mid woruldlicum hordum, þonne ne magon hí for ðære bysga smeagan embe þæs Hælendes menniscnysse
But when they busy themselves immoderately, some with earthly pursuits and some with worldly treasures, then they cannot for that business meditate on the humanity of Jesus

and eac him bið swiðe héfigtyme geðuht, þæt hí heora þeawas be his regole geemnetton
and it also seems to them very irksome to adjust their conduct to his rule

Sume eac beoð swa ðwyrlice gemódode, þæt hí ne magon Godes bodunge gehyran, ac mid ehtnysse Godes bydelas geswencað, swa swa þæt godspel her bæftan cwæð
Some also are so perversely minded, that they may not hear God's preaching, but with persecution afflict God's messengers, as the gospel hereafter says

Sume hí gelæhton þa bydelas, and mid teonan gewæhton, and ofslogon
Some seized the messengers, and with injury afflicted them, and slew them

Ac se cyning, ðaða he þis geaxode, sende his here to, and þa manslagan fordyde, and heora burh forbærnde
But the king, when he was informed of this, sent his army, and destroyed the murderers and burned their city

Þa manslagan he fordyde, forðan ðe hé ða arleasan ehteras hreowlice acwealde, swa swa we gehwǽr on martyra þrowungum rædað
He destroyed the murderers, because he fiercely slew the impious persecutors, as we read everywhere in the passions of the martyrs

Nero, se wælhreowa casere, [hét ahón Petrum, and Paulum beheafdian, ac he wearð færlice of his rice aflymed, and hine wulfas totæron
Nero, the cruel emperor, [commanded Peter and Paul to be beheaded, but he was suddenly driven from his realm, and wolves tore him in pieces

Herodes beheafdode þone apostol Iacob, and Petrum gebrohte on cwearterne
Herod beheaded the apostle James, and brought Peter into prison, but God saved him from his captivity, and when the king was inquiring how he came out of the prison, God's angel came to him afterwards and slew him to death

ac God hine ahredde of his hæftnede, and þaða se cyning smeade hú he of ðam cwearterne come, þa æfter þan him com to Godes engel, and hine to deaðe gesloh
Astryges, the Indian king, who slew Bartholomew, became mad, and in a fit of madness departed

Astriges, se Indisca cyning, þe Bartholomeum ofsloh, awedde, and on þam wodan dreame gewát
In like manner Egeas, who crucified Andrew, ended forthwith in a fit of madness

Ealswa Egeas, þe Andream ahencg, þærrihte on wodan dreame geendode
Longsome would it be to recount the ends of all the impious persecutors, how sternly the Almighty God avenged on them the sufferings of his saints

Langsum bið to gereccenne ealra þæra arleasra ehtera geendunga, hú gramlice se Ælmihtiga God his halgena þrowunga on him gewræc
The gospel says, that he burned their city, because they will be, both with soul and with body, burned in everlasting torment

He sende his here tó
because through his angels he destroys the wicked

forþan ðe he þurh his englas þa mánfullan fordeð
What are the hosts of angels but the army of the Heavenly King

Hwæt sind þæra engla werod buton here þæs Heofonlican Cyninges
He is called Dominus Sabaoth, that is 'Lord of an army,' or 'Lord of Hosts

Se cyning cwæð ða to his þegnum
The king then said to his servants

Ðas gyfta sind gearowe, ac þa ðe ic þærtó gelaðode næron his wyrðe
The marriage is ready, but those whom I have thereto invited were not worthy of it

Farað nu to wega utscytum, and swa hwylce swa ge gemetað, laþiað to þam gyftum
Go now to the outlets of the ways, and whomsoever ye find, invite to the marriage

Wegas sind mislice manna dæda
Ways are the various deeds of men

Utscytas þæra wega sind ateorung woruldlicera weorca
Outlets of ways are the perishing of worldly works

and þa for wel oft becumað to Gode, þe on eorðlicum weorcum hwonlice speowð
and those very often come to God, who in earthly works but little prosper

Hwæt ða ðæs cyninges ærendracan ferdon geond wegas, gadrigende ealle þa ðe hi gemetton, ægðer ge yfele ge gode, and gesetton þa gifta endemes
Hereupon the king's messengers went through the ways, gathering all whom they found, both evil and good, and at length made the marriage

On þyssere andwerdan gelaðunge sind gemengde yfele and gode, swa swa clæne corn mid fulum coccele: ac on ende þyssere worulde se soða Dema hæt his englas gadrian þone coccel byrþenmælum, and awurpan into ðam unadwæscendlicum fyre
In this present church are mingled evil and good, as clean corn with foul cockle: but at the end of this world the true Judge will bid his angels gather the cockle by burthens, and cast it into the unquenchable fire

Byrþenmælum hi gadriað þa synfullan fram þam rihtwisum: þonne ða manslagan beoð togædere getigede innon þam hellicum fyre, and sceaþan mid sceaþum, gytseras mid gytserum, forliras mid forlirum
By burthens they will gather the sinful from the righteous: then will murderers be tied together within the hellish fire, and robbers with robbers, the covetous with the covetous, adulterers with adulterers

and swa gehwylce mánfulle geferan on þam ecum tintregum samod gewriþene cwylmiað
and so all wicked associates, bound together, shall suffer in everlasting torments

and se clæna hwæte bið gebroht on Godes berne: þæt is, þæt ða rihtwisan beoð gebrohte to þam ecan life, þær ne cymð storm ne nan unweder þæt ðam corne derie
and the clean wheat shall be brought into God's barn: that is, the righteous shall be brought to everlasting life, where storm comes not nor any tempest that may injure the corn

Ðonne ne beoð þa godan nahwar buton on heofenum, and þa yfelan nahwar buton on helle
Then will the good be nowhere but in heaven, and the evil nowhere but in hell

Mine gebroþra, gif ge góde sind, þonne sceole ge emlice wiþercorenra manna yfelnysse forberan, swa lange swa ge on þisum andweardan life wuniað
My brothers, if ye are good, then should ye bear with equanimity the evilness of reprobate men, as long as ye continue in this present life

Ne bið se gód seþe yfelne forberan nele
He is not good who will not bear with the evil

Be þisum cwæð Godes stemn to þam witegan Ezechiel
On this the voice of God said to the prophet Ezekiel

Ðu mannes bearn, ungeleaffulle and yfel tihtende sind mid þe, and þu wunast mid þam wyrstan wyrmcynne
Thou son of man, unbelieving and prompters to evil are with thee, and thou dwellest with the worst wormkind

Eft Paulus se Apostol geleaffulra manna líf herode and getrymde, þus tihtende
Again Paul the Apostle praised and confirmed the lives of believing men, thus stimulating them

Gewuniað betwux þwyrum mancynne: scinað betwux þam swa swa steorran, lífes word healdende
Dwell among perverse mankind: shine among them as stars, holding the word of life

Se cyning eode inn, and gesceawode þa gebeoras, þa geseah he þær ænne mann þe næs gescryd mid gyftlicum reafe
The king went in, and beheld the guests, when he saw one man there who was not clad in a marriage garment

Þæt giftlice reaf getácnað þa soðan lufe Godes and manna
The marriage garment betokens the true love of God and men

Þa lufe ure Scyppend us geswutelode þurh hine sylfne, þaða he gemedemode þæt he us fram þam ecan deaþe mid his deorwurþan blode alysde, swa swa Iohannes se Godspellere cwæð
That love our Creator manifested to us in himself, when he vouchsafed to redeem us from eternal death with his precious blood, as John the Evangelist said

Swa swiþe lufode God þysne middangeard, þæt he his áncennedan Sunu sealde for us
So greatly God loved this world, that he gave his only-begotten Son for us

Se Godes Sunu, þe ðurh lufe to mannum becom, gebicnode on þam godspelle þæt ðæt giftlice reaf getácnode,—þa soðan lufe
The Son of God, who through love came to men, signified in the gospel that which the marriage garment betokened,—true love

Ælc þæra þe mid geleafan and fulluhte to Gode gebihð, he cymð to þam gyftum
Every of those who with faith and baptism incline to God, comes to the marriage

ac he ne cymð na mid gyftlicum reafe, gif he þa soþan lufe ne hylt
but he comes not with a marriage garment, if he holds not true love

Witodlice ge geseoð þæt gehwam sceamað, gif he gelaðod bið to woruldlicum gyftum, þæt he wáclice gescryd cume to þære scortan blisse
For ye see that everyone is ashamed, if he is invited to a worldly marriage, to come meanly clad to that short pleasure

ac micele mare sceamu bið þam ðe mid horium reafe cymð to Godes gyftum, þæt he for his fulum gyrelan fram þære ecan blisse ascofen beo into ecum þeostrum
but a much greater shame is it for him who with a sordid garment comes to God's marriage, so that for his foul habit he shall be cast from eternal bliss into eternal darkness

Swa swa reaf wlitegað þone man lichamlice, swa eac seo soðe lufu wlitegað ure sawle mid gastlicere fægernysse
So as a garment adorns a man bodily, so also true love adorns our soul with spiritual fairness

Ðeah se mann hæbbe fullne geleafan, and ælmessan wyrce, and fela to gode gedo, eal him bið ydel, swa hwæt swa he deð, buton he hæbbe soþe lufe to Gode and to eallum cristenum mannum
Though a man have full faith, and give alms, and do much good, all will be vain, whatsoever he does, unless he have true love for God and for all christian men

Seo is soð lufu, þæt gehwá his freond lufie on gode, and his feond for gode
It is true love, that everyone love his friend well, and his foe for his good

Dæghwamlice gæð se Heofonlica Cyning into þam gyftum, þæt is, into his gelaðunge, and sceawað hwæðer we beón mid þam gyftlicum reafe innan gescrydde
The Heavenly King goes daily to the marriage, that is, into his church, and looks whether we are clad within in the marriage garment

and swa hwylcne swa he gemet butan soþre lufe, ðæne he befrinð mid graman, þus cweðende
and whomsoever he finds without true love, him he questions with wrath, thus saying

Þu freond, humeta dorstest ðu gán to minre gearcunge buton gyftlicum reafe
Thou friend, how durstest thou come to my preparation without a marriage garment

Freond
Friend

he hine het, and þeah awearp fram his gebeorum
he called him, and, nevertheless, cast him from his guests

Freond he wæs ðurh geleafan, and wiþercora þurh weorc
A friend he was through faith, and a reprobate in works

He þærrihte adumbode, forþan þe æt Godes dome ne bið nán beladung ne wiþertalu
He was forthwith silent, because at God's doom there is no exculpation nor defence

ac se Dema þe wiðutan þreað, is gewita his ingehides wiðinnan
for the Judge who convicts without, is cognizant of his mind within

Ðeah ðe hwá þa soþan lufe gyt fulfremedlice næbbe, ne sceal he ðeah his sylfes geortruwian, forðan ðe se witega be swylcum cwæð to Gode
Though any one have not true love perfectly, yet should he not despair of himself, for of such the prophet spake to God

Min Drihten, þine eagan gesawon mine unfulfremednysse, and on þinre béc ealle] sind awritene
My Lord, thine eyes have seen my imperfections, and in thy book all] are written

Se cyning cwæð to his ðegnum
The king said to his servants

Bindað þone misscryddan hándum and fótum, and wurpað into ðam yttrum þeostrum, þær bið wóp and toða gebitt
Bind the misclad hands and feet, and cast him into outer darkness, there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth

Þa hánda and þa fét þe nú ne beoð gebundene mid Godes ege fram þwyrlicum weorcum, hi beoð þonne þurh strecnysse Godes domes fæste gewriðene
The hands and the feet which are not now bound through awe of God from perverse works, shall then, through the sternness of God's doom, be fast bound

Þa fét ðe nellað untrumne geneosian, and þa hánda þe nán ðing þearfum ne syllað, þa beoð þonne mid wite gebundene
The feet which will not visit the sick, and the hands which give nothing to the poor, shall then be bound in torment

forðan þe hí synd nú sylfwilles fram gódum weorcum gewriðene
because they are now wilfully bound from good works

Se misscrydda wæs aworpen on ða yttran þeostru
The misclad was cast into outer darkness

Þa inran þeostru sind þære heortan blindnys
The inner darkness is the blindness of the heart

Þa yttran þeostru is seo swearte niht þære ecan geniðerunge
The outer darkness is the swart night of eternal condemnation

Se fordémda þonne þrowað on þam yttrum þeostrum neadunge, forðan ðe he nú sylfwilles his líf adrihð on blindnysse his heortan, and næfð nán gemynd þæs soðan leohtes, þæt is, Crist, þe be him sylfum cwæð
The condemned will then by compulsion suffer in outer darkness, because he now wilfully passes his life in blindness of heart, and has no remembrance of the true light, that is, Christ, who said of himself

Ic eom middangeardes leoht
I am the light of the world

se ðe me fyligð, ne gǽð he on þeostrum, ac he hæfð lifes leoht
he who followeth me goeth not in darkness, but hath the light of life

On ðam yttrum þeostrum bið wóp and toða gebit
In the outer darkness shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth

Þær wepað ða eagan on ðam hellican lige, þe nú ðurh unalyfedlice gewilnunga goretende hwearftliað
There the eyes shall weep in the hellish flame, which now libidinously roll about with unallowed desires

and þa téð, þe nú on ofer-æte blissiað, sceolon þær cearcian on þam unasecgendlicum pinungum, þe Godes wiðerwinnum gegearcod is
and the teeth, which now rejoice in gluttony, shall there grate in the unspeakable torments, which are prepared for the adversaries of God

Þa eagan soðlice for swiðlicum smice tyrað, and þa téð for micclum cyle cwaciað
Verily the eyes will smart with the powerful smoke, and the teeth quake with the great chill

forðan ðe ða wiðercoran unacumendlice hætu þrowiað, and unasecgendlicne cyle
for the reprobates shall suffer intolerable heat, and unspeakable chill

Witodlice þæt hellice fyr hæfð unasecgendlice hǽtan and nán leoht, ac écelice byrnð on sweartum ðeostrum
Verily the hellish fire has unspeakable heat and no light, but burns eternally in swart darkness

Gif hwam twynige be æriste, þonne mæg hé understandan on þisum godspelle, þæt þær bið soð ærist þær ðær beoð eagan and téð
If any one doubt concerning the resurrection, he may in this gospel understand, that there will be a true resurrection, where there are eyes and teeth

Eagan sind flæscene, and téð bænene
Eyes are of flesh, and teeth of bone

forðan þe we sceolon, wylle we nelle we, arisan on ende þyssere worulde mid flæsce and mid bane, and onfón edlean ealra ura dæda, oððe wununge mid Gode for gódum geearnungum, oþþe helle-wite mid deofle for mándædum
for we shall, whether we will or not, arise at the end of this world with flesh and with bone, and receive the reward of all our deeds, either a dwelling with God for good deserts, or hell-torment with the devil for deeds of wickedness

Be þisum cwæð se eadiga Iob
Of this the blessed Job said

Ic gelyfe þæt min Alysend leofað, and ic sceal on þam endenextan dæge of eorðan arisan, and eft ic beo mid minum felle befangen, and on minum flæsce ic geseo God, ic sylf, and na oðer
I believe that my Redeemer liveth, and that I shall on the last day from earth arise, and that I shall again be clothed in my flesh, and that in my flesh I shall see God, I myself, and no other

Þæt is, na oðer hiw þurh me, ac ic sylf hine geseo
That is, no other form through me, but I myself shall see him

Þises godspelles geendung is swiðe egefull
The ending of this gospel is very awful

Fela sind gecígede and feawa gecorene
Many are called and few chosen

Efne nu ure ealra stemn clypað Crist, ac ure ealra líf ne clypað
Behold now the voices of us all call Christ, but the lives of us all call him not

forðan ðe manega wiðcweðað on heora ðeawum þæt þæt hí mid heora stemne geandettað
for many deny in their practices that which they profess with their voice

Sume menn habbað gód anginn sume hwile, ac hí geendiað on yfele
Some men have a good beginning for some while, but they end in evil

Sume habbað yfel anginn, and wel geendiað þurh soðe dǽdbote
Some have an evil beginning, and end well through true penitence

Sume onginnað wel, and bet geendiað
Some begin well and end better

Nu sceal gehwá hine sylfne micclum ondrædan, þeah þe hé góde drohtnunge hæbbe, and nateshwon be him sylfum gedyrstlæcan
Now everyone should greatly fear, though he lead a good life, and not presume on himself

forðan þe hé nát hwæðer hé wurðe is into þam ecan rice
for he knows not whether he is worthy to enter into the eternal kingdom

Ne he ne sceal be oðrum geortruwian, þeah ðe he on leahtras befealle
Nor should he despair of another, though he fall into vices

forðan ðe he nát þa menigfealdan welan Godes mildheortnysse
for he knows not the manifold abundance of God's mercy

Þam filigde sum flæsclic broðor to mynstre, na for gecnyrdnysse góddre drohtnunge, ac for flæsclicere lufe
Gregory now says, that a certain brother entered into a monastery which he himself had founded, and after regular probation received monkhood

Se gastlica broðor eallum þam mynster-munecum þearle ðurh góde drohtnunge gelicode
A fleshly brother followed him to the monastery, not for desire of a good life, but for fleshly love

and his flæsclica broðor micclum his lifes ðeawum mid þwyrnysse wiðcwæð
The ghostly brother, through his good life, was exceedingly liked by the monks of the monastery

He leofode on mynstre for neode swiðor þonne for beterunge
and his fleshly brother with perverseness greatly contradicted the usages of his life

He wæs gegaf spræce, and þwyr on dǽdum
He lived in the monastery rather from necessity than for bettering

wel besewen on reafe, and yfele on ðeawum
He was idle of speech, and perverse in deeds

He nahte geðyld, gif hine hwá to góddre drohtnunge tihte
appearing well in raiment, and evil in morals

Wearð ða his líf swiðe héfigtyme ðam gebroðrum, ac hi hit emlice forbæron for his broðer gódnysse
He had no patience, if any one exhorted him to a good course

He ne mihte nán ðing to gode gedón, ne he nolde nán gód gehyran
Hence was his life very irksome to the brothers, but they endured it calmly on account of his brother's goodness

Þa wearð hé færlice mid sumere coðe gestanden, and to deaðe gebroht
He could do nothing good, nor would he hear any good

Þaða hé to forðsiðe aháfen wæs, ða comon þa gebroðra to ði þæt hí his sawle becwædon
He was then suddenly seized with some disease, and brought to death

He læg acealdod on nyþeweardum limum: on ðam breoste anum orðode ða-gyt se gast
When he was raised up for departure, the brothers came that they might pray for his soul

Þa gebroðra ða swa micel geornfullicor for hine gebædon, swa micclum swa hí gesawon þæt he hrædlice gewítan sceolde
He lay chilled in his lower limbs: in his breast alone the spirit yet breathed

He ða færlice hrymde, þus cweðende
The brothers then prayed for him the more fervently, the more they saw that he would quickly depart

Gewitað fram me
He then suddenly cried, thus saying

Efne her is cumen an draca þe me sceal forswelgan, ac he ne mæg for eower andwerdnysse
Depart from me

Min heafod he hæfð mid his ceaflum befangen
Lo here is a dragon come which is to swallow me, but he cannot for your presence

Rymað him, þæt he me léng ne swence
He has seized my head in his jaws

Gif ic þisum dracan to forswelgenne geseald eom, hwí sceal ic elcunge þrowian for eowerum oferstealle
Give place to him, that he may no longer afflict me

Þa gebroðra him cwædon to
The brothers said to him

Hwí sprecst þu mid swa micelre orwennysse
Why speakst thou with such great despair

Mearca ðe sylfne mid tácne þære halgan róde
Mark thyself with the sign of the holy rood

He andwyrde be his mihte
He answered as he was able

Ic wolde lustbære mid tácne þære halgan róde me bletsian, ac ic næbbe ða mihte, forðan ðe se draca me þearle ofþryhð
I would joyfully bless myself with the sign of the holy rood, but I have not the power, for the dragon sorely oppresses me

Hwæt ða munecas ða hí astrehton mid wópe to eorðan, and ongunnon geornlicor for his hreddinge þone Wealdendan God biddan
Whereupon the monks prostrated themselves with weeping to the earth, and begun more fervently to pray to the Powerful God for his salvation

Efne ða færlice awyrpte se adliga cniht, and mid blissigendre stemne cwæð
Lo then, the sick man suddenly started, and with exulting voice said

Ic þancige Gode: efne nu se draca, þe me forswelgan wolde, is aflíged for eowerum benum
I thank God: behold now the dragon which would swallow me is put to flight through your prayers

He is fram me ascofen, and standan ne mihte ongean eowre þingunge
He is driven from me, and could not stand against your intercession

Beoð nu mine ðingeras, biddende for minum synnum
Be now my interceders, praying for my sins

forðan ðe ic eom gearo to gecyrrenne to munuclicere drohtnunge, and woruldlice ðeawas ealle forlætan
for I am ready to turn to monastic life, and to forsake all worldly practices

His cealdan limu þa ge-edcucodon, and he mid ealre heortan to Gode gecyrde, and mid langsumum broce on his gecyrrednysse wearð gerihtlæced, and æt nextan on þære ylcan untrumnysse gewát
His cold limbs then requickened, and he turned with all his heart to God, and by long sickness in his conversion was justified, and at length died of the same disease

ac he ne geseah þone dracan on his forðsiðe, forðan ðe he hine oferswiðde mid gecyrrednysse his heortan
but he saw not the dragon at his departure, for he had overcome him by the conversion of his heart

Ne sceole we beon ormode, þeah ðe on þyssere andweardan gelaðunge fela syndon yfele and feawa góde
We should not be hopeless, though in this present church many are evil and few good

forðan ðe Noes arc on yþum ðæs micclan flodes hæfde getácnunge þyssere gelaðunge, and hé wæs on nyðeweardan wíd, and on ufeweardan nearo
for Noah's ark on the waves of the great flood was a type of this church, and it was in the lower part wide and in the upper narrow

On ðære nyðemystan bytminge wunodon þa reðan deor and creopende wurmas
In the lowermost bottom dwelt the fierce beasts and creeping worms

On oþre fleringe wunodon fugelas and clæne nytenu
On the second flooring dwelt birds and clean animals

On þære ðriddan fleringe wunode Noe mid his wife, and his ðry suna mid heora þrim wifum
On the third flooring dwelt Noah with his wife, and his three sons with their three wives

On ðære bytminge wæs se arc rúm, þær ða reðan deor wunedon, and wiðufan genyrwed, þær ðæra manna wunung wæs
In the bottom the ark was roomy, where the fierce beasts dwelt, and narrowed above, where the dwelling of men was

forðan ðe seo halige gelaðung on flæsclicum mannum is swiðe brád, and on gastlicum nearo
for the holy church is in fleshly men very broad, and in spiritual narrow

Heo tosprǽt hire bosm þær ðær þa reðan wuniað on nytenlicum ðeawum, and heo is genyrwed on þone ende þe þa gesceadwisan wuniað, on gastlicum ðeawum drohtnigende
She spreads her bosom where the rugged dwell in brutal habits, and she is narrowed at the end which the discreet inhabit, living in spiritual practices

forðan swa hí haligran beoð on þyssere andwerdan gelaðunge, swa heora læs bið
for the holier they are in this present church, so the less of them there is

Micele ma is þæra manna þe lybbað be agenum lustum, ðonne þæra sy þe heora lifes ðeawas æfter Godes bebodum gerihtlæcað: þeah-hwæðere symle bið haligra manna getel geeacnod þurh arleasra manna wanunge
Much more is there of those men who live for their own lusts, than there is of those who regulate their life's actions after the commandments of God: yet is the number of holy men ever increased through the diminution of impious men

Nis þæt getel Godes gecorenra lytel, swa swa Crist on oðre stowe cwæð
The number of God's chosen is not little, as Christ said in another place

Manega cumað fram east-dæle and fram west-dæle, and sittað mid þam heahfædere Abraháme, and Isaace, and Iacobe on heofonan rice
Many shall come from the east part and from the west, and shall sit with the patriarch Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob in the kingdom of heaven

Eft, se sealm-wyrhta be Godes gecorenum cwæð
Again, the psalmist said of God's chosen

Ic hí getealde, and heora getel is mare ðonne sand-ceosol
I counted them, and their number is greater than the sand-grains

On ðisum andweardan life sind þa gecorenan feawa geðuhte ongean getel þæra wiðercorenra, ac þonne hí to ðam ecan life gegaderode beoð, heora tel bið swa menigfeald, þæt hit oferstihð, be ðæs witegan cwyde, sand-ceosles gerím
In this present life the chosen appear few in comparison with the number of the reprobates, but when they shall be gathered to the eternal life, their number will be so manifold, that it will exceed, according to the prophet's saying, the number of the sand-grains

Lǽd us, Ælmihtig God, to getele ðinra gecorenra halgena, inn to þære ecan blisse ðines rices, þe þu gearcodest fram frymðe middangeardes þe lufigendum, þu ðe leofast and rixast mid þam Ecan Fæder and Halgum Gaste on ealra worulda woruld
Lead us, Almighty God, to the number of thy chosen saints, into the everlasting bliss of thy kingdom, which thou hast prepared from the beginning of the world for those who love thee, thou who livest and reignest with the Eternal Father and the Holy Ghost for ever and ever

Amen
Amen

Halige láreowas ræddon þæt seo geleaffulle gelaðung þisne dæg Eallum Halgum to wurþmynte mærsige, and arwurðlice freolsige
Holy doctors have counselled that the faithful church should celebrate and piously solemnize this day to the honour of All Saints

forðan ðe hí ne mihton heora ælcum synderlice freolstide gesettan, ne nánum menn on andweardum life nis heora eallra nama cuð, swa swa Iohannes se Godspellere on his gastlican gesihðe awrát, þus cweðende
because they could not appoint a festival separately for each of them, nor to any man in the present life are the names of all of them known, as John the Evangelist wrote in his ghostly vision, thus saying

Ic geseah swa micele menigu, swa nán man geryman ne mæg, of eallum ðeodum and of ælcere mægðe, standende ætforan Godes þrym-setle, ealle mid hwitum gyrlum gescrydde, healdende palm-twigu on heora handum, and sungon mid hluddre stemne, Sy hǽlu urum Gode þe sitt ofer his þrym-setle
I saw so great a multitude as no man may number, of all nations and of every tribe, standing before the throne of God, all clad in white garments, holding palm-twigs in their hands, and they sung with a loud voice, Salvation be to our God who sitteth on his throne

And ealle englas stodon on ymbhwyrfte his ðrym-setles, and aluton to Gode, þus cweðende, Sy urum Gode bletsung and beorhtnys, wisdom and þancung, wurðmynt and strengð, on ealra worulda woruld
And all the angels stood around his throne, and bowed down to God, thus saying, Be to our God blessing and brightness, wisdom and thanksgiving, honour and strength, for ever and ever

Amen
Amen

Godes halgan sind englas and menn
God's saints are angels and men

Englas sind gastas butan lichaman
Angels are spirits without body

Þa gesceop se Ælmihtiga Wealdend on micelre fægernysse, him sylfum to lofe, and to wuldre and wurðmynte his mægenþrymme on ecnysse
These the Almighty Ruler created in great fairness, for his own praise, and to the glory and honour of his majesty for ever

Be þam we forhtiað fela to sprecenne, forðan ðe Gode anum is to gewitenne hú heora ungesewenlice gecynd, butan ælcere besmitennysse oþþe wanunge, on écere hluttornysse þurhwunað
Of these we fear to speak much, because for God alone is it to know how their invisible nature continues, without any pollution or decay, in eternal purity

Þeah-hwæðere we oncnáwað on halgum gewritum, þæt nigon engla werod sind wunigende on heofonlicum þrymme, þe næfre náne synne ne gefremedon
Nevertheless we know from holy writings, that there are nine hosts of angels existing in heavenly majesty, who never committed any sin

Þæt teoðe werod þurh modignesse losode, and to awyrgedum gastum behwyrfede wurdon, and ascofene of heofonlicere myrhðe inn to hellicere susle
The tenth host perished through pride, and were turned into accursed spirits, and driven from heavenly joy into hell-torment

Soðlice sume ðæra haligra gasta, þe mid heora Scyppende þurhwunodon, to us asende cumað, and towearde ðing cyðað
But some of those holy spirits, who continued with their Creator, come sent to us, and announce future things

Sume hí wyrcað, be Godes dihte, tácna and gelomlice wundra on middangearde
Some of them, by God's direction, work signs and frequently miracles in the world

Sume hí synd ealdras gesette þam oðrum englum, to gefyllenne þa godcundlican gerynu
Some of them are chiefs set over other angels for the fulfilment of the divine mysteries

Þurh sume gesett God and toscæt his domas
Through some God establishes and decides his dooms

Sume hí sind swa micclum to Gode geðeodde, þæt náne oðre him betwynan ne synd, and hí ðonne on swa micclan maran lufe byrnende beoð, swa micclum swa hí Godes beorhtnysse scearplicor sceawiað
Some are so closely associated with God, that no others are between them, and they are then burning in so much greater love, as they more clearly behold the brightness of God

Nu is þes dæg þisum englum arwurðlice gehalgod, and eac þam halgum mannum, þe þurh miccle geðincða fram frymðe middangeardes Gode geþugon
Now is this day piously hallowed to these angels, and also to those holy men, who through great excellences have thriven to God from the beginning of the world

Of þisum wæron ǽrest heahfæderas, eawfæste and wuldorfulle weras on heora life, witegena fæderas, þæra gemynd ne bið forgiten, and heora nama þurhwunað on ecnysse
Of these were first the patriarchs, religious and glorious men in their lives, the fathers of the prophets, whose memory shall not be forgotten, and their names shall last for ever, because they were acceptable to God through faith, and righteousness, and obedience

forðan ðe hi wæron Gode gecweme þurh geleafan, and rihtwisnysse, and gehyrsumnysse
These were followed by the chosen company of prophets: they held speech with God, and to them he manifested his secrets, and enlightened them with the grace of the Holy Ghost, so that they knew the things to come, and announced them in prophetic song

Þisum fyligð þæra witegena gecorennys: hí wæron Godes gesprecan, and þam he æteowde his digelnysse, and hi onlihte mid gife þæs Halgan Gastes, swa þæt hi wiston þa towerdan ðing, and mid witigendlicere gyddunge bododon
Verily the chosen prophets by many signs and foretokens were in their lives illustrious

Witodlice þa gecorenan witegan mid manegum tácnum and forebícnungum on heora life scinende wæron
They healed the sickness of men, and the bodies of dead men they raised to life

Hi gehældon manna untrumnysse, and deaddra manna líc to life arærdon
They also, for the people's perversity, withdrew the showers of heaven, and again in mercy permitted them

Hí eac for folces þwyrnysse heofonan scuras oftugon, and eft miltsigende getiþodon
They bewailed the people's sins, and their punishment prevented on themselves

Hi heofodon folces synna, and heora wrace on him sylfum forscytton
Christ's humanity, and his passion, and resurrection, and ascension, and the great doom, instructed by the Holy Ghost, they prophesied

On ðære Nywan Gecyðnysse forðstóp Iohannes se Fulluhtere, seðe mid witegunge Cristes to-cyme bodode, and eac mid his fingre hine gebícnode
In the New Testament John the Baptist stept forth, who with prophecy preached the advent of Christ, and also with his finger pointed him out

Betwux wifa bearnum ne arás nán mærra mann þonne is Iohannes se Fulluhtere
Among the children of women there hath arisen no greater man than is John the Baptist

Þisum Godes cempan geþwærlæcð þæt twelffealde getel Cristes apostola, þe he sylf geceas him to leorning-cnihtum, and hi mid rihtum geleafan and soðre láre geteah, and eallum ðeodum to láreowum gesette, swa þæt se swég heora bodunge ferde geond ealle eorðan, and heora word becomon to gemærum ealles ymbhwyrftes
With these champions of God accords the twelvefold number of Christ's apostles, whom he himself chose for his disciples, and instructed them in right belief and true doctrine, and set them as teachers to all nations, so that the sound of their preaching went over all the earth, and their words came to the boundaries of the whole world

To ðisum twelf apostolum cwæð se Ælmihtiga Hælend
To these twelve apostles said the Almighty Jesus

Ge sind middangeardes leoht: scine eower leoht swa ætforan mannum, þæt hi geseon eowre gódan weorc, and wuldrian eowerne Fæder þe on heofonum is
Ye are the light of the world: let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father who is in heaven

Ge sind mine frynd, and ic cyðe eow swa hwæt swa ic æt minum Fæder gehyrde
Ye are my friends, and I make known unto you whatsoever I have heard from my Father

Eornostlice Drihten forgeaf þa mihte his twelf apostolum, þæt hi ða ylcan wundra worhton þe hé sylf on middangearde gefremode
Verily the Lord gave power to his twelve apostles to work the same wonders which he himself performed in the world

And swa hwæt swa hí bindað ofer eorðan, þæt bið on heofonum gebunden
And whatsoever they bind on earth, that shall be bound in heaven

and swa hwæt swa hí unbindað ofer eorðan, þæt bið unbunden on heofonum
and whatsoever they unbind on earth, that shall be unbound in heaven

Eac he him behet mid soðfæstum beháte, þæt hí on ðam micclum dome ofer twelf dóm-setl sittende beoð, to démenne eallum mannum þe æfre on lichaman líf underfengon
He also promised them with a true promise, that at the great doom they shall be sitting on twelve judgement-seats, to judge all men who have ever received life in the body

Æfter þam apostolican werode we wurðiað þone gefæstan heap Godes cyðera, þe ðurh mislice tintrega Cristes ðrowunge werlice geefenlæhton, and ðurh martyrdom þæt upplice rice geferdon
After the apostolic company we honour the steadfast band of God's martyrs, who through divers torments courageously imitated the passion of Christ, and through martyrdom passed to the realm on high

Sume hi wæron mid wæpnum ofslagene, sume on líge forswælede, oðre mid swipum ofbeatene, oþre mid stengum þurhðyde, sume on héngene gecwylmede, sume on widdre sǽ besencte, oðre cuce behylde, oðre mid ísenum clawum totorene, sume mid stánum ofhrorene, sume mid winterlicum cyle geswencte, sume mid hungre gecwylmede, sume handum and fotum forcorfene, folce to wæfersyne, for geleafan and halgum naman Hælendes Cristes
Some of them were slain with weapons, some burned in flame, others beaten with scourges, others transfixed with stakes, some slain on the cross, some sunk in the wide sea, others flayed alive, others torn with iron claws, some overwhelmed with stones, some afflicted with winterly cold, some slain by hunger, some with hands and feet cut off, as a spectacle to people, for their faith and the holy name of Jesus Christ

Þas sind þa sigefæstan Godes frynd, þe ðæra forscyldgodra ealdormanna hæsa forsawon, and nu hí sind gewuldor-beagode midsige heora þrowunga on écere myrhðe
These are the triumphant friends of God, who despised the behests of those criminal princes, and now they are glory-crowned with the triumph of their sufferings in eternal joy

Hi mihton beon lichamlice acwealde, ac hi ne mihton fram Gode þurh náne tintregunga beon gebígede
They might be slain bodily, but they could not by any torments be turned from God

Heora hiht wæs mid undeadlicnysse afylled, þeah ðe hí ætforan mannum getintregode wæron
Their hope was filled with immortality, though before men they were tormented

Hí wæron sceortlice gedrehte, and langlice gefrefrode
They were for a short time afflicted, and lastingly comforted, for God tried them as gold in a furnace, and he found them worthy of him, and as holy offerings received them into his heavenly kingdom

Æfter ablunnenre ehtnysse reðra cynega and ealdormanna, on siblicere drohtnunge Godes gelaðunge, wæron halige sacerdas Gode ðeónde, þa mid soðre láre and mid halgum gebysnungum folces menn to Gode symle gebígdon
After the persecution of the cruel kings and princes had ceased, in the peaceful condition of God's church, there were holy priests thriving to God, who with true doctrine and holy examples ever inclined the men of the people to God

Heora mód wæs hluttor, and mid clænnysse afylled, and hi mid clænum handum Gode Ælmihtigum æt his weofode ðenodon, mærsigende þa halgan gerynu Cristes lichaman and his blodes
Their minds were pure, and filled with cleanness, and with clean hands they served God Almighty at his altar, celebrating the holy mystery of Christ's body and his blood

Eac hí offrodon hí sylfe Gode líflice onsægednysse butan womme, oþþe gemencgednysse þwyrlices weorces
They likewise offered themselves a living sacrifice to God, without blemish or admixture of perverse work

Hi befæston Godes láre heora underþeoddum, to unateorigendlicum gafele, and heora mód mid þreatunge, and bene, and micelre gymene to lifes wege gebígdon, and for nánum woruldlicum ege Godes riht ne forsuwodon
They delivered God's doctrine to their followers, as an imperishable revenue, and with chastisement, and prayer, and great care inclined them to the way of life, and for no awe of the world refrained from preaching God's law

and ðeah ðe hí swurdes ecge ne gefreddon, þeah ðurh heora lífes geearnunga hí ne beoð martyrdomes bedælede, forðan þe martyrdom bið gefremmed na on blodes gyte anum, ac eac swylce on synna forhæfednysse, and on bíggenge Godes beboda
and though they felt not the sword's edge, yet, through the merits of their lives, are they not deprived of martyrdom, for martyrdom is not effected by bloodshed only, but also by abstinence from sins, and by the observance of God's commandments

Þysum fyligð ancersetlena drohtnung, and synderlic ingehyd
This is followed by the life and extraordinary knowledge of anchorites

Þa on westenum wunigende, woruldlice éstas and gælsan mid strecum mode and stiðum life fortrædon
These dwelling in the waste, trampled with stern mind and rigid life on worldly delicacies and luxuries

Hi forflugon woruld-manna gesihðe and herunge, and on wáclicum screafum oððe hulcum lutigende, deorum geferlæhte, to engelicum spræcum gewunode, on micclum wundrum scínende wæron
They fled from the sight and praise of worldly men, and, crouching in miserable caves or huts, associated with beasts, accustomed to angelic speeches, were shining in great wonders

Blindum hí forgeafon gesihðe, healtum færeld, deafum hlyst, dumbum spræce
To the blind they gave sight, gait to the halt, hearing to the deaf, speech to the dumb

Deoflu hí oferswyðdon and afligdon, and ða deadan þurh Godes mihte arærdon
Devils they overcame and drove away, and through God's might raised the dead

Seo bóc þe is geháten Uitae Patrum sprecð menigfealdlice embe þyssera ancersetlena, and eac gemænelicra muneca drohtnunge, and cwyð, þæt heora wæs fela ðusenda gehwær on westenum and on mynstrum wundorlice drohtnigende, ac swa-þeah swyðost on Egypta-lande
The book which is called Vitæ Patrum speaks manifoldly concerning the lives of these anchorites, and also of common monks, and says that there were many thousands of them living wonderfully everywhere in the deserts and in monasteries, but yet especially in Egypt

Sume hí leofodon be ófete and wyrtum, sume be agenum geswince, sumum ðenodon englas, sumum fugelas, oðþæt englas eft on eaðelicum forðsiðe hí to Gode feredon
Some of them lived on fruit and herbs, some by their own labour, some were served by angels, some by birds, until angels afterwards by an easy death bore them to God

Eala ðu, eadige Godes cennestre, symle mæden Maria, tempel ðæs Halgan Gastes, mæden ǽr geeacnunge, mæden on geeacnunge, mæden æfter geeacnunge, micel is ðin mærð on ðisum freols-dæge betwux þam foresædum halgum
O thou, blessed parent of God, ever maiden Mary, temple of the Holy Ghost, maiden before conception, maiden in conception, maiden after conception, great is thy glory on this festival among the beforesaid saints

forðan ðe ðurh þine clænan cenninge him eallum becom halignyss and ða heofonlican geðincðu
because through thy pure childbirth holiness and heavenly honours came to them all

We sprecað be ðære heofonlican cwene endebyrdlice æfter wífháde, þeah-hwæðere eal seo geleaffulle gelaðung getreowfullice be hire singð, þæt heo is geuferod and aháfen ofer engla werod to þam wuldorfullan heahsetle
We speak of the heavenly queen, as is usual, according to her womanhood, yet all the faithful church confidently sing of her, that she is exalted and raised above the hosts of angels to the glorious throne

Nis be nanum oðrum halgan gecweden, þæt heora ænig ofer engla werod aháfen sy, buton be Marian ánre
Of no other saints is it said, that any of them is raised above the hosts of angels, but of Mary alone

Heo æteowde mid hire gebysnungum þæt heofonlice líf on eorðan, forðan þe mægðhád is ealra mægna cwén and gefera heofonlicra engla
She manifested by her example the heavenly life on earth, for maidenhood is of all virtues queen, and the associate of the heavenly angels

Ðyses mædenes gebysnungum and fótswaðum fyligde ungerím heap mægðhádes manna on clænnysse þurhwunigende, forlætenum giftum, to ðam heofonlicum brydguman Criste geþeodende mid ánrædum mode, and haligre drohtnunge, and sidefullum gyrlan, to þan swiðe, þæt heora for wel menige for mæigðháde martyrdom geðrowodon, and swa mid twyfealdum sige to heofonlicum eardung-stowum wuldorfulle becomon
The example and footsteps of this maiden were followed by an innumerable body of persons in maidenhood, living in purity, renouncing marriage, attaching themselves to the heavenly bridegroom Christ with steadfast mind and holy converse, and with wide garments, to that degree, that very many of them suffered martyrdom for maidenhood, and so with twofold victory went glorious to the heavenly dwelling-places

Eallum ðisum foresædum halgum, þæt is, englum and Godes gecorenum mannum, is þyses dæges wurðmynt gemærsod on geleaffulre gelaðunge, him to wurðmynte and us to fultume, þæt we ðurh heora þingrædene him geferlæhte beon moton
To all these beforesaid saints, that is, angels and God's chosen men, is the honour of this day celebrated in the faithful church, in honour to them and in aid to us, that we, through their intercession, may be with them associated

Þæs ús getiðige se mildheorta Drihten, þe hí ealle and ús mid his deorwurðan blode fram deofles hæftnedum alysde
May the merciful Lord grant us this, who redeemed them all and us with his precious blood from the devil's thraldom

We sceolon on ðyssere mærlican freols-tide mid halgum gebedum and lofsangum us geinnian, swa hwæt swa we on oðrum freols-dagum ealles geares ymbrynes, þurh mennisce tyddernysse hwónlicor gefyldon, and carfullice hógian þæt we to ðære ecan freols-tide becumon
We should, on this great festival, complete, with holy prayers and hymns, whatsoever we on other festivals of the whole circuit of the year have, through human weakness, less perfectly performed, and carefully cogitate that we may come to the eternal festival

Ðæt hálige godspel, þe nu lytle ǽr ætforan eow gerædd wæs, micclum geþwærlæcð þyssere freols-tide, forðan ðe hit geendebyrt þa eahta eadignyssa ðe ða halgan to heofonlicum geðincðum gebrohton
The holy gospel, that has just now been read before you, accords greatly with this festival, for it sets forth in order the eight beatitudes, which have brought the holy to heavenly honours

Matheus awrát on þysum dægþerlican godspelle, þæt se Hælend on sumere tide
Matthew wrote in this day's gospel, that Jesus at a certain time

gesawe micele menigu him fyligende
saw a great multitude following him

þa astah he upp on ane dune
then he went up on a mount

Þaða hé gesæt, þa genealæhton his leorning-cnihtas him to, and hé undyde his muð, and hi lærde, þus cweðende, Eadige beoð þa gastlican ðearfan
When he sat his disciples approached him, and he opened his mouth, and taught them, thus saying, Blessed are the spiritual poor

et reliqua
etc

Se wisa Augustinus trahtnode þis godspel, and sæde, þæt seo dún þe se Hælend astah getácnað ða healican bebodu soðre Rihtwisnysse: þa læssan beboda wæron gesette ðam Iudeiscan folce
The wise Augustine expounded this gospel, and said, that the mount which Jesus ascended betokens the high commandments of true Righteousness: the less commandments were appointed for the Jewish folk

An God þeah-hwæðere gesette, þurh his halgan witegan, þa læssan bebodu Iudeiscre ðeode, þe mid ógan ða-gyt gebunden wæs
One God, nevertheless, appointed, through his holy prophets, the less commandments to the Jewish nation, which was yet bound by fear

and he gesette, þurh his agenne Sunu, þa maran bebodu cristenum folce, þa ðe he mid soðre lufe to alysenne com
and he appointed, through his own Son, the greater commandments for the christian folk, whom he with true love came to redeem

Sittende he tæhte: þæt belimpð to wurðscipe láreowdomes
He taught sitting: that belongs to the dignity of teachership

Him to genealæhton his discipuli, þæt hí gehendran wæron lichamlice, þa ðe mid mode his bebodum genealæhton
His disciples approached him, that they might be nearer bodily, who with mind approached to his commandments

Se Hælend geopenode his muð
Jesus opened his mouth

Witodlice se geopenode his muð to þære godspellican láre, seðe on ðære ealdan ǽ gewunelice openode þæra witegena muð
Verily he opened his mouth to the evangelic lore, who in the old law was wont to open the mouths of the prophets

Þeah-hwæðere his muðes geopenung getácnað þa deoplican spræce ðe he ða forð-ateah
Yet the opening of his mouth betokens the deep speech which he then drew forth

He cwæð
He said

Eadige beoð þa gastlican ðearfan, forðan þe heora is heofonan rice
Blessed are the spiritual poor, for of them is the kingdom of heaven

Hwæt sind ða gastlican ðearfan buton ða eadmodan, þe Godes ege habbað, and nane toðundennysse nabbað
Who are the spiritual poor but the humble, who have awe of God, and have no arrogance

Godes ege is wisdomes angynn, and modignyss is ælcere synne anginn
Awe of God is the beginning of wisdom, and pride is the beginning of every sin

Fela sind ðearfan þurh hafenleaste, and na on heora gaste, forðan ðe hí gewilniað fela to hæbbenne
Many are poor through indigence, and not in their spirit, because they desire to have much

Sind eac oðre ðearfan, na ðurh hafenleaste ac on gaste, forðan þe hí synd, æfter þæs apostolican cwyde
There are also other poor, not through indigence but in spirit, because they are, according to the apostolic saying

Swa swa naht hæbbende, and ealle ðing geagnigende
As having nought and possessing all things

On þas wisan wæs Abraham ðearfa, and Iacob, and Dauid, seðe, on his cynesetle aháfen, hine sylfne geswutelode þearfan on gaste, þus cweðende
In this way Abraham was poor, and Jacob, and David, who, raised on his throne, showed himself poor in spirit, thus saying

Ic soðlice eom wædla and þearfa
I truly am poor and needy

Þa módigan rican ne beoð þearfan ne þurh hafenleaste ne on gaste, forðan ðe hí synd gewelgode mid æhtum, and toðundene on mode
The proud rich are not needy through indigence nor in spirit, for they are enriched with possessions and swelled up in mind

Þurh hafenleaste and on gaste synd þearfan ða fullfremedan munecas, þe for Gode ealle ðing forlætað to ðan swiðe, þæt hi nellað habban heora agenne lichaman on heora anwealde, ac lybbað be heora gastlican láreowas wissunge
Poor through indigence and in spirit are those perfect monks, who for God so completely forsake all things, that they will not have their own bodies in their power, but live by direction of their ghostly teacher

and forði swa micclum swa hí her for Gode on hafenleaste wuniað, swa micclum hí beoð eft on ðam toweardan wuldre gewelgode
and therefore as much as they here for God continue in indigence, so much will they be hereafter enriched in the glory to come

Eadige beoð þa liðan, forðan þe hí þæt lánd geagniað
Blessed are the meek, for they shall possess the land

Þa synd liðe and gedefe, þa ðe ne wiðstandað yfelum, ac oferswyðað mid heora góódnysse þone yfelan: hi habbað þæt lánd þe se sealm-sceop embe spræc
They are meek and gentle, who withstand not the evil, but with their goodness overcome the evil: they shall have the land of which the psalmist spake

Drihten, þu eart min hiht: beo min dæl on þæra lybbendra eorðan
Lord, thou art my hope: be my portion in the earth of the living

Þæra lybbendra eorðe is seo staðelfæstnyss þæs ecan eardes, on ðam gerest seo sawul swa swa se lichama on eorðan
The earth of the living is the stability of the eternal country, in which the soul rests as the body does on earth

Se eard is rest and líf gecorenra halgena
That country is the rest and life of the chosen saints

Eadige beoð ða þe heofiað, forðan ðe hi beoð gefrefrode
Blessed are they who mourn, for they shall be comforted

Na beoð þa eadige, þe for hynðum oððe lirum hwilwendlicra hyðða heofiað
They are not blessed who mourn for calamities or losses of transitory comforts

ac ða beoð eadige, ðe heora synna bewepað, forðan þe se Halga Gast hí gefrefrað, seðe deð forgyfenysse ealra synna, se is geháten Paraclitus, þæt is, Frefrigend, forðan ðe he frefrað þæra behreowsigendra heortan þurh his gife
but they are blessed who bewail their sins, for the Holy Ghost will comfort them, who grants forgiveness of all sins, who is called Paraclete, that is Comforter, because he comforts the hearts of the penitent by his grace

Eadige beoð þa þe sind ofhingrode and ofþyrste æfter rihtwisnysse, forðan ðe hi beoð gefyllede
Blessed are they who are hungry and thirsty after righteousness, for they shall be filled

Se bið ofhingrod and ofðyrst æfter rihtwisnysse, seðe Godes beboda lustlice gehyrð, and lustlicor mid weorcum gefylð: se bið þonne mid þam mete gefylled ðe Drihten embe spræc
He is hungry and thirsty after righteousness who joyfully hears God's commandments and more joyfully by works fulfils them: he will then be filled with the meat of which the Lord spake

Min mete is, þæt ic wyrce mines Fæder willan, þæt is rihtwisnys
My meat is, that I work my Father's will, that is righteousness

Þonne mæg hé cweðan mid þam sealm-sceope
Then may he say with the psalmist

Drihten, ic beo æteowed mid rihtwisnysse on ðinre gesihðe, and ic beo gefylled, þonne ðin wuldor geswutelod bið
Lord, I will appear with righteousness in thy sight, and I shall be filled, then will thy glory be manifested

Eadige beoð þa mildheortan, forðan þe hí begytað mildheortnysse
Blessed are the merciful, for they shall get mercy

Eadige beoð þa ðe earmra manna þurh mildheortnysse gehelpað, forðan ðe him bið swa geleanod, þæt hí sylfe beoð fram yrmðe alysede
Blessed are they who help miserable men through mercy, for they shall be so rewarded that they themselves shall be redeemed from misery

Eadige beoð þa clænheortan, forðan ðe hí geseoð God sylfne
Blessed are the clean of heart, for they shall see God himself

Stunte synd þa ðe gewilniað God to geseonne mid flæsclicum eagum, þonne he bið mid þære heortan gesewen
Foolish are they who desire to see God with fleshly eyes, when he will be seen with the heart

ac heo is to clænsigenne fram leahtrum, þæt heo God geseon mage
but it is to be cleansed from sins, that it may see God

Swa swa eorðlic leoht ne mæg beon gesewen buton mid clænum eagum, swa eac ne bið God gesewen buton mid clænre heortan
So as earthly light cannot be seen but with clean eyes, so also God cannot be seen but with a clean heart

Eadige beoð þa gesibsuman, forðan ðe hí beoð Godes bearn gecígede
Blessed are the peaceful, for they shall be called children of God

On sibbe is fulfremednyss þær ðær nán ðing ne þwyrað: forði synd þa gesibsuman Godes bearn, forðan ðe nán ðing on him ne wiðerað ongean God
In peace there is perfectness where nothing thwarts: therefore are the peaceful children of God, because nothing in them is adverse to God

Gesibsume sind þa on him sylfum, ðe ealle heora modes styrunga mid gesceade gelógiað, and heora flæsclican gewilnunga gewyldað swa þæt hí sylfe beoð Godes rice
Peaceful are they in themselves, who order all the perturbations of their mind with reason, and govern their fleshly desires so that they are themselves God's kingdom

Ðeos is seo sib ðe is forgyfen on eorðan þam mannum þe beoð gódes willan
This is the peace which is given on earth to those men who are of good will

God ure Fæder is gesibsum
God our Father is peaceful

witodlice forði gedafenað þam bearnum þæt hi heora Fæder geefenlæcon
verily therefore it befitteth the children to imitate their Father

Eadige beoð ða ðe þoliað ehtnysse for rihtwisnysse, forðan ðe heora is heofonan rice
Blessed are they who suffer persecution for righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven

Fela sind ða ðe ehtnysse ðoliað for mislicum intingum, swa swa doð mannslagan, and sceaðan, and gehwilce fyrnfulle
Many are they who suffer persecution for divers causes, so as murderers do, and robbers and all criminals

ac seo ehtnys him ne becymð to nánre eadignysse
but to them persecution leads to no beatitude

ac seo ehtnys ana þe bið for rihtwisnysse geðolod becymð to ecere eadignysse
but the persecution only which is suffered for righteousness leads to everlasting beatitude

Nis to ondrǽdenne ðwyrra manna ehtnys, ac má to forðyldigenne, swa swa Drihten to his leorning-cnihtum cwæð
The persecution of perverse men is not to be dreaded, but rather to be patiently borne, as the Lord said to his disciples

Ne ondræde ge eow ða ðe eowerne lichaman ofsleað, forðan ðe hí ne magon eowre sawle ofslean, ac ondrædað God, ðe mæg ægðer ge sawle ge lichaman on helle-susle fordón
Fear not those who slay your body, for they cannot slay your soul, but dread God, who can fordo both soul and body in hell-torment

Ne sceole we ðeah þa ðwyran to ure ehtnysse gremian, ac swiðor, gif hí astyrede beoð, mid rihtwisnysse gestillan
Yet should we not irritate the perverse to persecute us, but rather, if they be provoked, still them with righteousness

Gif hi ðonne þære ehtnysse geswycan nellað, selre ús bið þæt we ehtnysse ðolion þonne we riht forlæton
But if they will not cease from persecution, better will it be for us to suffer persecution than to forsake the right

Eahta eadignyssa synd on þisum godspelle geendebyrde
Eight beatitudes are set forth in this gospel

is ðeah gyt an cwyde bæftan, ðe is geðuht swilce he sy se nygoða stæpe, ac he soðlice belimpð to ðære eahteoðan eadignysse, forðan ðe hi butu sprecað be ehtnysse for rihtwisnysse and for Criste
but there is yet one sentence remaining, which seems as though it were the ninth step, but it truly belongs to the eighth beatitude, for they both speak of persecution for righteousness and for Christ

Þa eahta eadignyssa belimpað to eallum geleaffullum mannum, and se æftemysta cwyde, þeah ðe he synderlice to þam apostolum gecweden wære, belimpð eac to eallum Cristes limum, forðan ðe hé nis se nygoða, ac fyligð þære eahteoðan eadignysse, swa swa we ǽr sædon
The eight beatitudes belong to all believing men, and the last sentence, though it was particularly said to the apostles, belongs also to all members of Christ, for it is not the ninth, but follows the eighth beatitude, as we before said

Se Hælend cwæð
Jesus said

Eadige ge beoð þonne man eow wyrigð, and eower eht, and ælc yfel ongean eow sprecð leogende for me
Blessed are ye when men curse you, and persecute you, and lying speak every evil against you for me

Se bið eadig and gesælig þe for Criste ðolað wyriunge and hospas fram leasum licceterum, forðan ðe seo lease wyriung becymð þam rihtwisum to eadigre bletsunge
He will be blessed and happy who for Christ suffers malediction and insults from false hypocrites, because false malediction becomes a blessed benediction to the righteous

Blissiað and fægniað, forðan ðe eower méd is menigfeald on heofonum
Rejoice and be glad, for your meed is manifold in heaven

Geleaffullum gedafenað þæt hi wuldrion on gedrefednyssum, forðan ðe seo gedrefednys wyrcð geðyld, and þæt geðyld afándunge, and seo afándung hiht
It befits the faithful to glory in tribulations, for tribulation works patience, and patience trial, and trial hope

Se hiht soðlice ne bið næfre gescynd, forðan þe Godes lufu is agóten on urum heortum þurh ðone Halgan Gast, seðe us is forgífen
But hope is never confounded, because the love of God is poured into our hearts, by the Holy Ghost who is given to us

Be þisum cwæð se apostol Iacobus
Of this spake the apostle James

Eala ge mine gebroðra, wenað eow ælcere blisse, þonne ge beoð on mislicum costnungum, forðan þe seo afándung eowres geleafan is miccle deorwurðre þonne gold þe bið ðurh fyr afándod
O ye my brothers, hope for yourselves every bliss, when ye are in divers temptations, for the trial of your faith is much more precious than gold which has been tried by fire

Eft cwyð þæt halige gewrit
Again, holy writ says

Læmene fatu beoð on ofne afándode, and rihtwise menn on gedrefednysse heora costnunge
Vessels of clay are tried in a furnace, and righteous men in the affliction of their temptation

Be þisum cwæð eac se Hælend on oðre stowe to his leorning-cnihtum
Of these said Jesus also in another place to his disciples

Gif ðes middangeard eow hatað, wite ge þæt hé me hatode ǽr eow
If this world hate you, know ye that it hated me before you

and gif hí min ehton, þonne ehtað hi eac eower
and if they persecuted me, then will they also persecute you

Crist sylf wæs fram arleasum mannum acweald, and swa eac his leorning-cnihtas and martyras
Christ himself was slain by impious men, and so also his disciples and martyrs

and ealle ða ðe gewilniað arfæstlice to drohtnigenne on geleaffulre gelaðunge, hí sceolon ehtnysse ðolian, oððe fram ungesewenlicum deofle oððe fram gesewenlicum arleasum deofles limum: ac þas hwilwendlican ehtnyssa oþþe gedrefednyssa we sceolon mid gefean for Cristes naman geðafian, forðan ðe he þus behet eallum geðyldigum
and all those who desire to live religiously in the faithful church shall suffer persecution, either from the invisible devil or from visible impious limbs of the devil: but these transitory persecutions or tribulations we should with joy undergo for Christ's name, because he has thus promised to all the patient

Blissiað and fægniað, efne eower méd is menigfeald on heofonum
Exult and rejoice, behold your meed is manifold in heaven

We mihton ðas halgan rædinge menigfealdlicor trahtnian, æfter Augustines smeagunge, ac us twynað hwæðer ge magon maran deopnysse ðæron þearflice tocnawan
We might more elaborately expound this holy text, according to the interpretation of Augustine, but we doubt whether ye can accurately judge of greater deepness therein

ac uton biddan mid inweardre heortan þone Ælmihtigan Wealdend, seðe ús mid menigfealdre mærsunge ealra his halgena nu to-dæg geblissode, þæt he us getiðige genihtsumnysse his miltsunge þurh heora menigfealdan þingrædena, þæt we on écere gesihðe mid him blission, swa swa we nu mid hwilwendlicere þenunge hí wurðiað
but let us with inward heart pray to the Almighty Ruler, who has gladdened us to-day with the manifold celebration of all his saints, that he grant us abundance of his mercy through their manifold intercessions, so that we ever in their sight may rejoice with them, as we now with transitory service honour them

Sy wuldor and lóf Hælendum Criste, seðe is anginn and ende, Scyppend and Alysend ealra halgena, mid Fæder and mid Halgum Gaste, á on ecnysse
Be glory and praise to Jesus Christ, who is the beginning and end, Creator and Redeemer of all saints, with Father and with Holy Ghost, ever to eternity

Amen
Amen

Menn ða leofostan, eower geleafa bið þe trumra, gif ge gehyrað be Godes halgum, hú hi þæt heofonlice rice geearnodon
Most beloved men, your faith will be the firmer, if ye hear concerning God's saints, how they earned the heavenly kingdom

and ge magon ðe cuðlicor to him clypian, gif heora lifes drohtnunga eow þurh láreowa bodunge cuðe beoð
and ye may the more certainly call to them, if the course of their lives be known to you through the preaching of teachers

Þes halga wer Clemens, þe we on ðisum andweardan freols-dæge wurðiað, wæs þæs eadigan Petres apostoles leorning-cniht
This holy man Clement, whom we honour on this present festival, was a disciple of the blessed apostle Peter

Þa wæs he ðeonde on gastlicere láre and gecneordnysse to ðan swiðe, þæt se apostol Petrus hine geceas to papan Romaniscre ðeode æfter his dæge, and ǽr his ðrowunge hine to papan gehádode, and on his biscop-setle gesette, to ði þæt he ðæra cristenra manna gymene hæfde
Then was he thriving in ghostly lore and study so greatly, that the apostle Peter chose him for pope of the Roman people after his day, and before his passion ordained him pope, and placed him in his episcopal seat, that he might have care of christian men

Hé gehádode twegen biscopas ǽr ðan, Linum et Cletum, ac hé ne sette na hí on his setle, swa swa hé dyde þisne halgan wer, þe we to-dæg wurðiað
He had ordained two bishops previously, Linus and Clitus, but he did not place them in his seat, as he did this holy man, whom to-day we honour

Hwæt ða, Clemens æfter Petres ðrowunge geðeah on fægernysse góddra ðeawa, swa þæt he gecweme wæs Iudeiscum, and hæðenum, and cristenum samod
Clement then after Peter's passion thrived in fairness of good morals, so that he was acceptable to Jews, and heathens, and christians together

Þam hæðenum leodum he gelicode, forðan ðe he mid hospe heora godas ne gebysmrode, ac mid bóclicum gesceade him geswutelode hwæt hí wæron, and hwær acennede þa ðe hí him to godum wurðodon, and heora drohtnunge and geendunge mid swutelum seðungum gewissode
He was liked by the heathen people, because he did not insult their gods with contumely, but with bookly reasoning manifested to them what they were, and where born whom they honoured as their gods, and showed to them, with manifest proofs, their lives and ends

and cwæð, þæt hí sylfe eaðelice mihton to Godes miltsunge becuman, gif hí fram heora dwollicum biggengum eallunga gecyrdon
and said that they themselves might easily attain to God's mercy, if they would wholly turn from their erroneous worship

Iudeiscre ðeode hylde he begeat, forðan þe he soðlice geseðde þæt heora forðfæderas Godes frynd gecígede wæron, and him God halige ǽ sette to heora lifes rihtinge
The favour of the Jewish people he got, because he truly proved that their forefathers were called friends of God, and that God appointed them a holy law for their lives' direction

and cwæð, þæt hí fyrmeste on Godes gecorennysse wæron, gif hí mid geleafan his bebodum gehyrsumodon
and said, that they would have been foremost in God's election, if with belief they had obeyed his commandments

Fram cristenum he wæs swiðost gelufod, forðan ðe he gehwilce eardas namcuðlice on gemynde hæfde, and þa wanspedigan cristenan ðæra earda ne geðafode þæt hí openre wædlunge underðeodde wurdon, ac mid dæghwomlicere bodunge hé gemánode þa rican and þa spedigan, þæt hi ðæra cristenra wædlunge mid heora spedum gefrefrodon, þe-læs ðe hí ðurh hæðenra manna gifa besmitene wurdon
By the christians he was most beloved, because he had all countries by name in his memory, and permitted not the indigent christians of those countries to be reduced to public mendicity, but by daily preaching he exhorted the rich and affluent to alleviate the poverty of the christians with their affluence, lest by the gifts of heathen men they should be corrupted

And Dionisius, Godes cyðere, seðe þurh Paules Apostoles láre and tácna to Cristes geleafan mid haligre drohtnunge gecyrde, gewende on ðam timan fram Greclande to ðam halgan papan Clementem, Petres æftergencgan, and he hine mid micclum wurðmynte underfeng, and for arwurðnysse his halgan lifes him cuðlice tolét, and mid lufe geheold
And Dionysius, God's martyr, who through the lore and miracles of Paul the Apostle had with holy life turned to the faith of Christ, returned at that time from Greece to the holy pope Clement, Peter's successor, and he received him with great honour, and in veneration expressly remitted to him his holy life, and with love retained him

Eft æfter fyrste cwæð se eadiga Clemens to ðam halgan were Dionisium
Again, after a time, said the blessed Clement to the holy man Dionysius

Si ðe forgyfen miht to gebindenne and to alysenne, swa swa me is
Be to thee given might to bind and to loose, so as there is to me

and þu far to ðæra Francena rice, and boda him godspel and heofonan rices wuldor
and go thou to the realm of the Franks, and preach to them the gospel and the glory of heaven's kingdom

Dionisius þa wearð his hæsum gehyrsum, and mid geferum ferde to Franclande, cristendom bodigende mid micclum wundrum to ðan swiðe þæt þa reðan hæðenan, swa hraðe swa hi hine gesawon, oððe hí feallende his fét gesohton, him and Gode gehyrsumigende, oððe gif heora hwylc ðwyrode, þonne wearð se mid swa micelre fyrhte fornumen, þæt hé ðærrihte his andweardnysse forfleah
Dionysius was then obedient to his commands, and with his companions went to Frankland, preaching christianity with great miracles so effectually, that the fierce heathen, as soon as they saw him, either falling sought his feet, obeying him and God, or if any one of them was hostile, he was seized with such great fear, that he straightways fled from his presence

Wearð ða gebíged eal Francena rice to Godes geleafan, þurh bodunge and wundra þæs eadigan weres Dionisii
Then was all the realm of the Franks inclined to God's faith, through the preaching and miracles of the blessed man Dionysius

and hé eac sume his geferan to Ispanian gesende, þæt hi ðam leodscipe lifes word gecyddon
