and he also sent some of his companions to Spain, to announce the word of life to that nation

Hwæt ða, Clemens Romana papa wearð gewreht to ðam casere Traianum, for ðam micclan cristendome þe he gehwær on his rice arærde
After this, Clement, the Romans' pope, was accused to the emperor Trajan, for the great christianity which he had raised everywhere in his realm

Þa sende se casere Traianus gewritu ongean, þæt se halga papa Clemens to hæðengylde gebugan sceolde, oððe hine mann asende ofer sǽ on wræcsið to sumum westene, on þam þe cristene menn for geleafan fordemde wræcsiðedon
Then sent the emperor Trajan letters back, that the holy pope Clement should bow to heathenism, or should be sent over sea in exile to a waste, to which christian men condemned for belief were banished

Þæs caseres hǽs wearð þa forðgencge, and swa micele gife foresceawode se Ælmihtiga God Clemente, þæt se hæðena dema his sið mid wope bemænde, þus cweðende
The emperor's command was then carried into effect, and the Almighty God had provided so great grace for Clement, that the heathen judge bewailed his journey with weeping, thus saying

Se God þe ðu wurðast gefrefrige ðe, and fultumige on ðinum wræcsiðe
May the God whom thou worshipest comfort and support thee in thy exile

And het ða hine to scipe lǽdan, and ealle his neoda foresceawian, þe hé to bigwiste habban mihte
And he then ordered him to be led to a ship, and all his needs to be provided for, which he might have for sustenance

Wearð ða þæt scip gefylled mid cristenum mannum, þe þone halgan papan forlǽtan noldon
The ship was then filled with christian men, who would not forsake the holy pope

Þaða hé to ðam westene becom, þa gemette he ðær má þonne twa ðusend cristenra manna, þe mid langsumere genyðerunge to marmstán-gedelfe gesette wæron, þe his tocymes micclum fægnodon, mid anre stemne cweðende
When he came to the waste, he found there more than two thousand christian men, who by a longsome condemnation were set to the digging of marble, who greatly rejoiced at his coming, with one voice saying

Efne her is ure hyrde, efne her is se frefrigend ures geswinces and weorces
Behold here is our shepherd, behold here is the comforter of our tribulation and work

Þaða hé mid tihtendlicum wordum heora gewǽhtan mód getrymde and gefrefrode, ða geaxode hé þæt hí dæghwomlice ofer six mila him wæter on heora exlum gefetton
When he with persuasive words had confirmed and comforted their afflicted minds, he was informed that they daily fetched water for themselves on their shoulders more than six miles

Ða cwæð se eadiga biscop
Then said the blessed bishop

Uton biddan mid fæstum geleafan Drihten Hælend, þæt hé us his andetterum ða æddran his wyllspringes gehendor geopenige, þæt we on his wel-dædum blission
Let us with firm faith pray to the Lord Jesus, to open nearer at hand for us his professors the veins of his wellsprings, that we may rejoice in his benefits

Þaða ðis gebed gefylled wæs, þa beheold se biscop on ælce healfe, and geseah ða on þa swiðran healfe an hwít lamb standan, þe bícnode mid his swyðran fét, swilce hit þa wæter-æddran geswutelian wolde
When this prayer was ended, the bishop beheld on each side, and saw on the right side a white lamb standing, which beckoned with his right foot, as if it would show the water-vein

Ða undergeat Clemens þæs lambes gebícnunge, and cwæð
Then Clement understood the lamb's beckoning, and said

Geopeniað þas eorðan on þyssere stowe þær ðær þæt lamb to-gebícnode
Open the earth in this place where the lamb beckoned

His geferan ða his hæse gefyldon, and þærrihte æt ðam forman gedelfe swegde út ormæte wyllspring, and mid micclum streame forð-yrnende wæs
His companions fulfilled his command, and straightways at the first digging an immense wellspring sounded out, and ran forth in a great stream

Hwæt hí ealle ða micclum blissodon, and Gode ðancodon heora geswinces lisse
Whereupon they all greatly rejoiced, and thanked God for this alleviation of their tribulation

Þa wæs se cwyde gefylled, þe hí on ðæs biscopes to-cyme gecwædon
Then was the saying fulfilled, which they said at the bishop's coming

Efne her is ure hyrde, efne her is se frefrigend ures geswinces
Behold here is our shepherd, behold here is the comforter of our tribulation

Ðis wundor ða asprang geond þa gehendan scira, and hí ealle þone halgan biscop mid arwurðnysse geneosodon, biddende þæt hé hí mid his láre getrymde
This miracle then became known through the neighbouring provinces, and they all visited the holy bishop with reverence, praying that he would confirm them with his lore

He ða hi ealle to Godes geleafan gebígde, and binnan feawum dagum þær fif hund manna gefullode
He then inclined them all to God's faith, and within a few days baptized there five hundred men

and wurdon ða fela cyrcan gehwær arærede, and deofolgild toworpene
and many churches were raised everywhere, and idols overthrown

swa þæt binnan anes geares fyrste næs gemet hæðengild geond hund-teontig mila neawiste
so that within the space of one year idolatry was not found over a neighbourhood of a hundred miles

Þa gelámp hit þæt sume ða hæðenan wurdon mid ándan getyrigde, and heora ærende to ðam casere asendon, and him cyddon þæt his folc eall endemes astyred wære, and eallunga fram his biggencgum gecyrred, þurh Clementem ðæra cristenra biscop
It happened then that certain heathens were stimulated by envy, and sent their errand to the emperor, and announced to him that his folk were at last all excited, and wholly turned from his worship, through Clement, the christians' bishop

Þa wearð se hæþena casere Traianus mycclum astyred, and asende ænne wælhreowne heretogan, his nama wæs Aufidianus, se mid mislicum witum fela cristenra manna acwealde, þæt he þone halgan biscop mid þam geleaffullan folce adylegian sceolde
Then was the heathen emperor, Trajan, greatly excited, and sent a cruel commander, his name was Aufidianus, who with divers torments had killed many christian men, that he might destroy the holy bishop with the faithful folk

Se arleasa cwellere ða, Aufidianus, ðaða he ne mihte mid nánum þeowracan ða cristenan geegsian, forðan ðe hi ealle samod blissigende to martyrdome onetton, þa forlét he þæt folc, and ðone biscop ænne to þam hæðengylde genydde
The impious murderer then, Aufidianus, when he could not by any threats terrify the christians, for they all rejoicing together hastened to martyrdom, left the folk and would compel the bishop alone to idolatry

ac ðaða he geseah þæt hé nateshwon hine gebígan ne mihte, þa cwæð he to his underðeoddum
but when he saw that he could not in any way incline him, he said to those under him

Lædað hine to middere sǽ, and getigað ænne ancran to his swuran, and ascufað hine út on middan þære dypan
Lead him to the middle of the sea, and tie an anchor to his neck, and thrust him out into the middle of the deep

Hit wearð þa gedón be hǽse þæs wælhreowan cwelleres, and micel menigu þæra cristenra stód on þære sǽ-strande, wepende and biddende þone Ælmihtigan, þe sǽ and eorðan gesceop, þæt hí moston his halige líc mid heora ðenungum behwurfan
It was then done by command of the cruel murderer, and a great multitude of the christians stood on the sea strand, weeping and praying to the Almighty, who created sea and earth, that they might attend his holy body with their services

Þa cwædon his twegen leorning-cnihtas, Febus and Cornelius
Then said his two disciples Phœbus and Cornelius

Eala ge gebroðra, uton anmodlice biddan urne Drihten, þæt hé us geswutelige ða arwurðfullan andweardnysse his halgan cyðeres
O ye brothers, let us unanimously pray to our Lord, that he manifest to us the venerable presence of his holy martyr

Hwæt ða, seo sǽ, ðurh Godes hǽse, útflowende, him gerymde þreora mila dries færeldes, swa þæt þa cristenan bealdlice inn-eodon, and gemetton niwe ðruh of marmanstáne on cyrcan wison gesceapene, and þæs halgan cyðeres líc ðær-binnan ðurh engla ðenunge gelogod, and þone ancran wið his sidan licgende
Whereupon the sea, at God's behest, flowing out, cleared for them three miles of dry space, so that the christians boldly went in, and found a new coffin of marble shaped in form of a church, and the holy martyr's body placed therein through the ministry of angels, and the anchor lying by his side

Þa wearð him geswutelod þæt he æt Gode abǽde, þæt on ælces geares ymbryne, ymbe his ðrowung-tíde, seo sǽ seofan dagas drígne grund þam folce gegearcige, þæt hí binnan ðam fyrste his halgan lichaman gesecan magon
Then was manifested to them that they should obtain from God, that in the course of every year, at the time of his passion, the sea for seven days should prepare dry ground for the people, that they within that time might seek his holy body

Þæt belimpð to lofe and herunge ures Hælendes, seðe his halgan cyðere ða arwurðan byrgene gegearcode
That happens to the praise and honour of our Saviour, who prepared the honourable sepulchre for his holy martyr

Þa ðurh ðis tácn wurdon ealle þa ungeleaffullan cristene, swa þæt nateshwón næs gemét on ðam earde naðor ne hæðen ne Iudeisc ðe nære gebíged to cristenum geleafan
Then through this miracle all the unbelieving became christians, so that there was not found in the country either heathen or Jew that was not converted to the christian faith

Soðlice æt þære halgan þrýh sind getiðode heofonlice lacnunga adlium lichaman, þurh ðingunge ðæs halgan cyðeres
But at the holy coffin heavenly cures are permitted for diseased bodies, through the intercession of the holy martyr

Swa hwá swa on his freols-tide untrum his byrgene gesehð, he gewent blissigende and gesundful ongean
Whosoever sick seeks his sepulchre on his festival, returns rejoicing and healthy

Þær beoð blinde onlihte, and deofolseoce gewittige, and gehwilce gedrehte þær beoð geblissode
There are the blind enlightened, and the possessed with devils restored to reason, and all afflicted are there made joyful

and ealle geleaffulle his weldæda brucað, and mid wurþmynte Godes gerynu ðær beoð gefyllede
and all the faithful enjoy his benefits, and with reverence God's mysteries are there fulfilled

Hit gelámp ða on sumum geare on his freols-tide, þæt sum wíf mid hire nywerenan cylde betwux oðrum mannum þone halgan wer geneosode
It happened in one year at his festival, that a woman with her tender child among other persons visited the holy man

Þa geendodum dagum þære freols-tide com seo sǽ færlice swegende, and þæt folc swiðlice aweg efste, and þæt wíf ðurh ða færlican styrunge ne gymde hire cildes ǽrðan þe heo to lánde becom
When the days of the festival were ended, the sea came suddenly sounding, and the folk hastened away with all speed, and the woman, through the sudden tumult, heeded not her child before she came to land

Heo ða sárig þa twelf monað adreah, and eft embe ðæs geares ymbryne, on þære ylcan freols-tide, for-arn ðam folce, and genealæhte to þære byrgene mid wope, þus biddende
She then passed the twelve months in sorrow, and again after the expiration of the year, at the same festival, ran before the folk, and approached the sepulchre with weeping, thus praying

Þu Drihten Hælend, þe ðære wydewan ancennedan sunu to life arærdest, beseoh me to miltse, þæt ic, ðurh ðingunge þines halgan þe her gerest, beo ðæs tiðe þe ic geornlice bidde
Thou Lord Jesus, who didst raise the widow's only son to life, look on me in mercy, that I, through the intercession of thy holy one who here resteth, may obtain that for which I fervently pray

Þa mid þyssere bene beseah heo to ðære stowe ðær heo þæt cild ǽr forlét, and gemette hit swa slapende swa heo hit ǽr gelede
Then with this prayer she looked to the place where she had before left the child, and found it so sleeping as she had previously laid it

Heo ða mid micelre blisse hit awrehte, and wepende cossode
She then with great joy awakened it, and weeping kissed it

Þa befrán heo þæt cild, betwux ðam cossum, hú hit macode on eallum ðam fyrste þæs geares ymbrynes
Then she asked the child, between the kisses, how it had fared in all the time of the year's course

Þæt cild þære meder geandwyrde
The child answered the mother

Modor min, nyste ic hú ðyses geares ymryne geendode, forðan ðe ic softum slæpe me gereste, swa swa ðu me forlete, oð þæt þu eft me nu awrehtest
My mother, I know not how this year's course has ended, for I was resting in soft sleep, as thou didst leave me, until thou now again hast awakened me

Þæt geleaffulle folc ða micclum blissigende, herode and bletsode þone Ælmihtigan Hælend, seðe his halgan mid tácnum and wundrum gewurðað, and swa heora geearnunga geswutelað
The believing folk then greatly rejoicing, praised and blessed the Almighty Jesus, who honours his saints with signs and wonders, and so manifests their merits

Oft hwónlice gelyfede menn smeagað mid heora stuntan gesceade, hwí se Ælmihtiga God æfre geðafian wolde þæt þa hæðenan his halgan mid gehwilcum tintregum acwellan moston
Oft men of slight faith inquire with their foolish reason, why the Almighty God would ever permit that the heathen should slay his saints with all kinds of torments

ac we wyllað nu eow gereccan sume geswutelunge of ðære ealdan ǽ, and eac of ðære niwan, hú mihtiglice se Wealdenda Drihten his halgan wið hæðenne here, oþþe wælhreowe ehteras gelome ahredde, and heora wiðerwinnan bysmorlice gescynde
but we will now relate to you some manifestation from the old law, and also from the new, how mightily the Powerful Lord has frequently saved his holy from the heathen host or from cruel persecutors, and ignominiously confounded their adversaries

Hit gelámp on ðam feowerteoðan geare Ezechían cynedomes, Iudeisces cyninges, þæt Sennacherib, Syria cyning, manega leoda mid micclum cræfte to his anwealde gebígde, and swa wolde eac þone gelyfedan cyning Ezechíam, and asende his heretogan Rapsacen to þære byrig Hierusalem mid micclum ðrymme, and mid ærend-gewritum þæs Ælmihtigan Godes mihte gehyrwde, þus cweðende to ðam ymbsettan folce
It happened in the fourteenth year of the reign of Hezekiah, the Jewish king, that Sennacherib, king of Assyria, had bowed many nations with great craft to his power, and so would he also the faithful king Hezekiah, and sent his general Rabshakeh to the city of Jerusalem with a great host, and by his letters contemned the power of the Almighty God, thus saying to the beleaguered folk

Ne bepǽce Ezechías eow mid leasum hopan, þæt God eow wið me ahredde
Let not Hezekiah deceive you with false hope, that God will save you from me

Ic gewyllde and oferwánn fela ðeoda, and heora godas ne mihton hí gescyldan wið minne ðrymm
I have conquered and overcome many nations, and their gods could not shield them against my host

Hwæt is se god þe mage ðas burh wið minne here bewerian
Who is the god that can defend this city against my army

Hwæt ða, se cyning Ezechías awearp his purpuran reaf, and dyde hæran to his lice, and bær ða gewritu into Godes temple, and astrehtum limum hine gebæd, þus cweðende
Hereupon the king Hezekiah cast off his purple robe, and put haircloth on his body, and bare the letter into God's temple, and with outstretched limbs prayed, thus saying

Drihten, weroda God, þu ðe gesitst ofer engla ðrymm, þu eart ana God ealra ðeoda
Lord, God of hosts, thou who sittest above the company of angels, thou alone art God of all nations

þu geworhtest heofonas, and eorðan, and ealle gesceafta
thou wroughtest heavens, and earth, and all creatures

Ahyld ðin eare and gehyr, geopena ðine eagan and geseoh ðas wórd, þe Sennacherib asende to hospe and to tále ðe and þinum folce
Incline thine ear and hear, open thine eyes and see these words, which Sennacherib hath sent in scorn and reproach to thee and thy folk

Soðlice hé towende þa hæðenan godas, and hí forbærnde, forðan ðe hí næron godas, ac wæron manna hand-geweorc, treowene and stænene, and he hí forði tobrytte
Verily he overthrew and burned the heathen gods, for they were not gods, but were the handiwork of men, of wood and of stone, and he therefore brake them in pieces

Alys us nu, Drihten, fram his gebeote and mihte, þæt ealle ðeoda tocnawon þæt þu ána eart Ælmihtig God
Redeem us now, Lord, from his threatening and might, that all nations may know that thou alone art Almighty God

Ezechías eac asende his witan mid hǽran gescrydde to ðam witegan Isaiam, þus cweðende
Hezekiah also sent his counsellors clad in haircloth to the prophet Isaiah, thus saying

Ahefe ðine gebedu for Israhela ðeode, þæt se Ælmihtiga God gehyre þa talu ðe Syria cyning asende to hospe and to edwite his micclan mægenðrymme
Raise thy prayers for the people of Israel, that the Almighty God may hear the calumnies which the king of Assyria has sent in scorn and reproach of his great majesty

Þa andwyrde se witega Isaias þam bodum
Then answered the prophet Isaiah to the messengers

Secgað eowrum hlaforde, þæt hé unforht sy
Say to your lord that he be fearless

God Ælmihtig cwyð, Ne ascytt Sennacherib flán into ðære byrig Hierusalem, ne mid his scylde hí ne gewylt
God Almighty saith, Sennacherib shall not shoot arrows into the city of Jerusalem, nor with his shield overpower it

ac ic geslea ænne wriðan on his nosu, and ænne bridel on his weleras, and ic hine gelǽde ongean to his leode, and ic do þæt he fylð under swurdes ecge on his agenum eðele
but I will cast a hook into his nose, and a bridle on his lips, and I will lead him back to his people, and I will cause him to fall under the sword's edge in his own country

and ic ða burh gescylde for me and for minum ðeowan Dauid
and I will shield the city for myself and for my servant David

Þa on ðære nihte ferde Godes engel, and ofsloh ðæs Syrian cyninges here án hund þusend manna, and fif and hund-eahtatig þusenda
Then on that night God's angel went, and slew of the Assyrian king's army a hundred and eighty-five thousand men

Þæs on merigen arás Sennacherib, and geseah ða deadan líc, and gecyrde mid micelre sceame ongean to þære byrig Niniué
On the morrow Sennacherib arose, and saw the dead bodies, and turned with great shame back to the city of Nineveh

Hit gelámp ða þæt he hine gebæd to his deofolgylde, and his twegen suna hine mid swurde acwealdon, swa swa se witega þurh Godes Gast gewitegode
It happened then that he was praying to his idol, and his two sons slew him with the sword, as the prophet through the Spirit of God had prophesied

Eft siððan Nabochodonossor, se Chaldeisca cyning, het gebindan handum and fotum þa ðry gelyfedan cnihtas, Annanias, Azarias, Missael, and into ánum byrnendum ofne awurpan
After that Nebuchadnezzar, the Chaldean king, commanded the three believing youths, Hananiah, Azariah, and Mishael, to be bound hands and feet, and cast into a burning oven

forþan ðe hí noldon hí gebiddan to his deofolgilde
because they would not pray to his idol

Ac se Ælmihtiga God, þe hí anrædlice on belyfdon, asende his engel into ðam ofne mid þam cnihtum, and he ða tosceoc þone líg of ðam ofne, swa þæt þæt fyr ne mihte him derigan, ac sloh út of ðam ofne nigan and feowertig fæþma, and forswælde þa cwelleras þe þæt fyr onældon
But the Almighty God, in whom they stedfastly believed, sent his angel into the oven with the youths, and he scattered the flame from the oven, so that the fire might not hurt them, but struck out of the oven nine and forty fathoms, and burned the executioners who had kindled the fire

Þa sceawode se cyning þæra ðreora cnihta feax and lichaman, þus cweðende
Then the king beheld the hair and bodies of the three youths, thus saying

Sy gebletsod eower God, seðe asende his engel, and swa mihtelice his ðeowan of þam byrnendan ofne alysde
Blessed be your God, who hath sent his angel, and so mightily released his servants from the burning oven

Eac syððan, on Cyres dagum cyninges, wrehton ða Babiloniscan þone witegan Daniel, forðan ðe he towearp heora deofolgyld, and cwædon anmodlice to ðam foresædan cyninge Cyrum
Also afterwards, in the days of Cyrus the king, the Babylonians accused the prophet Daniel, because he had cast down their idol, and said unanimously to the beforesaid king Cyrus

Betæc us Daniel, ðe urne god Bél towearp, and þone dracan acwealde, þe we on belyfdon
Deliver unto}} us Daniel, who hath cast down our god Bel, and slain the dragon, in which we believed

Gif ðu hine forstenst, we fordylegiað þe and ðinne hyred
If thou protectest him, we will destroy thee and thine household

Þa geseah se cyning þæt hí anmode wæron, and neadunga þone witegan him to handum asceaf
Then the king saw that they were unanimous, and unwillingly delivered the prophet into their hands

Hi ða hine awurpon into anum seaðe, on þam wæron seofan leon, þam mann sealde dæghwomlice twa hryðeru and twa scép, ac him wæs ða oftogen ælces fodan six dagas, þæt hí ðone Godes mann abitan sceoldon
They then cast him into a pit, in which were seven lions, to which were given daily two oxen and two sheep, but then all food had been withheld from them for six days, that they might devour the man of God

On þære tide wæs sum oðer witega on Iudea-lande, his nama wæs Abacuc, se bær his ryfterum mete to æcere
At that time there was another prophet in the land of Judah, his name was Habakkuk, who bare for his reapers meat to the field

Þa com him to Godes engel, and cwæð
Then God's angel came to him, and said

Abacuc, bær ðone mete to Babilone, and syle Daniele, seðe sitt on ðæra leona seaðe
Habakkuk, bear the meat to Babylon, and give it to Daniel, who sitteth in the lions' pit

Abacuc andwyrde þam engle
Habakkuk answered the angel

La leof, ne geseah ic næfre ða burh, ne ic ðone seað nát
Sir, I never saw the city, nor know I the pit

Þa se engel gelæhte hine be ðam fexe, and hine bær to Babilone, and hine sette bufan ðam seaðe
Then the angel seized him by the hair, and bare him to Babylon, and set him above the pit

Ða clypode se Abacuc
Then Habakkuk cried

Þu Godes ðeowa, Daniel, nim ðas lac ðe þe God sende
Thou servant of God, Daniel, take this gift which God hath sent thee

Daniel cwæð
Daniel said

Min Drihten Hælend, sy ðe lof and wurðmynt þæt þu me gemundest
My Lord Jesus, be to thee praise and honour, for that thou hast remembered me

And he ða ðære sande breac
And he then ate of the dish

Witodlice Godes engel þærrihte mid swyftum flihte gebrohte ðone disc-ðen, Abacuc, þær he hine ǽr genam
And the angel of the Lord straightways brought the minister of food, Habakkuk, to the place whence he had before taken him

Se cyning ða Cyrus on ðam seofoðan dæge eode dreorig to ðæra leona seaðe, and innbeseah, and efne ða Daniel sittende wæs gesundful on middan þam leonum
Then the king Cyrus on the seventh day went sad to the lions' pit, and looked in, and behold, there was Daniel sitting unhurt in the midst of the lions

Þa clypode se cyning mid micelre stemne
Then the king cried with a loud voice

Mære is se God þe Daniel on belyfð
Great is the God in whom Daniel believeth

And he ða mid þam worde hine ateah of ðam scræfe, and het inn-awurpan ða þe hine ǽr fordón woldon
And he then with that word drew him from the den, and ordered those to be cast in who before would fordo him

Þæs cyninges hæs wearð hrædlice gefremmed, and þæs witegan ehteras wurdon asceofene betwux ða leon, and hi ðærrihte mid grædigum ceaflum hí ealle totæron
The king's command was quickly executed, and the prophet's persecutors were thrust among the lions, and they straightways with greedy jaws tore them all in pieces

Þa cwæð se cyning
Then said the king

Forhtion and ondrædon ealle eorðbuende Danieles God, forðan ðe he is Alysend and Hælend, wyrcende tácna and wundra on heofonan and on eorðan
Let all dwellers on earth fear and dread the God of Daniel, for he is the Redeemer and Saviour, working signs and wonders in heaven and on earth

On ðære Niwan Gecyðnysse, æfter Cristes ðrowunge, and his æriste and upstige to heofonum, wurdon ða Iudeiscan mid ándan afyllede ongean his apostolas, and gebrohton hí on cwearterne
In the New Testament, after Christ's passion, and his resurrection and ascension to heaven, the Jews were filled with envy towards his apostles, and brought them into prison

On ðære ylcan nihte Godes engel undyde þa locu ðæs cwearternes, and hí út-alædde, þus cweðende
In the same night God's angel undid the locks of the prison, and led them out, thus saying

Gað to ðam temple, and bodiað þam folce lifes word
Go to the temple, and preach to the folk the word of life

And hí swa dydon
And they so did

Hwæt ða Iudeiscan þæs on merien ðeahtodon embe ðæra apostola forwyrd, and sendon to ðam cwearterne, þæt hí man gefette
Then the Jews on the morrow deliberated concerning the destruction of the apostles, and sent to the prison, that they might be fetched

Þa cwelleras ða geopenodon þæt cweartern, and nænne ne gemetton
The executioners then opened the prison, and found no one

Hí ða cyddon heora ealdrum
They then announced to their elders

Þæt cweartern we fundon fæste beclysed, and ða weardas wiðutan standende, ac we ne gemetton nænne wiðinnan
We have found the prison fast closed, and the wards standing without, but we found no one within

Eft siððan Herodes, Iudea cyning, sette ðone apostol Petrum on cwearterne mid twam racenteagum gebundenne, and weardas wiðinnan and wiðutan gesette: ac on ðære nihte þe se arleasa cyning hine on merigen acwellan wolde, com Godes engel scinende of heofonum, and gelædde hine út ðurh ða isenan gatu
After that Herod, king of Judah, set the apostle Peter in prison bound with two chains, and set wards within and without: but on the night when the impious king would slay him on the morrow, God's angel came shining from heaven, and led him out through the iron gates, and on the morrow the prison again stood fast locked

Domicianus, se hæðena casere, het awurpan þone godspellere Iohannem on weallendne ele, ac he, þurh Godes gescyldnysse, swa gesundfull út eode swa he inn aworpen wæs
Domitian, the heathen emperor, commanded the evangelist John to be cast into boiling oil, but he, through God's protection, went out as unhurt as when he was cast in

Þam ylcan Iohanne sealde sum hæðengylda attor drincan, ac hé, æfter ðam drence, ansund and úngederod ðurhwunode
To the same John an idolater gave poison to drink, but he, after the draught, continued sound and uninjured

Paulus se apostol awrát be him sylfum, and cwæð, þæt hé ænne dæg and ane niht on sǽ-grunde adruge
Paul the apostle wrote concerning himself, and said, that he passed one day and one night at the bottom of the sea

Eft, æt sumum sæle hine gelæhte án næddre be ðam fingre, ac he ascoc hí into byrnendum fyre, and he ðæs ættres nán ðing ne gefredde
Again, on a time a serpent seized him by the finger, but he shook it into the burning fire, and he felt nothing of the poison

Ne mæg nán eorðlic mann mid gewritum cyðan, ne mid tungan gereccan hú oft se Ælmihtiga Wealdend his gecorenan fram mislicum frecednyssum ahredde, to lofe and to wurðmynte his mægenþrymnysse
No earthly man may by writings make known, nor with tongue relate how often the Almighty Ruler has saved his chosen from divers perils, to the praise and honour of his majesty

Ac he geðafað forwel oft þæt ða arleasan his halgan ðearle geswencað, hwilon mid hefigtymre ehtnysse, hwilon mid slege, þæt seo reðe ehtnyss becume ðam rihtwisan to ecere reste, and ðam cwellerum to ecum wite
But he very often allows the impious greatly to afflict his saints, sometimes with painful persecution, sometimes with slaying, that fierce persecution may end for the righteous in eternal rest, and for the murderers in eternal torment

Se sealm-scop cwæð
The psalmist said

Fela sind þæra rihtwisra gedreccednyssa, ac Drihten fram eallum ðysum hí alyst
Many are the tribulations of the righteous, but the Lord from all these will release them

On twá wisan alyst God his gecorenan, openlice and digellice
In two ways God releases his chosen, openly and secretly

Openlice hí beoð alysede, þonne hí on manna gesihðe beoð ahredde, swa swa we nu eow rehton
Openly they are released, when in sight of men they are saved, as we have now recounted to you

Digellice hí beoð alysede, þonne hí ðurh martyrdom becumað to heofonlicum geðincðum
Secretly they are released, when through martyrdom they come to heavenly honours

Gif hí for soðum geleafan oððe for rihtwisnysse þrowiað, hí beoð þonne martyras
If they suffer for true faith or for righteousness, they will then be martyrs

Gif hi ðonne unscyldige gecwylmede beoð, heora unscæððignyss hí gelǽt to Godes halgena geferrædene
But if they are slain guiltless, their innocence will lead them to the fellowship of God's saints

forðan þe unscæððignyss æfre orsorh wunað
for innocence ever continues secure

Gif hwá ðonne for synnum ehtnysse ðolað, and hine sylfne oncnæwð, swa þæt he Godes mildheortnysse inweardlice bidde, þonne forscyt þæt hwilwendlice wite ða ecan geniðerunge
But if any one suffers persecution for sins, and knows himself, so that he inwardly pray for God's mercy, then will the transient punishment prevent eternal damnation

For mándædum wæron þa twegen sceaðan gewitnode ðe mid Criste hangodon, ac heora oðer mid micclum geleafan gebæd hine to Criste, þus cweðende
For crimes were the two thieves punished who were crucified with Christ, but one of them with great faith prayed to Christ, thus saying

Drihten, geðenc mín þonne ðu to þinum rice becymst
Lord, think of me when thou comest to thy kingdom

Crist him andwyrde
Christ answered him

Soð ic þe secge, nu to-dæg þu bist mid me on neorxna-wanges myrhðe
Verily I say unto thee, now to-day thou shalt be with me in the joy of paradise

Unwilles we magon forleosan ða hwilwendlican gód, ac we ne forleosað næfre unwilles ða ecan gód
Against our will we may lose the transitory good, but against our will we never lose the eternal good

Þeah se reða reafere ús æt æhtum bereafige, oððe feores benæme, hé ne mæg us ætbredan urne geleafan ne þæt ece líf, gif we us sylfe mid agenum willan ne forpærað
Though the cruel robber bereave us of our property, or deprive us of life, he cannot take from us our faith or the eternal life, if we do not of our own will pervert ourselves

Se soða Drihten us ahredde fram eallum frecednyssum, and to ðam ecan life gelǽde, seðe leofað and rixað á butan ende
May the true Lord save us from all perils, and lead us to everlasting life, who liveth and reigneth ever without end

Amen
Amen

Crist on sumere tide ferde wið þære Galileiscan sǽ, and geseah twegen gebroðra, Simonem, se wæs gecíged Petrus, and his broðor Andream: et reliqua
Christ on a time went along the Galilean sea, and saw two brothers, Simon, who was called Peter, and his brother Andrew, etc

Swa swa hí ǽr mid nette fixodon on sǽlicum yðum, swa dyde Crist þæt hí siððan mid his heofonlican láre manna sawla gefixodon
As they before with a net had fished on the sea waves, so Christ caused them afterwards by his heavenly lore to fish for the souls of men

forðan ðe hí ætbrudon folces menn fram flæsclicum lustum, and fram woruldlicum gedwyldum to staðolfæstnysse lybbendra eorðan, þæt is to ðam ecan eðle, be ðam cwæð se witega þurh Godes Gast
for they withdrew the people from fleshly lusts, and from worldly errors to the stability of the earth of the living, that is, to the eternal country, of which the prophet, through God's Spirit, said

Ic asende mine fisceras, and hí gefixiað hí
I will send my fishers, and they shall fish for them

mine huntan, and hí huntiað hí of ælcere dune and of ælcere hylle
my hunters, and they shall hunt them from every down and from every hill

Fisceras and ungetogene menn geceas Drihten him to leorning-cnihtum, and hí swa geteah, þæt heora lár oferstáh ealne woruld-wisdom, and hí mid heora bodunge caseras and cyningas to soðum geleafan gebigdon
Fishers and uneducated men the Lord chose to him for disciples, and so instructed them, that their lore excelled all worldly wisdom, and they by their preaching inclined emperors and kings to the true faith

Gif se Hælend gecure æt fruman getinge láreowas, and woruldlice uðwitan, and ðyllice to bodigenne sende, þonne wære geðuht swilce se soða geleafa ne asprunge ðurh Godes mihte, ac of woruldlicere getingnysse
If Jesus had chosen at first eloquent teachers, and sent worldly philosophers, and the like to preach, then would it have appeared as if the true faith had not sprung up through God's might, but from worldly eloquence

He geceas fisceras ǽrðan ðe hé cure caseras, forðan ðe betere is þæt se casere, þonne hé to Romebyrig becymð, þæt he wurpe his cynehelm, and gecneowige æt ðæs fisceres gemynde, þonne se fiscere cneowige æt þæs caseres gemynde
He chose fishers ere he chose emperors, because it is better that the emperor, when he comes to Rome, cast aside his crown, and kneel at the fisher's memorial, than that the fisher kneel at the emperor's memorial

Caseras hé geceas, ac ðeah hé geendebyrde þone unspedigan fiscere ætforan ðam rican casere
Emperors he chose, but yet he ranked the indigent fisher before the rich emperor

Eft siððan hé geceas ða welegan
Afterwards he chose the wealthy

ac him wære geðuht swilce hí gecorene wæron for heora æhtum, gif hé ǽr ne gecure þearfan
but it would have appeared as if they had been chosen for their possessions, if he had not previously chosen the needy

Hé geceas siððan woruldlice uðwitan, ac hí modegodon, gif he ǽr ne gecure þa ungetogenan fisceras
He then chose worldly philosophers, but they would have waxed proud, had he not before chosen the uneducated fishers

Smeagað nu hú Drihten mancynne ætbræd wuldor, þæt hé him wuldor forgeafe
Consider now how the Lord took glory away from mankind, that he might give them glory

Hé ætbræd ús ure idele wuldor, þæt hé us þæt ece forgeafe
He took from us our vain glory, that he might give us the eternal

Ne scealt ðu on ðe silfum wuldrian, ac, swa swa se apostol cwæð
Thou shalt not glory in thyself, but, as the apostle said

Se ðe wuldrige wuldrige on Gode
Let him who glorieth glory in God

Petrus and Andreas, be Cristes hæse, ðærrihte forleton heora nett, and him fyligdon
Peter and Andrew, by Christ's behest, straightways left their nets, and followed him

Ne gesawon hí ða-gyt hine ænige wundra wyrcan, ne hí naht ne gehyrdon ða-gyt æt his muðe be méde þæs ecan edleanes, and hí ðeah, æfter stemne anre hæse, þæt þæt hi hæfdon forgeaton
They had not yet seen him work any wonders, nor had they yet heard from his mouth of the meed of everlasting reward, and yet, after the utterance of one command, they forgot that which they had

Fela Godes wundra we habbað gehyred and eac gesewene
Many of God's miracles we have heard of and also seen

mid manegum swingelum gelóme we sind geswencte, and mid menigfealdum ðeowracena teartnyssum gebregede, and swa-ðeah we forseoð Godes hæse, and him to lífes wege fylian nellað
by many stripes we are oftentimes afflicted, and by manifold asperities of threats terrified, and yet we despise God's behest, and will not follow him to the way of life

Nu hé sitt on heofonum, mid þære menniscnysse gescrydd þe hé on ðisum lífe gefette, and mynegað ús be ure gecyrrednysse, þæt we ure ðeawas fram leahtrum symle clænsion, and be his bebodum gerihtlæcon
Now he sits in heaven, clothed with the humanity which he fetched in this life, and admonishes us of our conversion, that we constantly cleanse our lives from sins, and direct them by his commandments

Eallunga hé underðeodde ðeoda swuran his geoce, hé astrehte middangeardes wuldor, and mid gelomlæcendum hryrum nealæcunge his strecan domes geswutelað, and swa-ðeah ure modige mód nele sylfwilles forlætan þæt þæt hit dæghwomlice forlyst neadunge
He has wholly subjected the necks of nations to his yoke, he has prostrated the glory of the world, and by frequent destructions manifests the approach of his rigid doom, and, nevertheless, our proud mind will not voluntarily forsake that which it loses daily by compulsion

Mine gebroðra, hwilcere tale mage we brucan on his dome, nu we nellað bugan fram ðyssere andweardan woruld-lufe, þurh his beboda, ne we ne synd þurh his swingla gerihtlæhte
My brothers, what excuse can we use at his doom, now that we will not turn from this present love of the world, through his commandments, nor are we corrected by his stripes

Wén is þæt eower sum cweðe to him sylfum on stillum geðohtum, Hwæt forleton has gebroðru, Petrus and Andreas, þe for nean nán ðing næfdon
It is to be expected that one of you in his still thoughts say to himself, What did the brothers, Peter and Andrew, leave, who had almost nothing

ac we sceolon on þisum ðinge heora gewilnunge swiðor asmeagan þonne heora gestreon
but in this case we should rather consider their desire than their possession

Micel forlæt se ðe him sylfum nán ðing ne gehylt
Much he leaves who holds nothing for himself

Witodlice we healdað ure æhta mid micelre lufe, and ða ðing þe we nabbað we secað mid ormætre gewilnunge
Verily we hold our possessions with great love, and the things which we have not we seek with infinite desire

Micel forlét Petrus and Andreas, ðaða heora ægðer þone willan to hæbbenne eallunga forlét, and agenum lustum wiðsóc
Peter and Andrew left much, when both of them wholly left the will to have, and renounced their own lusts

Cwyð nu sum mann, Ic wolde geefenlæcan þam apostolum, þe ealle woruld-ðing forsawon, ac ic næbbe náne æhta to forlætenne
Some man will now say, I would imitate the apostles, who despised all worldly things, but I have no possessions to leave

Ac God sceawað þæs mannes heortan, and na his æhta
But God beholds the man's heart, and not his possessions

Ne hé ne telð hú miccle speda we on his lacum aspendon, ac cepð mid hú micelre gewilnunge we ða lác him geoffrion
He reckons not what great riches we spend in gifts to him, but observes with how great desire we offer to him our gifts

Efne nu þas halgan cýpan, Petrus and Andreas, mid heora nettum and scipe him þæt ece líf geceapodon
Behold now these holy chapmen, Peter and Andrew, with their nets and ship bought for themselves everlasting life

Næfð Godes rice nánes wurðes lofunge, ac bið gelofod be ðæs mannes hæfene
God's kingdom has no price of worth, but is priced according to a man's property

Heofonan rice wæs alæten þisum foresædum gebroðrum for heora nette and scipe, and eft syððan ðam rican Zacheó to healfum dæle his æhta, and sumere wudewan to ánum feorðlinge, and sumum menn to anum wæteres drence
The kingdom of heaven was given to these beforesaid brothers for their net and ship, and afterwards to the rich Zacchæus for the half part of his possessions, and to a widow for one farthing, and to a man for a drink of water

Ic wene þæt þas word ne sind eow full cuðe, gif we hí openlicor eow ne onwreoð
I imagine that these words will not be quite clear to you, if we do not explain them to you more openly

Zachéus wæs sum rice mann, and cepte þæs Hælendes fær, and wolde geseon hwilc hé wære
Zacchæus was a rich man, and had observed the Saviour's course, and would see who he was

ac he ne mihte for ðære menigu ðe him mid ferde, forðan ðe hé wæs scort on wæstme
but he could not for the many that went with him, because he was short of stature

Þa forárn hé ðam Hælende, and stah uppon an treow, þæt he hine geseon mihte
He then ran before Jesus, and ascended a tree, that he might see him

Crist ða beseah upp wið þæs rican, and cwæð, Zachée, stíh ardlice adún, forðan ðe me gedafenað þæt ic nu to-dæg þe gecyrre
Christ then looked up towards the rich man, and said, Zacchæus, descend quickly, for it seemeth good to me that I now to-day enter thy dwelling

Zachéus ða swyftlice of ðam treowe alihte, and hine blissigende underfeng
Zacchæus then swiftly alighted from the tree, and received him rejoicing

Þaða Zachéus Crist gelaðod hæfde, ða astód he ætforan him, and him anmodlice to cwæð
When Zacchæus had invited Christ, he stood before him, and unhesitatingly said to him

Drihten, efne ic todæle healfne dǽl minra góda ðearfum, and swa hwæt swa ic mid fácne berypte, þæt ic wylle be feowerfealdum forgyldan
Lord, behold I distribute the half part of my goods to the poor, and whatsoever I have robbed by fraud, that I am willing to compensate fourfold

Drihten him to cwæð
The Lord said to him

Nu to-dæg is ðisum hirede hæl gefremmed, forðan ðe he is Abrahames ofspring
Now to-day is salvation accomplished to this household, for he is Abraham's offspring

Ic com to secenne and to gehælenne þæt þe on mancynne losode
I come to seek and to save that which was lost among mankind

Þa hæfde Zacheus beceapod heofonan rice mid healfum dǽle his æhta: ðone oþerne dæl he heold to ðy þæt hé wolde þam be feowerfealdum forgyldan, þe hé ǽr unrihtlice bereafode
Thus had Zacchæus bought the kingdom of heaven with the half part of his possessions: the other part he held to the end that he might indemnify those fourfold whom he had unjustly bereaved
